story:
We’re Whatever Guise Productions, and we need your help to bring the world Premier of Jess Moore’s play “Gin For Breakfast” to the stage.

Gin For Breakfast will run from September 26th – October 21st in the heart of the West End at Tristan Bates Theatre - an intimate studio theatre with a reputation for showcasing new writing and contemporary work. We need help making the show everything we know it can be.

The play means a great deal to the team; it’s our first production and the start of something very exciting for us. But supporting Gin For Breakfast is not just about supporting a show. It’s a piece with a purpose and a cause. The play tackles depression and mental health issues head on, so as part of our production, we will also be running events, talks and workshops supported by CALM (Campaign Against Living Miserably). We want to get people talking and to play our part in reducing the stigma and isolation that comes with depression. To do that, we need your help.

The Team

This is Whatever Guise’s first production. Best known for his roles in The Hobbit and The Musketeers, the play will be directed by Ryan Gage. Our designer is the Emmy-nominated, Erica Hemminger who is Associate Designer on a number of Broadway shows, including Beautiful, which has toured the US and Internationally.

Your Help

Mental health is one of the most pressing issues in British society, and one we still don’t talk about enough. At least one in four of us will experience mental health issues during our lifetimes. Suicide is the biggest killer of men under 40, and suicide rates for women are at their highest since 2011. This isn’t a battle we’re currently winning, and it’s one that many people face alone.

Your contribution will not only help us make the show everything it can be, it will also help us do our bit in tackling the stigma and isolation of living with depression and mental health issues.

https://www.thecalmzone.net

What do we need?

We need your help to make the show everything it can be, and build the platform this story and subject matter needs. This is a huge opportunity for us to make wonderful work, start something new in the industry and make a difference as best we can. But theatre involves significant costs and we’re not eligible for public subsidy, so we need your help!

Any donation will go towards building a set worthy of our wonderful, double Emmy-Award nominated designer Erica, paying the wonderful technicians who’ll be working full time for us, and printing posters and flyers so we can get bums on seats and get our story and message out there.

We are also welcoming support from people and organisations that are able to offer help in-kind, such as prop and costume loans, photography, digital skills and press and marketing expertise.

If you’re feeling *particularly* generous, you’ll get rewarded! Pick from our plethora of fun gin based rewards below! Whichever perk you go for, you'll receive the corresponding gin cocktail recipe as a bonus.

For anyone with a keen eye for emerging talent who'd like to invest or donate a larger amount, please get in touch at jessica.guise@googlemail.com

Starting a theatre company, getting a play programmed, finding the funds, all of these things have challenges; we couldn’t do any of it without the support of the friends we have and people we know.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come and see the show! Buying a ticket and spending an evening in the theatre with us is not only a massive compliment, it’s a massive help.

Get the word out! You can help enormously by promoting the show on your social media, amongst your pals and in any way you can. You can also share this fundraiser to people you think might be interested in getting involved.

Contribute goodies! If you aren’t able to contribute funds but you have any STUFF we might be able to use - costume, cake, gin….give us a shout!

story:
Campaign Details

Imagine you find a way to turn your passion into something more. Imagine the art you create could also become your source of healing. This is what Laura Rae’s performers experience through their hard work and dedication. And to them, the journey itself is sufficient reward.

However, we believe talent and perseverance should be encouraged and repaid. And because Laura’s work is also about experiencing this healing journey vicariously, we are offering you the opportunity to embark on and contribute to the InnerVoyage - Mudita Arts Performance.

This campaign is aimed at raising funds for the upcoming performances in Amsterdam, NL and San Francisco, US. All proceeds will go to the dancers, musicians and production crew.

How Can I Contribute?

Each and every contribution, no matter how small is highly appreciated.

  • $5 - poster and program of performances
  • $10 - entry to events, poster and program of performances
  • $25 - invitation to rehearsals, entry to events, poster and program of performances
  • $50 - Shi’atsu massage or private dance class with Ms. Bernasconi (1 hr), all the above

About Laura Rae Bernasconi

Laura’s aim is to create choreography that is rejuvenating and healing as opposed to destructive or injurious. The objective is that both artists and audience feel more at ease in their body, mind and spirit. As a result, performers and audience members experience a neurological response of peace, equipoise and homeostasis.

Laura Rae Bernasconi is an acclaimed choreographer, contemporary ballet dancer and Odissi Temple dancer. Apart from dancing, Laura also teaches wellness and is a certified Shi’atsu therapist as well as a Hatha Yoga and AcroYoga teacher. Using principles of the Alexander Technique, Feldenkrais, Gyrokenisis, Ilan Lev Method, and mindfulness, Laura's approach to dance focuses on the individual needs of each performer with love, support, empathy, and mudita - vicarious joy.

story:
What's a CartHorse?

In the spring of 2016, on the heels of our tenth anniversary season, Buran Theatre moved our mission forward through the creation of the CartHorse Fellowship. Through the CartHorse, Buran provides equitable opportunities to artists whose work would otherwise not be developed and presented; simultaneously, we seek to challenge organizational paradigms in the non-profit performing arts field that favor marginalization, nepotism, commercialization, and hierarchy. In line with Buran's mission of generosity and inclusion, we actively seek - through our presentations, explorations and administration - to demote and dismantle capitalism's influence on theatre-making by promoting and bestowing our horizontal practices through the Fellowship toward radical, queer and impossible performance ventures.

Our first CartHorse Fellow Cara Scarmack is now seeing her work fully realized through two years of developmental and creative support. The Fellowship allowed Cara to take the lead in the creative process, with Buran Theatre responding and serving her vision as best as we could. The result of Cara's CartHorse will be the premiere of some higher glimmer in our landscape of flat at the Collapsable Hole in the West Village (NYC) from October 20-November 3 under the direction of Sarah Hughes.

Cara has written a wild and beautiful text that defies genre and, quite frankly, explanation. The text itself is experiential and immersive, bending your mind and inner ear toward a zany poetic realm of maternal warmth that embraces the humanness of failure and desire. The play lives between the folds of theatre, dance and music; it is a play about slippage between time, genre and ever-evolving relationship.

Described by Cara as a “journey play that traverses the double-edged sword of solitude,” every character has their turn in this play: to take up space, to speak, and to challenge and alter the course of narrative. A central character is a singular force in the world: a Mother who has just given birth and now wears her raw heart on the outside. Harnessing her severe vulnerability and the love she’s newly discovered, she provokes a slew of philosophical revelations. Simultaneously or consequently, a number of duos – dancing, singing, and conversing – uncover everything we once knew but have forgotten, the ills we are unaware of, and how these unknowns are hurting us.

Cara, Sarah and Buran Theatre have assembled an absolutely stellar team of collaborators to bring this work to life, including many Buran associates as well as many new faces to the company. Collaborators include choreographer lisa nevada, composer Johnny Gasper, lighting/video designer Jeanette Oi-Suk Yew, costume designer Peiyi Wong, set designers Carolyn Mraz & Cori Williams, musical director Alaina Ferris, technical director Nicholas Kostner, and performers Laurena Allen, Kate Benson, LaToya Lewis, Lanxing Fu, Manny Rivera, Kate Schroeder, and Merlin Whitehawk, among others.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Over the past year we have persistently sought funding for this project and have successfully raised nearly $10,000 from grants, including The Edith Lutyens and Norman Bel Geddes Design Enhancement Fund grant from A.R.T./N.Y. However, we still need to raise an additional $6,000 to pay for the performance space and stipends for artists.

For your donation, we have amazing perks including tickets to the premiere, drink tickets at the shows, as well as a personalized Mix CD  and a home-cooked meal, both provided by Buran artistic director Adam R. Burnett (who dabbles as a chef).

In the spirit of absolute transparency, below is a budget for the production, including our goal of $6k from IndieGoGo and our projected Box Office.

EXPENSES

Space Rental: $4,000

Artists fees (director, playwright, designers, choreographer, performers, etc.): $12,000

Production Materials/Construction: $5,000

Documentation: $500

Insurance: $500

Administration: $400

Travel (for out of town artists): $600

Marketing: $600

Miscellany: $400

TOTAL EXPENSES: $24,000

 

CURRENT CONTRIBUTED INCOME

Bel Geddes: $5,000 (designated for design)

Mental Insight Foundation: $1,000

Nancy Quinn Fund: $750

Off-Broadway Angels: $2,000

Individual giving: $1,250

TOTAL: $10,000

 

PROJECTED INCOME

Box-office: $8,000

IndieGoGo Fundraiser: $6,000 (minus $250 platform fees)

TOTAL: $14,000

TOTAL CURRENT INCOME + PROJECTED: $24,000

 

The Impact

In a world ever-increasingly saturated with commercial ventures in theatre-making, Buran Theatre remains a space for risk-taking, adventurous, radical and ridiculous projects that do not align with capital-enhancing values.

In the years to come we intend to continue widening our circle so that this fellowship becomes even more inclusive, representative and supportive of the wildest ideas that are not aimed toward commercial runs and, most definitely, do not have their sights set toward Broadway.

The CartHorse Fellowship is adjudicated and administrated in the spirit of Absolute Transparency. Applicants apply without a resume, letters of recommendations, professional affiliations, or names attached. In return, they are given complete access to the adjudicator's history and are able to watch, in real time, all applications adjudicated on a Google doc. Throughout the entire process, from semi-finals to finals, the applicant is kept anonymous. Only days within announcing do we finally gain access to the artist's full identity.

Our current CartHorse Fellows are Cara Scarmack (2017/18) and Raja Feather Kelly (2018/19). The next round for the Fellowship will go live in February with applications due in May 2019.

The success of this funding campaign will directly impact Cara's production, and thus, the future of the Fellowship.

 

Risks & Challenges

For a decade Buran Theatre has created a canon of experimental, joyful, iconoclastic theatre works and the risks have always been associated with the challenge of producing with little funds and lots of backbreaking work, but always with a full heart. We have mitigated these risks by formalizing into a 501c3 non-profit, as of 2016, and with the support of a board of directors, we are able to confidently move toward risky and challenging endeavors. What we need most in this time is the support of our community to hold our CartHorse Fellowship up and to carry Cara's play toward production in the fall.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate but want to help, please share this campaign and spread the word of the work Buran Theatre has done for nearly 12 years now and the radical, generous work this Fellowship is accomplishing! We rely on our entire community - from NYC to Albuquerque to Los Angeles to Kansas City and beyond - to realize all our theatrical ventures.

We thank you in advance!

 

**Production artwork & campaign video by David Pym

**Campaign original music by Johnny Gasper

**Kate Schroeder, Nikki Calonge, Zoe Geltman, Colleen O'Neill, Manny Rivera, & Lindsley Howard featured in campaign video from workshop in May 2018

story:
Short Summary

Be a part of a rare opportunity to help us build a brand new 1,000-seat commercial theater in the heart of Nashville! Part of the business of creating a new Broadway show is mounting the show for an out-of-town tryout. While there are many non-profit theater who bring short-run shows and tours through various towns, there are actually few commercial theater venues in the United States.  Nashville is primed for such a theater given its exploding population and huge tourist population. 

We hope to launch the theater with a new, pre-Broadway show called Tennessee Whiskey the Musical, the life story of Dean Dillon.  Dean has written most of George Strait's number 1 hits, and his life, struggles, and triumphs in the country music industry as he became a legendary songwriting icon is an incredible story. It's a musical about Nashville and one of Nashville's own sons of country music, so it's a perfect fit for the launch of a new commercial venue!

What We Need & What You Get

Ultimately the majority of the $30M needed to complete the project will be capitalized through private investments, but there are always individuals who love to support the arts no matter the amount of their contribution -- which is always appreciated!

Through Indiegogo we are looking to raise a minimum of $500,000 -- only 5,000 people contributing $100 each!  

As a big thank you to anyone contributing $100, we will create a permanent art installation in a prominent location in the theater that includes your name as a supporter!  It'll be great fun to come visit the theater and find your name, knowing that you had a big part in making this entire building happen!

The Impact

The impact to Nashville will be immense. We are bringing a new entertainment venue to the area, not only helping to improve a growing neighborhood, but also bring new jobs for artists and other staff to the area.

Risks & Challenges

Obviously capitalizing $30M for a new building is not an easy thing to do. There is always the risk and challenge that the building may not be built.  However, with our incredible team of designers, architects, theater planners, marketers, and experienced Broadway producing team, we are confident that the venue will not only get built but be a huge success in Nashville.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please help spread the word to Nashville and theater lovers everywhere!  If you are an individual who may be interested in making an investment in an Opportunity Zone Property, contact us as dewey@dmossproductions.com for more information.

story: In the summer of 2018, Mikey Morado and I began to develop 'Solo for One in Doubt' for the emerging choreographer's Platform showing at Place des Arts during Springboard Danse Montreal.  Following it's original debuts, we were able to show the solo on it's own and as part of 'BIG KID', another work I have been developing in the past year. The majority of these opportunities, and my other choreographic endeavours, were made possible by the incredible support I've received through fundraising.  I have been so fortunate to develop my work to provide happiness beyond choreographing as an occupation, and have enjoyed being in a place where I can support my peers and fellow artists who are in need as well.  As any emerging artist would be able to tell you, opportunities for growth usually come at a great cost.  While I am definitely in need of support to make our performance at Boston Dance Festival possible, I am also hoping this is an opportunity to further the culture around me of support; one that I will always do my best to give back to.

story:
Playback Theatre is an improvisational form of theater that allows audience members to share true stories and see them enacted on the spot. This process can be thoroughly entertaining, and also highly therapeutic in terms of offering reconciliation in situations of conflict, and comfort and repair in the aftermath of traumatic events. For these reasons, since it was created in the 1970s by Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas, Playback Theatre is now practiced in over 70 countries! Yet Los Angeles has not hosted a Company until now.

We come to you as a powerful group of 18 forward-thinking progressive artist/educator/healers with a vested interest in social justice and bringing a stronger sense of connection and community to our unique metropolis through the performing arts.

We began practicing together in January 2019 and we will offer our first public performance at Highways Performance Space on May 29 & 30 of 2020. We are asking for your support in making this performance not only possible, but as strong as it can be.

The director, Joyce Lu, is investing $10,000 of her own funds and is inviting you, the community, as a collective to match this amount. The things your funds would support are:

Actor & Musician Artist Fees*

Stage Management

Space Rental

Psychodrama Training

Publicity / documentation

Website Design

*Our 18 company members are a diverse crew of professional performing artists and healers who come from Long Beach, the Inland Empire, Orange County, the Westside – all over Los Angeles County – and are getting a measly $10-20 stipend per rehearsal. As we get better, our wish is to make a living wage from this, but this is where we’re starting at!

If you are able to donate a gift of any amount, you’ll be investing in making Los Angeles a more inclusive and more human town. We also have awesome perks that make super holiday gifts! Donate on behalf of a friend and gift them with a perk! Classy! 

What's more: Your donation is tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor Highways Performance Space!

 

THE ENSEMBLE

 

Anatalia Vallez is a proud daughter of migrants, artivist and UC Berkeley graduate passionate about using art as a tool for creating consciousness and community. She's had the honor of performing in several spaces including: Brava Theater Center in San Francisco, Frida Kahlo Theater in Los Angeles, South Coast Repertory Theater in Costa Mesa, Community Art Theater in San Diego and La Boheme in Tijuana, Mexico. She's written several plays and her work has been published in over 7 zines including a self-published zine called Manos A La Obra. She is currently an ensemble member of Breath of Fire Latina Theater Ensemble in Orange County (Tongva land) and is working on publishing her first book of poetry with Flowersong Books. http://anataliavallez.weebly.com/

Antonieta Gimeno Cardona includes writing, music, dance, meditation and other practices as integral parts of her work. She sees these strategies as essential ingredients of human development, involving body, mind and spirit. Antonieta has participated in international Theatre of the Oppressed and Playback Theatre forums in New York, India, Nicaragua and Mexico. She believes we need more than ever imagination and creativity to become more human and address the complex problems we face everyday. Solidarity among people is essential to survive the current attacks directed to immigrant, Indigenous, Afro descendants, LGBT, women, elders and children.  Theatre and the arts are dynamic tools, useful in this struggle!

Audrey Kuo is a genderqueer femme poet, writer, bread baker and organizer. Their art is part of their commitment to nurturing relationships and community among queer and trans people of color. Audrey believes in the liberatory possibilities of gathering to share food & stories. Audrey currently lives on unceded Tongva territory (in Los Angeles) and is interested in reconnecting with Taiwanese and Chinese food histories and land. 

Ben Campbell has been practicing playback for the past three years and is thrilled to be a part of this playback company! After graduating from NYU Tisch, he began working in recovery centers across Los Angeles to help those suffering from addiction. Using tools from Improvisation, Drama Therapy, and especially Playback Theater, Ben has found joy engaging with the recovery community. Ben is also an actor and has spent time on the Second City Stage, London's West End, and Netflix cues.

 

Carla Vega is a multi-disciplinary performing artist raised in San Francisco, based in Los Angeles. Her roots in theatre, film, writing, singing, martial arts/ dance/ yoga, teaching and spirit have led her to perform locally and internationally. Currently she is a company member of PlaygroundLA Theatre Co. and LA Playback Theatre Co., Kaiser Permanante’s CareActors. She is a teaching artist for TeAda Productions and a collaborator with Great Leap, Inc. Her on-camera acting career includes multiple commercials, TV, and films. Carla believes in the power of the performing arts, utilizing imagination and storytelling, as catalysts for healing, compassion & positive change- to help create leaders who shape our future with inspiration, innovation and love for humanity. Follow her on FB: @carla.vega.universalbreath  or IG: @i.am.carlavega 
 

Craig Ng, an actor for more than forty-five years, has accumulated over six-dozen credits in film, television and theatre. His heart and soul continue to express through many art forms. His talents as an actor, dancer and martial artist have opened opportunities for him to work with many well known dance companies, theater companies and motion capture movement for video games. He is also an award winning Foley artist (2 Emmys), body-mind integrator (body work), handyman and workshop leader. 


Denice Lee has a Theater background in Chicago, most notably, she studied and performed at Steppenwolf and the Goodman Theatre. She also starred in a few independent films. When she is not acting, she works as a Body Mind Therapist. Denice is thrilled to be part of this Playback Theater company which perfectly marries her two passions: acting and being a mirror for others!

Elizabeth Yochim is a multi-media performance artist, art historian, dancer, and filmmaker. She creates solo and group performance works internationally in the environment—be it the city or the natural world. She created the Angelbird and performed throughout nine countries and over 50 cities in the United States, Canada, and Europe. She is a founding artist in residence with the Nomadic School of Wonder and recently released a short documentary ANGELBIRD.

Ernie González, Jr. TV credits include co-starring roles in: “Indebted” (NBC), “Carol’s Second Act” (CBS), “One Day At A Time” (Netflix), “Grace and Frankie” (Netflix), “Alone Together” (Freeform), “No Tomorrow” (The CW), “Training Day” (CBS), “American Crime” (ABC), “Jimmy Kimmel Live” (ABC), and national commercials for Sonic Drive-In, Rite Aid, Lowes, and Nopalina (which is Mexican fiber….yup). Select Regional Theater credits: La MaMa (off-Broadway), Creative Place Theatre (off-Broadway), The Milwaukee Repertory Theatre, The Second City Chicago (BrownCo.), The Victory Gardens Theatre, Porthouse Theatre, and Ohio Shakespeare Festival. When in doubt, visit AllAboutErnie.com.

Joseph Reynolds is an interdisciplinary artist focused on: creating his personal approach to movement; deepening his understanding of dance's social, educational, and performative potential; and communicating his perspective as a queer black man of Caribbean descent. JoeChoreo houses his modeling, acting, dancing, music, and film endeavors. Formally trained as a Modern and Ballet dancer in college, Joseph has since expanded his training to include: Salsa, Afro-Cuban, House, Hip Hop, Afro-Brazilian, Dancehall, and Contemporary styles. Joseph is currently training in Playback Theatre to incorporate more interactive elements into his dance performances.  http://www.joechoreo.com/

Joyce Lu is a former member of the Living Arts Playback Ensemble in the San Francisco Bay Area and she has participated in two Asia region Playback Gatherings and advanced trainings led by Jonathan Fox, Jo Salas, and Hannah Fox. Joyce has extensive training also in Psychodrama and somatics and is a recent graduate of the Playback Theatre Leadership Institute offered by the Centre for Playback Theatre. She is a Feldenkrais Method Practitioner and the current chair of the Department of Theatre and Dance at Pomona College. 

Jubilee Lopez, originally from Portland, Oregon, recently graduated from Pitzer College. After several years, she has enjoyed returning to acting by engaging with the joys and power of improvisation in many forms — training under Joyce Lu in Playback Theater and also at Upright Citizens Brigade. Jubilee hopes to continue applying improv to meaningful projects focused on creative play, healing and community formation. 

June Marisa Kaewsith, also known as "Jumakae,", is a multidisciplinary artist, storytelling coach, and wellness consultant based in Long Beach, CA. She has conducted spoken word workshops and mural projects with various youth groups, and has facilitated theater skits with community members addressing local issues from wage theft to environmental racism. As a keynote speaker, she has motivated crowds through her original spoken word poetry in high schools, college campuses, and various nonprofit groups throughout California. Through her additional practice as a wellness consultant, she is a 200 hour registered yoga teacher trained to work with survivors of sexual trauma and a professionally certified transformational life coach. With her passion for the arts and somatic learning, she holds self-care and storytelling workshops for organizations and individuals to become more comfortable with their mind and body. www.jumakae.com


Kimeiko Rae Vision is a Professional Intuitive Life Coach and Spiritual Guide, an Ametuer Brain Scientist, and a Nightly Shower Singer. She has danced for the Alaska State Visitors Bureau and the Dance Contempo troupe in Anchorage, AK and acted in community theater productions of Arsenic and Old Lace, Grease, and The Vagina Monologues. 
Kimeiko is often referred to as a “Court Jester” offering her community a good, healing laugh.

Magan Wiles is co-owner of Oxygen Tango, an Argentine Tango school with locations in Inglewood, Venice, and Torrance. She is also the owner of Hustle Creative, a boutique business management firm offering virtual CFO support for creative entrepreneurs. Magan also holds an MFA in acting from the University of Tennessee-Knoxville, and is a working Equity stage actress with credits in classical theater across the country. She was a part of Playback Workshop Theater in St. Louis MO from 2005-2009, and has worked as a teaching artist in St Louis, New York, and the Occupied Territories of Palestine.

María Elena Fernández is the daughter of Mexico City immigrants. Her first person essays have been published in the anthologies Waking Up American and Remembering Frida. Her full-length solo shows include the poetry performance, Ancestral Body Navegante, and the hilarious Confessions of a Cha Cha Feminist. She also wrote about Latino music, books and film for the LA Weekly. She teaches in the Chicana/o Studies Department at Cal State Northridge.

Meenadchi (pronouns: Meenadchi/they/them) is a performing artist and licensed occupational therapist with over 10 years of experience in trauma services and crisis stabilization. Craniosacral therapy, family constellations, and bachata are additional modalities that Meenadchi incorporates into their work. Meenadchi is also the author of the workbook Decolonizing Non-Violent Communication.

Molly Kauffman got involved with Playback Theater by way of her love of improvisational theater. At 16 she performed with an adult troupe, Zootown Improv in Missoula, Montana. Since moving to LA she has been taking classes at The Groundlings and from a troupe called April's Fools Improv in Hermosa. Molly accompanies her improv with stand up and writing. She is a rising senior at Occidental College and her original play, Just Die Already, was produced in the 21st annual New Play Festival, there where she also founded and leads the sketch comedy troupe 2 Paws Up.

Sheetal Gandhi is a Los Angeles based director/choreographer and multi-hyphenated artist (singer, dancer, actor, percussionist).  As a performer and interdisciplinary artist, Sheetal’s career has spanned genres and disciplines.  She was a lead character and creator for Cirque du Soleil’s Dralion, played a leading role in the Broadway production of Bombay Dreams, danced throughout Ghana with the traditional West African dance company Novisi, and currently sings with the L.A. based, 30-person a cappella group, The Over Tones.  She is Artistic Director of Sheetal Gandhi Dance Theater and a founding member of Dancing Storytellers, a group of artists that create assembly shows for schools in the greater Los Angeles area. Gandhi’s choreography has toured to over 16 cities in the U.S. and to Israel, Mexico, India, the Netherlands and Norway. sheetalgandhi.com

 

CURRENT FUNDERS

Thanks to these individuals and entities for their support: John Pennington & A Room to Create, Dave and Sue Hirsch, Los Angeles Poverty Department, Pomona College, Studio 34 LLC

 

Thanks also to Steven Liang http://www.stevenliang.com/ for the video and photos and Matt C. Lu for our logo!
story_txt: Playback Theatre is an improvisational form of theater that allows audience members to share true stories and see them enacted on the spot. This process can be thoroughly entertaining, and also highly therapeutic in terms of offering reconciliation in situations of conflict, and comfort and repair in the aftermath of traumatic events. For these reasons, since it was created in the 1970s by Jonathan Fox and Jo Salas, Playback Theatre is now practiced in over 70 countries! Yet Los Angeles has not hosted a Company until now.We come to you as a powerful group of 18 forward-thinking progressive artist/educator/healers with a vested interest in social justice and bringing a stronger sense of connection and community to our unique metropolis through the performing arts.We began practicing together in January 2019 and we will offer our first public performance at Highways Performance Space on May 29 & 30 of 2020. We are asking for your support in making this performance not only possible, but as strong as it can be.The director, Joyce Lu, is investing $10,000 of her own funds and is inviting you, the community, as a collective to match this amount. The things your funds would support are:Actor & Musician Artist Fees*Stage ManagementSpace RentalPsychodrama TrainingPublicity / documentationWebsite Design*Our 18 company members are a diverse crew of professional performing artists and healers who come from Long Beach, the Inland Empire, Orange County, the Westside – all over Los Angeles County – and are getting a measly $10-20 stipend per rehearsal. As we get better, our wish is to make a living wage from this, but this is where we’re starting at!If you are able to donate a gift of any amount, you’ll be investing in making Los Angeles a more inclusive and more human town. story:
Theatre is not a hobby. It’s something you feel inside. Something that represents you.

In Italy it’s not usual to go to the theatre. This country would be more alive if everyone, once in their lifetime, decided to go to the theatre.

One day someone told me: it’s not that we have no money. We have no people with imagination. And willing to use it, I might add.

We have no wish to be bold, to be creative.

We live in constant fear of judgments, we need to conform to a society that tends towards apathy.

I firmly believe in The Black Box Project because I know it will change the history of theatre in Italy for good.

After centuries we’ll bring back to life one of our best traditions: the pantomime!

It is Commedia dell’Arte, it is a musical, it is entertainment, and much more.

It’s for everybody, none excluded, from 0 to 100 years old people!

It’s a project that involves people who want to create, people who want their voice to be heard, who want to show their talent on a theatre stage.

However, like any other project it needs everybody’s help. When the government cannot help, we are there to help, all together.

I am here to ask you to donate something. Something for a community, for a society, something for me and all of us. And all of you.

Theatre is something that doesn’t belong only to me, it belongs to you, to all of us.

If we help each other, we will take a step forward to better ourselves.

Thank you so much. Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

We need 5000 pounds to get started. We want everybody to perform a great job and it is fair that everybody is paid for that. We also need props, costumes, to pay the theatre rent and much more.

All the money will be spent on the project, to create something great that will help people fall in love with theatre and willing to go back on a regular basis.

We create something different because we are artists with a huge imagination and we want to share our passion with all of you.

I promise that this will be the best show ever of 2020. Let us deliver a quality job and all the dreams you are looking for in a play.

story:
Anything Whatsoever

(français suivrait)

 

Dear friend,

To imagine ourselves in the future - We must imagine a newly emanating world. We are caught in old fashioned ways of seeing the world. Compagnie Katie Ward asks - how can we regenerate our imaginations and create new futures? Let your imaginations guide you and participate in propelling this kind of contemporary dance forward – the kind that is engaged in these questions.

Spring 2020 will be a busy period for CKW. March and April 2020 will be devoted to the development and finalization of the solo Anything Whatsoever.

A "dream room" will be created for the spectator where it is possible to contemplate and access A-Ha! moments, moments of realization and insight. The public is invited to contribute to the work, by using their imaginations and following scores that ask them to speak. This dialogue btween dance and spoken words creates and underlines a present centered awareness in all participants.

Supporting CKW means participating in the development of its creations, produced with an eco-responsible ethic.

 

Thanks to your donation, you will contribute to :

- Research and creation of the new solo called Anything Whatsoever which will be in developed during a technical residency at La Rotonde (Quebec City) and presented in Great Britain and in the Netherlands.

- Network development of CKW. Supporting CKW's network means participating in the growth of the company’s creations, both in Montreal (FTA, La Chapelle Scènes Contemporaines, Tangente), elsewhere in Canada (Festival of New Dance, La Rotonde, Fluid Festival, Kinetic Studio) and internationally (Festival Via, and Maison des Arts de Créteil - (France), Dance4 (United Kingdom), Saari residency (Finland) Dansateliers (Netherlands).

 

Dancers / danseurs : Audrée Juteau, Nathan Yaff, Dany Desjardins, Kelly Keenan

Photo : Svetla Atanasova

 

Compagnie Katie Ward (CKW) creates, produces and presents the choreographic projects of artistic director Katie Ward. CKW’s work examines the endless loop between imagination and reality. Her performance scores are works that index reality, establishing conditions to disrupt the way we see it so that so that our relationship with it can be rethought.

CKW's mandate is characterized by reasonable, ethical and fair production and creation practices and a philosophy that promotes diversity in all its manifestations. CKW is also committed to contributing to the development of the field of contemporary dance by providing a structure to develop experimental and multidisciplinary work of Katie Ward, and associated artists.

CKW creates and hosts performance events ranging from contemporary dance to performance installations, including performances. CKW also organizes and hosts workshops, residencies and practice sharing events where practitioners and the public can discuss what dance is as well as what it can do. In these events, reflection, interest, imagination and curiosity, risk-taking and diversity in all its manifestations are encouraged.

 

Allocation of funds

This fundraising campaign will help Compagnie Katie Ward to offset operating costs for the season. The funds will go to studio rental, transportation, rehearsal time, research materials and living expenses.

This campaign is important for the company, as it helps support CKW's role in the dance community as a company dedicated to experimenting and developing new forms of performance, both at the local level and internationally!

Founded in 2011 - CKW is committed to fostering the development of new contemporary dance and performance experiments, as well as community-public interaction and dance literacy at the local, national and international levels. Through ethical and creative practices - and a philosophy that promotes diversity of experience and perspective - CKW supports Katie Ward's experimental and multidisciplinary work and contributes to the field of practice of contemporary dance.

CKW is pooling resources for this exciting year of discovery, creation and development. To do this, the company has a fundraising goal of $ 2,000, and we invite you to join us in achieving this goal. If you want to contribute towards the realization of our projects, participate in our online campaign by making a contribution and spreading the word to your friends.

Thank you from team CKW!!

***

 

Chèr.e ami.e,

Pour nous projeter dans le futur, nous devons nous prêter à l’exercice d’imaginer les possibles, une infinité de mondes émanant. Nous sommes cependant coincés dans des façons conventionnelles et usées de percevoir le monde. Cette question est au cœur de la démarche de la compagnie Katie Ward : comment régénérer l’imaginaire collectif afin de créer un avenir différent, unique?

Laissez votre imagination vous guider et participez à l'essor d'une compagnie de danse contemporaine qui s'engage profondément à répondre à cette interrogation.

Le printemps 2020 sera une période chargée et ambitieuse. Mars et avril 2020 seront, entre autres, consacrés au développement et à la finalisation du solo Anything Whatsoever.

Un environnement envoûtant sera créé de toutes pièces, une espèce de « chambre de rêves » pour le spectateur où il lui est possible de contempler, d’accéder à des moments sensibles de dévoilement. Le public sera invité à contribuer à l’œuvre, par l’intermédiaire de la parole et de son imagination.

Un autre dialogue se crée avec comme seul pouvoir celui d’être dans le moment présent.

 

Grâce à votre don, vous contribuerez à :

- La recherche et création du nouveau solo Anything Whatsoever qui sera en résidence technique à La Rotonde (Ville de Québec) et diffusé en Grande-Bretagne et aux Pays-Bas

- Au rayonnement de la compagnie, tant à Montréal (FTA, La Chapelle, Tangente, Agora de la danse), qu’au Canada (Festival of New Dance, La Rotonde, Fluid Festival, Kinetic studio) et à l'international (Festival Via et Maison des arts de Créteil - France, Dance4 - Grande Bretagne, Saari residency - Finlande, Dans Ateliers - Pays-Bas).

Soutenir le rayonnement de CKW, c'est participer à l'essor de ses créations, réalisées dans le constant respect d’une éthique écoresponsable, valeur fondamentale de la compagnie.

 

La Compagnie Katie Ward (CKW) crée, produit et présente les projets chorégraphiques de la directrice artistique Katie Ward. Les œuvres de CKW examinent la boucle constitutive infinie entre l’imagination et la réalité. Ses partitions de performance sont des travaux qui indexent la réalité, établissant des conditions pour perturber la façon dont nous la voyons afin que afin que notre relation avec elle puisse être repensée.

La Compagnie Katie Ward (CKW) s'est aussi engagée à contribuer au développement du domaine de la danse contemporaine en fournissant une structure permettant de développer le travail expérimental et multidisciplinaire de Katie Ward, et des artistes associé-e-s.

CKW crée et héberge des événements de performance qui vont de la danse contemporaine aux installations performatives, en passant par les performances. CKW organise et anime également des ateliers, des résidences et des événements de partage de pratiques où les praticien-ne-s et le public peuvent discuter de ce que la danse est ainsi que de ce qu’elle peut faire. Dans ces événements, la réflexion, l’intérêt, l’imagination et la curiosité, la prise de risque ainsi que la diversité dans toutes ses manifestations sont encouragés.

 

À quoi servira la collecte

Cette campagne de financement aidera la compagnie Katie Ward à compenser les coûts d'exploitation de la saison. Les fonds contribueront à la location de studio, au transport, au temps de répétition, au matériel de recherche et aux frais de subsistance.

Cette campagne est déterminante pour la compagnie, car elle contribue à soutenir le rôle de CKW dans le milieu de la danse en tant que compagnie dédiée à l'expérimentation et au développement de nouvelles formes de performance, et ce, tant à l’échelle locale qu’internationale!

Fondée en 2011, la compagnie Katie Ward s'est profondément engagée à favoriser le développement de nouvelles expériences de danse et de performances contemporaines. La compagnie recherche également à provoquer des interactions entre la communauté et le public, et alphabétisation en danse à l'échelle locale, nationale, et internationale par des pratiques de créations éthiques, écoresponsables et une philosophie favorisant la diversité d'expérience et de perspective, CKW soutient le travail expérimental et multidisciplinaire de Katie Ward. CKW met en commun des ressources pour cette année passionnante de découvertes, de création et de développement. Pour ce faire, la compagnie a un objectif de collecte de fonds de 2000 $, et nous vous invitons à vous joindre à nous dans l’atteinte de cet objectif. Si vous souhaitez contribuer à la réalisation de nos projets, participez à notre campagne en ligne en faisant une contribution et en passant le mot à vos amis.

Merci de tout l’équipe!!
story_txt: Anything Whatsoever(français suivrait) Dear friend,To imagine ourselves in the future - We must imagine a newly emanating world. We are caught in old fashioned ways of seeing the world. Compagnie Katie Ward asks - how can we regenerate our imaginations and create new futures? Let your imaginations guide you and participate in propelling this kind of contemporary dance forward – the kind that is engaged in these questions.Spring 2020 will be a busy period for CKW. March and April 2020 will be devoted to the development and finalization of the solo Anything Whatsoever.A "dream room" will be created for the spectator where it is possible to contemplate and access A-Ha! moments, moments of realization and insight. The public is invited to contribute to the work, by using their imaginations and following scores that ask them to speak. This dialogue btween dance and spoken words creates and underlines a present centered awareness in all participants.Supporting CKW means participating in the development of its creations, produced with an eco-responsible ethic. Thanks to your donation, you will contribute to :- Research and creation of the new solo called Anything Whatsoever which will be in developed during a technical residency at La Rotonde (Quebec City) and presented in Great Britain and in the Netherlands.- Network development of CKW. Supporting CKW's network means participating in the growth of the company’s creations, both in Montreal (FTA, La Chapelle Scènes Contemporaines, Tangente), elsewhere in Canada (Festival of New Dance, La Rotonde, Fluid Festival, Kinetic Studio) and internationally (Festival Via, and Maison des Arts de Créteil - (France), Dance4 (United Kingdom), Saari residency (Finland) Dansateliers (Netherlands). Dancers / danseurs : Audrée Juteau, Nathan Yaff, Dany Desjardins, Kelly KeenanPhoto : Svetla Atanasova Compagnie Katie Ward (CKW) creates, produces and presents the choreographic projects of artistic director Katie Ward. CKW’s work examines the endless loop between imagination and reality. Her performance scores are works that index reality, establishing conditions to disrupt the way we see it so that so that our relationship with it can be rethought.CKW's mandate is characterized by reasonable, ethical and fair production and creation practices and a philosophy that promotes diversity in all its manifestations. CKW is also committed to contributing to the development of the field of contemporary dance by providing a structure to develop experimental and multidisciplinary work of Katie Ward, and associated artists.CKW creates and hosts performance events ranging from contemporary dance to performance installations, including performances. CKW also organizes and hosts workshops, residencies and practice sharing events where practitioners and the public can discuss what dance is as well as what it can do. In these events, reflection, interest, imagination and curiosity, risk-taking and diversity in all its manifestations are encouraged. Allocation of fundsThis fundraising campaign will help Compagnie Katie Ward to offset operating costs for the season. The funds will go to studio rental, transportation, rehearsal time, research materials and living expenses.This campaign is important for the company, as it helps support CKW's role in the dance community as a company dedicated to experimenting and developing new forms of performance, both at the local level and internationally!Founded in 2011 - CKW is committed to fostering the development of new contemporary dance and performance experiments, as well as community-public interaction and dance literacy at the local, national and international levels. Through ethical and creative practices - and a philosophy that promotes diversity of experience and perspective - CKW supports Katie Ward's experimental and multidisciplinary work and contributes to the field of practice of contemporary dance.CKW is pooling resources for this exciting year of discovery, creation and development. To do this, the company has a fundraising goal of $ 2,000, and we invite you to join us in achieving this goal. If you want to contribute towards the realization of our projects, participate in our online campaign by making a contribution and spreading the word to your friends.Thank you from team CKW!!*** Chèr.e ami.e,Pour nous projeter dans le futur, nous devons nous prêter à l’exercice d’imaginer les possibles, une infinité de mondes émanant. Nous sommes cependant coincés dans des façons conventionnelles et usées de percevoir le monde. Cette question est au cœur de la démarche de la compagnie Katie Ward : comment régénérer l’imaginaire collectif afin de créer un avenir différent, unique?Laissez votre imagination vous guider et participez à l'essor d'une compagnie de danse contemporaine qui s'engage profondément à répondre à cette interrogation.Le printemps 2020 sera une période chargée et ambitieuse. story:
A PRODUCTION OF
Shakespeare Approves: Your Friendly Neighborhood Shakespeare
The Social Distancing Players
The Zenith Players
and Maisha Elonai

 

UPDATE: An anonymous benefactor has agreed to match anything we earn up to $2,500! Please help us fund this program so we can take full advantage of the match for the NAACP's LDF and for our cast members!

 

Revel with faeries, lovers, and fools in this live, online reading of William Shakespeare’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” The magic of the forest will whisk you away as our diverse cast, comprised of some of your favorite East Coast Renaissance Faire performers, comes together to read to you this classic comedy.

We hope that you will help us fund this show for two wonderful causes. Half of all donations will go to the NAACP’s Legal Defense Fund, a 501(c)3 charitable organization that fights for racial justice by working to protect voting rights, reform our criminal justice system, achieve education equity, and ensure economic justice for all.

The other half of your donations will support those of our actors who have lost all sources of income because of COVID-19 show cancellations and yet unprocessed unemployment claims.

CAST

Robin Goodfellow, “Puck”
read by Dan Kostelec
William Shakespeare, Shakespeare Approves
www.shakespeareapproves.com

Theseus
read by Tom Zadoyko
Captain Red Swash Rogers, Buckle and Swash Show
www.facebook.com/buckleandswash

Hippolyta
read by Melissa L. E. Baker
Lady Morgan and Founder, Chaste Treasure
www.chastetreasure.com

Egeus
read by Matt Celly
Sausage King, Pennsylvania Renaissance Faire
Duke Hugh Percy, New Jersey Renaissance Faire
www.parenfaire.com
www.njrenfaire.com

Philostrate, Master of Revels
read by Claire Bochenek
Co-Founder, Zenith Players
www.zenithplayers.com

Helena
read by Jasmine Leilani Kyle
Sultana Lyla, Chaste Treasure
www.chastetreasure.com

Demetrius
read by Ezekiel Jackson
Randy Smooth, Lords of Adventure
www.lordsofadventude.com

Hermia
read by Aileen Cairns
Lady Rosaline Howard, Chaste Treasure
www.chastetreasure.com

Lysander
read by TJ Miller
Founding Partner, New Jersey Renaissance Faire
Roger Awesome, Lords of Adventure
Owner, The Ludus Academy of Martial Arts
www.actionjkd.com

Oberon
read by James Ellerby
Actor, Roundtable Productions
Cast Member, New Jersey Renaissance Faire
www.facebook.com/roundtableproductions

Titania
read by Maisha Elonai
Cast Member, New Jersey Renaissance Faire
www.njrenfaire.com

A Fairy
read by Meadow Perry
Meadow Perry, Bubble Magician
www.meadowperry.com

Nick Bottom
read by William G. Lewis
Dialect Coach, NJ Renaissance Faire
www.njrenfaire.com

Peter Quince and Peasblossom
read by Ami Reader
Lady Arabella Proudmore, Chaste Treasure
www.chastetreasure.com

Tom Snout and Cobweb
read by Eleonore Thomas
Lady Elsa, Chaste Treasure
www.chastetreasure.com

Francis Flute
read by Shakira Searle
Actor, Trans Voices Cabaret
Actor, Zenith Players
www.transvoicescabaret.com
www.zenithplayers.com

Robin Starveling and Mustardseed
read by Katherine Mendez
Cast Member, New Jersey Renaissance Fair
www.chastetreasure.com

Moth
read by An Nichols
Improv Artist, ComedySportz Philadelphia
www.comedysportzphilly.com

 

What We Need & What You Get

We would like to raise at least $2,500 for this performance, so that we can donate $1,300 to the NAACP’s Legal Defense Fund and still guarantee each otherwise unemployed performer a minimum of $100 for their time creating this magic. Please help make this happen! 

For patrons donating $50 or more, our Bard will record a Shakespearean sonnet of your choice, just for you.

 

The Impact

Funding our campaign will directly help the struggle for racial equality in the United States. At this time of social injustice, we need all the allies we can get! The NAACP is a BBB certified charitable organization of the highest caliber, and we are proud to support them.

You will also become a patron of the arts, helping professional entertainers pay their bills, their groceries, and avoid further poverty or credit card debt.

Last but certainly not least, you will help extend hope and build morale for our fellow members of humanity by giving them a much-needed distraction during this crisis, a sense that we all have people around us who care enough to make this world more just, more equitable, and more magical.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Many of us cannot afford to support any cause financially during this troubled time, and we all (personally) understand how this feels. You can still help this campaign by sharing it with friends, family, social groups, etc. And if you can do so in the future, please donate to the NAACP or other organizations fighting for racial equality.

story:
THE LAUNCH: John on the Island of Patmos

JOHN @PATMOS springs to life in this world-premier work by Daniel Stompor! Set on a Greek island roughly 1000 years after the life and death of Christ, PATMOS follows the exile of the forgotten, beloved apostle John amidst an incursion led by King Henry II of England on his way to pay homage in Jerusalem. In tow are the royal sons (and would-be kings) Fitz and Rich, an imprisoned Eleanore of Aquitaine, and a curious guard named Petra. With the End of Days fast approaching, John grapples with a royal family struggling to live both Queer and Catholic while searching for where in the world has space for an immortal jewish apostle thriving far afield of any binary. As John grapples with his role in creating a world of cultural colonization, it becomes less and less clear if this whole Christianity thing is worth saving.

Directed by Sofía Anastasia, PATMOS features the talents of Madison Couture, Irisdelia Garcia, Ash Laraque-Ho, Elle Vallejos, and Angel Zeas. The show’s design incorporates the work of costumes by Paul Van Sickle, lights by Erik Peterson, sound by Emma Hasselbach, and space by Madison Couture. Script development and dramaturgy by Viv\\Ian Chace.

Living somewhere between historical fantasy and spiritual passion play, PATMOS is a conjecture of queer identities encountering one another in a world somewhere adjacent to our own. Queer imaginings and reimaginings of historical figures have long been an element of euro-western LGBTQ storytelling. Exploring this tradition laid the foundation for PATMOS, wherein queer bodies navigate the claiming of their narratives and bodies by others, and the violence that can result from losing control of your own story. JOHN @PATMOS was conceived at Northwestern University and is in continued development in Queens, NY from December 2018 to present.

By supporting us, you are supporting our artists.

As a part of our work model, we are prioritizing supporting our team. Accordingly, 100% of funds raised will go directly to compensating our artists. 

The more we raise, the more that our artists will receive for their efforts bringing PATMOS to life.  By supporting our campaign, you are making a direct contribution to the lives of our designers, actors, and production team.

As a thank you from us, we would love to give you the best seats in the house to experience JOHN@PATMOS for yourself, as well as a chance to meet our artists for us to personally thank you.

Can't donate? Not to worry!

We would love to see you all the same. JOHN @PATMOS will be performing June 28-30, 2019 at Sitting Shotgun in Brooklyn, NY. A portion of all ticket sales will be allotted to our artists as well, so you are supporting all of us just by attending! All performance details (as well as ticket info) below:

SQUARE1
885 Park Ave, Brooklyn, NY
Friday 6/28 at 8pm
Saturday 6/29 at 2pm and 8pm
Sunday 6/30 at 4pm and 8pm

Meet outside the large wood and glass lobby doors, an usher will escort you to the theatre.

Early bird tickets are $10 when purchased before 6/18 and are $12 thereafter; $10 young artist tickets are also available. Buy tickets here: https://johnatpatmos.brownpapertickets.com/

story:
A little about me...

Hello hello!

Thank you so much for visiting this page. 


Since the age of ten I've been trying to make my acting dreams come true.
I've had rejections, the "not this times" and many hard lessons.


After applying to drama school three years in a row...I finally got in! Hurrah!

I studied film at Falmouth university in Cornwall. The culmination of my studies let me to write and direct a film titled "The Roaring", which was very successful in two BAFTA affiliated bodies (Aesthetica, Underwire) alongside winning the Royal Television Society student award for Best Film. See link below for a peek.

Link: 

 

Whilst working full-time after graduation I joined The Crescent Theatre company in Birmingham - performing whenever I could get the chance on evenings and weekends! The Crescent is an amazing company and I made some great friends. I treasure my time so much there - I really am going to miss it. 

I love film-making. But I know in my heart, acting is wedged right in there too.

In September I'll be leaving my beloved hometown of Birmingham, and going to East 15. A small, friendly, and amazing drama school near London.

 

 

The MA Acting course at East 15 is a thoroughly practical, highly intensive vocational course. Exploring techniques from some of Europe's most influential practitioners as well as innovative professional practice from the UK and internationally.  It's a great honor to be accepted and I know it's place where I can truly learn my craft!  And now I'm so close, I'm terrified of it slipping away. For me this is such an opportunity!

I'll have to leave my job, leave where I'm living and enter an entire world of unknowns in the big scary smoke.

Actors normally can usually rely of funds, grants and bursaries to help them on their way. But since Covid, they've all dried up. 

I'm a normal (I think) Birmingham girl. I have little in the way of funds. And its now more expensive and dangerous to live your dream as an actor. 

The bucket of dreams...

I have applied to over 20 funds. Spoken to everyone I can possibly speak to. 

I'm asking for any small change. Anything at all to add into my bucket of dreams.

It'll be for food, books, courses, and help during my time at East 15. Books and materials alone cost £800.

I know it's a big ask, especially now, but whether it's 50p or £50, whatever you send will mean a world of difference and will help me find my feet.

 

 

A world without actors... 

I know, if I can get through this course, I can help people smile, understand, be excited, feel passion, drama, love. On stage or on screen I hope to open minds and hearts. 

I'm a little lass with a big heart and big dreams. 

Whatever you can spare will make all the difference

- x - 

PS: if you can't help right now, please still share my post. It'd mean so so much xx Thank you!
story_txt:
A little about me...Hello hello!Thank you so much for visiting this page. Since the age of ten I've been trying to make my acting dreams come true.I've had rejections, the "not this times" and many hard lessons.After applying to drama school three years in a row...I finally got in! Hurrah!I studied film at Falmouth university in Cornwall. The culmination of my studies let me to write and direct a film titled "The Roaring", which was very successful in two BAFTA affiliated bodies (Aesthetica, Underwire) alongside winning the Royal Television Society student award for Best Film. See link below for a peek.Link:  Whilst working full-time after graduation I joined The Crescent Theatre company in Birmingham - performing whenever I could get the chance on evenings and weekends! The Crescent is an amazing company and I made some great friends. I treasure my time so much there - I really am going to miss it. I love film-making. But I know in my heart, acting is wedged right in there too.In September I'll be leaving my beloved hometown of Birmingham, and going to East 15. A small, friendly, and amazing drama school near London.  The MA Acting course at East 15 is a thoroughly practical, highly intensive vocational course. Exploring techniques from some of Europe's most influential practitioners as well as innovative professional practice from the UK and internationally.  It's a great honor to be accepted and I know it's place where I can truly learn my craft!  And now I'm so close, I'm terrified of it slipping away. For me this is such an opportunity!I'll have to leave my job, leave where I'm living and enter an entire world of unknowns in the big scary smoke.Actors normally can usually rely of funds, grants and bursaries to help them on their way. But since Covid, they've all dried up. I'm a normal (I think) Birmingham girl. I have little in the way of funds. And its now more expensive and dangerous to live your dream as an actor. The bucket of dreams...I have applied to over 20 funds. Spoken to everyone I can possibly speak to. I'm asking for any small change. Anything at all to add into my bucket of dreams.It'll be for food, books, courses, and help during my time at East 15. Books and materials alone cost £800.I know it's a big ask, especially now, but whether it's 50p or £50, whatever you send will mean a world of difference and will help me find my feet.  
A world without actors... I know, if I can get through this course, I can help people smile, understand, be excited, feel passion, drama, love. On stage or on screen I hope to open minds and hearts. I'm a little lass with a big heart and big dreams. Whatever you can spare will make all the difference- x - PS: if you can't help right now, please still share my post. It'd mean so so much xx Thank you!

story:
Milo's World: A Digital Musical Song Cycle About Creating Art!

 

4Score Productions and On Its Way Musical Productions are raising funds to produce, record, and present Milo's World, an original musical song cycle premiering digitally this fall.

 

Summary

Milo’s World follows a budding sculpture artist, stuck attempting to create the final piece for a career-defining commission. The pressure from her agent, an unforgiving deadline, and herself, send her spiraling on a dark and desperate search for inspiration in the confines of her studio. Throughout the riveting score of 13 original songs, Milo fluxes in and out of reality and begins to see that her world contains much more than meets the eye.

Help Produce This New Musical Song Cycle and Album!

About the Writer

Sean Yauk is an emerging Canadian composer and lyricist whose work has won critical acclaim in the music and theatre community. He wrote Milo's World to explore and musicalize the creative process that a visual artist goes through. Milo’s World serves as the first full musical song cycle that Sean has written on his own. Contributing to this campaign serves as a great opportunity for you to support an emerging voice in music and theatre!

About the Companies (4Score and On Its Way MP)

This project is being produced by 4Score Productions and On Its Way Musical Productions. 4Score is an indie music production group that creates music-oriented storytelling projects. On Its Way is an emerging musical theatre company striving to provide young artists with the opportunity to work in theatre. Both companies are determined to bring Milo’s World to life digitally with your help.

Perks of Contributing 

Contributing to the production of this new digital musical has some incredible perks, including screening passes, merchandise, original sheet music, art from the show, and more! Check out our various contribution levels, to see theawesome ways to your generosity can be recognized.

The Impact of Contributing 

Milo's World is being produced by two small indie companies (4Score Productions and On Its Way Musical Productions) who care deeply about the work that they do and the young artists that they work with! They are taking a risk by employing an artistic team of emerging professionals to work on this show. This is also the first original musical that both companies have been involved in bringing it to life.

Where Contributions Go? 

Milo's World is the first original musical being produced by two small indie companies. We trying to reach our goal of $5,000. Your money goes directly into paying our emerging artists, accessing rehearsal and filming space, providing proper Covid safety equipment for our team, and more as we work towards the completion of film and album versions of Milo’s World.

Risks & Challenges

The financial risk involved in bringing a brand new musical and album to life is rather large for us. Additionally, this piece has been rehearsed and is being filmed in full compliance with Canadian Public Health restrictions in order to limit the spread of COVID 19. The project has its risks. But with your support, we will be able to bring it to life. We have dreams of continuing to support and develop new musical works by this artist, so if Milo’s World is successful this surely won’t be the first original musical and cast album that we produce! 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that this has been a financially difficult time for many. If donating is not an option at this time, you can support us by liking and following 4Score Productions and On Its Way Musical Productions on Facebook and Instagram, and sharing this campaign page link with all of your friends and family!

story:
Hello my name is David King. I am the founder and owner of Death Guild.  I'm starting this campaign to try and help my employees through this extraordinary time. The DJ's, security, and coatcheck people all depend on the money they make every week to eat and pay their bills.  With your help they can get through this trying time.

 

We basically are offering a bunch of perks from a discounted year pass to future Death Guild events to extremely limited edition merch or just the ability to share a little bit forward.

Thank you for for your time and patronage.

story:
The GSU Players need your help.

  • Georgia State University, a thriving university in the heart of Atlanta, Georgia, is  home to the Georgia State University Players, the oldest organization on campus, honing on providing Atlantans with prime performances, lead by the faculty and working professionals in the area to feature students both on stage and off in two main stages a year, along with a student showcase,  a staged reading, as well as bringing the GSU Players several workshops and many opportunities to hone their craft.
  • I, Evan Ruede, Junior at GSU and a Theatre Performance major, wants to direct a show, and be surrounded by a team fueled by students. I chose Almost, Maine for it has endless capabilities, and is perfect for our space. Almost, Maine will make it's way to Georgia State in February 2016 in being one more oppurtunity of the year to show audiences what the players can do, but only if we can reach our budget goal. 

Almost, Maine February 2016

    • Almost, Maine by John Cariani is the show that will not only reel in a community all over the metropolitan Atlanta area, but will pull actors, and technical artists alike to create an experience that will dazzle audiences like the northern lights. 
  • Almost, Maine is a romantic comedy that consists of short, 10 minute vignettes of the citizens of the titular town. The show takes it’s time going from pair to pair, and let’s the viewer get to slowly get the idea of what the citizens of Almost are all about; which is them finding out who they are, and who they do or do not need in their lives to find that person. The show is funny, smart, sweet, and sincere, and is never trying to be anything other than honest. I feel the struggle of being sincere to one’s true character is an epidemic all college students can relate to in this whirlwind period of our lives. Not only is this a show many can relate to, it has taken the nation by storm as a popular showcase of emotion that many theatre patrons citywide will flock towards. With Valentine's Day, and cold weather to cuddle up to, February couldn't be more appropriate to feature this love-ly tale.

It's a Win, Win, Win, Win, Win.

The production of Almost, Maine will cost nothing compared to the "MainStage series", that of which is directed by faculty, and consisting of a paid team. Students will not be paid for their efforts, similarly to how the actor's and those who volunteer for experience in the mainstages. Yes, these tasks will be significantly more hands on, but it comes with endless learning opportunities. 

Where the budget is needed comes in two important parts: the rights, and the rest. Rights aren't cheap, $100 per performance. We will go on for one full weekend which will feature 4 opportunities to visit Almost. The other $800 will be used to set the scene with set design, costuming, and lighting. No one will be compensated in making this miracle happen, but funds are more than necessary for setting it all up. Still, this small asking budget of $1,200 will fill seats, and bring the Players much more to make projects like these a consistent reality. 

  • If the entire goal is not reached by May of this year, as long as the $400 for rights are met, Almost, Maine will still go on. The Players will have to fundraise outside of indiegogo, and what better way to get the word out other than the internet! Less money means less funding for sets, costumes, props, etc. That would be unfortunate, but your donation will help immensely to making AM a reality regardless of the final take fundraising wise.

If you can't donate, PROJECT SO THE BACK SEATS CAN HEAR YOU

If you can't donate, then a godsend would be to SPREAD THE WORD. Hit that share button, and most of all, COME SEE THE SHOW NEXT FEBRUARY.

story:
Hello everyone, my name is Dagny Ingle. First, a little about me. I am a 14 year old high school freshman from Macon, Georgia, USA (small town about 100 miles south of Atlanta).  I am a straight "A" student (nerd) pursuing an International Baccalaureate diploma with a Fine Arts minor (in Dance) from Central High School's magnet programs. I am a devout Sherlock/Dr. Who fan (go BBC!). An avid reader of John Green novels. I also play the violin. But first and foremost (and most relevant), I am a Dancer. 


I have been dancing since I was 3 years old. I have turned my 3 year old's outlet to burn excess energy into a passion I will pursue for the rest of my life. If only mom had known then that the weekly 30 minute Saturday class would become an daily 3 to 4 hour, every weekend for rehearsals, every hour outside school phenomenon,  she might have reconsidered.




















I have found my calling.  I wish to dance professionally and in that pursuit, I am attempting to gain best instruction from the best available.  I have been fortunate to have had my ballet education with Mrs. Jane Madison at the Madison Studio - Dance Education for the last 10 years.  Under her mentorship and her excellent faculty, I have gained the technique, strength and artistry that allowed me the confidence to audition for the American Ballet Theater Summer Intensive and gain a coveted invitation to attend their New York City Advance program.


      Dagny as Clara in the Nutcracker of Middle Georgia 2013

    


Now for the hard part, funding. I will need to fund my tuition, accommodations for two (room and board), proper dance attire (ABT dancewear) and transportation. As I am 14, my age requires me to have a chaperon. As the intensive is for 5 weeks, June 22nd until July 24th, the accommodations will need to be for both my mother and myself. Finding accommodations for 5 weeks in New York City has been eye opening and frankly frightening experience. The price is intimidating but as I have informed my mom, the internet is vast. So I am turning to you, the dance enthusiasts of the web to help me obtain a piece of my dream.

I am asking you to take a journey with me this summer.  Support me with a donation and/or share my story/link on your social networking platform (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc.).  I will let everyone who donates follow me on my Facebook Blog during the intensive.  I will share insight into the day to day and just keep you all informed on how NYC is treating me. 

In all honesty this dream is currently beyond my single mom's means.  If I am going to continue to get the best instruction from true Ballet Master teachers, I know I am going to need financial help. Please consider supporting me. Donate, spread my story (share, share, share) and join me on my Dancing Dream journey.  Thank you everyone.

{That went well, don't you think.:)}


p.s. please scroll up to top and look through my Gallery of dance performances and photos.

story:
“I couldn’t call UCLA home without the family I’ve come to have in HOOLIGAN”  - Noah Holliday, 4th Year

HOOLIGAN Theatre Company was founded in February 2006 and has been dedicated to providing educational theater opportunities both on and offstage for UCLA students of all majors and experience levels for the past 10 seasons. We have grown from our first musical, written, rehearsed, and performed in just six weeks, to producing four mainstage shows, a 24-Hour Musical for charity, a festival of one-acts, and a variety of educational workshops and events every season. Before HOOLIGAN was founded, there was no way to be involved with theatre on campus unless students were in the theater major. Now, we are able to provide opportunities as performers, technicians, or staff for over 200 UCLA students, from Engineering majors to English majors and everything in-between! HOOLIGAN has become a family for many students on campus and strives to provide a home away from home for students of all backgrounds with an interest in theater.

Producing theatre as a student group at UCLA becomes more expensive every year. Last year, HOOLIGAN’s annual budget reached a high of $120,000. As less funding comes from the university, we as students become more dependent on the generosity of donors and the cast and crew becomes responsible for fundraising a larger percentage of the budget.  We are hoping to celebrate our 10th season by raising $10,000 to relieve much of the financial burden placed on students to make theater happen on campus. This sum will help ensure that students do not have to spend their own money up front to guarantee that we have a venue to perform in. We are so grateful for our first decade on campus and hope to keep HOOLIGAN Theatre around for many more seasons to come.  Each and every donation makes a tremendous difference for us!  

This is the largest fundraising effort we have ever attempted, and we are so excited to celebrate our 10th season on campus and hope that you can donate $10 to help keep theatre opportunities alive for UCLA students of all majors! Whether you can afford to donate or not, we ask that you spread the word about HOOLIGAN Theatre at UCLA and share our campaign with 10 friends! We hope to keep out theatrical family strong for Bruins for years to come! Every little bit helps!

story:
Welcome to Part 1 of our campaign for The Nutcracker and the Mouse King
Check out the message from our Producer, Jeremy Terry, below!


I love Christmas.

When I was first approached about  creating a play based off of The Nutcracker Ballet, I was a little intimidated, frankly. I didn't think a show could capture the essence of the magical story we know and love from the ballet. But the more I read the script and listened to our director's concepts for the shows, the more I knew this was something that NEEDED to happen.

We're looking to raise between $15,000-$40,000 for the world premiere of this show in New York City, this holiday season. That's where we need YOU to help.

Unfortunately, a show of this nature is not cheap. If you're going to give your money to the show, we want you to know exactly where those funds are going. Check out our minimum budget needs for the show:

Estimated Minimum Budget

Theatre Space - $5,000

Scenery and props - $4,000

Electrics - $2,000

Costumes - $3,000

Marketing and miscellaneous expenses - $1,000

Total Budget for the show - $15,000

Our total goal is $15,000, but we don't want to stop there. 

The first part of our campaign here is to raise money for a theatre space. Our minimum budget is $5,000, but the more money we raise, the better space we can afford. We've got some really great offers on spaces for the premiere in New York City, but we need your help to get the show to that financial level.


Donation Incentives

​I get it, you don't want to just give your money away for free. So that's why we're offering incentives, the largest one of course being the opportunity for our grand prize package - a backstage tour of our facilities led by myself and Taryn Verley, our director. We will take you behind the scenes of the show to stand onstage, look at our scenery, props, and costumes up close, and view our backstage areas. You might even be able to meet a few of the actors! There will only be 15 spots available for this tour. Each winner will be able to bring a friend and will receive two tickets for the opening night of the show.

In addition to the grand prize, there are other amazing perks. In this first of our campaigns, you can potentially receive a copy of an original scenic design for the show, signed by the designer, Joe Bauer! This is something that won't be available in parts 2 or 3 of our campaign, so don't miss out on this opportunity. Check out all of our donor circles listed in the perks!

Not everyone can be a member of the Gold Circle, and we get that. But every donation brings this story closer to the stage.

Have we piqued your interest with this show? Does it sound like something you'd like to see? Consider giving. I believe in this show. The story and vision is just too good not to be shown. I know that giving your money to something is a big investment. If you have any questions or concerns at all, you can contact me at jeremyterryproductions@gmail.com. Thank you so much for your time.
