Check out our minimum budget needs for the show:Estimated Minimum BudgetTheatre Space - $5,000Scenery and props - $4,000Electrics - $2,000Costumes - $3,000Marketing and miscellaneous expenses - $1,000Total Budget for the show - $15,000Our total goal is $15,000, but we don't want to stop there. The first part of our campaign here is to raise money for a theatre space. Our minimum budget is $5,000, but the more money we raise, the better space we can afford. We've got some really great offers on spaces for the premiere in New York City, but we need your help to get the show to that financial level.Donation Incentives​I get it, you don't want to just give your money away for free. So that's why we're offering incentives, the largest one of course being the opportunity for our grand prize package - a backstage tour of our facilities led by myself and Taryn Verley, our director. We will take you behind the scenes of the show to stand onstage, look at our scenery, props, and costumes up close, and view our backstage areas. You might even be able to meet a few of the actors! There will only be 15 spots available for this tour. Each winner will be able to bring a friend and will receive two tickets for the opening night of the show.In addition to the grand prize, there are other amazing perks. In this first of our campaigns, you can potentially receive a copy of an original scenic design for the show, signed by the designer, Joe Bauer! This is something that won't be available in parts 2 or 3 of our campaign, so don't miss out on this opportunity. Check out all of our donor circles listed in the perks!Not everyone can be a member of the Gold Circle, and we get that. But every donation brings this story closer to the stage.Have we piqued your interest with this show? Does it sound like something you'd like to see? Consider giving. I believe in this show. The story and vision is just too good not to be shown. I know that giving your money to something is a big investment. If you have any questions or concerns at all, you can contact me at jeremyterryproductions@gmail.com. Thank you so much for your time.

story:
WillTory - Studio where knowledge connect with the movement and bring great benefit to your daily life!
Over 20 years our Teacher spend with Different Body Workouts:

Dance Ballet, Jazz, Tribe, Belly Dance, Modern, Contemporary, Hip Hop different styles;

Energy and power practices - Chi Goon, Thai Chi, Meditation;

Yoga of different schools and levels - Iyengar, Hatha, Baptiste, Yoga Mala, Ashtanga;

Recover from sport injures and help to other people. Now all this knowledge we are ready to teach and share with everybody who wants to live Happy and Healthy Life.

Heal the World with us!

Under one roof we are planing to have a Fitness Gym Club, for your own creation of Human Art;

Dance classes with international Teacher;

Healing Yoga and Ballet for Health classes with professional trainer;

And small Cafe with home made bakery and healthy slim tea and goji drinks where are you can chilling at evening with big screen Cinema.

We are open our studio at Northern Thailand - land of Magical double rainbows.


We are teaching now and providing Dance Therapy - to recover from the sport injures and other accidents. Classical Ballet for kids and Adults, fun and joyful Hip Hop, Jazz and Contemporary dance classes, where you can express yourself and be fit, AND also where you can create your own happiness and shine. Life full of joy and success. Different power moving classes help to find your energy and to understand your body as a best friend for your daily life. Energetic and feminine Belly dance classes where you can learn to savor the joy of life, to express your feelings using body language, give a sense of harmony and keep your body and spirit looks and feel forever young and health.

Knowledge of bodywork, experience of 20 years practice, performing, teaching and helping to others - all this our Teacher collect and create special approach, conciseness program for everybody can learn Dance and be Fit in any time, in any age and with any basic.

Owner and Teacher of WillTory Studio - Me is Ukrainian professional choreographer,
teacher and dancer of Ballet, Contemporary, Jazz, Hip-Hop, Ballet for Health and Arabian belly dances.
Certified specialist "Master Degree" by Ukrainian Kharkov State Academy of Culture.
For last  8 years travel around Asia as a Professional Teacher and Performer, living in Thailand with Husband.
Start dancing since kinder garden times, but take it to professional level from 11 years old. Spend a lot of time with Classical Ballet and Popular Dancing, Performing and showing on different Competitions.
Since year 2000 - take body work to advance level - Get Certificated as Teacher, Artist, Choreographer, Performer. Run own Hip Hop Dance Crew.
Keep going with International Competitions, where was win couple medals - Gold and Silver for Contemporary and Hip Hop Choreography and Performing.
Since 2006 - work and travel around Asia as Teacher, Dancer, Choreographer.
All that time not only Teaching and be a student too for Kung Foo and yoga classes with different international teachers.
Now Teacher and Performer at Russian Ballet School Thailand for Ballet, Jazz, Hip Hop and Ballet for Health programs.


We need this fund support about gym equipment(15 000-20 000 USD), renovate place(10 000-15 000USD), clear about documents with government(10 000-15 000USD), lawyers and get a certification and legalization for our teaching programs( 5 000-8 000 USD).

It's can take little longer time that we are aspect. But we will keep teaching and performing, even by SKYPE.

Health its something what we create every day! Heal the World with us!

We open this project because we love dancing and be fit, we love to share our art, we love to see more happy and beautiful people around, we love when you are feel healthy happy and success, we love and ready to spread our experience.

Everybody who support us from now will get a great perks: Online classes, videos, slim tea, healthy tips for daily life. You will able discover experience of 20 years in one touch.

We are believe that everybody wants to be a good looking, health and fit, success and beautiful, live a happy bright life. And we know how to do this - its what our project all about!!!

And we accept any help - to get the word out and make some noise about WillTory campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
RE-LAUNCHED!

We have re-launched the campaign – thank you all who helped us in the first fundraising phase.  Our new campaign link is The Widow of Tom's Hill (phase II campaign)

Our Story

In the winter of 2014 the Artistic Director of Luna Stage (a reputable professional theater in New Jersey) asked Rachel Black-Spaulding if she would like to direct a workshop of The Widow of Tom’s Hill  by Aleks Merilo. This was a play Rachel - in her capacity as Literary and Dramaturge Associate of Luna Stage - had read and admired earlier that season. Rachel reread the play and answered with a resounding yes!

What followed was months of discussion between Merilo and Black-Spaulding, further work on the script, and then in June, three weeks of rehearsals with the actors and even more re-writes led to three sold out performances and a lot of positive buzz. This workshop/production had been produced by David Spaulding (in association with Scripts Up!, a non for profit new play development company) and presented by Luna Stage in Luna’s Lab Theater. David Spaulding then submitted it to 59E59 Theaters, a prestigious Off Broadway theater, and it was accepted into their 2015 season!

Just this spring, the Beverly Hills Theatre Guild declared The Widow of Tom’s Hill  a second place winner of the prestigious Julie Harris Playwright Awards - The Dr Henry and Lilian Nesburn Playwright Award.  Established in 1977 by Neil Simon, the Julie Harris Awards are the culmination of a national competition which over the last ten years has evaluated over 5,000 plays.

The Widow of Tom’s Hill is an emotionally gritty and spellbinding tale about trust, misinformation, and survival during what was and what still remains the deadliest plague in human history, the 1918 Influenza Pandemic. When a small American town on the Washington coast becomes the subject of an armed quarantine, a nineteen-year-old widow and a young sailor from opposite sides of the blockade engage in a surprising and dangerous match. Their lives and the town’s fate hang in the balance.

We are at an exciting moment of bringing this play to full life! The Widow of Tom’s Hill  has been given an impressive home for its fast approaching New York City premiere, the director and playwright are hard at work with script refinements based on discovery from the workshop performances, and production planning is well underway for set design, costumes, and building our production team.

But we need your help!

Your contributions are TAX DEDUCTABLE. Please read on.

The Impact of the Play

Dramatic impact:

Alex Merilo, a young, award winning and critically acclaimed playwright manages to do successfully what many contemporary playwrights cannot, and that is to continually twist and turn a suspenseful tale until it reaches an outcome audiences do not see coming.

Additionally, not only is the plot captivating, but the characters speak in beautifully written prose, so rare in contemporary playwriting, yet so enriching for the audience’s ear.

From an acting standpoint, this two-hander is a tour de force for two young actors. They are on stage the entire time, embroiled in a byzantine relationship, surrounded by extreme circumstances.

What a thrilling way for audiences to spend an evening, instead of slumped on one’s couch in front of the television screen!

On the global front:

Although this play is not intended to be an historic account by any means, it is significant to note that the workshop production of The Widow of Tom’s Hill at Luna went up in June 2014, just one week before any major news arrived of last spring’s Ebola outbreak, and numerous weeks before the onset of abject hysteria, media frenzy, and clear mishandling by authorities. Aside from the questions the play raises about the capacity of human interplay as a whole, interestingly, the reactions to the illness explored in this fable and the misinformation of authorities thereof, not only embody a small microcosm of what happened in 1918, but also how the world handled - or rather mishandled - the more recent Ebola Outbreak.

As for the Influenza of 1918, it is lost history. We have forgotten its enormous impact and the scope of loss. Three to five percent of the world’s population died from the illness. It killed more people in twenty four weeks than AIDS killed in twenty four years, and more people in a year than the Black Death of the middle ages killed in a century.

The story told in The Widow of Tom’s Hill moves us to ask: What impact do global disasters have on us as a people? But perhaps most pointedly, how does human nature, and the complexities and circumstances of our individual lives play a part in how we react?

What We Need & What You Get

Ticket sales will only cover part of the costs.  We need $10,500 to complete our production budget. 

Join us in the final stages of this play’s development and be a part of theatre in the making! Please give a TAX-DEDUCTABLE gift that feeds the spirit, stirs the heart, and informs the mind.

Please help bring The Widow of Tom’s Hill to life at the prestigious Off Broadway 59E59 Theatres! In so doing, not only will you help a play to its feet in New York, but it will also create opportunity for it to become a viable piece for regional theaters across the country – perhaps a theater near you!

What do you get? Besides a huge thank you from the bottom of our hearts, check out the Select a Perk Column to your right to learn what you will receive!

We thank you for your interest, and we’re so grateful for any contribution!

story:
THE NIKOLAIS/LOUIS FOUNDATION FOR DANCE

in association  with 

THE ABRONS ARTS CENTER

Presents

FROM THE HORSE'S MOUTH

From the Horse's Mouth celebrates Murray Louis, dancer, choreographer, teacher, mentor, and overall force of nature, who with Alwin Nikolais helped to shape the heart and history of dance at Henry Street Settlement. Twenty-five outstanding dancers, choreographers, critics, and friends of all ages and traditions will share their stories of Murray through their own unique styles of dance. Conceived and directed by Tina Croll and Jamie Cunningham.

                                   

 Murray Louis was born on November 4, 1926 in Brooklyn, New York. He is known as one of the most influential American modern dancers and choreographers. He grew up in Manhattan near Henry Street where he would later attend class at the Henry Street Playhouse and also start his company. He was one out of five children and his mother died when he was eight years old. He was then sent to an orphanage until he was twelve. He graduated from Samuel Tildon High School in 1944.

Louis was discharged from the Navy in 1946 and began to live in San Francisco, California. He then enrolled at Colorado College for a summer session conducted by Hanya Holm in 1949. It was there during one of their workshops where he met Alwin Nikolais, who would later become his mentor and lifelong partner. That year he moved back to New York to pursue a Dramatic Arts degree at New York University and attend class with Nikolais at Henry Street Playhouse. Louis made his debut as the lead soloist in Nikolais’ newly formed Playhouse Dance Company (which would late be renamed the Nikolais Dance Theater)

                                             

Louis was chosen as Associate Director to Nikolais and together they created the Nikolais/Louis dance technique, which would become a major influence on modern dance and is still taught by his students. Louis founded his own company in 1968 known as the Murray Louis Dance Company. His company was then chosen to represent the U.S. State Department on a two-month tour of India in 1968. In 1972 he piloted the “Artist in School” program. He also created two works for Rudolph Nureyev to debut on Broadway in 1978. Louis additionally worked in television in the United States and Europe. In 1984 the Murray Louis Dance Company collaborated with the Dave Brubeck Quartet and had four very successful seasons, which were broadcast in the United States, Europe, and Japan. Some of his choreographed works include Pulcinello for Batsheva Dance Company for Israeli television and The Tales of Cri-Cri for Mexico City television. In July 1987 PBS televised Nik and Murray, an award winning documentary film by Christian Blackwood, in their American Masters series. The Princeton Book Publishing Company released a video called Murray Louis in Concert, a collection of solos in 1989.

Louis also had his collection of essays, Inside Dance, published by St. Martin’s Press and released a five-part film series, Dance as an Art Form, which is now used as an introduction series for Educational Arts programs in the United States.[4] A Cappella Books published his second book of essays, On Dance. Louis’s and Nikolais’ dance companies merged in 1989.[5] On May 8, 1993 Louis’s most influential mentor and partner, Alwin Nikolais, died. Louis did not dance for 2 years after Nikolais’ death. In 1995 his company performed at Carnegie Hall for 10,000 children during their “LINK” program and in 1996 he completed a five-part video series titled, The World of Alwin Nikolais.

Work & Accomplishments

Louis had many accomplishments and received copious amounts of awards, recognitions, and honorary degrees. He received the Dance magazine award in 1977, which was presented to him by his former dance instructor Hanya Holm. He also received a Thank You letter from Harry Truman, the Colorado Contemporary Dance Award, two John Simon Guggenheim Fellowships, and the Scripps/American Dance Festival award (June 18, 2006). In 1998, he was selected as a Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Scholar for a “distinguished lecture” tour of twelve universities and colleges in the United States. Louis received his first Honorary Degree from Indiana University in 1970, his Honorary Doctorate of Performing Arts from Ohio University in 1999, his second Honorary Degree from Rutgers University in 2000, and his third Honorary Degree from Boston Conservatory in 2004. In 1998 Louis started assembling his archives and they are now available at the Ohio University’s Vernon R. Alden Library in Athens, Ohio.[6] He has created over 100 works (including 70 ballets), performed in 20 nations and every state of the United States, and has toured five continents. He is one of the few choreographers to dance in his own creations and a variety of composers have produced music for him and his performances. He has also choreographed to the music of Bach, Brahms, Schubert, Stravinsky, Tchaikovsky, and many others. Some of the companies he has choreographed dances for include: The Royal Danish Ballet, The Jose Limon Company, The Hamburg Opera Ballet, The Scottish Ballet, The Berlin Opera Ballet, and The Cleveland Ballet.

Louis speaking of his choreography once said, “I don’t have a style. I come out of dance itself. I operate the principles of dance the way I talk. I get a point of view. Each piece has its own identity. It’s what choreography is all about.”

Murray Louis continues to live and work in New York City, New York.


What We Need & What You Get 

We are seeking $5,000 to fund the production of From the Horse's Mouth, celebrating Murray Louis.  This includes fees to the Horse's mouth, production staff and additional expenses for the performance in May.  

  • Expenses include: Licensing fee, curator's fee, studio rental, promotion, archival video, Misc. performance costs.

DONATE

  • $10  Virtual Thank YOU on Facebook
  • $25  A Ticket to Horse's Mouth Celebration

  • $50  "Inside Dance" signed by Murray Louis

  • $100  Alwin Nikolais electronic dance music. 

  • $250  Murray Lous in concert DVD. 

  • $500 Antique Murray Louis Dance Company 

  • $1,000 Dinner with Murray Louis


Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate any gift you can give to The Nikolais/Louis Foundation for Dance, Inc.  Every little bit will help us celebrate the Life and Legacy of Murray Louis and Alwin Nikolais. 

Please help us by spreading the word about this campaign: share this link on Facebook, email your friends and family, tell everyone you know!

He is one of the few choreographers to dance in his own creations and a variety of composers have produced music for him and his performances. He has also choreographed to the music of Bach, Brahms, Schubert, Stravinsky, Tchaikovsky, and many others. Some of the companies he has choreographed dances for include: The Royal Danish Ballet, The Jose Limon Company, The Hamburg Opera Ballet, The Scottish Ballet, The Berlin Opera Ballet, and The Cleveland Ballet.
Louis speaking of his choreography once said, “I don’t have a style. I come out of dance itself. I operate the principles of dance the way I talk. I get a point of view. Each piece has its own identity. It’s what choreography is all about.”
Murray Louis continues to live and work in New York City, New York.

What We Need & What You Get 

We are seeking $5,000 to fund the production of From the Horse's Mouth, celebrating Murray Louis.  This includes fees to the Horse's mouth, production staff and additional expenses for the performance in May.  
Expenses include: Licensing fee, curator's fee, studio rental, promotion, archival video, Misc. performance costs.

DONATE


$10  Virtual Thank YOU on Facebook
$25  A Ticket to Horse's Mouth Celebration

$50  "Inside Dance" signed by Murray Louis



$100  Alwin Nikolais electronic dance music. 


$250  Murray Lous in concert DVD. 

$500 Antique Murray Louis Dance Company 

$1,000 Dinner with Murray Louis
    

    Other Ways You Can Help 
We appreciate any gift you can give to The Nikolais/Louis Foundation for Dance, Inc.  Every little bit will help us celebrate the Life and Legacy of Murray Louis and Alwin Nikolais. 
Please help us by spreading the word about this campaign: share this link on Facebook, email your friends and family, tell everyone you know!

story:
Fire On the Prairie!

It started last October in Springfield, Illinois.  Byron Civic Theatre won the State Theatre Competition in the American Association of Community Theatre's 2015 Festival Competition cycle with their production of RING OF FIRE - The Johnny Cash Musical.  Now it's on to the Regional Competition in Midland, Michigan.

The cost for registration, transportation, and lodging is $5,330.  Help us "Keep the Fire Burning!" as we travel to Michigan to bring the Regional title back to Illinois.

Help us Travel to Midland

There are many ways to help BCT make it to the Regional Festival.  Your donations will get us closer.  Each $25 donation moves us 30 miles closer to reaching the Festival.  

For your donation, contributors can receive a "Keep the Fire Burning!" t-shirt, a private performance by members of the cast, or dinner and a performance of RING OF FIRE for you and seven of your closest friends.  We may even be able to obtain a "special" venue for this event.

BCT's Impact

BCT is celebrating our 20th Season of Shows this year.  We'd like to show others at the Regional (and hopefully the National) level the kind of quality theatre that we provide locally.  

How Else Can You Help

In addition to making a contribution here at Indiegogo, you can attend our Special "Send Off Performance" on April 12 at the Byron Middle School Theatre.  For a minimum suggested donation of $10.00, you can see the performance of RING OF FIRE as it will be performed at the Regional Competition, participate in raffles and a Chinese Auction, and get a sneak preview of "THE GRAND OLE OPRY!  Through the Years."

story:
My name is Margaret Phyllis Johnson and I am a dancer, mover, maker and creator. I am currently a sophomore BFA candidate at Seattle’s Cornish College of the Arts where I have the privilege of learning ballet and modern technique as well as choreographic and somatic practices.

I am excited to have been accepted into the 2015 New York Gaga intensive – a globally renowned workshop designed by Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin, the artistic director of Batsheva Dance Company. We will be learning Ohad Naharin’s repertory and Gaga methodics. I have also enrolled at the Boulder Jazz Dance Workshop in Boulder, Colorado. Both of these intensives will help my technique, artistry, and kick-start my professional career; summer intensives not only augment dance education as a whole, but play a vital role in establishing much-needed connections with other artists – in the US and beyond.

I chose to be a dancer not just as a hobby but to make a career. The thought of making art through dance, teaching, and performing as a means to elicit social change has been a dream of mine since I can remember. Unfortunately, however, artists rarely get paid living wages despite their immense work and the inspiration they bring to others. That being said, I am currently a full-time student in the arts and I work two part-time jobs every chance I have… but plane fare and intensives are exorbitantly expensive; for this reason, I would greatly appreciate any help I can get to afford these endeavors!

The money, should you choose to donate, will go towards airplane tickets, the cost of the intensives themselves, and cost of living (food, laundry, etc.). Luckily I have a place to stay in both Colorado and New York, but the rest of the money is up to me to make!

I completely understand if you are unable to donate, but if you know any dance enthusiasts please pass the message along!

Thank you so much,

Margaret Johnson

story:
The Company

Hi there! We're The Barrington Collective- six American graduate students about to complete our MFA at East 15 Acting School in London. We graduate in July, but August will be an adventure of a different kind as we don some kilts and head to Scotland!
Why Scotland? 
It's the home of the world's largest theatre event- The Edinburgh Fringe Festival! Ed Fringe is a month-long arts extravaganza during which nearly 50,000 performances take place in Scotland's capital city.
And this year - we get to be a part of it. We've signed a contract to work with theSpace UK, one of Ed Fringe's largest and most respected venues, in a prime time slot on the Royal Mile.
The Barrington Collective is committed to giving voice to new and untold stories affecting the modern world. Theatre is a powerful tool for introspection, change, and joy and Ed Fringe is the perfect place to begin telling our stories. 

The Shows

TheSpace UK is excited to host both of our shows - Reconciling and PiTH - that will perform in repertoire for the full run of the festival (August 7th-31st).
Reconciling: What do a Baptist, a bro in handcuffs, & a botched funeral have in common? Not enough and more than you think. This dark comedy, written by company member Jenny King and directed by Julia Hinson, explores how three couples’ unique problems complement & crash into each other. Hearts opened and words spoken become recurring refrains through a collective unconscious where one word can have multiple meanings. And vodka…that always makes things interesting. Join the entire Barrington Collective, as they bring this fractal tree of a play to life. 
PiTH: This interactive one woman show, written and performed by company member Katie Morrill, follows Izzy, a plucky American adventurer from the 1800’s, as she navigates the joys and consequences of time travel. A woman apart, a ghost skimming across the fabric of time, Izzy finds herself in complete isolation unable to interact with anyone around her. Can she stop the swiftly increasing roller-coaster that is her life? What will happen if she doesn’t? Can you help her? Join Izzy in an honest and quirky exploration of modern humanity, technological isolation and the universe, micro to macro. Oh and did we mention there is whip cream, machetes and music?

The Budget

The numbers below represent theatre on a budget. As 6 American grad students living with a strong Pound/weak Dollar exchange rate for two years, we have honed our penny pinching skills and frugality is our motto. This project may be expensive, but the experience is essential. Here is a breakdown of our current budget:
Venue:                                         £2700    =    $4150
Accommodation:                     £3200   =    $4920
Travel:                                          £500     =    $770
Marketing & Registration:     £1600   =    $2460
Living Expenses:                       £2000  =    $3075
Props & Set:                               £500     =    $770
Total:                                    £10,500 = $16, 145

Our company members have student loans and part-time jobs, but no matter how hardworking or industrious we are, we can't get to Fringe without your help! If you do choose to donate, we've included some fun perks to say thank you and to help you follow us on our journey.


Why help?

The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the first step in what we plan to be a important journey for the Barrington Collective. It's difficult to gain momentum in the theatre world and producing our shows in Edinburgh is the best way to showcase our talents and share ideas with leading industry professionals. You're contributing to the first chapter of a promising book. In order to tell the rest of our stories, we need this foundation. 
When we began training at East 15, the 6 of us came from diverse backgrounds with no knowledge of each other. We are now knit together by our desire to explore and absorb as much as we can in this big, old world. Over the past two years we've worked on countless projects together and have grown to trust and respect each other as artists and people. 
After we finish our journey in the UK, together we will take our experiences back to influence future projects. The world is in crisis and, though often overlooked, theatre and performance are tried and tested methods of engendering introspection and change. The Barrington Collective intends to brings these things in force and leave behind joy in our wake. Our company wants to innovate and bravely forge ahead in our field and we are committed to being dynamic influences for good in our craft and society as a whole. 
We are confident that with your help we can create something truly special!

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you can't contribute monetarily at this time. That's ok- we'll still like you! Here are some other ways you can help:

*We're all over social media and would love for you to like, comment, share, subscribe, retweet, and retumble to help us get the word out!

Facebook:  facebook.com/BarringtonCollective
Twitter:       twitter.com/BarringtonCoUK
Instagram: instagram.com/BarringtonCollective
Tumblr:       barringtoncollective.tumblr.com
Website:      barringtoncollective.com

*Are you crafty? Do you own your own business? Perhaps you have a reward you'd like to donate to our campaign! We'll gladly find your perk a home.

*Do you know of any other funding opportunities for us- grants, fundraisers or the like? We'd love any extra help in this area.

*Will you be at Ed Fringe this summer? We'd always appreciate volunteers to help with flyering, word of mouth, and technical support.

If you can help in any of the ways above, shoot us an email at barringtoncollective@gmail.com and let us know!


Thank you!

"I believe if you have been successful at what you dreamed of doing with your life, then it is your obligation to spend a good portion of your time sending the elevator back down...All of us can send the elevator back down because it doesn't matter what floor you're on; in life there is always someone below, just waiting for the chance to be invited up. Our job is to make sure the floors we live on are not so high we no longer hear the voices of young people crying out for opportunity and experience that will help shape a better future." -Kevin Spacey
Thanks in advance for sending the elevator back down.
-The Barrington Collective

story:
Seoul Shakespeare Company, founded in 2010, is an all-volunteer theatre company, and Seoul’s only English-language Shakespeare company.  We are preparing our fifth mainstage production, Titus Andronicus, which is our most ambitious project to date.  With this campaign, we are mobilizing our community of friends, family, and supporters across the globe to back our project and help us pay for our theatre space and set, so that we can put on our beautiful version of this play, and so that this production can be the beginning of a higher profile for the company.  

What is Titus Andronicus, and why is it relevant today?

Titus Andronicus is a brutal but beautifully poignant play about the heads of two opposing families--the Roman general Titus, and the Queen of the Goths, Tamora--who each choose the path of revenge over mercy and are ultimately destroyed by that choice. Metamorphosis is a major theme in this play, and many of the characters undergo major transformations, physical or otherwise, but the most central transformation is that of the character of Titus, from a dispassionate follower of rules, authority, and ritual, to a feeling, hurting, passionate human being, who is capable of emotion-filled acts of violence.  

This is a provocative play about the themes of violence (including sexual violence), revenge, racism, and the concepts of barbarity versus civilization.  While these deep themes are sometimes overlooked in favor of an emphasis on the gore and grotesqueness of the play, they point to the play's--and Shakespeare's--underlying sense of humanity. 

Although Titus Andronicus was quite popular among Elizabethan audiences, it was maligned for centuries as too violent to be either respectable or believable.  However, during the latter half of the twentieth century, and particularly since the beginning of the twenty-first century, the play has undergone a resurgence in popularity, possibly because the violence depicted in the play no longer seems unbelievable.  Although we live in a time that is actually less violent than in the past, we have unprecedented access to images of extreme violence, depicted in television shows like Game of Thrones, and in real–world events.  

This year in particular seems an appropriate year for this play, with its attention to the issues of rape, extreme violence, and racism.  Just under a year ago, the Isla Vista shooter expressed sentiments of hatred, desire for chaos, and racial otherness that bear similarity to those of the character Aaron, as well as simultaneous woman-desiring and woman-hating feelings similar to those of Tamora’s sons, Chiron and Demetrius, toward Titus’s daughter, Lavinia.  Furthermore, anyone with Youtube access is able to witness the extreme violence and deliberate cruelty of ISIS.  Finally, the theme of racism in Titus is shockingly relevant this year.  Despite being one of Shakespeare's earliest plays, Titus Andronicus can feel surprisingly modern.

Whereas violence in television and film is often more graphic than violence depicted on stage, live theatre has a unique ability to jar us from a sense of complacency towards it.  In the theatre, audience members share not only a physical space with actors, but also a powerful experience together in real time.  That is part of the magic of theatre and part of the value of this particular play.  

Our wonderful director Ray Salcedo, who brought us A Midsummer Night's Dream last year, is emphasizing the humanity of this play and combining aesthetic elements that are distinctly ancient and classical with those that are edgy and modern, highlighting the distinct Roman setting of the play while giving a nod to the timelessness of its themes. 

We’re bringing this play to a mixed English-speaking and Korean-speaking audience, and the play will be performed in English with Korean surtitles.

What are you all doing in Korea?

South Korea can be a wonderful place to be an artist.  Many of the people in our company at least originally came to Korea to teach English, or music, or theatre, etc., and these kinds of jobs allow them to support themselves while having time to pursue artistic activities.  However, for that to happen, we need artistic organizations like Seoul Shakespeare Company to provide these kinds of opportunities.  Various English-speaking theatre companies have come and gone in the last few years here because the expat community is so transient.  Right now the Seoul theatre community is down to just two theatre companies, Seoul Players and Seoul Shakespeare Company, which means that what we do in this company has become even more vitally important to our theatre community.

Why is Seoul Shakespeare Company important?

Seoul Shakespeare Company serves three different groups of people, making Shakespeare widely accessible to audiences and artists alike.  

First, we’re a unique resource for Korean audiences, though largely unknown and untapped at this point.  Shakespeare is widely taught in Korea, and widely performed in Korean translation, but we are the only theatre company in Seoul that performs Shakespeare in its original language, which is a very different experience from a performance in translation.  

Secondly, Seoul has a large English-speaking expat population, many of whom would like to see theatre regularly but have few chances to see live theatre performed in English, aside from big touring shows.  For them, we’re an important part of the local artistic community.  

The third group of people that we serve are the people directly involved in the production.  There are a lot of English-speaking theatre artists living in Seoul who are looking for opportunities to use and develop their talents.  A number of our past company members have gone on to pursue a career in the theatre, and one of our goals is to nurture the talent we have here in Seoul so that they can pursue a future theatre career.    

Some of our actors actually work professionally as actors in Korea doing roles in Korean dramas and films, and also in the expat indie film scene.  Our company gives those actors a chance to explore classical material and to experience some of the greatest plays and roles ever written.  These are the kinds of roles that shape great actors, and we’re the only company here that gives English-speaking actors the opportunity to play those roles.  

For this production, we also have a wonderful voice and text coach, Amy Mihyang Ginther, who has been giving our actors additional training as well.  

Aside from our mainstage productions, we also offer educational workshops and small performances throughout the year to bring Shakespeare to more intimate local audiences.

What is special about this year’s production, and where is the money going?

With this production, we are trying to attract larger general audiences and to become more widely recognized as a resource for Shakespeare in Korea.  We’ve therefore increased our production values this year, particularly with our set. In the past, our sets have been pretty minimalistic, but this play is written for a stage that has at least two levels.  We have a wonderful set designer who specializes in carpentry, but we need to be able to afford the materials to realize his design.  Reaching our funding goal will allow us to realize the beautiful set that he has designed for us, which will help our company and also help further his career in set design. 

We’re still keeping our production costs very reasonable, but there is no getting around the cost of renting a theatre space in Seoul.  The cost of everything else is completely overshadowed by the cost of our theatre.  That is really why we need this Indiegogo campaign.  The amount we are raising is about half of the total cost to rent our theatre, and it’s just something that we cannot get around or penny-pinch our way out of.  We are asking for your support to help us pay for our theatre space and bring this production to life.

What is the long-term impact of this campaign?

When this company first started in 2010, it was a small group of people performing Shakespeare in places like bars, with machines behind the bar making loud noises--that kind of thing.  One of the goals that Lindsey Higgins, our previous artistic director, had for the company was to produce Shakespeare’s works in actual theatre spaces, beginning with our production of Macbeth in 2011. 

In Seoul, however, theatres are very expensive.  The fundraising events that we typically hold throughout the year are usually enough to pay for props, costumes, printing, and rehearsal space, but paying for the theatre space has always been impossible without company members using their own resources.  We are trying to make this production the last one under this model, shifting our revenue toward ticket sales instead.  This year, with an eye toward long-term development, we are changing our budgeting approach by increasing the number of performances and trying to earn enough money from ticket sales this year for our next production’s theatre rental.  This means that this is our crunch year: we started the year with very little, and our budget this year is higher than in the past in order to have enough performances (and to sell enough tickets) to start a sustainable financial cycle of ticket sales.  This is why we need your support, but also why your support for this show will have an ongoing long-term impact.

Thank you!

Thank you so much for your support in helping us make this production happen, and helping us take a major step in our company’s development.  For those of you not in Korea, we’ll be sure to have a video of the production available so that you can see the work you have helped bring to life. Thank you!


Other ways you can help

Aside from backing our show directly, sharing this campaign on social media is one of the best ways you can help!  

If you have a Korean bank account, you can also contribute via bank transfer.  Your contribution won't show up in our Indiegogo total, but we can still send you the perks listed above.  Send us an email to let us know that you've contributed, and we can add you to our list of donors.  Here is a link to our bank information: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/contribu...    

You can also purchase Seoul Shakespeare Company products from our Cafepress store:  http://www.cafepress.com/seoulshakespearecompanystore.  (We receive 20% of sales.)  

Finally, we have lots of videos on our Youtube page that are currently monetized with ads.  Want to help us without spending any money?  Browse our videos and share any you like.  The amount we receive per view is very small, but every little bit helps!  We have two Youtube channels: 

www.youtube.com/channel/UCIkl2wZH1PiMmNQwdiW_r7Q/playlists?flow=grid&view=1&sort=lad (Our archive of performances; all are monetized.)

and https://www.youtube.com/user/lindseyjade223 (Only 2 videos are monetized, but check out the channel anyway!)


Performance Information

SSC presents Titus Andronicus May 30-June 14, 2015, at Theater Egg and Nucleus (알과핵 소극장) in Seoul's theatre district, Daehangno/Hyehwa.   

For more information, please visit our website: www.seoulshakespearecompany.org 

And find us on Facebook here:

https://www.facebook.com/seoulshakespeare?fref=ts


Director: Ray Salcedo
Stage Manager: Hee Sunwoo
Artistic Director/Producer: Lauren Ash-Morgan

Voice/Text Coach: Amy Mihyang Ginther

Assistant Stage Managers: Lindsay Bellinger, Laura Jasi, Sung Ho Seo

Sound Designer: Brian MacQueen

Set Designer: David Spadaccini

Lighting Designer: Iain Culp

Fight Choreographer: Patrick Foley

Costume Design/Construction: Lauren Ash-Morgan

English Publicity: Katie Lloyd

Makeup Designer: Jungsoo Lee

Graphic Designer: Charles Joongwon Jeong

Photography: Jorge Toro, My Seoul Photography

Indiegogo Videos: Lauren Ash-Morgan

Cast:

TITUS: Michael Downey
MARCUS: Miles Meili
TAMORA: Lauren Ash-Morgan
LAVINIA: Heather Moore

story_txt:
Seoul Shakespeare Company, founded in 2010, is an all-volunteer theatre company, and Seoul’s only English-language Shakespeare company.  We are preparing our fifth mainstage production, Titus Andronicus, which is our most ambitious project to date.  With this campaign, we are mobilizing our community of friends, family, and supporters across the globe to back our project and help us pay for our theatre space and set, so that we can put on our beautiful version of this play, and so that this production can be the beginning of a higher profile for the company.  


What is Titus Andronicus, and why is it relevant today?
Titus Andronicus is a brutal but beautifully poignant play about the heads of two opposing families--the Roman general Titus, and the Queen of the Goths, Tamora--who each choose the path of revenge over mercy and are ultimately destroyed by that choice. Metamorphosis is a major theme in this play, and many of the characters undergo major transformations, physical or otherwise, but the most central transformation is that of the character of Titus, from a dispassionate follower of rules, authority, and ritual, to a feeling, hurting, passionate human being, who is capable of emotion-filled acts of violence.  
This is a provocative play about the themes of violence (including sexual violence), revenge, racism, and the concepts of barbarity versus civilization.  While these deep themes are sometimes overlooked in favor of an emphasis on the gore and grotesqueness of the play, they point to the play's--and Shakespeare's--underlying sense of humanity. Although Titus Andronicus was quite popular among Elizabethan audiences, it was maligned for centuries as too violent to be either respectable or believable.  However, during the latter half of the twentieth century, and particularly since the beginning of the twenty-first century, the play has undergone a resurgence in popularity, possibly because the violence depicted in the play no longer seems unbelievable.  Although we live in a time that is actually less violent than in the past, we have unprecedented access to images of extreme violence, depicted in television shows like Game of Thrones, and in real–world events.  This year in particular seems an appropriate year for this play, with its attention to the issues of rape, extreme violence, and racism.  Just under a year ago, the Isla Vista shooter expressed sentiments of hatred, desire for chaos, and racial otherness that bear similarity to those of the character Aaron, as well as simultaneous woman-desiring and woman-hating feelings similar to those of Tamora’s sons, Chiron and Demetrius, toward Titus’s daughter, Lavinia.  Furthermore, anyone with Youtube access is able to witness the extreme violence and deliberate cruelty of ISIS.  Finally, the theme of racism in Titus is shockingly relevant this year.  Despite being one of Shakespeare's earliest plays, Titus Andronicus can feel surprisingly modern.
Whereas violence in television and film is often more graphic than violence depicted on stage, live theatre has a unique ability to jar us from a sense of complacency towards it.  In the theatre, audience members share not only a physical space with actors, but also a powerful experience together in real time.  That is part of the magic of theatre and part of the value of this particular play.  Our wonderful director Ray Salcedo, who brought us A Midsummer Night's Dream last year, is emphasizing the humanity of this play and combining aesthetic elements that are distinctly ancient and classical with those that are edgy and modern, highlighting the distinct Roman setting of the play while giving a nod to the timelessness of its themes. 


We’re bringing this play to a mixed English-speaking and Korean-speaking audience, and the play will be performed in English with Korean surtitles.


What are you all doing in Korea?
South Korea can be a wonderful place to be an artist.  Many of the people in our company at least originally came to Korea to teach English, or music, or theatre, etc., and these kinds of jobs allow them to support themselves while having time to pursue artistic activities.  However, for that to happen, we need artistic organizations like Seoul Shakespeare Company to provide these kinds of opportunities.  Various English-speaking theatre companies have come and gone in the last few years here because the expat community is so transient.  Right now the Seoul theatre community is down to just two theatre companies, Seoul Players and Seoul Shakespeare Company, which means that what we do in this company has become even more vitally important to our theatre community.

Why is Seoul Shakespeare Company important?
Seoul Shakespeare Company serves three different groups of people, making Shakespeare widely accessible to audiences and artists alike.  First, we’re a unique resource for Korean audiences, though largely unknown and untapped at this point.  Shakespeare is widely taught in Korea, and widely performed in Korean translation, but we are the only theatre company in Seoul that performs Shakespeare in its original language, which is a very different experience from a performance in translation.  
Secondly, Seoul has a large English-speaking expat population, many of whom would like to see theatre regularly but have few chances to see live theatre performed in English, aside from big touring shows.  For them, we’re an important part of the local artistic community.  The third group of people that we serve are the people directly involved in the production.  There are a lot of English-speaking theatre artists living in Seoul who are looking for opportunities to use and develop their talents.  A number of our past company members have gone on to pursue a career in the theatre, and one of our goals is to nurture the talent we have here in Seoul so that they can pursue a future theatre career.    
Some of our actors actually work professionally as actors in Korea doing roles in Korean dramas and films, and also in the expat indie film scene.  Our company gives those actors a chance to explore classical material and to experience some of the greatest plays and roles ever written.  These are the kinds of roles that shape great actors, and we’re the only company here that gives English-speaking actors the opportunity to play those roles.  For this production, we also have a wonderful voice and text coach, Amy Mihyang Ginther, who has been giving our actors additional training as well.  
Aside from our mainstage productions, we also offer educational workshops and small performances throughout the year to bring Shakespeare to more intimate local audiences.

What is special about this year’s production, and where is the money going?
With this production, we are trying to attract larger general audiences and to become more widely recognized as a resource for Shakespeare in Korea.  We’ve therefore increased our production values this year, particularly with our set. In the past, our sets have been pretty minimalistic, but this play is written for a stage that has at least two levels.  We have a wonderful set designer who specializes in carpentry, but we need to be able to afford the materials to realize his design.  Reaching our funding goal will allow us to realize the beautiful set that he has designed for us, which will help our company and also help further his career in set design. 
We’re still keeping our production costs very reasonable, but there is no getting around the cost of renting a theatre space in Seoul.  The cost of everything else is completely overshadowed by the cost of our theatre.  That is really why we need this Indiegogo campaign.  The amount we are raising is about half of the total cost to rent our theatre, and it’s just something that we cannot get around or penny-pinch our way out of.  We are asking for your support to help us pay for our theatre space and bring this production to life.


What is the long-term impact of this campaign?
When this company first started in 2010, it was a small group of people performing Shakespeare in places like bars, with machines behind the bar making loud noises--that kind of thing.  One of the goals that Lindsey Higgins, our previous artistic director, had for the company was to produce Shakespeare’s works in actual theatre spaces, beginning with our production of Macbeth in 2011. 
In Seoul, however, theatres are very expensive.  The fundraising events that we typically hold throughout the year are usually enough to pay for props, costumes, printing, and rehearsal space, but paying for the theatre space has always been impossible without company members using their own resources.  We are trying to make this production the last one under this model, shifting our revenue toward ticket sales instead.  This year, with an eye toward long-term development, we are changing our budgeting approach by increasing the number of performances and trying to earn enough money from ticket sales this year for our next production’s theatre rental.  This means that this is our crunch year: we started the year with very little, and our budget this year is higher than in the past in order to have enough performances (and to sell enough tickets) to start a sustainable financial cycle of ticket sales.  This is why we need your support, but also why your support for this show will have an ongoing long-term impact.Thank you!Thank you so much for your support in helping us make this production happen, and helping us take a major step in our company’s development.  For those of you not in Korea, we’ll be sure to have a video of the production available so that you can see the work you have helped bring to life. Thank you!Other ways you can helpAside from backing our show directly, sharing this campaign on social media is one of the best ways you can help!  If you have a Korean bank account, you can also contribute via bank transfer.  Your contribution won't show up in our Indiegogo total, but we can still send you the perks listed above.  Send us an email to let us know that you've contributed, and we can add you to our list of donors.  Here is a link to our bank information: http://www.seoulshakespearecompany.org/contribu...    You can also purchase Seoul Shakespeare Company products from our Cafepress store:  http://www.cafepress.com/seoulshakespearecompanystore.  (We receive 20% of sales.)  Finally, we have lots of videos on our Youtube page that are currently monetized with ads.  Want to help us without spending any money?  Browse our videos and share any you like.  The amount we receive per view is very small, but every little bit helps!  We have two Youtube channels: www.youtube.com/channel/UCIkl2wZH1PiMmNQwdiW_r7Q/playlists?flow=grid&view=1&sort=lad (Our archive of performances; all are monetized.)and https://www.youtube.com/user/lindseyjade223 (Only 2 videos are monetized, but check out the channel anyway!)Performance InformationSSC presents Titus Andronicus May 30-June 14, 2015, at Theater Egg and Nucleus (알과핵 소극장) in Seoul's theatre district, Daehangno/Hyehwa.   For more information, please visit our website: www.seoulshakespearecompany.org And find us on Facebook here:https://www.facebook.com/seoulshakespeare?fref=tsDirector: Ray SalcedoStage Manager: Hee SunwooArtistic Director/Producer: Lauren Ash-Morgan
Voice/Text Coach: Amy Mihyang Ginther
Assistant Stage Managers: Lindsay Bellinger, Laura Jasi, Sung Ho Seo
Sound Designer: Brian MacQueen
Set Designer: David Spadaccini
Lighting Designer: Iain Culp
Fight Choreographer: Patrick Foley
Costume Design/Construction: Lauren Ash-Morgan
English Publicity: Katie Lloyd
Makeup Designer: Jungsoo Lee
Graphic Designer: Charles Joongwon Jeong
Photography: Jorge Toro, My Seoul Photography
Indiegogo Videos: Lauren Ash-Morgan

TITUS: Michael DowneyMARCUS: Miles MeiliTAMORA: Lauren Ash-MorganLAVINIA: Heather MooreAARON: Kahlid Elijah TapiaSATURNINUS: Jamie HoranLUCIUS: Za’chary WestbrookBASSIANUS/PUBLIUS: Brian PetersenDEMETRIUS: Alex SawyerCHIRON: Charles Joongwon JeongYOUNG LUCIUS/MUTIUS: Joseph Van DornALARBUS/EXECUTIONER: Robert Evans                                                     QUINTUS/GOTH 1: Simon Clarke                                                                     MARTIUS/GOTH 2: Michael PerezNURSE/CLOWN: Sarah McRobertsAEMILIUS: Edward Burgos

story:
Here at Verb, we have a special place in our hearts for those coping with Alzheimer’s Disease or related dementia as well as for their caregivers. This year we want to give something back to those individuals and families through our new pilot program, VIA: Verb’s Improv for Alzheimer’s.

The VIA Program was founded based on two truths:

1.  Coping with Alzheime'rs can be deeply isolating and lonely for both those diagnosed with Alzheimer's and their families, but opportunities to socialize and build community with others going through similar experiences can drastically improve spirits for all involved.

2.  For those diagnosed with Alzheimer’s, the opportunity to experience live performance as either spectator or participant often disappears. Improvisation, however, is an ideal artistic form for those suffering with Alzheimer’s Disease. Each scene can be short, fun, and requires no rehearsal.  It’s a perfect creative outlet for loved ones who live in the moment, though their memories may have escaped them.  Live performance provides a sense of inclusion, community, and joy for both audiences and participants.

With these two truths in mind, V.I.A. will offer free improvisational theatre classes to Calgarians living with Alzheimer’s and their family caregivers.  Led by Calgary-based improviser Karen Johnson-Diamond and Verb Theatre Co-Artistic Director Col Cseke, these classes will aim to bring some much needed and joyful escape to families and individuals going through an emotionally and financially challenging time at no cost to participants.

This is a brand new program, and we need to ensure that we are approaching our new collaborators in the Alzheimer's community with respect, care, and preparation. Your donations will support this development as well as the delivery of the VIA pilot program. This up-front investment will allow us to continue offering the program to Calgary families, at no-cost to them, for years and years to come.

The V.I.A. program is partly funded by The Calgary Foundation. Any funds raised above and beyond our initial goal will be put towards V.I.A. offerings in the fall of 2015, all proceeds will stay in the program and will go directly to offering this program at no cost to participants.

All donors will also be issued a tax receipt for the value of the donation minus the value of the donor reward level.

story:
Don't Hate. Donate:

This is the official The Francesco Show Tour. We are taking  on the US starting with the east coast. Your assistance will help with touring costs and helping me to survive personally while I'm touring and making money to support myself or my family. We will be able to introduce parts of the east coast (NY, PA, CT, NJ, MA, VA, FL, etc. )  to what and who Francesco is. This will eventually grow into a national tour, and soon enough international. The reel shows it all. A writer, actor, comic, with the desire to host his own late night show. Let's build fans while promoting his upcoming live album coming March 2015. This tour will serve as a promotional tool as well as growing the ongoing following which we call the "fancescos". Give what you can, but give. Support our artists even when they are comics! Love you.

story:
Short Summary

Hello! I'm Jaybird Stone, a teenager in Colorado. I have a lot of ambitious dreams, but this is one that I want to come true. I want to direct a stage version of Hedwig and the Angry Inch! Sadly, I'm a jobless 15 year old girl with a lot of time on her hands. I'd like to raise $2,500 to cover the basics, including advertising, costumes, and props. I would appreciate anything you can donate, even just a dollar can help make my dream come true!

What We Need 

We'd like to be able to get the costumes and props necessary to make this play effective, which could cost plenty, due to the price of fabric. We also need to pay for Performance rights and Scripts, and advertising as well. 

The Impact

I've always been a big fan of show business, especially theater. The first musical I was ever introduced to was The Rocky Horror Picture Show. I was 9. I instantly fell in love with musicals: Little Shop of Horrors, Wicked, Rent, Carrie the Musical, and so many more. Growing up in a musically influenced household was also a big part of my love for musicals. Songs that could tell stories kept me motivated. The first time I watched Hedwig, I was hed (pun intended) over heels. Everyone could connect with a misfit, because we've all felt the need to belong, deep within ourselves. I figure that, with how accepting and liberal our generation is, this production could touch the hearts of so many, maybe even help them accept themselves. 

Risks & Challenges

There are quite a few risks I'm taking with this production. One is that I have pretty much no idea how to direct anything, let alone a full musical. I also happen to be a 15 year old girl with no experience in theater outside of school musicals. However, I believe that I can pull it off, especially with the amount of people I already have supporting me. I just need the extra shove to make my dream come true!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, don't worry! But, could you please share this? Tell your friends, your enemies, your parents, your teachers, the police, a stray cat, and people in Argentina! Even a dollar can help me reach my goal in no time!

story:
Join us and support this exciting new revival of Ted Whitehead's Alpha Beta at the Finborough Theatre this summer.

"You know... when a structure has lost its essence but retained its shape, the geologists call it: a Pseudomorph. A false shape. That’s our marriage..."

ALPHA BETA was first performed in 1972, and has rarely been seen since. It's about the disintegration of a young couple's marriage over a period of nine years, and the innumerable ways in which two people can make each other's lives miserable if they really want to.

Do we really have to arrange our lives to fit in with social conventions? Or is that some kind of punishment we've devised for ourselves.

Purni Morell's bold and unflinching new staging of this powerful, yet neglected, play will challenge and astonish audiences with its honest look at how people treat each other when we're not looking.

WHO IS ON BOARD?

We have raised £9000 from Arts Council England.

The creative team is Purni Morell (director), Verity Quinn (designer), Phil Bentley (lighting designer) and a cast to be announced shortly.

ALPHA BETA is supported by fieldwork; a collective of theatre-makers based in London who share similar values in their approach to seeking out new form and representing the rich diversity of 21st century Britain on stage.

WHY SUPPORT US

  • This is the first time this once ground-breaking play has been produced since the 1970s
  • Whether you  were in your late twenties then or are in your late twenties now, this play asks timeless questions about relationships and why we make the choices we make
  • We'll be taking the Finborough Theatre back to its orignial use as a domestic space, with natural light, and removing the barrier of a stage - underlining that these events could be happening in any sitting room, anywhere in the city, right now.
  • This will also mean an exciting new dynamic between audience and performers.
  • We'll be holding events and discussions encouraging other artists to discuss their work, take risks and try new things
  • One of our motivations is the woeful lack of social and ethnic diversity in the arts in London; we believe that any piece of theatre made in London in the twenty-first century should reflect the people living in this city, and we'll show by example that this is easy this is to achieve if chosen as a priority.
  • It will encourage other artists to take risks and try new things
ALL THE MONEY YOU GIVE WILL GO DIRECTLY TO SUPPORTING THE ARTISTS AND THE DESIGN, AND TO OFFER OPPORTUNITIES TO TWO APPRENTICES, GIVING THEM THEIR FIRST THEATRE JOB

story:
Short Summary

Many thanks to everyone who contributed to our first campaign. Since our first run of Branson The Sitcom was such a success with overflow audiences every night, we want to continue bringing you clean, funny situation comedy. This year we're going to perform in the biggest live theater festival in LA, the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival. We need money to pay the cost of the theater rental and buy some lighting, sound and video equipment for future runs of Branson and other shows we have in development.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds are needed to pay our entry fee into the Hollywood Fringe Festival, LA's biggest performing arts event and we need to rent the theater for 4 nights.  We offer several perks ranging from tickets to the live performance and DVD's of our shows to caps and T-shirts.

The Impact

You can help us create the next "All In the Family," "Big Bang Theory" or the next *M*A*S*H." Your contributions will help the next generation of comedic actors gain valuable exposure to casting directors and agents in the entertainment industry.

Risks & Challenges

Actors in Hollywood are often victimized by people wanting them to do things for free with little in return. Projects are often used to make profits at the expense of hard-working artists and crew members. We want to change that.  We want to give our actors and crew the best opportunity to display their talents to decision-makers in Hollywood.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have any unused Amazon gift cards you wish to donate, we have a wish list on Amazon.  It contains a list of equipment that we badly need to keep improving on the quality of our shows. http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/7FEM...
story_txt:
Short Summary
Many thanks to everyone who contributed to our first campaign. Since our first run of Branson The Sitcom was such a success with overflow audiences every night, we want to continue bringing you clean, funny situation comedy. This year we're going to perform in the biggest live theater festival in LA, the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival. We need money to pay the cost of the theater rental and buy some lighting, sound and video equipment for future runs of Branson and other shows we have in development.
  What We Need & What You GetThe funds are needed to pay our entry fee into the Hollywood Fringe Festival, LA's biggest performing arts event and we need to rent the theater for 4 nights.  We offer several perks ranging from tickets to the live performance and DVD's of our shows to caps and T-shirts.
  The ImpactYou can help us create the next "All In the Family," "Big Bang Theory" or the next *M*A*S*H." Your contributions will help the next generation of comedic actors gain valuable exposure to casting directors and agents in the entertainment industry.
  Risks & ChallengesActors in Hollywood are often victimized by people wanting them to do things for free with little in return. Projects are often used to make profits at the expense of hard-working artists and crew members. We want to change that.  We want to give our actors and crew the best opportunity to display their talents to decision-makers in Hollywood.
  Other Ways You Can HelpIf you have any unused Amazon gift cards you wish to donate, we have a wish list on Amazon.  It contains a list of equipment that we badly need to keep improving on the quality of our shows. http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/7FEM...

story:
Guys. Guys. I have an idea.

Every year on Puerto Rican day, I notoriously air my frustrations with the ensuing celebrations. We are a rich and complicated culture, and I've always felt that gets lost in the madness surrounding the parade, parties, and the like.
This year, instead of complaining, I figured: why talk the talk? I should DO something. So I came up with the following.
A poetry slam featuring some of the most talented Puerto Rican poets I know, along with featured music from some friends of Caribbean heritage and origin, and- get this- a live salsa band. It's going to be legit, guys.

Here's what we need.

Right now, the funds we need go directly to renting out the Nuyorican Poets Cafe (I know, right?!) for the night of June 14th, and to pay the band I feel best fits the entire feel of the event. I would also like to stipend all featured performers. Tiny stipends, but stipends nonetheless. At it's most basic, the primary needs are for the space and the band if not all funds are met, but let's try!

The Impact

Afro-Latino and Caribbean culture gets lost in the sauce sometimes; this is a chance to feature some of the most talented people I know who fall into that category. It's also a chance for us to take back our day and celebrate it our way!

The Challenges

I think, as of right now, our biggest challenge is exposure. Most of us are relatively unknown, and I would like to see this event be as full as possible! We have a lot of really wonderful art to contribute.

Other Ways You Can Help

I'm the first person who understands not being able to contribute; times is hard, folks. But if you're interested in teching, making a poster for the event, helping set up, anything- just let me know!

story:
Summary

Corpus Quixote presents Anton Chekhov's underproduced masterpiece Ivanov in the Studios at Fourteen G from May 28th to June 7th. This is our first independent production in the Hartford area, and we are delighted and excited to bring our talents to the Hartford audience.

Ivanov will star Andrew Patrick Mazer in the titular role, as well as Hyten Davidson and Miranda Morgan Scott as Sasha Lebedev and Anna Petrovna respectively. Andrew, Hyten and Miranda are all alumni of the Hartt School BFA Acting program. The production will be directed by Paul Willis, Jr, in his third independent directing project, and he is also a former student of the Hartt School's BFA Acting program.

This campaign is solely for the collection of our production budget. We are looking to raise $5,000, which is detailed in our Costs and You section below. Our contributors will be helping to open the foundation production of what will become a professional theatre company, looking to produce a full season of plays within the next few years.

Perks of Being a Supporter

We are excited to offer a series of awesome perks to our donors. You can see them listed on the side panel as well, but here they are in some detail.

For all of our donors, we offer you a personalized email of thanks for your contribution, which will be instrumental in allowing us the opportunity to see out our dreams. For those who donate over $10, a personal hand-written note will be mailed to your address signed by the director and producers.

To those of you who are feeling extra-generous, our perks get more exciting from here. At $20, you will receive a picture from the cast at our first read through holding up a sign with your name written on it, and their smiling faces showing our appreciation for your donation.

For a contribution of $50, you receive not only a photo with the entire cast and your name, but a poster signed by the cast mailed out with your handwritten thank you, which you can also opt to pick up on the night you attend.

If you contribute $75 or more, along with your poster, note, and picture, you will receive two tickets to any performance, and a copy of Ivanov signed by the entire cast.

At the $100 contribution mark, instead of simply a signed copy of the script, you will receive a copy of Ivanov with all of director Paul Willis's personal notes from rehearsal: including blocking schematics, acting notes, production ideas, and more. You will also receive an invitation to a private cocktail hour hosted by the production staff for all donors at or above the $100 line. 

For the extremely generous donors who support by donating $250 or more, we will list you in our program specially as a Founding Producer, and you will be invited to submit to us a portrait of yourself for dedicated display in the program. You will also receive, as with all other levels, any perks of lower amounts.

With our humble shock, if you provide us with $500 of your own money to produce our show, you will receive not only your signed director's-edition copy of Ivanov, a signed poster, your name and face in the program, four tickets to any show, a photo of the cast holding up a sign of your name, and a handwritten note of gratitude, but you will also be given a DVD of our final dress rehearsal, which will be conducted as a performance and filmed professionally. We could not express our gratitude any more grandly than this.

Though it seems impossible for us to imagine, should any of you decide to donate $1,000 or more, you will receive everything listed above, but more incredibly, we will sell out any performance of your choosing to be shared privately by you and any 50 friends you wish you bring along. We promise you a performance of human lightning onstage and an unforgettable night, as we will never forget you nor your humbling generosity.

Costs and You

As stated above, we are looking for a production budget of $5,000. This budget is designed to cover the comprehensive costs of our production--everything from marketing, to set and costumes, to props, to venue rental costs.

Here are the details:

Our largest expense so far is the rental of our space. We are renting out a studio space usually reserved for photography and videography projects. The space is giving us a wonderfully reduced price of $2,500 for the entire run of our show.

Our marketing costs are another large part of our budget. We are finishing up a cinematic trailer for the production which will cost us around $500 for camera rentals, prop rentals, and costuming. Also included in our marketing costs is our brilliant marketing designer, CM Dugan, who has designed many, many theatrical productions, who charged us a reduced price of $150. Finally, in terms of marketing, we need to produce our physical marketing materials (posters, postcards, business cards, etc.) which will run an estimated $500 all told.

Next, our set, props, and costume budget will be approximately $1000. We've done the math on the set, which will cost us around $300 for lumber, molding, and decoration. Costumes are difficult to estimate at this time, but we can't imagine a budget much higher than $500 all told, and a budget of $200 for props.

Other various costs have included the creation of our website, which has come to around $150 for hosting, building, and service.

Here is an itemized budget:

Property Rental: - $2,500

Marketing: - $1,150

Set: - $300

Costumes: - $500

Properties: - $200

Miscellaneous: - $150

Total: - $4,800

Our budget projection of $5,000 is designed to give us some cushion for unexpected costs, of which there are many in theatre.

The Importance of Ivanov

Chekhov was a hundred years ahead of his time. He is said to have written Ivanov in just ten days, before seeing it performed and almost completely rewriting the entire script claiming he couldn't recognize the words he wrote.

Ivanov beautifully paints the picture of a man, Nikolai Ivanov, who is struggling with what we would today call clinical depression. However, in Chekhov's day, depression was not a neurological illness, but rather it was considered a state of mind--one of weak constitution, and one that could be overcome through sheer power of will. Depression is progressively becoming more understood by modern medicine, but much remains unknown about it, and about most emotional disorders. 

Ivanov also seriously considers the situation of suicide. For hundreds of years, philosophers literary and otherwise have speculated and mused on the idea of self-sacrifice and martyrdom, and conversely the selfishness of taking your own life. While Chekhov does not take sides on the issue, he does brilliantly illustrate a fact echoed by data and research that suicide is most often attempted successfully by a culmination of emotional turmoil and a sudden, random event. Most suicides are not premeditated or pre-planned. With so many events of celebrity suicide in the news recently, we think that both themes of depression and suicide are important, not only philosophically, but personally in a country so deeply riddled by emotional disorders and misunderstanding.

Also, especially in the United States, the world has been experiencing a recent period of disillusionment with the rich by not only the poor, but also the middle class, and even members of the 1% themselves. In Chekhov's day, Russia was going through the decades leading up to the Bolshevik Revolution--an iconoclastic overthrow of the Russian Upper Class. In the same way, America went through an exacerbated period of unrest in the 1920's, which may have led to a revolution of its own if it hadn't been for the stock market crash and the Depression that followed. For this reason, we've chosen to design our production in a setting reminiscent of the 1920's in the United States.

All of this, and the text itself makes us extremely excited about this project. We hope that you are more in tune with our goals and message. Feel free to give us your thoughts on the subject: we will take what you say to heart while rehearsing and building this incredible show.

Challenges Facing Ivanov

Primarily, the challenges we face are financial ones. We do not have the personal capital available to pay for this production at the level we want to see it done. If it wasn't for all of your support, this project would not be possible. To offset the possibility of not reaching our goals, we will be applying for a grant through the city of Hartford, but as these grants are hard to come by, we are truly relying on you and your generosity to pull us through.

We are also doing everything ourselves. We are designing our set, building it by hand, painting it, papering it, moving it into the space, gathering furniture, costumes, and props ourselves, and setting up all of our marketing and web builds on our own. We are experienced in all of these things--all of us have worked on the back stage side of things with experience in set design, set construction, property management and acquisition, costume construction and design, and marketing. Through both our in depth education at the Hartt School, and many, many productions under our belts, we are prepared to deal with all of these issues and more.

If we cannot solve any of these problems ourselves, we also have the luxury of excellent connections, who can guide us to solutions on any issues we might face, from former directors, to professionals in the field, to family with great success in the business. 

How You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. The best thing you can do for us is to shout out loud about Ivanov and share it with as many people as you can! Share it on Facebook, share it on Twitter, share it in an email, share it in a text, it doesn't matter to us! Just get that word out there for us, and thank you so much for your contribution to this incredible project, We look forward to meeting you on opening night!
