story:
EDIT: We might not able to reach our initial goal, but we still think we can pass $1000. Check out the update tab above for the details on a bonus perk which we will offer to all backers if we can make it there!


What are we creating?

This is the first step on the road to creating something that’s not often seen in our corner of the world: an independent, grassroots opera project, created by a pair of new writers, and (ultimately) brought to life by some of Halifax’s most promising emerging performers. 

This is a story we’ve always wanted to tell, brought to life through a uniquely vibrant, engaging medium that combines the twin strengths of drama and music.  

“Two hundred and eighty six years have passed since the Great War ravaged the earth; one hundred and ninety seven since the founding of Scientia among the ruins of a city once part of Nova Scotia. Here, the radiation isn’t as strong. Our water needs only minor purification, and under controlled settings, plants can grow without contamination. Built on the promise that through science we could solve all of our problems, the city of Scientia could not afford to ignore the effect of radiation on unborn life. Reproduction, a dangerous trial since the advent of the war, became a state-controlled affair: conception, a routine procedure performed by dispassionate doctors. At the age of twenty we partner – either with a partner of our choice, or one appointed by the state. At twenty-one, we give birth to our first of two required children.”

Based on a short story by Emilie Hurst, this is the story of Lucy, a young cis woman living in a future society where resources are rationed, knowledge is tightly controlled, and reproduction is mandatory.  Though she submits to the medical procedure that’s said to be 99.9 percent effective in causing pregnancy, it slowly becomes apparent that something is wrong. Who, she wonders, are the 0.1 percent? What happens to them, and what does that mean for her?

We’ve sometimes referred to this piece as “a feminist science fiction opera” - and it’s all of those things and more.  Like all good science fiction, it asks difficult questions about our own world, and, ultimately, about ourselves.  What is the value of a person’s life when they can’t contribute in the way that’s set out for them by their society? What is the extent of the damage done by a system that’s unsympathetic to those who fall through the cracks? In an age where politicians moralise over reproductive rights, and where we engage every day with the commodification of women’s bodies, this is a story that we feel is increasingly relevant.  For opera fans, it could be a breath of fresh air in a genre full of cherished classics.  For those who’ve come for the story, it could be a chance to engage with a new medium in a way they might not have experienced before.

Who are we?

  • Emilie Hurst (librettist) is an academic and creative writer living in Ottawa.  Raised in the Maritimes, she has a degree in Music and Creative Writing from Dalhousie University, and is currently completing a Master’s thesis which deals with, among other things, the use of music in Doctor Who.  She will be pursuing doctoral studies at York University in the fall.
  • Michael Robson (composer) creates theatre and concert music that fuses contemporary sensibilities with elements of early music.  Based in Halifax, Nova Scotia, he has contributed incidental music and song settings to The Villain’s Theatre and the King’s Theatrical Society, and directs the student-run Unconscious Collective Vocal Ensemble.  Michael holds a Bachelor of Music (Composition) from Dalhousie University, where he studied with Jérôme Blais and Scott Edward Godin.

Why Crowdfunding?

“When we arrive home, Tom reveals he was busy while I slept, and pulls from a brown paper bag two carrots, a head of lettuce and a single tomato. I gasp at the expenditure – fresh produce is a rare commodity – and take the tomato in my hand to feel the elastic skin. On an impulse I take a bite. The tart juice drips onto my shirt, but I cannot bring myself to care. Tom laughs, and offers me a cloth before pulling out a final gift, a flat parcel poorly wrapped in brown paper.”

This project is really dear to both of us.  We’ve had it on the table for a few years now (since we both finished our undergrads, in fact), but every time we bring it up, it gets forced once again to the back burner, whether due to conflicting projects, asynchronous life plans, or - most of all - our various day jobs getting in the way.  And there’s the rub - this kind of project requires a full-time commitment of several months at least, and, being twenty-somethings who are still in the process of getting established, taking that amount of time off with no steady income just isn’t feasible.  In short, the funds raised by this campaign are going to allow Emilie to pay rent and buy groceries for the two or three months it takes to get our bearings and produce a workable, usable text.  This is a timely, relevant, compelling story that we really want to bring to life, but we can’t starve while we’re doing it.

This campaign is a jumping-off point - the first step in a long series of things that we need to make happen in order to bring this project to fruition.  At this stage, our story only exists in the realm of pen, paper, and plain text files; we have no free album downloads, no cool gadgets to show off, no hand-drawn artwork or DVD bonus material to share.  But we hope that contributing to us will be like planting a seed which you can watch growing as we continue to develop this project; in return, we’ll share the results of our work as it happens, and with it, a bit of ourselves.

Where do we go from here?

“As we walk through the streets of Scientia, I notice how the city core seems stitched together, new square angled constructions contrasting with the makeshift project of the early founders. When we move towards the edge of the city, the houses slowly morph into a standardized form, grey concrete and white doors, until I feel as if we are caught between two mirrors, the same unit reflected back to us eternally. I busy myself with cataloguing the small discrepancies…”

Once we have a libretto, then comes the all-important composition process, in which our story is retold - again - in the language of flowing vocal melodies and colourful orchestrations, transforming it from a narrative poem into an honest-to-goodness opera score.  This is the main part of creating the work that we want to create, and will (hopefully) be funded through Arts Nova Scotia’s Grants To Individuals program.  The grant application will be submitted in early May, and we should know by mid-July whether it’s been approved - which should allow the composition process to start in late July / early August, and to continue for the next 4-6 months.  (NB: Just so we’re perfectly clear, the libretto process - being primarily Emilie’s work - isn’t eligible for for this grant, as she’s continuing to pursue graduate / doctoral studies - hence, this campaign.)

With a completed score in hand, our next step will be to put the story into the hands of performers and hear it for the first time.  We’re aiming to do this in summer 2016; most likely, it will take the form of a semi-staged workshop performance.  If all goes well, we’ll start soliciting support for a fully staged production, to be developed over the following year.

Why this project?

“As I step out into the unknown landscape, my ears pick up on the faint hum of the wind turbines, usually barely audible within the city walls. I stand for a moment, letting the sound wrap around me…”

Beyond just telling a story that matters, we see this project as filling a hole within Halifax’s vibrant arts community.  Halifax has a flourishing independent theatre scene, and is famous for the creativity and diversity of its music, but opera - possibly the most exciting and multifaceted of all forms of live performance - remains the provenance of universities and arts organisations. Young Halifax singers overwhelmingly go elsewhere to specialise and pursue performance careers.  It would be wonderful to see Halifax build a bridge between the two worlds - a vibrant young independent opera scene with one foot in the university community and the other in the theatre world, where we tell our own stories about people and places that matter to us, where new work is celebrated and forms the backbone of what we do, holding a mirror up to the classics that we know and love.
But right now, there is no infrastructure that will help us tell the story that we want to tell.  So it’s up to you - if you find any of this intriguing, or if you like the direction we’re going, you can help us build the boat that will test these uncharted waters.

I want this to happen, but I’m a starving artist too.

As with anything, please keep watching us and share this widely! This is a project with a tremendous amount of crossover potential, so if you know anyone who’s interested in any aspect of this work - whether it’s opera, theatre, music, science fiction, or social commentary - send them our way.  If you’re interested in getting involved at a later stage of this project, feel free to get in touch! And of course, the Indiegogo share tools work too.
story_txt:
EDIT: We might not able to reach our initial goal, but we still think we can pass $1000. Check out the update tab above for the details on a bonus perk which we will offer to all backers if we can make it there!
What are we creating?This is the first step on the road to creating something that’s not often seen in our corner of the world: an independent, grassroots opera project, created by a pair of new writers, and (ultimately) brought to life by some of Halifax’s most promising emerging performers.  This is a story we’ve always wanted to tell, brought to life through a uniquely vibrant, engaging medium that combines the twin strengths of drama and music.  “Two hundred and eighty six years have passed since the Great War ravaged the earth; one hundred and ninety seven since the founding of Scientia among the ruins of a city once part of Nova Scotia. Here, the radiation isn’t as strong. Our water needs only minor purification, and under controlled settings, plants can grow without contamination. Built on the promise that through science we could solve all of our problems, the city of Scientia could not afford to ignore the effect of radiation on unborn life. Reproduction, a dangerous trial since the advent of the war, became a state-controlled affair: conception, a routine procedure performed by dispassionate doctors. At the age of twenty we partner – either with a partner of our choice, or one appointed by the state. At twenty-one, we give birth to our first of two required children.”Based on a short story by Emilie Hurst, this is the story of Lucy, a young cis woman living in a future society where resources are rationed, knowledge is tightly controlled, and reproduction is mandatory.  Though she submits to the medical procedure that’s said to be 99.9 percent effective in causing pregnancy, it slowly becomes apparent that something is wrong. Who, she wonders, are the 0.1 percent? What happens to them, and what does that mean for her?We’ve sometimes referred to this piece as “a feminist science fiction opera” - and it’s all of those things and more.  Like all good science fiction, it asks difficult questions about our own world, and, ultimately, about ourselves.  What is the value of a person’s life when they can’t contribute in the way that’s set out for them by their society? What is the extent of the damage done by a system that’s unsympathetic to those who fall through the cracks? In an age where politicians moralise over reproductive rights, and where we engage every day with the commodification of women’s bodies, this is a story that we feel is increasingly relevant.  For opera fans, it could be a breath of fresh air in a genre full of cherished classics.  For those who’ve come for the story, it could be a chance to engage with a new medium in a way they might not have experienced before.Who are we?
Emilie Hurst (librettist) is an academic and creative writer living in Ottawa.  Raised in the Maritimes, she has a degree in Music and Creative Writing from Dalhousie University, and is currently completing a Master’s thesis which deals with, among other things, the use of music in Doctor Who.  She will be pursuing doctoral studies at York University in the fall.
Michael Robson (composer) creates theatre and concert music that fuses contemporary sensibilities with elements of early music.  Based in Halifax, Nova Scotia, he has contributed incidental music and song settings to The Villain’s Theatre and the King’s Theatrical Society, and directs the student-run Unconscious Collective Vocal Ensemble.  Michael holds a Bachelor of Music (Composition) from Dalhousie University, where he studied with Jérôme Blais and Scott Edward Godin.Why Crowdfunding?“When we arrive home, Tom reveals he was busy while I slept, and pulls from a brown paper bag two carrots, a head of lettuce and a single tomato. I gasp at the expenditure – fresh produce is a rare commodity – and take the tomato in my hand to feel the elastic skin. On an impulse I take a bite. The tart juice drips onto my shirt, but I cannot bring myself to care. Tom laughs, and offers me a cloth before pulling out a final gift, a flat parcel poorly wrapped in brown paper.”
This project is really dear to both of us.  We’ve had it on the table for a few years now (since we both finished our undergrads, in fact), but every time we bring it up, it gets forced once again to the back burner, whether due to conflicting projects, asynchronous life plans, or - most of all - our various day jobs getting in the way.  And there’s the rub - this kind of project requires a full-time commitment of several months at least, and, being twenty-somethings who are still in the process of getting established, taking that amount of time off with no steady income just isn’t feasible.  In short, the funds raised by this campaign are going to allow Emilie to pay rent and buy groceries for the two or three months it takes to get our bearings and produce a workable, usable text.  This is a timely, relevant, compelling story that we really want to bring to life, but we can’t starve while we’re doing it.This campaign is a jumping-off point - the first step in a long series of things that we need to make happen in order to bring this project to fruition.  At this stage, our story only exists in the realm of pen, paper, and plain text files; we have no free album downloads, no cool gadgets to show off, no hand-drawn artwork or DVD bonus material to share.  But we hope that contributing to us will be like planting a seed which you can watch growing as we continue to develop this project; in return, we’ll share the results of our work as it happens, and with it, a bit of ourselves.Where do we go from here?“As we walk through the streets of Scientia, I notice how the city core seems stitched together, new square angled constructions contrasting with the makeshift project of the early founders. When we move towards the edge of the city, the houses slowly morph into a standardized form, grey concrete and white doors, until I feel as if we are caught between two mirrors, the same unit reflected back to us eternally. I busy myself with cataloguing the small discrepancies…”
Once we have a libretto, then comes the all-important composition process, in which our story is retold - again - in the language of flowing vocal melodies and colourful orchestrations, transforming it from a narrative poem into an honest-to-goodness opera score.  This is the main part of creating the work that we want to create, and will (hopefully) be funded through Arts Nova Scotia’s Grants To Individuals program.  The grant application will be submitted in early May, and we should know by mid-July whether it’s been approved - which should allow the composition process to start in late July / early August, and to continue for the next 4-6 months.  (NB: Just so we’re perfectly clear, the libretto process - being primarily Emilie’s work - isn’t eligible for for this grant, as she’s continuing to pursue graduate / doctoral studies - hence, this campaign.)With a completed score in hand, our next step will be to put the story into the hands of performers and hear it for the first time.  We’re aiming to do this in summer 2016; most likely, it will take the form of a semi-staged workshop performance.  If all goes well, we’ll start soliciting support for a fully staged production, to be developed over the following year.Why this project?“As I step out into the unknown landscape, my ears pick up on the faint hum of the wind turbines, usually barely audible within the city walls. I stand for a moment, letting the sound wrap around me…”
Beyond just telling a story that matters, we see this project as filling a hole within Halifax’s vibrant arts community.  Halifax has a flourishing independent theatre scene, and is famous for the creativity and diversity of its music, but opera - possibly the most exciting and multifaceted of all forms of live performance - remains the provenance of universities and arts organisations. Young Halifax singers overwhelmingly go elsewhere to specialise and pursue performance careers.  It would be wonderful to see Halifax build a bridge between the two worlds - a vibrant young independent opera scene with one foot in the university community and the other in the theatre world, where we tell our own stories about people and places that matter to us, where new work is celebrated and forms the backbone of what we do, holding a mirror up to the classics that we know and love.But right now, there is no infrastructure that will help us tell the story that we want to tell.  So it’s up to you - if you find any of this intriguing, or if you like the direction we’re going, you can help us build the boat that will test these uncharted waters.I want this to happen, but I’m a starving artist too.As with anything, please keep watching us and share this widely! This is a project with a tremendous amount of crossover potential, so if you know anyone who’s interested in any aspect of this work - whether it’s opera, theatre, music, science fiction, or social commentary - send them our way.  If you’re interested in getting involved at a later stage of this project, feel free to get in touch! And of course, the Indiegogo share tools work too.

story:
Let's Create a Dance Movement!!

Who doesn't love to dance?!  Moving to music brings joy and a sense of community.  

It all began in Sedona with a simple idea to get a few people together and spread some joy and fun.  First Lady Michelle Obama had challenged Ellen Degeneres to learn the dance to Uptown Funk as part of her "Gimme5" initiative and we thought it would be fun to do the dance against the backdrop of Sedona’s famed red rocks and send it in to the Ellen TV Show.  

Within 24 hours over 200 people had signed up to become a part of the event. 

At that point our thought was now how do we really make a difference all while having a great time? ...and Dance to Make a Difference was born.  We are dancing to raise money for local non-profits -- the Verde Valley Sanctuary ( local shelter for battered women and children: www.verdevalleysanctuary.org) and the Cornucopia Community Foundation (http://www.cornucopiacommunity.org)


Join us and Dance on Sunday May 3rd 8:30 am!!  

West Sedona School Ballfield (park in the Community Pool parking lot).  People of all ages and all walks of life are participating.  From our Sedona Mayor Sandy Moriarty, to kids from the local schools!

Have some fun spread some joy, shake your booty and Dance to Make a Difference!!

You don't need to know the dance - it is easy and we can teach it to you on the day of the event if you are personally coming.

All dancers are being asked to donate $$ or get sponsors - if we are going to play, lets'  play BIG!

Here's why you should help

  • Both organizations are having their funds cut because of statewide budget cuts
  • Whether we reach the goal or not all funds will go to help provide a safe place for women and children, and to feed the needy in our community

There are no administrative Costs  - all funds directly go to both organizations.   You will be helping to provide food and a safe place - simple things we all need.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this link with  friends - spread the word.
  • Join our group on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/821170981251462/
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

This July 10-18, 2015, DAIPANbutoh Collective: Sheri Brown, Diana Garcia-Snyder, Joan Laage, Kaoru Okumura and Helen Thorsen are germinating exciting adventures for the 6th Seattle Butoh Festival with the strong Latino presence of Diego Piñón, esteemed teacher and guest artist for 2015. Our biggest event so far! 

This year’s theme is “Investigating the Global Body” through the cross-pollination of Mexican Shamanism and Japanese Butoh. Exploring the Asian-Latino-Caucasian connections that deepen cultural understanding. DAIPAN is excited to invite you to join us this year in celebration of the Latino spirit, strength and passion! 

So far we have been collectively supported each other’s projects, but now, we will unify our efforts and talents to create our first full-length ensemble piece researching movement as a potential of the human body to be the deepest and most effective global communicator. 

We are unique because we are the primary presence of butoh in the Northwest and we do that powerfully because of your support. Every year we pool our passion and energy to produce the Seattle Butoh Festival bringing world recognized artists to Seattle to teach and perform along with us. We create provocative performances and inspiring workshops that enliven and awaken the spirit. We are a small and dedicated collective who have spent our lives making and promoting art.  

We are fortunate to have received small grants to support our festivals, but due to our size, we're unable to receive large grants. The NEA stopped funding small local artists 25 years ago and states and counties have difficulty just helping large art organizations. That’s why we come to you, the one percent.  The one percent that loves art and our work enough to empower people power through butoh dance. If you’ve read this far it means, that’s probably you. We ask that you support this festival to help bring Mexican Shamanistic Butoh Artist Diego Pinon's transformative and magical performance and teaching to Seattle. 

Thank You in advance for your support!!  We project the Seattle Butoh Festival to cost upwards of $20,000.  We are thrilled to be able to produce this caliber of art year by year, but we can't do this without your help. The money you give goes is to bringing internationally-recognized butoh artists as well as production and administrative costs.  DAIPAN's work is a labor of love which goes far indeed.  Your support truly is the catalyst that brings our labor of love into a powerful reality.

DAIPANbutoh Collective’s mission is to bring stimulating, provocative, and exceptional performances, workshops and forums to the diverse communities of the Northwest and beyond. Empowering local and global artists, we provide opportunities for national and international artists to work together in an environment for growth, creativity and transformation. In doing so, we aim to deeply influence our community’s evolution.

We continually enlarge our community by interfacing with artists of various disciplines. Co-promoting, producing, and performing, we are a vehicle for cross-cultural exchange with artists internationally. We are reaching out as individual artists and as a group to become an integral, intelligent international presence in the evolving butoh aesthetic inside a global boom of butoh-inspired art.

WORKSHOP with Diego Pinon

Butoh Ritual Mexicano (BRM) challenges us to awaken and explore all the human qualities ranging from the subtle to the outrageous. BRM seeks the emergence of the deeper self. Through this process of transforming our daily life through the rebirth of our dance, we can offer more inspired energy to our community. BRM training involves high-impact aerobic movement, active meditation, and guided improvisation, all embraced within a space of communal ritual. The collective physical training consists of shaking, low-level ground work, partnering, impulse exchange, and transpersonal communication in order to expand our currents of energetic exchange. Guided improvisations then give participants the opportunity to integrate this new-found sensory awareness within their physical body, external environments, and the collective presence to reach new realms of creative potential.

July 10th-12th @Taoist Studies Institute, 225 N 70th St, Seattle 98103

Secure your spot in the workshop as soon as possible! http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/1179163

July 10: 6 ~ 9 pm

July 11: 12 ~ 6 pm

July 12: 10 am ~ 4 pm

PERFORMANCES July 17 & 18th Broadway Performance Hall

July 19th Kubota Gardens

DAIPAN members have been collectively supported each other’s projects, but now, we will unify our efforts and talents to create our first full-length ensemble piece researching movement as a potential of the human body to be the deepest and most effective global communicator. Join us! !!July 17 & 18 at the Broadway Performance Hall when DAIPANbutoh members in their highest new phase of growth together with Mr. Piñon in his unique mastery will present two transformative stage performances. Then join us outdoors Sunday July 19th for a liberating free outdoor performance at Kubota Garden organized by Joan Laage and choreographed by Diego Piñon.

DAIPAN is powered by Shunpike

story:
Dance on the Lawn is back for for a second year of free dance performances in northern New Jersey. 

And this year, we're bigger and better than before:  

  • We've rounded up more dance companies -- a full dozen -- to perform free of charge on the lawn at St. Luke's Episcopal Church on Saturday, Sept. 12th at 4.30pm. 
  •  We've launched an "Emerging New Jersey Choreographer" program, to develop and mentor new artists.  This year's DOTL will feature a specially commissioned performance by our very first Emerging Choreographer, Robert Mark Burke.  
 

Who We Are  

Dance on the Lawn is a small, all-volunteer organization dedicated to exposing everyone -- especially folks intimidated by enormous ticket prices and fancy theaters -- to the glory of dance in all its forms.  We present an annual dance festival, free of charge.  This year, we have added a mentorship program for young artists, awarding a $1000 stipend to an "Emerging New Jersey Choreographer."  

Our founder, Charmaine Warren, has performed with several New York dance companies and is a former faculty member at The Ailey School, Fordham University, and the Joffrey Ballet.  She curates dance festivals for Harlem Stage and the Wassiac Project.  This past year, DOTL has grown to include an entire team of volunteers are are working hard to help make DOTL 2015 a success.  

Charmaine is ferociously committed to the power of dance to move us, to change our perspectives, and to enlarge our sense of empathy and compassion.  She is passionate about sharing that power, and started Dance on the Lawn to help give everyone a chance to see and feel how a little dance can rock your world.  


What We Need  

Dance on the Lawn has received support from local community organizations in Montclair, NJ (where we are based), including  Toni’s Kitchen, Studio042, The Spoon Group, and TonyTurnerPhotography.  This year, we have added Investor's Bank and Dance New Jersey to our roster of supporters.  

Our support is mostly the "in-kind" variety -- we will perform in donated space, on a donated stage with a donated Marley floor, donated microphones and donated speakers.  The fabulous dancers who agreed to perform said YES!, knowing that DOTL has no money to pay them.  We started this campaign to help raise funds to pay the artists. 

  • 99% of all funds we raise will go directly to the dancers.  (The other 1% will be used for administrative/logistical things like Gaffer's tape, ice and water for the dancers, and renewing our domain name) 

Your Impact

The artists agreed to perform without a fee, so your contribution is it! 

The 2015 Lineup:

Festival Host: Former Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre company member: Nasha Thomas

 New Jersey Schools: Kathy Costa’s DanceWorks & Company (Montclair),  Sharron Miller’s Academy for the Performing Arts’ Performance Workshop Ensemble (SMAPA/PWE- Montclair), Andrea Kramer's Ballet Forte (Chester), and Nancy Turano’s New Jersey Dance Theatre Ensemble (Summit) 
New Jersey Companies:   Donna Scro’s Freespace Dance (Montclair), Maurice Chestnut's Dance Therapy (Newark), and Randy James’ 10 Hairy Legs (Highland Park) 
"Dance on the Lawn's Emerging New Jersey Choreographer" - Robert Mark Burke (Hoboken)
New York Companies: Choreography by Troy Powell (Ailey II - Artistic Director), Janis Brenner & Dancers, Darrell Moultrie's DanceGrandMoultrie, and BHdos: The Second Company of Ballet Hispanico  
PLUS: Surprise Performances!

Risks & Challenges

We really need your help.  We've applied for grants, but most institutions are unwilling to fund an organization as new and as "all-volunteer" as DOTL.   We still think the artists deserve to be compensated, so all we can offer is what you're willing to give. Your help is crucial!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation at this time, here are some ways you can help our organization:

  • Help us get the word out! If you can't donate, maybe someone you know can! Send our Indiegogo campaign to your e-mail list or post it on your social media platforms. The more people who know about our project, the better! 
  • Volunteer! DOTL is happy to accept any skill set you'd like to contribute (marketing, development, accounting, outreach, . . . and anyone with enthusiasm for dance)
  • Come to the event! Even if you can't offer a donation, we would love to see your smiling face on Saturday, Sept. 12th at St. Luke's Episcopal Church (73 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair NJ) at 4.30pm. Children are not just welcome, they're encouraged!

Come to the event! Even if you can't offer a donation, we would love to see your smiling face on Saturday, Sept. 12th at St. Luke's Episcopal Church (73 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair NJ) at 4.30pm. Children are not just welcome, they're encouraged!

story:
Aloha a E Komo Mai to our MCPS Vision - Maui's FIRST and ONLY professional state-of-the-art Circus, Aerials and Parkour Studio.

                                           

  

We will be offering classes in Circus, Aerials & Parkour, AND we will provide an open gym where athletes can train. 



OUR GOAL

Our Mission here at MCPS is to bring together the art, technique and skills of 3 incredible programs for all ages, engaging and building each other up through classes, workshops, performances, parties, and summer camps.

Parkour, Aerials and Circus Performance all give people a healthy way to challenge themselves by working to reach movement goals, while providing an excellent outlet for creativity and artistry.  (What is Parkour? Read more below.)

Our new facility will create an ideal place for new and current Parkour practitioners, circus performers & aerialists to explore, train and develop new movement.  

We are excited to give back to the community we love by creating a safe and encouraging place for people of all ages to challenge themselves, get fit, and have FUN. 

We will be offering classes for ages 6 - 80+ years old, as well as birthday parties, open gyms, and special events.  

WHAT WE NEED

We are raising $85,000 via this campaign. This will position us to fully build, equip and grow the roots for a healthy, community-oriented organization that will last for years to come. You’ll be equipping our space (5-6 thousand SQ ft Minimum. average (~7-9$ k monthly)  with mats (~7-8k) , flooring(~10k) aerial equipment (~8k rigging included) , rigging, construction of Parkour boxes, rails,(~20k) and a huge Foam Pit,( ~3-4k) studio insurance (~5k)Accreditations & specialized workshops (~14k). 

$85K is enough to help us get space leased, built out and programs running.  If we raise more than our goal, it will add stability for our start up as well as give us the opportunity to engage with community groups and offer financial aid to students.

Maui Circus and Parkour Studio is excited to be a committed member of the Maui community.
Programs we will be offering:

Parkour (youth and adult classes level 1-3) 

Parkour is the art of movement, also known as tracuers. The discipline of using your body to overcome any and all obstacles in your path, it's a way of life. "All obstacles in life mentally and physically can be over come."

  • Flat ground tricks including front/back/side flips and variations, aerials, tumbling, other flips, and twists.
  • Wall tricks such as flips, spins, and twists.
  • Bar work including flyaways, releases, and other gymnastic elements.
  • Static freerunning tricks like flags, handstands, and levers.
  • Additional combos, tricks, and creative movement on all types of obstacles.
  • Ninja Warrior courses/ timed trials 
  •  Rope climb, Tyrollean traverse, wall climbs, vaulting, crawling, rolling, swinging                                                                             

Aerials (Youth and adult, beginner, intermediate and advanced classes ) 

  • Lyra hoop
  • Silks 
  • Corde lisse/rope
  • Net
  • Trapeze , dance & static
  • Invented apparatus
  • Flexibility
  • Conditioning & Strengthening      
Circus
  • Juggling
  • Tight-wire  
  • Contortion  
  • Hooping
  • Stilting
  • acrobats and more!

The Maui Circus & Parkour Studio will be the only facility of its kind in Maui County! We have lined up some great certified instructors with years of teaching experience. If you donate, based on the size of your donation, you will be qualified to receive one or more of our awesome "mahalo" gifts.                                                                                                                                                                                    

The Inspiration of Maui Circus & Parkour Studio 

Aloha~ My name is Halle, I am an extremely passionate, hard working individual and a  believer that movement and energy create love and inspiration in everyone. I know Parkour, aerials and circus arts provide so much more than just fitness! They inspire greater creativity, boost self-confidence, bring people together, and make exercise FUN! 
In teaching aerials here on the island of Maui, I observed the demand for these programs that I know will provide invaluable tools for the community. There is a need and I have the skills, support network, heart and passion to make this happen. 
I'm truly called to this mission of creating Maui Circus & Parkour. It's a BIG mission, and I'm grateful for all your support! Read on for more about me and our team.

                           


                                      

I knew when I was 5 that I wanted  to be a circus performer. I started young, making my own clown costumes and juggling. I even built my very own stilts when I was 9.

I've always been a passionate, motivated, agile, mechanically minded person. For the past 5 years I have  reconnected with my dream of circus and movement. I've traveled around - training, learning, teaching and performing aerials and circus arts, sprinkling in some Parkour on the side, and building some pretty profound relationships with amazingly talented successful athletes, performers, and business owners. 

My training, certifications and dedication go above and beyond. I have also spent the last 12 years as a tower climber, mechanic, welder & high rigger/stage rigger. I have been working in the most dangerous industry in America and take my safety, work, and goals very seriously. 

To me, safety and following through are as important as my love for movement and fun. Our studio will have all the necessary safety equipment and policies. I believe in open communication and promise to be someone the community can rely on. I want to see people fall in love with creative movement! 

  


Examples of what we are building: Bigger the better!



And some fun!


          


The A Team: 

With a little help from my friends :)

I am lucky to have some incredibly talented, positive, and supportive friends that are involved with this amazing opportunity.  I'm proud to introduce you to:

Lorin Ball

Co-Founder, American Ninja Warrior and Urban Acrobatics Parkour gym manager

Native to Hawaii, Lorin grew up on the island until he was 10 years old. Lorin has been teaching Parkour for over 10 years and is the co-founder and gym manager at Urban Acrobatics in Denver, CO. He has competed in American Ninja Warrior - all seasons. Lorin's favorite thing about Maui is the food! Lorin is excited to come home to visit aunties, uncles and grandparents while he oversees the construction of the Parkour side, as well as making sure our instructors are certified and professionally ready to perform the highest level of instruction to our community. He is coming to personally make sure this gets up and running in the community he loves and grew up in. We are so lucky and grateful to have him as part of our team.


Olessya Kurgayeva 

  

Russian Circus performer

Olessya Kurgayeva is an amazingly talented, highly experienced Circus performer.  She has 22 years of circus experience and began training in 1992 in Kazakhstan.

She attended Circus College Almaty and studied under many talented circus performers including Lyudmila Vasilenko who now runs Moscow Circus School.

Olessya has performed in the Kazakhstan International Circus, Lewis and Clark Cirque, Cirque Hawaii, Cirque Polynesia, Moscow International State. Her career has taken her all over the world and she has performed in Japan, Russia, China, Kazakhstan, Hawaii and mainland USA.  

She specializes in hoops, multiple aerial apparatuses (lyra, perch, trapeze, silks, loop, corde lisse), and contortion. Olessya is an integral part of our aerials and circus program and we are incredibly lucky to have her talent and passion on our team.

Olessya Has lived On Maui for over 5 years now and has made this her home.

Heather Booth
Aerialist, Aerial Coach, Social Circus Trainer, Certified Circus Arts Therapist




Heather Booth first learned the art of trapeze and aerial dance in 1997 in New Orleans. Heather founded Miraas Aerial, a Denver-based aerial studio, where she spent four years as Creative Director and Lead Instructor, teaching aerial silk/fabric, static trapeze, and lyra to adults and children. A circademic, advocate of social circus, and Certified Circus Arts Therapist,  Heather has worked as an aerial trainer in Israel, Palestine, and Thailand, teaching trust and peace through circus skills.  Heather’s aerial trainers have included: Julio Batista de Souza of Cirque du Soleil’s “Ka”, Alexandra Walker of the Slavic Sisters; Carrie Heller of the Circus Arts Institute; Shayna Swanson of Aloft;Lisa Natoli of Lisa’s Bright Ideas; and Ukoyia Mastin of New England Center for Circus Arts.  Heather been the lead aerial instructor at Still and Moving Center in Honolulu for the past two years and she is very excited to be part of the team at Maui Circus and Parkour Studio when she moves to Maui this fall.  

More To Come: We have many more amazingly talented people on board and are ready to add some talent to this island studio! 

Places I've trained and am influenced by are:

Sky Candy - Austin, TX

Miraas Aerials - Denver, CO

STREB - New York City, NY

Aerial Revolution - San Diego, CA

Apex Movement - Denver, CO

Urban Acrobatics - Denver, CO

NECCA - Brattleboro, VT

Circus Smirkus - Greensboro, VT

Meesh Aerial- Denver, CO

Michele Frances Aerial- Austin, TX


Risks & Challenges

Being passionate means Taking Risks

Every move with aerials and Parkour is a risk and a challenge. That is why it takes time, patience, determination and passion to build up strengths. 

I anticipate the same models in opening the doors to this studio. We are taking this risk and accepting the challenge. We have an amazing support system of professionals that have our backs. We will embrace any challenges and create strengths through them.

Once we raise these funds we will be positioned to sustain as a business; however, we are keenly aware that the work is just beginning. Running a Parkour and aerial studio involves a lot of overhead costs. We are committed to being fiscally healthy so that MCPS can thrive. We will pay a living wage and have comprehensive insurance for our studio and programming.   

Your active support of MCPS is essential for our success. Sign up for our classes, camps and workshops! Engage in our wonderful workshops for traveling or local professionals and aspiring performers, stunt artists, ninja warriors and circus creatives.  

It is our responsibility to offer the best possible instruction and opportunities so that you want to be at MCPS. Ultimately, our success will be a result of Maui seizing this opportunity as a community and creating some ripples.

It is our passionate intention that we fully fund our campaign with your support! However, if we do not meet our campaign goal, we will start with a smaller space and less equipment and build it up as we grow. 

The seed is planted. The roots will grow. The talent, passion and experience will prove itself, and create ripples.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us by spreading the word! Share this campaign with a few other people you think might be in the position to give! 

Need some ideas? 

Do you know anyone who loves Maui, HI and want’s to be able to see something like this on the island and see it thrive? Or someone who loves Parkour, Aerials or Circus? How about someone who loves you - we know there are many - and would want to support something you care about deeply?

You can also ask people you know and love to match your donation - or to send it to three of their contacts - a simple “Will you match me in my support for this thing I believe in” is often very fruitful!

From our hearts to yours - Thank you for supporting Maui Circus & Parkour Studio (MCPS)! 

It is a labor of love and inspiration. MCPS simply would not be possible without support from the amazing local and global community of Maui, HI, aerial, circus and Parkour lovers, and believers in play, creativity, and inclusion. 

We are so grateful for your support. 

Contact me with any questions at mauiaerialparkour@gmail.com

Mahalo~ Halle & MCPS Team~

story:
Short Summary

 "Toys" is a play that tells the story of the separated lives of two sisters who grew up on enemy grounds and reunite after 30 years in an explosive encounter. The play shines light on the impact of international adoptions on children and families.
J.U.S.T. Toys Productions is a growing performing arts company that is building an artistic community around socially conscious stage and screen productions. "Toys" is the first in what is expected to be many theatrical and film productions that focus on social justice issues. Our team of internationally-recognized, award-winning artists creates it's compelling and iconic first production.
http://www.toystheplay.com

The Artistic Team

SAVIANA STANESCU - writer

Saviana Stanescu is a Romanian-born award-winning playwright. Her work has been widely presented internationally and in the US. Saviana’s play “White Embers” produced by Dramalabbet made it in the TOP 3 of Best Plays in 2008, and in NYC is published by Samuel French as one of their 2010 OOB festival winners. http://www.saviana.com

GABOR TOMPA- director 

He graduated in stage and film directing at the I.L. Caragiale Theatre and Film Academy in Bucharest in 1981 as a student of Liviu Ciulei, Mihai Dimiu, Cătălina Buzoianu, founders of the world-famous Romanian school of stage directing. Since 1981 Tompa has directed plays at the Cluj-Napoca Hungarian Theatre in Cluj-Napoca. In 1987 he became the artistic director of the theatre, after the Romanian Revolution of 1989 he became the managing director of the theatre as well. He has staged more the 80 plays and produced other 80 wordlwide. http://theatre.ucsd.edu/people/faculty/GaborTompa/

TUNDE SKOVRAN- actress /producer

The award winning actress Tunde Skovran was born in Transylvania ( Romania). After graduating from the Dramatic Arts Department of Babes-Bolyai University in Cluj-Napoca, Romania, she joined the internationally acclaimed Hungarian State Theater of Cluj-Napoca, where she performed in over 30 productions during a span of 10 years. Her debut in film in 2013 ( "Puzzle") brought her two Best Actress in a Lead Role Awards at international film festivals in NYC and Buffalo. Focusing on her film career, the talented, exotic actress trained with various renown acting teachers in the US.                                               http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4704504/reference

JULIA UBRANKOVICS- actress /producer

Julia Ubrankovics is an acclaimed film, television and theater actress. Her career covers 10+ years of work with 19 movies & shorts, 15 theater plays, radio plays and commercials. She was awarded Best Actress at the 40th Hungarian Film Week for her leading role in the film"Virtually a Virgin". In a recent theater success she performed the title role in Ibsen's “Hedda Gabler” in Hawaii, the show ran for 5 weeks with rave reviews. Soon she will star as a lead character in Gyorgy Palfi's new feature film "For Ever".                    http://www.imdb.com/name/nm2067161/reference

AND OUR DEDICATED VOLUNTEERS:

DEKONTEE TUCRKILE, BERNARD MAZZINI, JON ERIC HOFFMAN


What We Need & What You Get


We are raising $ 5,000  to cover the basic costs of our endeavor. Our Premiere is already set for October 29th, 2015 at the well respected Hudson Theater in Hollywood. The show is scheduled to run for six weeks. Your contribution adds to our existing funding and enables us to secure the theater rental and crew. The world premier of Toys will be one of its kind. After opening in Los Angeles our aim is to bring this unique specifically Eastern European theater experience to several communities across the United States and Europe. By being our co-funder you become part of our team and we invite you to share our journey all the way. Your donation will get you a voucher entitling you to a ticket (or tickets)- valid for any performance of our six week run. 

The Impact

Getting the show on in Hollywood for a 6 week run will be a major step forward for us. It will mean;

Our profile will shoot up! The marketing campaign for the run will see us plastered all over Los Angeles and beyond. The opening night will see us reviewed across the national and international media, bringing our show to the world's attention.

Having done a West Coast run will allow us to do so much more in future, but we won't forget our faithful supporters and wherever we go in future we will still offer affordable tickets.


Risks & Challenges

If the show doesn't go ahead for whatever reason, we will refund our backers in full. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass the campaign details along to people who you think might be interested in helping out and seeing our show in the Hudson Theater. Thanks!

We are happy to offer tailored corporate and group packages for large numbers of people to come see the show. Again, just get in touch!

Our production company (J.U.S.T. Toys Productions) has a fiscal sponsor (Art Without Limits) through which we can accept grants and tax deductible donations. If you wish to receive a gift acknowledgement letter for tax purposes reach out to us. 

If you feel like you cant spare a few dollars, then please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share our link with your friends on social media like Facebook, Twitter and get your contacts involved.   Use the Indiegogo share tools!

He has staged more the 80 plays and produced other 80 wordlwide. http://theatre.ucsd.edu/people/faculty/GaborTompa/
TUNDE SKOVRAN- actress /producer
The award winning actress Tunde Skovran was born in Transylvania ( Romania). After graduating from the Dramatic Arts Department of Babes-Bolyai University in Cluj-Napoca, Romania, she joined the internationally acclaimed Hungarian State Theater of Cluj-Napoca, where she performed in over 30 productions during a span of 10 years. Her debut in film in 2013 ( "Puzzle") brought her two Best Actress in a Lead Role Awards at international film festivals in NYC and Buffalo. Focusing on her film career, the talented, exotic actress trained with various renown acting teachers in the US.                                               http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4704504/reference
JULIA UBRANKOVICS- actress /producer
Julia Ubrankovics is an acclaimed film, television and theater actress. Her career covers 10+ years of work with 19 movies & shorts, 15 theater plays, radio plays and commercials. She was awarded Best Actress at the 40th Hungarian Film Week for her leading role in the film"Virtually a Virgin". In a recent theater success she performed the title role in Ibsen's “Hedda Gabler” in Hawaii, the show ran for 5 weeks with rave reviews. Soon she will star as a lead character in Gyorgy Palfi's new feature film "For Ever".                    http://www.imdb.com/name/nm2067161/reference
AND OUR DEDICATED VOLUNTEERS:
DEKONTEE TUCRKILE, BERNARD MAZZINI, JON ERIC HOFFMAN





   What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $ 5,000  to cover the basic costs of our endeavor. Our Premiere is already set for October 29th, 2015 at the well respected Hudson Theater in Hollywood. The show is scheduled to run for six weeks. Your contribution adds to our existing funding and enables us to secure the theater rental and crew. The world premier of Toys will be one of its kind. After opening in Los Angeles our aim is to bring this unique specifically Eastern European theater experience to several communities across the United States and Europe. By being our co-funder you become part of our team and we invite you to share our journey all the way. Your donation will get you a voucher entitling you to a ticket (or tickets)- valid for any performance of our six week run. 



The Impact Getting the show on in Hollywood for a 6 week run will be a major step forward for us. It will mean;
Our profile will shoot up! The marketing campaign for the run will see us plastered all over Los Angeles and beyond. The opening night will see us reviewed across the national and international media, bringing our show to the world's attention.
Having done a West Coast run will allow us to do so much more in future, but we won't forget our faithful supporters and wherever we go in future we will still offer affordable tickets.

    Risks & Challenges 
If the show doesn't go ahead for whatever reason, we will refund our backers in full. 
    Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass the campaign details along to people who you think might be interested in helping out and seeing our show in the Hudson Theater. Thanks!
We are happy to offer tailored corporate and group packages for large numbers of people to come see the show. Again, just get in touch!
Our production company (J.U.S.T. Toys Productions) has a fiscal sponsor (Art Without Limits) through which we can accept grants and tax deductible donations. If you wish to receive a gift acknowledgement letter for tax purposes reach out to us. 

If you feel like you cant spare a few dollars, then please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Share our link with your friends on social media like Facebook, Twitter and get your contacts involved.   Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The Show

In 1958, Edward Albee wrote the story of two very different men meeting by a park bench. Originally titled "Peter and Jerry" this play would go on to be more well known as "The Zoo Story." Then nearly fifty years later Edward Albee revisited his work and added a first act prologue titled "Homelife" and combined the two plays together in a joined work called "At Home at the Zoo."

The performance dates for the show are Thursday, June 18th through Saturday June 20th at 7:30pm and Sunday at 2:30pm

The performance will takes place at The Forum at Koelbel Library on Holly and Orchard in Centennial, Colorado.

The Company

5th Wall Production is the creation of two brothers Jo and Thomas Gerlick. 5th Wall was formed to showcase new and different theater and to stretch the boundaries of theater and bring it to a new generation. 5th Wall's highest calling is to create theater which touches, moves, and inspired its audience.

By helping out this company you are helping a new theater company get off its feet. This is this company's first full length production and the first production to take place at The Forum at Koelbel Library on Holly and Orchard. We at 5th Wall are very proud of this association with the library and the city of Centennial and every little bit helps this dream of theater come closer to being a reality.

What we're up against...

Starting a new company, especially one producing theater, can be daunting and honestly, every little donation helps. That's why the donations start at $1 and go on up from there!

Theater is an art from that has the power to bring communities together in  way that few things can and now you have the opportunity to help this community thrive!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate now then please tell everyone you know about this project. Like, share, retweet and blog about this show to the highest mountain because we have high hopes for this thing and with your help we can make it great!

Thank you so much for your time and consideration. It helps a lot!

story:
Greyman Theatre Company, created in 2009, is a non-profit theatre company in New York City dedicated to discovering and cultivating under-recognized artistic voices whose work challenges and shapes audience experience, expectation, and point of view. 

While looking for a new start in Tarrytown, Ichabod befriends a troubled married couple, forcing them all to come to terms with past regrets and fears for the future. 

Tarrytown is written by an exciting new voice in musical theatre, Adam Wachter, who has worked on and off-broadway for almost a decade. Greyman Theatre Company and I are very excited to join with Adam to give Tarrytown its first fully realized production here in the heart of NYC. Tarrytown is a new musical that has a beautiful, soaring, classically inspired score, a contemporary sense of humor and a little bit of theatrical magic for good measure! When we first read it we were blown away by how uniquely beautiful it was in both score and lyric and how its use of mystery and magic added an electric excitement to the piece.

It grabbed us, and neither my team nor I could stop dreaming about what a production of it would look like. Six months later we are making that dream a reality. We fell in love with this risk taking, form-breaking musical and we hope you will too. See you on opening night!

Tyler Spicer

Artistic Director, Greyman Theatre Co.

Tarrytown runs at the American Theatre of Actors from Sept 26th to October 4th 2015.

story:
Who are you guys?

Brookville Theatre Co. is a brand new collective of artists who use theatre, storytelling, and visual art to bring about political and social awareness and activism.

Why Julius Caesar?

Because it's an important piece of political theatre.  It's central theme is power and the perception of power, which begs the question: Who saw who as a threat?

We watched people get maced, hosed, beaten, assaulted, and arrested for standing up for what's right.   Maybe Caesar sacrificed himself for his ideals as well.

We were born and bred in New York City; and if we haven't seen it firsthand, we can easily recall people like Dorothy Day who spoke truth to power from the eyes of the oppressed workers. 

We recall the Stonewall riots, where the LGBT community rose up against bigotry and prejudice.  

We remember Occupy Wall Street, when thousands of the working and middle classes brought the fight for economic equity to the front lines.

We honor those who lent their spirit and their strength, giving birth to a movement that will never yield, why Julius Caesar is the perfect debut piece for a company as bold as ours.   We want to be the artists, the dreamers, and the history makers that will continue a legacy of real, tangible change.  

So what do you want from me?

Your support.

We are a brand new company.  Fresh out of the box.  As of right now, our company is comprised of a handful of people who want to make great art that makes people want to get active in their communities.   We need all the help we can get to bring that message to our audience.   By donating money to our production, or by donating your time by reading our updates and posts,  you're helping give life to a potential groundswell of artists and activists that could shake the world for the better.

Okay, so what am I helping to pay for?

To oversimplify, we need:
- A performance venue
- A rehearsal space
- Costumes
- Advertising/web presence
- Props
And here's the kicker:
Paying the people involved.

What?

Brookville Theatre operates as a collective.  We all split the profits from the gross; so the more money that's donated, the more that leaves us to pay everyone involved.  It helps the actors and crew that give their time and effort to help put up the show, and it also frees us from corporate/big money interests!  Grassroots theatre at it's best!
PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD!  We can't grow without your support!
HAIL CAESAR!

story:
The Scoop on SPRINGLOADED 

There are no mistakes in this world. If I hadn't stalled and gotten stuck, in my life as well as with my show; if I'd finished my show sooner, I wouldn't have had my story; not even close. Why? Because the woman I am, despite clawing the air, spinning like a top and lamentations - had to be just as I am today in order to know how to unravel the skein and learn what I can.

 When I was 11, maybe 12, my sister Judith and I had a nightly tradition. We perched on my bed next to the open window, leaned on the sill and peered out to the shadowed street. Air mics in hand, we delivered the Up to the Minute Report. ("attention all chipmunks! There's a new crow causing trouble all over the block - be careful out there!"). 

Well, SPRINGLOADED is my present day Up to the Minute Report.                                              "Now where did those 35 years run off to? When did I lose my faith in possibility, in myself? What do I do to get those years back? And what about my lost faith?  How, where do I look for that? And she turns to her past, younger selves for help. If she's lucky, maybe even a few answers

As for the genesis of it all - I got the idea to write a one-woman show - wait for it- over 25 years ago. I figured the idea made good sense: I'd worked as an actor most all my adult life;         1) 

as a singer-songwriter, playing in the clubs throughout LA, my  tunes were invariably, achingly autobiographical;

 (2

 last but definitely not least,   I have an enormously, um - colorful - back story. "Easy peasy", I  thought, and I got right to  work. Drawing on the aforementioned back story, I wrote about a dozen vignettes, named the piece DIGS and  performed it in a Cornerstone Theatre workshop. I didn't put any  music in the first incarnation of my show, but I could hear the whole soundtrack-I knew which songs I'd use that I'd already written, like Runner...

3)​

I knew where in the story I'd need to write something new, I heard how and where the songs would fit. It was  the most exciting feeling. That whole year I was charged and optimistic; I wrote three, then four new songs that fit my show perfectly, like No Applause...

4

At the same time, I was prepping to begin recording my first independent album project, Gravity of the Heart. with my pal, Mike Clinco. Mike and I went on to collaborate on two new songs for my show: 25 and 14. They're still two of my absolute favorite songs : 5) https://acquaintance.com/margot-rose/ springloaded25-1 

During this time, I was also lucky enough to be getting fabulous TV bookings. Definitely the best and most exciting of these jobs was on Star Trek, The Next Generation as Eline in The Inner Light. I couldn't have wished for a better role. To this day, it's one of the best roles I ever had the good fortune to play on TV.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        (6 

I think most every artist experiences times that are more fertile than others. For me, the years in the early 1990's definitely were one of those times. But our fortunes tend to rise and fall like the tides; terrific times seem to even out with more challenging ones. Before I got too comfortable with all my good fortune, I hit several chapters of that evening out time - first, it came dressed as a crippling, ridiculously hard-to-diagnose chronic illness. This took my attention for the better part of 5 years - and my show gathered dust. When I'd pushed away from my island of illness, my partner Pat and I got serious about creating a family (yep, I'm gay). After four plus years of shots in the butt, insemination, and finally In Vitro Fertilization, she gave birth to our twins, Will and Nora. Now THIS was (and still is) a real quality problem. But twins don't leave a lot of elective time; when a few minutes do turn up, one usually opts for a shower or a meal. And so my show gathered an even thicker layer of dust.  

As the kids sprouted, my focus began to expand. For the first time in years, my field of vision included more than two small people. At the same time, the need to finish what I started began to preoccupy my kid-centric brain. The desire to get back to my artist self spread like heat from a hot plate. So I warily ventured out to a few tiny clubs for the first time in ages; songwriter rounds and short sets. I swallowed my pride, bitch-slapped my ego and forced myself to go to some open-mic nights (Me: Don't they know who I am? Me : Well, it's been every bit of 15 years, babe, so that would be a no). I went back to my stories, added more, retooled what I'd written before. I moved forward, then stalled once again.                     

In the story of my story, the saga goes on; more illness, more conflict, enormous love, crippling heartbreak, paralyzing hurt, all-encompassing fear; all shot through with the joy, frustration and frequent overwhelm of having kids. And like so many stories, especially true ones, there are stories within the stories within the stories, like Russian nesting dolls.

Suffice it to say the twists and turns of life as well as the monsters in residence under my bed kept the road blocks coming like whack-a-moles.

So, here it is all these years later - and I'm finally, finally ready to jump off the cliff, no matter where I land.

I'm asking you, my family, my family of friends and my friends unmet, to help me get my butt to the finish line and get my show ON ITS FEET!

(my  feet)

With enormous love and my forever gratitude,

xo Margot

PS - a small gift: I wrote this song as part of a musical based on a children's book; it may or may not find its way into SPRINGLOADED. Either way, it's all about magic. Everything that's happening lately? It's the miracle I always heard I should stick around for- just another word for magic.

                                                                                                 I freakin' love magic. 

 
 

What We Need & What You Get

I'm asking you to help me raise $30,000. "What a pile of dough! " you say?  

It certainly is - so here's how it breaks down:

$250 - Hollywood Fringe Festival 2017 Registration 

$3000 -  Hudson Theatre: Rental, crew, rehearsal time and approx. overage costs for six (6)  Fringe Festival performances  (90-110 mins)

$500 liability insurance, Hudson Theatre 

$2500- Director, flat fee

$2500  - musical director/keyboard 

  • rehearsals x 12 $1200-$1500
  • perf x 6 = $1200

$4200 - Band (musicians x 3)                                                                               

  • rehearsals x 6 @ $75 per musician= $1350;
  • 2 tech @ $100 per x 2 x3 =  $600
  • perf @$125 x 6 x 3 =$2250

$1500- music coordinator/ soundboard                                                                     

  • Coordination & prep @$100 x 5= $500
  • tech@$125 x 2=$250 + perf @$125 x 6 = $1000

$1000-$1200- Props, set pieces 

$1000-$1500 - Additional lighting, misc equip rental

$1000 - Press, ads (hard copy)

$500 - Social Media Ads (ads & promos)

$500 - Google Analytics

$1500 - Indiegogo pitch video                                                                                                           

  • $500 - DP                                                                                                                                                            
  • $500 - Editor                                                                                                                                                   
  • $1000- Video Director/Social Media Consultant

$3000- $3400 Solo-Show Coach/Dramaturge                                                                              

  • 3 months x 6 -8 sessions @ $115- $225 per = 22 x $150 average

$1250- Acting Coach, $250 per mo x5 mos

$1200 (total) -DIY writer retreats @$600 per retreat x 2

$1500-$2000 misc expenses (food for staff & crew, tips, Box Office cash)

$1500 -one (1) pre-production workshop concert reading (house concert)

Total total- $29,800 

Impact 

For me, a big part of this campaign is accountability. I’m very approval oriented - not always a plus, but in this case, it's a great tool to help me stay on track. Just at the thought of disappointing folks who've put their cash and/or faith in me  and I break out in a rash. I know I'll show up for us. If  you take this ride with me at any level, you keep me honest. And when we’re honest, we make better art.

PS - You can quote me on that last sentence if you want

WHAT ELSE YOU CAN DO (PLEASE AND THANK YOU!)

If you can't donate or you’d like to give me a bundle but you can only afford 40 quarters,  that's okay! Believe me, I get it. And you can still help enormously;

Please, spread the word, share the campaign on FB, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, Pinterest, Tumbler, your first grader’s Etch-a-Sketch

I went back to my stories, added more, retooled what I'd written before. I moved forward, then stalled once again.                     
In the story of my story, the saga goes on; more illness, more conflict, enormous love, crippling heartbreak, paralyzing hurt, all-encompassing fear; all shot through with the joy, frustration and frequent overwhelm of having kids. And like so many stories, especially true ones, there are stories within the stories within the stories, like Russian nesting dolls.
Suffice it to say the twists and turns of life as well as the monsters in residence under my bed kept the road blocks coming like whack-a-moles.
So, here it is all these years later - and I'm finally, finally ready to jump off the cliff, no matter where I land.
I'm asking you, my family, my family of friends and my friends unmet, to help me get my butt to the finish line and get my show ON ITS FEET!
(my  feet)
With enormous love and my forever gratitude,
xo Margot

PS - a small gift: I wrote this song as part of a musical based on a children's book; it may or may not find its way into SPRINGLOADED. Either way, it's all about magic. Everything that's happening lately? It's the miracle I always heard I should stick around for- just another word for magic. 
                                                                                                 I freakin' love magic. 

 
 

What We Need & What You Get
I'm asking you to help me raise $30,000. "What a pile of dough! " you say?  
It certainly is - so here's how it breaks down:
$250 - Hollywood Fringe Festival 2017 Registration 
$3000 -  Hudson Theatre: Rental, crew, rehearsal time and approx. overage costs for six (6)  Fringe Festival performances  (90-110 mins)
$500 liability insurance, Hudson Theatre 
$2500- Director, flat fee
$2500  - musical director/keyboard 

rehearsals x 12 $1200-$1500
perf x 6 = $1200

$4200 - Band (musicians x 3)                                                                               

rehearsals x 6 @ $75 per musician= $1350;
2 tech @ $100 per x 2 x3 =  $600
perf @$125 x 6 x 3 =$2250

$1500- music coordinator/ soundboard                                                                     

Coordination & prep @$100 x 5= $500
tech@$125 x 2=$250 + perf @$125 x 6 = $1000

$1000-$1200- Props, set pieces 
$1000-$1500 - Additional lighting, misc equip rental
$1000 - Press, ads (hard copy)
$500 - Social Media Ads (ads & promos)
$500 - Google Analytics
$1500 - Indiegogo pitch video                                                                                                           

$500 - DP                                                                                                                                                            
$500 - Editor                                                                                                                                                   
$1000- Video Director/Social Media Consultant

$3000- $3400 Solo-Show Coach/Dramaturge                                                                              
3 months x 6 -8 sessions @ $115- $225 per = 22 x $150 average
$1250- Acting Coach, $250 per mo x5 mos
$1200 (total) -DIY writer retreats @$600 per retreat x 2
$1500-$2000 misc expenses (food for staff & crew, tips, Box Office cash)
$1500 -one (1) pre-production workshop concert reading (house concert)
Total total- $29,800 
Impact 
For me, a big part of this campaign is accountability. I’m very approval oriented - not always a plus, but in this case, it's a great tool to help me stay on track. Just at the thought of disappointing folks who've put their cash and/or faith in me  and I break out in a rash. I know I'll show up for us. If  you take this ride with me at any level, you keep me honest. And when we’re honest, we make better art.
PS - You can quote me on that last sentence if you want 
WHAT ELSE YOU CAN DO (PLEASE AND THANK YOU!)
If you can't donate or you’d like to give me a bundle but you can only afford 40 quarters,  that's okay! Believe me, I get it. And you can still help enormously;
Please, spread the word, share the campaign on FB, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, Pinterest, Tumbler, your first grader’s Etch-a-Sketch

story:
Short Summary

For ASF's 5th anniversary season we have plowed ahead with a two show season.  We hope you will assist us as we continue to put works on stage that helps break down the terrible stereotypes that exist about Arabs and Muslims in our world today.  Over the previous four years we have produced two distinctly Arab stories: We Made Bread, a one woman show celebrating the women of Kuwait, and A Message, a comedy about religious and social tolerance; and two Shakespearean productions: Othello and Macbeth; both of which approached the broad themes of the plays from an Arab point of view.

This year we are producing Yussef El Guindi's Jihad Jones and the Kalashnikov Babes and Hamlet in addition to our yearly one day New Works Festival.  El Guindi's Jihad Jones takes on the portrayal of Arabs in the American media with a brilliantly funny dark comedy, while our production of Hamlet aims to look directly at how the youth contend with the actions of the older generation as well as how to continue to function under a new, and perhaps authoritarian government.  Finally, this year's New Works Festival will feature four short plays created from Elmaz Abinader's wonderful poetry.

Your donation will allow us to present both an Arab story and one of Shakespeare's in the same season for the first time.  Our mission is to create a cultural bridge between the Arab world and the West and now we will be able to do this twice as quickly.

What We Need & What You Get

At ASF we have always put well over 60%, sometimes upwards of 80% of our budget into paying our artists.  While we have been fiscally sound in our first four years of existence, we very much need to raise the funds to pay for as many artists as we can.  We are seeking to raise $6,500 in order to pay for the actors and stage manager for our first ever spring production.  Every single dollar that we raise will go directly to a Bay Area artist, even if we do not reach our goal we will use all of the funds to pay our artists.

The Perks!

Everyone who gives even $1 will be celebrated and rewarded!  You can check out the specifics to the right of the screen but let's highlight a few right now.  Folks giving a single dollar will be given the all important digital shout out via facebook, folks donating $50 will receive a ticket to either  Hamlet or Jihad Jones, $100 gets tickets to both shows, and for $350 you get...

We need a whole paragraph to explain the $350 level.   Have you ever wanted your face on a movie poster?  Now is your chance.  Jihad Jones illustrates and condemns the way that Arabs and Muslims are portrayed in Hollywood.  To do this we will be creating a series of movie posters on the walls of the set, which can star you!  Check out the sample above to get an idea of just what you could be the star of.  Whichever night you attend the show you will get to take it off the wall and take it home with you.  If you are unable to attend we will send you a picture of it up on the stage, and then ship it to you.

 

Risks & Challenges

We are happy to say that we plan to move forward our two show season no matter what!  Every dollar that you give will go to an artist in our 2017 season!  Guaranteed!

Our greatest challenge moving forward will be sustaining two show seasons as we move into the coming years.  Your support will help ease this transition to many future years of multi-show seasons.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Unable to contribute?  We understand.  You can still help however, share our campaign on your social media platforms, every single person that knows about it can help.  Come see one of our shows! 

    Follow us on facebook, send an email to wjbrown3@arabianshakes.org to get on our mailing list.
