story:
All donations to this Indiegogo campaign will go through 1st Street Players Non-profit organization and be considered tax deductible.

What is GATZ?

Gatz is a post-modern post-apocalyptic vaporwave infused interracial parody on the Great Gatsby.  I know it seems like a lot of stuff but all elements of the show share common themes that make them work.

There are many changes that were made to the original text that were not meant to negotiate the original themes but rather enhance the story. By providing an alternate view point one can compare the show to the original text and see elements they might have missed. That being said the work itself stands on its own as a well thought out piece that the entire family can enjoy.

There are a countless number of themes in The Great Gatsby as it is but Gatz touches upon areas unexplored. One of the more controversial elements of this production is Gatsby himself being played by a black man. Symbolically Gatsby has always been black and one can come to these conclusions by looking at the symbolism objectively. It would not be right if the production did this any other way and we stand by our choice.

Who came up with this?

Harrison Stengle is a producer/playwright/director in Philadelphia. Stengle made his directorial debut with his original work Cult Classic in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where he received considerable media attention as part of the city’s 2015 Fringe Festival.  The following year, Stengle staged Wolfhead Hamlet at the Society Hill Playhouse in Philadelphia. Stengle’s adaptation of Hamlet quickly garnered him a reputation for edgy and, sometimes controversial, work.  Harrison is excited for his off-off Broadway debut of “Sword of the Unicorn” which will be in the “Theatre for a New City” Dream up Festival.  Sword of the Unicorn deconstructs false narratives about the coming out experience for the LGTBQ community, through a sci-fi fantasy twist of the Hero’s Journey. 

What is 1st Street Players?

A small community theater nestled in the heart of Birdsboro, PA, the 1st Street Players have a huge amount of talent to display. Opening their doors in 2015,they provide top notch entertainment to the community and the surrounding areas. Their goal is to provide a safe place where children, adults and families can come and have fun, be educated and create lasting memories.  

Thanks to Mr.Mascaro for his unending generosity of leasing the use of this building to make a home for this theater company.  This blackbox type of theater holds 92 seats in an intimate environment and is great for many different types of show-casings.

 

Our Mission is to provide an outlet for creative community involvement, while producing quality entertainment for the entire family. Our goals are to enrich, educate, and entertain our community by providing an exceptional and safe theater experience. We want to stimulate, enhance and celebrate the understanding of ourselves and others through the experiences of live theater, on stage, off stage, and throughout the entire process.

 

The 1st Street Players' offer the community a wide range of quality theatrical experiences while supporting local arts and education.

 

What is the Philadelphia Fringe Festival?

The Fringe Festival, presented by FringeArts, is a 17-day, city-wide celebration of innovation and creativity in contemporary performance. Each September, the Festival explodes into every nook and cranny in neighborhoods across Philadelphia with more than 1,000 artistically daring performances, including national and international performances curated by FringeArts, and works that are produced by independent artist and promoted by FringeArts. The party continues late night, every night with music, food and drink at FringeArts’ center on the Delaware River waterfront. This vast assemblage of curated and self-produced innovators offers an unparalleled opportunity to see a cross section of the world’s greatest experimenters at one time, in one city.

Where is this going to be performed?

This show will be performed at 2111 Samson street in the heart of Philadelphia. You may also know the theatre as the “Philadelphia Shakespeare Theatre”. There are plenty of parking garages and restraints in the area.

How will this help?

The hope is (or at least should be) in art is to create a higher form of communication so that we can become closer to our fellow human. This show in particular covers many controversial topics that so desperately need to be addressed. What is it like being gay and being pressured to be straight? What are the implications of being in an interracial relationship? How does our political environment shape our reality? These are questions that boggle many people. Gatz address these questions and more. By seeing events unfold in front of us we come to a higher level of understand of the people around us. The hope of this play is to end discrimination and find love.

We hope to hold charity events that will raise money to end inner-city violence in Philadelphia.

What is my money going towards?

The money you are so generously donating to this project will go into a few things. One of the major issues with this production is payment of crew. There are a lot of furniture pieces in the performance. To move these furniture pieces quickly and effectively requires a crew of at least three people. We pay everyone who wants to be involved with the project and wish only to treat people fairly. However, we are limited.

Our costume budget is very limited as well. Gatz requires many different high end costume pieces. We have a basic budget laid out but to get the quality we are looking for it would require some more funds.

When the theatre group tragically left the space, we occupy now, they took all the lighting equipment with them. To perform in this space, we will need to rent all the technical equipment, that are typically the standard in other theatres. This can be very costly and the fear is that we will not have enough money to satisfy the shows lighting needs.

Is there any other way I can help?

Why sure you can. We are always looking for and excepting volunteers to help with seating or be in our crew. If you would like to be a part of this production please contact Harrison Stengle at his email hstengle@aol.com.

story:
About "In Manhattan"

IN MANHATTAN is a socially relevant play that looks at the lives of a young couple that come to New York City with big city dreams, but end up far from where they expected to be. It's a story of hopes, dreams, and the realities that sometimes take us off course and force us to make life saving decisions that may not be too pretty, but are the only option. On the fringe, are many such people living all around us.  For Rick Charles Mueller, as a playwright, it is important to tell these stories because they are real or based on real issues. IN MANHATTAN explores the lives of a young couple and the disappointments and challenges they face after arriving in New York City with dreams to become actors. They get scammed, and with no option, end up homeless and without money. It's a tale about being young and on top of the world, finding their saddest, lowest point, and with the help of a stranger, eventually finding their way. It is also a story about parenting, about sexual awakening and discovery, and the obstacles that either bind us, or frees us.  

Rick Charles Mueller is an activist who speaks internationally about social issues and the importance of acceptance and understanding. He is also a novelist, playwright, and actor who has written about many of the issues we face in our world, especially issues so concentrated in a big metropolis like New York City.

As a playwright, he writes about injustices and brings some of the dark things he has encountered to the stage. As president of his non-profit organization, Pride Not Prejudice, Inc., he finds ways to bring his message to the forefront and initiate dialogue, discussion and solutions. With his work as a playwright, he does the same. IN MANHATTAN is a work that delves into issues such as homelessness, drug addition, parenting, sexuality, puberty, and even Tourette's Syndrome. His characters are memorable and you will want to continue the dialogue beyond your time at the theater.

This campaign is the first attempt for Mr. Mueller to take his work beyond the theatre festival circuit, and bring his story to a broader audience. As a playwright, he has produced, directed, and acted in many of his plays, all with social issues worth discussing and viewing. But with IN MANHATTAN, Mr. Mueller makes his first attempt at bringing his message of hope and understanding to the general public.

During these tumultuous times, when our political and social differences are causing a divide, especially in a city like New York, Mr. Mueller hopes to create a general dialogue that brings us closer and not further apart. It promises to be an important journey that can make an impact, even if to only a small section of the local population.

Without the support of contributors, sponsors, and even other social activists (or socially conscious supporters), we can't tell this story and promote it widely.  Even the smallest contribution will help!

With your contribution, we can create a play production that incorporates an inspiring, tight script, a talented professional group of actors, and the highest quality production values we can bring to the stage. With this kind of core value, we can then focus on promoting the play, not because of some commercial endeavor, but because the message matters, and many people should be exposed to it. At this point, we have already secured the opportunity to be covered by some media outlets largely in part due to contributions of some initial supporters. With this non-profit project, your tax-deductible contribution will be the final step in bringing In Manhattan to the New York stage.

We need you. Here's how. 

There is no doing this without you.

  • We need approximately $24K+ to mount a full production of IN MANHATTAN. We want to do this in New York City (uh, actually "in Manhattan") and run for three full weekends, including matinees and evening performances including Wednesday and Thursdays. More importantly, we plan to offer tickets to folks who otherwise wouldn't be able to afford theatre, and get groups of the disenfranchised into some special performances. We also want to appeal to the general public and create some buzz and notice within larger groups.
  • We are asking for your support so that we can not only mount this production, but also create attention to some of the most needy in our society. Our production will incorporate a fundraising element that we hope will be visible outside the show itself so that we can encourage people to donate to causes that help fight homelessness, drug additions, disorder such as Tourette’s Syndrome and more! Your contribution will help us focus attention on some of the non-profits out there that help these people so that we can create interest and support for these groups. IT WILL GO FAR BEYOND these performances!
  • Contributors will be thanked in many different ways. Depending on what level of contribution you make (again, all tax-deductible), you will receive free tickets to the show, mentions in our program, invites to a very special opening party, and the opportunity to meet people just like you that CARE!

The Impact

Mr. Mueller has been working for many years to take his message to young audiences throughout the NYC Board of Ed system in an effort to inspire tomorrow's future to be more compassionate and understanding of other people's situations. His success is that he and his Pride Not Prejudice non-profit organization has been invited back to these schools for years. His involvement in gay rights and other issues that matter, has resulted in life altering situations where young people have shared how he has changed their lives and their perception of life. He wants to bring this message to a larger audience, gain more visibility for his cause, and inspire thousands more to advocate positive change and a stronger charitable philosophy. He asks that if you help him, he can help thousands more, an inspire his audiences to do the same! Your contribution is life-altering. It's for the sake of art... that matters.

Risks & Challenges

Our hurdle is money. Mr. Mueller has already invested thousands in getting this play to the stage, has enlisted the help of many who can contribute with marketing, PR, promotion, advertising, and even the work required to logistically plan this journey to the larger stage. Without your contributions, we can't stage this play in a manner that will gain the visibility it needs. 

Any contribution you can make will be instrumental in helping us finish what we started. We have the script, are planning another reading, and are looking to enlist the help of professionals who will make the vision come to life! Without you, we can't achieve this greater mission. Please help.

Many Ways You Can Help

A contribution is phenomenal. Any contribution. But we only have 60 days to raise the monies needed to find the right venue, hire the cast, begin production on sets, marketing, lighting, sound, costumes, and so much more. We are looking for many ways to achieve this and are working round the clock to accomplish our goals. But there are so many other ways you can help.

  • Help us spread the word. Share our videos, our links, our social media posts! Subscribe to our site and share what updates we share with you so that we can kick this off in a big way!
  • Know of any interested sponsors? Businesses? Or organizations that can help? Please let us know by emailing InManhattanThePlay@Gmail.com. Donations, if not in dollars, are welcomed in-kind. A free theatre venue, volunteers, all those things matter!

Thank you!

It is also a story about parenting, about sexual awakening and discovery, and the obstacles that either bind us, or frees us.  
Rick Charles Mueller is an activist who speaks internationally about social issues and the importance of acceptance and understanding. He is also a novelist, playwright, and actor who has written about many of the issues we face in our world, especially issues so concentrated in a big metropolis like New York City.
As a playwright, he writes about injustices and brings some of the dark things he has encountered to the stage. As president of his non-profit organization, Pride Not Prejudice, Inc., he finds ways to bring his message to the forefront and initiate dialogue, discussion and solutions. With his work as a playwright, he does the same. IN MANHATTAN is a work that delves into issues such as homelessness, drug addition, parenting, sexuality, puberty, and even Tourette's Syndrome. His characters are memorable and you will want to continue the dialogue beyond your time at the theater.
This campaign is the first attempt for Mr. Mueller to take his work beyond the theatre festival circuit, and bring his story to a broader audience. As a playwright, he has produced, directed, and acted in many of his plays, all with social issues worth discussing and viewing. But with IN MANHATTAN, Mr. Mueller makes his first attempt at bringing his message of hope and understanding to the general public.
During these tumultuous times, when our political and social differences are causing a divide, especially in a city like New York, Mr. Mueller hopes to create a general dialogue that brings us closer and not further apart. It promises to be an important journey that can make an impact, even if to only a small section of the local population.
Without the support of contributors, sponsors, and even other social activists (or socially conscious supporters), we can't tell this story and promote it widely.  Even the smallest contribution will help!
With your contribution, we can create a play production that incorporates an inspiring, tight script, a talented professional group of actors, and the highest quality production values we can bring to the stage. With this kind of core value, we can then focus on promoting the play, not because of some commercial endeavor, but because the message matters, and many people should be exposed to it. At this point, we have already secured the opportunity to be covered by some media outlets largely in part due to contributions of some initial supporters. With this non-profit project, your tax-deductible contribution will be the final step in bringing In Manhattan to the New York stage.

We need you. Here's how. 
There is no doing this without you.

We need approximately $24K+ to mount a full production of IN MANHATTAN. We want to do this in New York City (uh, actually "in Manhattan") and run for three full weekends, including matinees and evening performances including Wednesday and Thursdays. More importantly, we plan to offer tickets to folks who otherwise wouldn't be able to afford theatre, and get groups of the disenfranchised into some special performances. We also want to appeal to the general public and create some buzz and notice within larger groups.
We are asking for your support so that we can not only mount this production, but also create attention to some of the most needy in our society. Our production will incorporate a fundraising element that we hope will be visible outside the show itself so that we can encourage people to donate to causes that help fight homelessness, drug additions, disorder such as Tourette’s Syndrome and more! Your contribution will help us focus attention on some of the non-profits out there that help these people so that we can create interest and support for these groups. IT WILL GO FAR BEYOND these performances!
Contributors will be thanked in many different ways. Depending on what level of contribution you make (again, all tax-deductible), you will receive free tickets to the show, mentions in our program, invites to a very special opening party, and the opportunity to meet people just like you that CARE!


The Impact
Mr. Mueller has been working for many years to take his message to young audiences throughout the NYC Board of Ed system in an effort to inspire tomorrow's future to be more compassionate and understanding of other people's situations. His success is that he and his Pride Not Prejudice non-profit organization has been invited back to these schools for years. His involvement in gay rights and other issues that matter, has resulted in life altering situations where young people have shared how he has changed their lives and their perception of life. He wants to bring this message to a larger audience, gain more visibility for his cause, and inspire thousands more to advocate positive change and a stronger charitable philosophy. He asks that if you help him, he can help thousands more, an inspire his audiences to do the same! Your contribution is life-altering. It's for the sake of art... that matters.

Risks & Challenges
Our hurdle is money. Mr. Mueller has already invested thousands in getting this play to the stage, has enlisted the help of many who can contribute with marketing, PR, promotion, advertising, and even the work required to logistically plan this journey to the larger stage. Without your contributions, we can't stage this play in a manner that will gain the visibility it needs. 
Any contribution you can make will be instrumental in helping us finish what we started. We have the script, are planning another reading, and are looking to enlist the help of professionals who will make the vision come to life! Without you, we can't achieve this greater mission. Please help.

Many Ways You Can Help
A contribution is phenomenal. Any contribution. But we only have 60 days to raise the monies needed to find the right venue, hire the cast, begin production on sets, marketing, lighting, sound, costumes, and so much more. We are looking for many ways to achieve this and are working round the clock to accomplish our goals. But there are so many other ways you can help.

Help us spread the word. Share our videos, our links, our social media posts! Subscribe to our site and share what updates we share with you so that we can kick this off in a big way!
Know of any interested sponsors? Businesses? Or organizations that can help? Please let us know by emailing InManhattanThePlay@Gmail.com. Donations, if not in dollars, are welcomed in-kind. A free theatre venue, volunteers, all those things matter!

Thank you!

story:
who we are|

creator: Keyierra Collins with Catalyst Movmnt

curator: Catalyst Movmnt

Choreographers: Keyierra Collins, Trinity Bobo, & Keisha Bennett

Performers: Trinity Bobo, Keisha Bennett, Ambe'r Johnson, Marceia Scruggs, & Aaliyah Christina

meet the choreographers|

Trinity Dawn Bobo is a New York based performer, dance maker, and visual artist. She received her Bachelors of Fine Arts in Dance from Columbia College Chicago in Spring 2016. She’s worked with Christina Noel and The Creature, This Is Not A Theater Company, Anna Martine Whitehead, Peter Carpenter and Darrell Jones. As a creator, Trinity values the practice of improvisation and is interested in the sensually-potent nature of vulnerability in energy. As a queer person, Trinity is also interested in queering all of the spaces and elevating the voices of under represented people.

See her work here: trinitybobo.com/work

Originally from Georgia, Keisha Bennett graduated with a Bachelors of Fine Arts in Dance from Columbia College Chicago where she currently works as a Teaching Artist and Office Assistant for the Center for Community Arts Partnerships. She dances with BraveSoul Movement and Project Tool in collaboration with Onye Ozuzu. She has performed in shows like the Chicago Jazz Festival at Jay Pritzker Pavilion, The Seldoms' Power Goes at The Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago, and the American College Dance Association at The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

See her work here: https://vimeo.com/232580676

Keyierra Collins hails from Columbus, OH with a focus in West African and Afro contemporary dance styles. She graduated with a Bachelors of Arts in Dance creating work about the sociopolitical climate and her views thereof as a black womyn. Right now, she serves as Onye Ozuzu's apprentice -- collaborating on Project Tool and Technology of the Circle workshops. She also works with the Columbia College Chicago's Center for Community Arts Partnerships as a teaching artist. The American College Dance Association selected her choreography to be presented on the Terrace Theater stage at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

See her work here: https://vimeo.com/234616738

meet the curator|

Catalyst Movmnt curates shows and spaces for emerging movers and performers to present their work. They aim to showcase movement artists of color who desire to establish their voice on this bold and raw Earth. Based in Chicago, the communities crowd with burgeoning bodies that not only dream to be heard, but scream to show out. 

Their mantra: "It's our stage; only we can make it lit."

what you can bring to the table|

Lather. Rinse. Repeat. seeks funding ($4000 flexible rate) for the feature length production set for January 2018. We strive to make this a collaborative effort amongst our peers. We hope to properly compensate all of those involved with the production of the show. With your support, we will be able to provide for the following:

  • Venue
  • Photography/Cinematography
  • Costume Design
  • Sound Design
  • Printing
  • Performers
  • Travel Expenses (one of our artists is based in NYC)

Your contribution not only supports the dreams of the performers, but the dreams of those behind the scenes who are also emerging in the industry.

why you should help|

Every artist tells their story in a way that cannot always be put into words. These stories are important and necessary for the cultivation of authentic work. These works strive to create bonds with the viewer. The artists look through a therapeutic lens when researching their movement practices. Those working on Lather. Rinse. Repeat. create their work from the depths of their true, vulnerable selves in order to ring out the triumphs and pitfalls of day-to-day life. All three of the movement artists investigate their place in this sociopolitical climate with the collision of their individual lives as new adults, working womyn, and emerging artists.

what this means|

Without the support of their peers, mentors, and mentees this production could not be possible. So the choreographers, performers and crew thank you in advance for your contribution to their brain child as it continues to manifest.

Share. Post. Come!

We understand that not everyone is able to give, but if you know of anyone who can -- please share our campaign with them. It also doesn't hurt to come out and see the show!

**All contributors who give above $10 receive perks! All perks will be distributed at the commencement of show week in January of 2018!

story:
On Aug 8th at Lyric Hyperion Theatre in Los Angeles, internationally touring theater artist, music artist, and activist Sariyah Idan will perform HOMELESS IN HOMELAND to be filmed in front of a live audience. (RSVP on Eventbrite.) This filming will both open doors and make it eternal, at least digitally. This campaign is to cover the costs of the space rental and filming.

Through its development process, this acclaimed interdisciplinary theater show has been presented at festivals and colleges in California, New York, Massachusetts, Maryland and England UK. Now, with a brand new prologue that ties the central themes of the show to more universal questions about identity, migration and diaspora, it is time to properly document HOMELESS IN HOMELAND.  Donors to this Indiegogo campaign will receive access to the final edited video.

The high-quality, three-camera shoot and edit facilitated by Hal Masonberg of Off Leash Films will accomplish three important goals.

  • It will provide new images and clips for promotional and booking material.
  • It will enable people who cannot attend a live performance (due to location, etc.) to see it on video.
  • It will archive the show so that there is a solid record of it after it is no longer being performed. Sariyah is extremely proud of this piece, and of all the work that collaborating artists have put in, namely Shymala Moorty and Troy Acendor. It is important that this material can live on.

The $1200 will go towards the theater rental, tech, and camera gear. Breakdown of the budget below. Any additional funds raised will go towards stipends for the generous work of cinematographer and editor Hal Masonberg, director Shyamala Moorty, and writer/performer Sariyah Idan.

 

SHOW DESCRIPTION:
What and where is home? Combining poetry, dance, and character monologue, Sariyah Idan conveys a young Jewish-American woman’s struggle to understand her identity, her family and relationships, justice, and the meaning of home through the lens of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Idan’s portrayal of seventeen vibrant and diverse Americans, Palestinians, and Israelis, uncovers a new Middle East of grief, daily struggle, and humor. HOMELESS IN HOMELAND is a solo show in a documentary hip-hop theatre aesthetic, based on a trip taken by the writer-performer to the State of Israel and the occupied West Bank. “a dramatic tour-de-force…not to be missed (Hollywood Progressive).” The play briefly touches on Idan’s studies of Islam and her birth on a Sufi commune in New York.

“…A stunning piece of theater. Highly recommended.”

— Gail Louw, Brighton Fringe Review, England, 2013                                              http://fringereview.co.uk/review/brighton-fring...

 

HOMELESS IN HOMELAND was born from Sariyah’s commitment to the intersection of multiple narratives through a lens of compassion, her investigation of the responsibility that comes with privilege, and her belief that interdisciplinary performance has the capacity to create transformational experiences. During the writing process Ms Idan spent time in Israel and the occupied West Bank meeting and working with various different groups, both coexistence and direct action organizations.

“Idan boldly, but never recklessly, confronts these simmering issues with sensitivity, intelligence and an over-abundance of talent in this solo show.”
— Ed Rampell, The Forward, 2014  http://forward.com/schmooze/192168/finding-home...


THE TEAM:
Directed by Shyamala Moorty
Sound Design by Alcendor & Sariyah Idan
Set Design by Shyamala Moorty & Sariyah Idan
Lighting by Dan Kwong & Sariyah Idan
Consulting Producer - E Amato


SPECIAL THANKS:  Great Leap, La Mama ETC, Contra Tiempo, Common Ground On The Hill,  The Vanaver Caravan, ArtShare LA, Danyol Jaye, Antonio Rodriguez, Rha Goddess, Baba Israel, R. Ernie Silva, Nuyorican Poets Cafe, ONE Festival, Theatre In The Mill, La Peña, The Marsh Theater, Chelsea Gregory, Deema Daibis, Jason Siegel, and all the people who's stories HOMELESS IN HOMELAND is based upon.

 

THE NUMBERS    (for this filming)
Theater Rental - $350
Lights/Sound Tech - $250
Additional Lights - $50
Camera Rental - $250
Harddrive - $75
SD Cards - $70
Set Equipment - $70
Costume upgrades - $30
Indiegogo fees- $50

TOTAL $1195

 

AVAILABLE FOR BOOKINGS
Would you like to bring HOMELESS IN HOMELAND to your community? HOMELESS IN HOMELAND is available for bookings at colleges, universities and art centers. Sariyah is happy to partner with organizations and student groups on strategies for funding and producing effective events. In conjunction with performances, Sariyah offers workshops in interdisciplinary solo theater and derived theater. Workshops are appropriate for both artists and activists/organizers. Ms Idan holds an MFA in Theater and Music from CIIS and a BA in Arts and Social Change from Hampshire College. For booking inquiries email info@sariyah-idan.com with “HOMELESS IN HOMELAND” in the subject line.

 


ABOUT SARIYAH IDAN
Sariyah Idan is an internationally touring actor, writer, singer/musician/composer, and educator who utilizes interdisciplinary theater and multi-genre music to create transformational experiences, both personal and societal. Her work interrogates toxic forms of patriarchy while offering alternative ways to navigate its landscape while embodying a complex identity. Committed to the intersection of multiple narratives through a lens of compassion, she investigates the responsibility that comes with privilege and provides spaces for connectivity. As an educator/coach she passionately empowers the authentic voice of individuals while encouraging communal accountability.  http://sariyah-idan.com

For booking inquiries email info@sariyah-idan.com with “HOMELESS IN HOMELAND” in the subject line.

story:
Summary

London-based collaborators Otto Farrant (BBC’s War & Peace) and Finn Cooke (Royal Ballet School) are tied up. Straight from their “endearingly ridiculous and ludicrously delightful” (Broadway Baby 4****) run at the Edinburgh Fringe, Murmurations Theatre are pleased to present Spool at the IDGTF. A duet of Body and Mind exploring their co-dependency using “a charming combination of text and dance, sound and imagery.” (A Younger Theatre) Don’t miss this “expertly staged” production. (The Scotsman)

       

Otto Farrant & Finn Cooke met in the late of Summer 2015, dancing in a tent at a festival.

It didn't occur to them then, but that admittedly intoxicated meeting would result in not only an enduring friendship, but also a creative collaboration that led to the founding of their own company and a two week run at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.  

Having trained at The West London School of Dance and The Royal Ballet’s Lower and Upper schools, Finn has accumulated over 14 years of experience in movement and dance. He has performed numerous roles in a variety of productions across London and the UK in venues such as The Royal Opera House and Peacock Theatre to the streets of Taunton and Essex. 

Otto has worked throughout the UK and across the globe as an actor. He has played roles at London’s National Theatre, Young Vic and Shakespeare’s Globe. He has also established himself in television and film since he began in 2008, taking on roles in productions for the BBC, ITV and Warner Brothers.

Together, they are synergising theatre and dance to create a new dynamic in physical theatre.

What We Need

Below is an outline of some of the costs associated with taking a show to Dublin. This campaign's goal is a realistic crowdfunding contribution towards our total funding target. 

So, just with the basics: £2027!

We're utterly grateful for any donations we receive, and look forward to playing out our reward system!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the message by sharing this campaign with your friends and family.

If you have any other resources that you feel could help, please get in touch. We need as much publicity, rehearsal space and other fund raising opportunities as possible.

Thank you so much for reading this and please do come to see the show. Tickets are on sale now at http://www.gaytheatre.ie/

Much love,

Finn & Otto

story:
Andrea Mellis (opera singer, actress, director, writer, singing teacher - Website) and her husband Ron Hannah (composer, traveller, teacher - Website) embarked on a cultural mission in March of 2017 to commemorate the anniversary of 25 years of Canadian-Armenian relations.  Ron had composed an opera about Armenia's patron saint, Gregory, titled "The Illuminator".  It was the particular wish of Andrea (who wrote the libretto and directed the production) that there be many roles within the scope of young professionals just embarking on their career, and also important parts for children.

     After the acclaimed premiere (on April 3rd and 4th of 2017) that got 60 young Armenians involved and passionate about performing on stage, Andrea , with the support of the new Artistic Director, Constantine Orbelian, has been asked to launch a production of a Broadway musical at the Armenian National Academic Theater of Opera and Ballet in Yerevan.  Unfortunately, the Opera's budget is limited and they cannot afford the performance rights, rentals and royalties themselves. With your help we can get this project to materialise - we need 9,000 Euros to finance the rights and rentals for On The Town by Leonard Bernstein, which is Andrea’s first choice, not least because 2018 is Leonard Bernstein's 100th birthday!

      If we don’t reach our goal of €9,000 for this production we would use what we have collected to hold workshops in Musical Theater Arts in Yerevan, which are sorely needed. There is very little opportunity for young performers to hone their skills in song and dance with dialogue: the basics for musical theater. In this way we would start building a "stable" of accomplished performers for future productions.

    Andrea has almost 40 years’ experience as a teacher of singing and acting; she has already directed "On The Town" as well as dozens of other musicals, operas and plays, and she can get incredible performances out of total beginners (you can see what they can do by clicking on the link to "The Illuminator" above and viewing a video of the complete premiere performance). Young Armenian performers, although they have excellent voices and can sing beautifully, have very few opportunities to perform roles on stage, and this sort of work is vital to their future careers.

    Let's work together to bring joy and perspective to young singers and dancers in Armenia, a country in which the shadows of religious and cultural conflicts with its neighbours still linger, where poverty and stagnation affect large parts of the country, and where a symbol of hope and change is greatly welcomed.
story_txt:
Andrea Mellis (opera singer, actress, director, writer, singing teacher - Website) and her husband Ron Hannah (composer, traveller, teacher - Website) embarked on a cultural mission in March of 2017 to commemorate the anniversary of 25 years of Canadian-Armenian relations.  Ron had composed an opera about Armenia's patron saint, Gregory, titled "The Illuminator".  It was the particular wish of Andrea (who wrote the libretto and directed the production) that there be many roles within the scope of young professionals just embarking on their career, and also important parts for children.
     After the acclaimed premiere (on April 3rd and 4th of 2017) that got 60 young Armenians involved and passionate about performing on stage, Andrea , with the support of the new Artistic Director, Constantine Orbelian, has been asked to launch a production of a Broadway musical at the Armenian National Academic Theater of Opera and Ballet in Yerevan.  Unfortunately, the Opera's budget is limited and they cannot afford the performance rights, rentals and royalties themselves. With your help we can get this project to materialise - we need 9,000 Euros to finance the rights and rentals for On The Town by Leonard Bernstein, which is Andrea’s first choice, not least because 2018 is Leonard Bernstein's 100th birthday!
      If we don’t reach our goal of €9,000 for this production we would use what we have collected to hold workshops in Musical Theater Arts in Yerevan, which are sorely needed. There is very little opportunity for young performers to hone their skills in song and dance with dialogue: the basics for musical theater. In this way we would start building a "stable" of accomplished performers for future productions.
    Andrea has almost 40 years’ experience as a teacher of singing and acting; she has already directed "On The Town" as well as dozens of other musicals, operas and plays, and she can get incredible performances out of total beginners (you can see what they can do by clicking on the link to "The Illuminator" above and viewing a video of the complete premiere performance). Young Armenian performers, although they have excellent voices and can sing beautifully, have very few opportunities to perform roles on stage, and this sort of work is vital to their future careers.
    Let's work together to bring joy and perspective to young singers and dancers in Armenia, a country in which the shadows of religious and cultural conflicts with its neighbours still linger, where poverty and stagnation affect large parts of the country, and where a symbol of hope and change is greatly welcomed.

story: Hispaniolove is a play that explores the sociopolitical tensions between Haiti and the Dominican Republic through a culturally modern adaptation of Romeo and Juliet in which the two families personify the strained relations between the two countries. Tackling the struggles of Haitians and Dominicans on the sister island, the story revolves around two lovers living in the midst of bigotry. Hispaniolove is a celebration of the joint history and culture of the island of Hispaniola. The trilingual production serves as a medium to help communities embrace diversity and unity.

story:
We need your help!  

We are a group of active and former sex workers and allies working together to bring you The Hooker Monologues. For the last year, we have been developing and refining our stories. Now, we are gearing up to bring those stories to the stage. 

We are very excited to be working with local director Mindy Parfitt and dramaturge Camille Gingras. We have received two small grants and we are applying for more. Our full budget is more than $50,000 and that is why we are turning to you, hoping you will help us raise $15,000, almost a third of what we need. 

Every dollar you can contribute will help us. Every person you share this campaign with could be a source of a few more dollars and a little bit more awareness. 

Make some noise! 

Share our campaign! 

We want you to be a big part of our intimate project!


Our stories spring from the entire spectrum of sex work. This is our world; we will share our stories to dispel the myths that stigmatize and marginalize sex workers. We want to show all that sex work is and can be.

Now is the time to undertake such a production, as Canada’s new sex work legislation, the Protecting Communities and Exploited Persons Act (PCEPA), has reduced sex workers’ freedom and human rights. We believe that through our production, community members, sex workers and allies will be transformed.  

Sex workers have a history and a culture fashioned from an outsider perspective and marked by resistance and hope. We are creative people comfortable using arts-based ways to express ourselves. 

For example, one of the voices in the production belongs to Sarah de Vries, one of Vancouver’s missing women, reading to us from journals left behind when she disappeared. 

Sarah’s is a story of survival sex work. Other stories come from many sources, including the world of exotic dancing, independent indoor sex work, a glimpse of Vancouver’s Shame the Johns movement, and a sex worker’s story from September 11, 2001. 

All monologues will be performed by members of our collective.

Sex workers arrived with the birth of Vancouver, not as victims, but as city-builders and entrepreneurs. They founded organizations and services for sex workers and many others, and for decades have advocated for sex workers’ rights and an end to violence. 

Thank you for taking a look at The Hooker Monologues appeal. We hope you can help us!

story:
Kunstler, a two-person play by Jeffrey Sweet, is a portrait of the famous radical attorney, William  Kunstler, rebellious to the last as he appears as part of a guest speaker program at a law school, very aware that the young black woman introducing him isn’t thrilled with the assignment.  As he tells the dramatic stories of his key battles during the Sixties, he also finds himself defending his kind of law to this smart, critical young woman who views him as a dinosaur. 

One of the leading figures of the Chicago theatre movement, Jeffrey Sweet's plays have picked up awards from the American Theatre Critics Association as well as the Jeff Award, a Best Plays citation, and critic's choices from the NY TIMES, THE LA TIMES and THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE.  Actors who have played in his writing include Amy Morton, Alan Bates, Jon Cryer, Jill Eikenberry, Reed Birney and Jack Klugman (who appeared in THE VALUE OF NAMES in six theatres). 

Kunstler was written specifically for Broadway veteran Jeff McCarthy (who received terrific reviews last season as one of the leads in Southern Comfort at the Public Theater and was one of the original stars of the Tony-winning Urinetown).  Jeff is joined by Nambi E. Kelley, a leading Chicago actor-writer (she recently received raves both as the star of the Goodman’s production of Two Trains Running and for her hit adaptation of Richard Wright’s Native Son).

The director is Meagen Fay, one of the most highly-regarded alums of Chicago’s famed Second City troupe and a guest star on almost every TV show worth your time (including Mad Men and Transparent).  Kunstler was a family friend (she called him “Uncle Bill”) who collaborated with her lawyer uncle on some of his most controversial cases.  (In fact, Abbie Hoffman and Jerry Rubin crashed in the family house during the Chicago 7 trial and she had waffles with them in the morning.)

The Creative Place International, Inc. in association with Artistic New Directions, two non-profit theatre companies  (donations are tax-deductible) have joined forces to bring this compelling play to an off-Broadway audience.  

The Creative Place International,Inc. is a Small Professional Equity Theatre based in Saratoga Springs, New York and resident at the National Museum of Dance. The Creative Place is dedicated to developing family audiences, producing new work, and participating in international cultural exchange.  For over 30 years, New York City based Artistic New Directions through its development program has provided a place for playwrights to create work through their choice of readings, workshops and improvisational exploration and has provided initial development support for Kunstler.

Kunstler has been presented twice before, once in Regional Theatre (Hudson Stage), where it was praised by the New York Times as “skillful, wise and revealing,” then as part of the New York Fringe, where Time Out dubbed it a “critic’s choice.”  (Among its fans were Mike Nichols, Sheldon Harnick, Marshall W. Mason and Tonya Pinkins, who shlepped up the stairs to a garret to see it.)  This production will continue Kunstler’s journey from Regional Theatre to Fringe Festival, Off Broadway and beyond, bringing this “gripping” (New York Theatre Review) work to a wider audience and launching it into the national repertoire so the true story of a remarkable and complex man can be shared around the country and the world!  

 

What We Need & What You Get

On our own, we have received more than half the funding we need to bring this play to the high-profile 59E59 Theatre in New York City.  We have dates booked for February 2017 but we need to complete our funding before September to ensure all costs are covered.  We have previously fully funded this play with a modest budget for the New York Fringe Festival, a bare-bones situation that served the play in a small black box theatre at the end of three long flights of stairs.  With minimal set pieces and creative lighting and sound, that presentation was a sell-out success.  With this production, we will be designing all-new sets, lights and sound, as well as paying the designers, actors and director (novelty!).   

If we are unable to reach our funding goal, both Creative Place and Artistic New Directions are committed to bringing this production to audiences with our February off-broadway dates and the show will go on!  All funds received for this campaign will go to producing Kunstler.  Should we receive more than our goal (a delicious thought!) any funds not used for this specific production will be used to extend or move this run or help send it on tour for others in the country to experience.

story:
Help get our B*tches outta lock up!

LOCKED UP B*TCHES is a riotous, raunchy hip-hop/sketch musical comedy, loosely based on of our favorite women's prison saga, currently streaming on a Netflix account near you. (Hint hint.) And we need your help to make it as b*tchtastic as it can be!

Hot off a hit run at serials@theflea last year, Catya McMullen's LOCKED UP B*TCHES is hitting The People's Improv Theater in NYC every Monday night this April! (That's the 4th, 11th, 18th, and 25th, all at 9:30p.) The PIT is the premiere comedy theater for Improv, Sketch Comedy and new comedic works like us. 

We've been putting in a ton of work rapping, dancing, singing, and working in as many dog sex jokes as possible. We've had way too much fun rehearsing and creating this wild thing, and we can't wait to share it with you guys!

From Left: Nick Carrillo, Kera Halbersleben, Sean Zia, Karsten Otto, Crystal Arnette, Ellie Phillips. Photo: Scott Fetterman. 

What We're About

Set in B#tchfield Animal Shelter, the show chronicles the ultimate war between felines and canines, the b’s and p’s, as they rap their paws off and fight to the death. This musical is a dirty, hilarious celebration of the value of community and finding yourself in the midst of a messed up world. (Oh and humping. It's also about humping.)

In the show, Pipsy, a finely bred dog from the West Village, gets sent to B*tchfield Animal Shelter and discovers and world of caged-up, fierce and funny cats and dogs. Pipsy starts out trying to survive and ends up entangled in the weird, wonderful and kind of strange world of B*tchfield. Dogs and cats go to war, alliances are formed, dog anatomy is referenced, someone gets pregnant.

Locked Up B*tches also features rap homages that span three decades of hip-hop: East- West- and South- coasts. And also Christina Aguilera and Aerosmith. We want to honor the history of rap and R&B while blending in Catya's unique mix of comedy and heart. 

From Upper Left Clockwise: Brett Aresco, Jessie Cannizaro,Juan "SkittLez" Ortiz, Desi Waters, Lady Moody Zia.  Photos: Scott Fetterman.


Meet the B*tches Behind B*tchfield! Our Creative Team Includes:

CATYA MCMULLEN (Book/Lyrics/Actor/Co-Musical Director) is a Member of EST/Youngblood and The Middle Voice Theater Company at Rattlestick, has written six full length plays including "AGNES!" which will have its workshop production at Rattlestick this summer. She is the creator of WE ARE ANIMALS a seminal variety mashup of monologues, Sketch Comedy and music with Scott Klopfenstein. WE ARE ANIMALS has had sold out runs at The Brick Theater, HERE Arts Center and the People's Improv Theater. She also raps as her alter ego, MC CHIHUAHUA FANCY. Her play "Missed Connection" won the 37th Samuel French OOB Short Play Festival and was directed by Leslye Headland. SHe has developed or produced work with Rattlestick, EST/Youngblood, the PIT, the LARK, Naked Angels, The Flea Theater, Rising Phoenix Rep, Ground UP Productions and more.


MICHAEL RAINE (Director/Choreography) is a NY based director and choreographer. A frequent partner in crime with Catya, he has directed her plays for EST/Youngblood, Atlantic 2nd Stage, the Tank and #serials@the flea, where they developed LUBs last year. His choreography has been seen at Joe’s Pub, Lincoln Center Jazz, Theater for a New City, Juilliard Drama and NYU. This fall he will be choreographing the world premier of Sarah Ruhl’s new play Scenes from Court Life at Yale Rep.    


SCOTT KLOPFENSTEIN (Music Direction/Additional Music) was a member of gold record selling REEL BIG FISH, of Ska/Rock fame. He musical directs and has premiered songs at WE ARE ANIMALS and is a co-creator. He also composed music for Catya McMullen's RUBBER DUCKS AND SUNSETS, for which he was nominated for a NYIT award. He appeared and composed for the movie Kingpins, Baseketball, The Wild Thornberries Movie, the Rice Krispies commercial "Rice Crackle Punk," and last but not least When Ninjas Attack.

JOEY PERNICIARO (PRODUCER) Last summer Joey co-produced Carner and Gregor’s Barely Legal Showtune Extravaganza 2015. Current projects include a new play, Sundogs by Howard Emanuel  and an independent film based on the best selling novel, The Coldest Winter Ever. He  has also produced many readings and plays throughout New York City. Other film credits include background casting for an independent feature, “My Name is David”. Joey, is a graduate of the New School (BFA), AMDA and the Commercial Theater Institute’s 2014 14 week program.  

From Upper Left Clockwise: Sean Zia, Catya McMullen, Karsten Otto, Kera Halbersleben, Ellie Phillips, Nick Lawson. Photos: Joey Perniciaro.


Running an animal shelter ain't cheap: Why IndieGoGo?

We're running this thing on a tight leash, but we wanna make the best show we can. Shows as crazy, original and totally unheard of like ours require a ton of setup and production work--we're blazing new ground and doing something NYC has never seen before, so we want to reach out to our communities and ask for your support. Every contribution helps us more fully realize what this show wants to be. Your contribution will help us afford:

  • Lighting: Cats deserve to be well lit, too. Lighting design helps us build the world of B*tchfield Animal Shelter.

  • Sound: Gotta lay down some tracks for the rapping dogs, you know?

  • Stipends for the Cast and Creative team: We believe in supporting our performers and our team. We hope you do too!

  • Rehearsal Space: With your help we get to work out bigger dance numbers in dedicated NYC rehearsal spaces!

  • Catnip and Squeaky Dog Toys: Pussies gotta relax. 


Thanks for reading!

Oh man, thank you so much for reading about us and our story. On behalf of everybody from the Locked Up B*tches team, we appreciate your support and hope to see you at the PIT in April!

story:
"THE DAY YOU LOVE ME" Short Summary

  • I'm John R. Lacey, Writer, Director & Producer of "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME"
  • This campaign is targeted at raising funds for producing "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME",  a new original musical play for Los Angeles Area Intimate Theatre audiences
  • Your contributions will help raise awareness of the "True Story" of legendary tango singer Carlos Gardel- the man selected by Paramount to replace Rudolf Valentino!

 "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME" has been in development over the past 5 years at The Actors Studio, Ensemble Studio Theatre, InterACT Theatre Company, Samuel French Hollywood Bookshop and started at WestFest New Playwrights Festival at Theatre West in Hollywood (as "The Tango Singer".).  I'm a member of The Dramatists Guild of America, Playwright & Director at Playwrights/Directors Unit of The Actors Studio, Director at Stage Directors & Choreographers Society and Independent Producer and Board member at Theatrical Producers League of Los Angeles. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise a budget of $20,000 to produce "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME"- yes, producing theatre is expensive even for Los Angeles Area Intimate Theatre.
  • There are special perks available for you as contributors, including tickets to see the show, VIP seats, CD cast recording, autographed show posters and programs, an exclusive private Cast Party at an Argentine restaurant- with free tango lessons included! And, we even have a special Secret Perk for a select few unique individuals who would like to become Patrons of the Arts!
  • Our audience will learn about the biographical life of South American immigrant Carlos Gardel, his lifelong love of young Isabel del Valle,  his French immigrant single mother's struggles to help Carlos get an education in his struggle to get ahead, his loyalty to friend and screenplay writer/ composer Alfredo LePera, the show business mentoring and clandestine practices of Maestro Jose' Razzano and angel Sadie Baron Wakefield who introduces them to Charlie Chaplin and helps negotiate a 7 picture deal with Paramount in Hollywood!

The Impact

  • The play has been thoroughly developed over the last 5 years in several writers workshops in Los Angeles Area Intimate Theatre: including the Playwrights/Directors Unit of The Actors Studio, Ensemble Studio Theatre, InterACT Theatre Company, Samuel French Hollywood Bookshop. Many artists have selflessly contributed their time and efforts ad honorem to making this an important play that many audiences should see.
  • "The Tango Singer" played to sold out audiences (in the summer of 2012) under Actors Equity L.A. 99-Seat Theatre Plan at Theatre West's WestFest New Playwrights Festival- but we only had 3 performances so only 300 people got a chance to see it!
  • Although everyone loved Carlos Gardel's story, not enough people saw the play or got to hear his wonderful tango songs- in English! If you were one of those people, your contribution will ensure you get the chance to attend a quality show- and please recommend us or better yet bring your friends!

Risks & Challenges

  • The Day You Love Me is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Day You Love Me must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
  • We have 45 days to reach our ambitious goal in order to rent the theatre space for this summer, build the set, design the lighting, sound, video, wardrobe- all while casting, rehearsing, learning lines, choreographing and directing the show!
  • Fractured Atlas will generate a tax receipt for every eligible contribution that is processed by Fractured Atlas.  Fractured Atlas will not accept nor issue a tax receipt for cash donations or money orders.
  • Indiegogo is a business partner of Fractured Atlas.  Donors can give online by credit/debit card and PayPal. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • You can also help us in other ways!  Please spread the word about our show "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME" and the short lived career of legendary tango singer Carlos Gardel!  Even if we reach our goal, we will still have a very limited budget for promotion and advertising- and word-of-mouth is always the best advertising- plus it doesn't cost you anything!  Feel free to share our campaign with your friends on social media to help us raise awareness and the needed funds to complete our project. Thank you for your help!
story_txt:
"THE DAY YOU LOVE ME" Short Summary  I'm John R. Lacey, Writer, Director & Producer of "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME" This campaign is targeted at raising funds for producing "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME",  a new original musical play for Los Angeles Area Intimate Theatre audiences Your contributions will help raise awareness of the "True Story" of legendary tango singer Carlos Gardel- the man selected by Paramount to replace Rudolf Valentino!   "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME" has been in development over the past 5 years at The Actors Studio, Ensemble Studio Theatre, InterACT Theatre Company, Samuel French Hollywood Bookshop and started at WestFest New Playwrights Festival at Theatre West in Hollywood (as "The Tango Singer".).  I'm a member of The Dramatists Guild of America, Playwright & Director at Playwrights/Directors Unit of The Actors Studio, Director at Stage Directors & Choreographers Society and Independent Producer and Board member at Theatrical Producers League of Los Angeles.    What We Need & What You Get  We need to raise a budget of $20,000 to produce "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME"- yes, producing theatre is expensive even for Los Angeles Area Intimate Theatre. There are special perks available for you as contributors, including tickets to see the show, VIP seats, CD cast recording, autographed show posters and programs, an exclusive private Cast Party at an Argentine restaurant- with free tango lessons included! And, we even have a special Secret Perk for a select few unique individuals who would like to become Patrons of the Arts! Our audience will learn about the biographical life of South American immigrant Carlos Gardel, his lifelong love of young Isabel del Valle,  his French immigrant single mother's struggles to help Carlos get an education in his struggle to get ahead, his loyalty to friend and screenplay writer/ composer Alfredo LePera, the show business mentoring and clandestine practices of Maestro Jose' Razzano and angel Sadie Baron Wakefield who introduces them to Charlie Chaplin and helps negotiate a 7 picture deal with Paramount in Hollywood!    The Impact  The play has been thoroughly developed over the last 5 years in several writers workshops in Los Angeles Area Intimate Theatre: including the Playwrights/Directors Unit of The Actors Studio, Ensemble Studio Theatre, InterACT Theatre Company, Samuel French Hollywood Bookshop. Many artists have selflessly contributed their time and efforts ad honorem to making this an important play that many audiences should see. "The Tango Singer" played to sold out audiences (in the summer of 2012) under Actors Equity L.A. 99-Seat Theatre Plan at Theatre West's WestFest New Playwrights Festival- but we only had 3 performances so only 300 people got a chance to see it! Although everyone loved Carlos Gardel's story, not enough people saw the play or got to hear his wonderful tango songs- in English! If you were one of those people, your contribution will ensure you get the chance to attend a quality show- and please recommend us or better yet bring your friends!    Risks & Challenges 
The Day You Love Me is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Day You Love Me must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
We have 45 days to reach our ambitious goal in order to rent the theatre space for this summer, build the set, design the lighting, sound, video, wardrobe- all while casting, rehearsing, learning lines, choreographing and directing the show!
Fractured Atlas will generate a tax receipt for every eligible contribution that is processed by Fractured Atlas.  Fractured Atlas will not accept nor issue a tax receipt for cash donations or money orders.
Indiegogo is a business partner of Fractured Atlas.  Donors can give online by credit/debit card and PayPal. 
   Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  You can also help us in other ways!  Please spread the word about our show "THE DAY YOU LOVE ME" and the short lived career of legendary tango singer Carlos Gardel!  Even if we reach our goal, we will still have a very limited budget for promotion and advertising- and word-of-mouth is always the best advertising- plus it doesn't cost you anything!  Feel free to share our campaign with your friends on social media to help us raise awareness and the needed funds to complete our project. Thank you for your help!

story:
We are bringing a reimagined Globe Theatre to the Playa and filling it with people witnessing one another speak with joy, passion, abandon, specificity, imagination, irreverence, humor and pathos.

The Burning Globe fully embraces the mission to change the paradigm of art from a commodified object to an interactive, participatory, shared experience of creative expression. As a piece of live theatre,  our work can only exist once in time and it is gone. Our gift will be a series of workshops, on site performances and around Playa performance journeys that are created by the players and audience; our company will only facilitate. We will bring Shakespeare’s language to a community of 60,000 people whose previous experience may be a play a teacher presented to them as literature, made them read rather than speak and then told them what it should mean to them. We do not believe there is a right way to speak Shakespeare; just the way that brings the words, speaker and audience to life.  It is a world in which the player gets to encounter who they are and who they might be.  Everything they need is within themselves and as they breathe their life into the text it comes alive as if for the first time. This heightened language is for everyone as it holds the sacred and the profane, the ridiculous and sublime. It asks big questions about the human experience in all its complexity and invites the speaker to commit body, voice, heart, and soul to the moment.  And it is enormously fun.  I often tell people that speaking Shakespeare from an authentic, passionate place is like getting to be Mick Jagger live in concert. To get up on a stage and say to a group of friends and strangers under a wide desert sky, "We are such stuff as dreams are made of and our little life is rounded with a sleep " transforms you and all those listening. It is my hope that people leave the Playa having had that experience and then allow it to have ripples in their lives and to deepen their appreciation of and hunger for live theatre.

As the lead artist on this project, I bring over twenty years of experience directing, teaching, coaching and performing Shakespeare. As an actor, I have performed with numerous professional theaters and Shakespeare festivals around the country. I am currently the Co Head of Voice and Dialects at the American Conservatory Theatre where I train actors in the MFA program as well as coach the mainstage productions. I am also on the faculty at UC Berkeley and have previously been on faculty at UC Davis, Syracuse University, and Shakespeare and Company. I have directed everything from full Shakespeare productions to rogue touring adaptations. I have coached over seventy professional productions and am a certified Linklater voice teacher who works with people of all ages and professions to free their voices and find more authentic, clear and effective ways of communicating. I know how to take something from nothing, to meet all obstacles head on,  to adapt as necessary and to make the experience fun and fulfilling for all involved.

This year, your contribution will allow us to build three performance/workshop spaces- a  20 foot dome space, a 10 x 12 x 2 stage and an 8 x 8 x10 balcony space, as well as a Shakespeare Tarot booth/bar. It will allow us to purchase swords, costumes, instruments,and a sound system that will also need to be transported to the Playa. It will allow us to document our work. This year is just the beginning. All leftover funds from this year will go toward our continuing goal of creating a fully realized Globe Theatre that is a work of art for all to enjoy in the middle of the Playa.

In return for your help, we have created a few fun perks of personalized Shakespeare recordings, Shakespeare Tarot cards and private vocal coaching sessions. If you are in the Bay Area, anyone who contributes will be invited to the pre event and post event thank you Gumbo celebrations. So give whatever you can and please pass the word to everyone you know. And if you are at the event, come find us at 5:45 and High Renaissance and join in.

story:
About The Play

Jane doesn’t know what to do with the literary character who has taken up residence in her bathtub. She doesn’t want Ophelia interrupting the obsessive order of her life with obnoxious songs about death and valentines. She doesn’t want Ophelia disrupting her relationship with Edmund, the oddly charming actor who might show up for dinner in a suit...of armor. And she most definitely doesn’t want Ophelia stirring up memories of a brother she would rather forget. But Ophelia doesn’t care about what Jane wants so much as what she needs. As Jane’s past intrudes dangerously on her present, it becomes clear that Ophelia is not simply a character from Hamlet, but a long-forgotten messenger with a question from Jane’s own troubled mind: How do you move on when reconciliation is not an option?

  • This timely, poetic play tackles many different issues facing the younger generations today including abuse, mental illness, suicide, and victim self-blame, without pandering or preaching to the audience. It's hard to come by plays with such a beautiful and difficult message of understanding and forgiveness, without victimizing or villainizing any character or party.

  • We live in a time where boundaries are being redefined: what constitutes rape? Who bears the responsibility of suicide? What is and is not okay to joke about? And in the course of these discussions and drawing of boundary lines, we often see everything in black and white, bad and good, evil and pure. We forget that even those we villainize are human. We, as a society enveloped in technology, have found a way to dehumanize those we find unworthy based on their actions. No matter how much we believe we have progressed as a species, we still find ways to carry on behavior we thought we eradicated hundreds of years ago; we’ve just done it from a longer distance, through a computer screen. This play has found a way to empathize with someone we thought we could never empathize with. Rachel Strayer has blurred our defined boundaries, and mixed the black with the white. In a time where we think everything is clear cut, Ms. Strayer makes us re-think judgment, and re-evaluate our standing as humans.

 

Why Now? Why This Show?

  • Never has there been a more important time to break down the technological armor that allows us to cyber bully, judge from a distance, say things we would never say in person, and more importantly, shield us from empathy. When one is faced with empathizing with someone thought to be “pure evil” based on their actions, we are completely uprooted, and have the opportunity to look at others we may have judged.

 

Giving Back

This play is a joint presentation of Ensemble Atria and EagerRisk Theater, and both Artistic Directors are keen on giving back to their communities. With Drowning Ophelia, Ensemble Atria & EagerRisk Theater plan to donate a percentage of ticket sales from the first two days of Fringe Shows to www.imalive.org, a Suicide Prevention Website during Suicide Awareness Week.

We won't stop there. With future productions, we hope to work with local and national abuse organizations, mental health awareness movements, and other non-profit organizations, to provide free seats to victims of abuse, neglect, and mental illness in order to help alleviate pain and understand no one is alone. Hopefully, we'll save a few lives and hearts with our efforts.

 

Our Journey- To Philly & Beyond

  • ​We want to share this show with as many people as possible, to do that, we've charted our journey, and the first stop is:
  1. Philadelphia 2016 Fringe Festival. By contributing to this campaign you'll help us take our first big step! We're already registered and have put the deposit down on our space, you can help us make it the best it can be.
  2. Off-Broadway Run, Fall 2017. Within a year's time, we hope to garner the acclaim and capital to take the play to a 100 seat house in our home of NYC with a month-long run to engage people everywhere. Working with non-profit abuse, suicide, and mental illness organizations, we'll be able to reach out to the great New York/NJ area, and help as many people as possible.
  3. Edinburgh Fringe Festival Summer 2018. Travel to Edinburgh and bring the play international, which will lead to either:
  4. A European or USA tour, Fall/Winter 2018. Bringing the play abroad, we can help men and women in countries without regular access to abuse counseling. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our Philadelphia Fringe Budget is $7,000. The money you donate will go towards

  • Travel, Food, and Lodging of Actors and Production Team in Philadelphia
  • Space Rental, Insurance, Lighting and Sound Equipment
  • Actor, Director, and Designer Stipends.

 

Our Track Record

Established in 2012 & 2013, respectively, EagerRisk Theater and Ensemble Atria have multiple productions, readings, and ventures under their belts that have kept them afloat and thriving in the hectic and competitive theatrical environment of NYC.

  • Ensemble Atria has won multiple awards, including Best Scenic Design for Envoy in the 2013 Manhattan International Theatre Festival, and  Outstanding Lead Actress in a Full Length Play for 2014's Frame 313.
  • EagerRisk Theater has been seen in the Philadelphia Fringe Festival before (under the title YeuxVeuxBelle Collective) with 2012's The Artists' Women by Artistic Director Annie R. Such. 

“The cast brims with as much physical and emotional passion as the script. Such packs the play with sensual imagery and ripe, time-honored artistic dilemmas, and she also contributes a digital slideshow, projected on the set’s backdrop, which peppers the stage with images of the characters’ most famous art. The artists’ women suffer the sublime pain of coming second to their lovers’ genius, or watching their own talents consumed by a male-dominated world, where they’ll be remembered by history not for what they did, but for who they loved…. This new acquaintance with the artists, their long-suffering lovers, and the imagined muse behind it all will leave you wanting to revisit the masterpieces themselves.” 

--Alaina Mabasco, review of The Artists' Women

  • EagerRisk's last show, an adaptation of Life is a Dream by Calderon, garnered a review 

    "Playwright Annie R. Such does an impeccable job at storytelling. Such breathes life into her adaptation... Keep an eye out for future productions from Eager Risk Theater. You’ll be intrigued by what they have to offer." --Michael Block, Theatre in the Now

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand how tight funds can be, there are other ways you can help!

  • Spread the word, tell your friends, or just tweet our link! 
  • Donate set pieces, costumes, or even space time! Rehearsal space in NYC is expensive, you can help us combat the course.

story:
BFAB Dance Crew: 

The crew formed in 2013. BFAB consists of dancers, who are young bunch of talents in various dance forms with more than 6 years of professional dance experience. We believe, this is the core strength of our crew. This makes our crew more stronger and look professional with disciplined features.

We are proud to say that we are going to represent India for the first time in the world hip hop championship presented by HIP HOP UNITE.

This competition is going to happen in Martinique this December 2015. This event is affiliated by more than 15 countries.

More details about the event is given in the link below:

http://www.hiphopunite.com/ 

We believe not only in winning titles but also winning the hearts of audience.  Wherever we go, we make sure we get a huge response from the crowd and this is what make us win again and again. Like yet another competition, we qualified in the national level championship conducted by hiphop unite INDIA.

Life as a dancer is so hard and its rare to get an opportunity to showcase our talents. Your contribution through this campaign will help us in chasing our dream as a dancer.

We see this as a huge opportunity and we have lot of hopes to prove ourselves. In order to take our talents outside our country, We need your help through this campaign. 

How the funds will be utilized?

  • Flight charges and VISA expenses for 7-8 performers.
  • Food and accommodation for 7-8 dancers during this 3 days event.
  • Registration fees for each dancers to participate in the HHU world championship.
  • Rehearsal charges which includes studio rentals and conveyances.
  • Costume stitching and fabric charges.

Our achievements:

  • B-FAB placed 4th out of 1800 teams participated in 7UP dance pattalam 2013
  • B-FAB placed 2nd in Techofes 2014 conducted by Anna university- College of engineering- Chennai
  • B-FAB placed 2nd in Power Of Desi Streets- PODS 2015 hosted by Dynamic Dance Crew- Mumbai
  • B-FAB placed 2nd in Instinct 2015 conducted by SSN Engineering college-Chennai
  • B-FAB placed 2nd in Hiphop UNITE- 2015 National championship held in Mumbai and qualified to represent India in Hiphop UNITE-World championship that is to be held in Martinque, France .
  • B-FAB placed 2nd in Hiphop Esctacy season 2- 2015 , organised by Graphic Wood Media – Chennai.
  • B-FAB got short-listed among top 45 contestants out of 10000 contestants who appeared for the auditions for the new reality show conducted by a famous TV channel.

“ Disappointments are just God’s way of saying: “I’ve got something better.” Be Patient,live life and have faith” 

B-FAB have a positive vibe that shows us we still have lot of space to improve and we firmly believe these achievements are just the beginning. The Strength of B-FAB is enormous and we look forward to clinch the victory in bigger stages. We are working hard for the world championship presented by Hip Hop Unite, that is to be held  at Martinque in December 2015. We hope that our long awaited first place will treat us in Martinque, given the glory to God.

Our website: http://www.bfab-dancecrew.com/

Other Ways You Can Help

A Big heart is bigger than a Big wallet. We started this campaign because we do not have a big wallet.People who have both heart and wallet bigger are treated to be high in heaven. We thank you so much for the time you spent in reading about our dream. Though you are not able to contribute to us, you can shout out to your friends to help us by sharing this campaign through social media. We really appreciate you to share this event using indiegogo share tool.
