B-FAB placed 2nd in Instinct 2015 conducted by SSN Engineering college-Chennai
B-FAB placed 2nd in Hiphop UNITE- 2015 National championship held in Mumbai and qualified to represent India in Hiphop UNITE-World championship that is to be held in Martinque, France .
B-FAB placed 2nd in Hiphop Esctacy season 2- 2015 , organised by Graphic Wood Media – Chennai.
B-FAB got short-listed among top 45 contestants out of 10000 contestants who appeared for the auditions for the new reality show conducted by a famous TV channel.




“ Disappointments are just God’s way of saying: “I’ve got something better.” Be Patient,live life and have faith” 
B-FAB have a positive vibe that shows us we still have lot of space to improve and we firmly believe these achievements are just the beginning. The Strength of B-FAB is enormous and we look forward to clinch the victory in bigger stages. We are working hard for the world championship presented by Hip Hop Unite, that is to be held  at Martinque in December 2015. We hope that our long awaited first place will treat us in Martinque, given the glory to God.
Our website: http://www.bfab-dancecrew.com/


Other Ways You Can Help
A Big heart is bigger than a Big wallet. We started this campaign because we do not have a big wallet.People who have both heart and wallet bigger are treated to be high in heaven. We thank you so much for the time you spent in reading about our dream. Though you are not able to contribute to us, you can shout out to your friends to help us by sharing this campaign through social media. We really appreciate you to share this event using indiegogo share tool.

story:
A Home for Dance

Each year, hundreds of dancers, choreographers, educators, students, and audience members come through our doors and fill the Performance Garage with movement, creativity, and love of the arts. 

The studios at the Performance Garage are one-of-a kind in Philadelphia's dance community.  We offer two spacious studios with sprung Marley floors, technical support for performances, as well as dressing rooms and other amenities.  Our performance space has a professional lighting and sound system with seating for 120 audience members.  Our rehearsal/class space has wall-to-wall mirrors, dance barres, and a reception area.  


What a New Floor Can Do

In order to continue serving our community of dancers and expand our reach, the Performance Garage is raising funds to replace the floor in Studio B.  For over 13 years, the Performance Garage's professional grade studios have been utilized by countless renters for rehearsals, productions, auditions, classes, workshops, and our Youth Outreach Program.  With all those feet twirling, jumping, leaping, stomping, and shuffling around, it's no surprise that our studio floors have become worn and are in desperate need of replacement.  Additionally, the current flooring does not accommodate all shoes types and limits the styles of dance that can utilize the space to those with bare feet, cloth or leather dance shoes, and pointe shoes.  


The new floor we have selected will allow for more styles of dance be hosted at the Performance Garage including Tap, Flamenco, Hip Hop, and more!  It also is a great surface for dancing in bare feet, ballet and point shoes, and sneakers- a true miracle floor! We will be purchasing the floor from a local company called Stage Step, who for over 40 years has been providing innovative flooring solutions specifically for dance, theater, and performing arts spaces.
 

Impact

Your contribution will help the Performance Garage to further its mission and increase our sustainability.  This new floor will help us expand our roster of classes, serve more types of dance companies, and develop new audiences.

Thus far in our 2014-2015 season, we have hosted and provided support to:

  • 52 production rentals with 771 participating artists
  • 71 performances with over 5,000 audience members
  • 28 dance workshops with 380 attendees
  • 75 studio rentals for classes, auditions, and rehearsals
  • 25 weeks of free outreach classes for underserved youth

The new floor will increase the impact we will have our our dance community and allow us to expand our constituency.  Please donate today to help us get a new floor and be floored by the results!

Every Little Bit Makes a Difference

The Performance Garage Give 'n' Get Floored campaign is aimed at donors of all levels! Your contribution, in any amount, represents a show of support for the many dancers and choreographers who rely on the Performance Garage as a home for their artistic work. The individual support from donors like you helps our organization flourish with a sense of community and personal connection. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to give at this time, please help us spread the word! Find us on Facebook,Twitter,Instagram, or at www.performancegarage.org. Join our email newsletter to stay up to date on all of our offerings and special announcements, and come enjoy a performance or class in our space. We hope to see you soon at the Performance Garage!

THANK YOU

All of us here at the Performance Garage are extremely grateful for your support.  
All our best~
Jeanne, Judy, Melissa, Megan, Matt, our intern Sean, & the Board of Directors

story:
ACTING OUT INK FEST IS BACK!!!!

2Cents Theatre Group is kicking off 2015 with the 2nd Annual Acting Out INK Fest! Acting Out INK Fest was such a HUGE success last year, and we're thrilled to be doing it again! We have a group of nearly 100 artists, from playwrights to directors to actors to street artists to crew, all ecstatic to be a part of this celebration of the FEMALE PLAYWRIGHT! The Fest will take place April 17th-19th at the lovely Hudson Theatres in Hollywood, right in the heart of Theatre Row, encouraging the entire Hollywood artistic community to join us for this wonderful weekend of ART!

2Cents is a young non-profit theater company in Hollywood, fiscally partnered with Los Angeles Women's Theatre Project. The wonderful women of LAWTP initially inspired this venture, with their dedication to the often overlooked female playwright. We spend months reading submitted plays by women, and this year, we have a selection of 21 beautiful works, all SO incredibly unique and varied in subject, theme, characters, everything. Our collection of plays for INK Fest represents the female artist as versatile, unpredictable, and ultimately undefinable.

It takes massive support for an event like this to be a success. We need help to make this powerful undertaking a reality! We hope to continue to make an impact in the community with this Festival, expose these incredibly talented female playwrights, and inspire the community with an exquisite array of ART!

Any and all contributions are much appreciated, and necessary to fund this inspiring festival. Your donation will help us pay our crew, pay for the theatre rental, acquire and/or build set pieces, acquire all props and costumes, pay our publicist, throw a stellar opening night party and worthy closing night awards ceremony & gala for ALL the artists and audience, and produce merchandise for Festival goers. Every little bit counts! And to express our gratitude, we have put together some pretty awesome PERKS, including Fest passes, VIP packages, merchandise, food and drink discounts, 2Cents Season tickets, etc.

We understand of course it is not always possible to contribute, in which case you can still help us by spreading the word about Acting Out INK! Sharing this event on Facebook, twitter, telling your community about us in any way you can, is also greatly appreciated. Tickets are on sale at www.plays411.com/inkfest2015. We hope to see you at the Fest!

Please visit www.2centstheatre.com to learn more about 2Cents. Explore our past seasons, meet our Company Members and check out our Mission Statement. Join our email list, or ask us questions! We want to know what you think.

Thank you & enjoy the ART!

story:
What is Eastside Heartbeats?

"Eastside Heartbeats" uses an actual event, Cannibal and the Headhunters opening for the Beatles at the Hollywood Bowl in 1965, to tell the largely fictional story of a young man's dreams and the vibrant East LA music scene of the 1960s. The full-length, rock and roll musical features a book by Tom Waldman, co-author with David Reyes of "Land of a Thousand Dances: Chicano Rock and Roll from Southern California." The music is composed by hit 60's songwriter, James Holvay, best known for writing the hits for The Buckinghams ("Kind Of A Drag," "Don't You Care" etc.), Rudy Salas, a founding member of Tierra, known for their hit song, "Together," and the composer David Reyes. Waldman and Nancy Bianconi (producer of three Off Broadway musicals) are co-producers of the show, which is being presented by Casa 0101. The director is Corky Dominguez, who directed "Real Women Have Curves" which premiered at Casa 0101 Theatre. 

Why we are doing this project

"Eastside Heartbeats" is among the few musicals ever to portray the cultural life of East Los Angeles in the 1960s. It will open November 2015 for a six-week run at Casa 0101, a vibrant arts center in Boyle Heights.  "Eastside Heartbeats" will have its premiere in Boyle Heights. But that is only its first stop; after that, it will be heading to Off Broadway.  Here is your chance to cheer, remember, and dance once again to the Eastside Sound! "Eastside Heartbeats" is about us, the Mexican-American and Latino community of Los Angeles.  Let’s bring this great musical to the stage together!  “Juntos, no hay nada que no puédamos hacer.”  Wherever you grew up, you will know the sound. 

We Need Your Help

Play a part in bringing "Eastside Heartbeats" to the stage and to finally give credit to the East LA musicians and songwriters in the 1960s who founded the East LA sound.  YOU can make this happen.  The creative team have put in their money, time and energy; however, we need your help in completing the score and orchestration and lyrics and to cover the final costs of building the sets.

Impact 

"Eastside Heartbeats" will have its Los Angeles premiere at Casa 0101 in Nov/Dec 2015, which will be the beginning of its worldwide journey.  The producers have joined forces with New York theatre producer and theatre owner Edmund Gaynes, and are planning on opening "Eastside Heartbeats" in 2016 at Off Broadway's premiere St Luke Theatre (stlukestheatre.com).  After a successful run Off Broadway, "Eastside Heartbeats" will tour the United States through Gaynes Theatrical Booking (gaynestheatricalbooking.com). We know what comes after the Los Angeles premiere, but getting the show mounted is where we need your help.

Who's in our Team

Tom Waldman/Playwright and Producer:  Co-author of “Land of a Thousand Dances:  Chicano Rock and Roll from Southern California,” and the author of three other books about music or politics.  He served as associate producer on the 2008 PBS documentary “Chicano Rock:  The Sounds of East LA.”  Tom is currently host of the Telly-award winning series “Rock and Roll Stories” on KLCS-TV in Southern California. When he served as District Director for Congressman Howard Berman, Tom led the successful effort to get Ritchie Valens selected to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.  From 2011-2014, Tom was Director of Communications for the Los Angeles Unified School District, the second-largest school district in the United States. 

Nancy Bianconi/ Managing Producer:  For more than 30 years, Nancy  has consulted with charities, corporations and government in arts programming including producing festivals, concerts and theatrical events. She is President/CEO of NoHo Communications Group, Inc., an arts marketing firm which has consulted with hundreds of theaters and dance companies in New York and Los Angeles in the areas of marketing and general management.  Contracted by the City of Los Angeles Community Redevelopment Agency, Nancy successfully developed and marketed the NoHo Arts District into a cultural tourist and entertainment destination. Nancy has produced three Off Broadway plays which cumulatively ran for more than 3 years and toured to other cities.

CASA 0101/Fiscal Receiver:   In 2000, Casa 0101, a not for profit 501 C 3 organization was founded by Josefina Lopez, author of Real Women Have Curves to fulfill her vision of bringing art and live theater programs to the community she grew up in, Boyle Heights.  CASA 0101 operated for 11 years at its original location – a converted former bridal shop and in September of 2011, moved to its new home: a fully-equipped 99-seat theater featuring an art gallery and a dedicated classroom.  This space is only 1 block away from its original location – now renamed “Little Casa” – and both spaces are a part of CASA 0101. CASA 0101 is now a leading arts venue for Los Angeles’ East Side, presenting theatrical productions, special events and free/discounted arts classes for the community.  

Corky Dominguez/Director:  He directed the critical acclaimed production of Anna In The Tropics at Sierra Madre Playhouse, CASA 0101 Theater's 20-year anniversary production of Real Women Have Curves and productions at  The Inglewood Playhouse, Highways Performance Space, Beverly Hills Playhouse, Barnsdall Theatre, and the Ivar Theatre including the assistant director on several productions at Center Theatre Group.  He served as a director for the John Lion New Plays Festival, Company of Angels New Play Festival and Ojai Playwrights Conference.  His production of This Land was performed at Stramash ‘95, West Lothian, Scotland & the Cockpit Theater, London, England. Corky is a teaching artists at Inner-City Arts, Geffen Playhouse and Casa 0101. 

James Holvay/Composer and Lyricist: A Chicago native, James Holvay grew up listening to the great sounds of local soul music giants such as Jerry Butler, the Impressions, and Curtis Mayfield. When he was a teenager, James wrote two sides for Dee Clark; "I Can't Runaway and "She's My Baby." A few years later, James was hired as a guitarist for the Dick Clark Caravan of Stars. On the tours, he performed with such R&B stars as Wilson Pickett, the Supremes and the Four Tops. In 1967, James wrote four Top 10 hits for the Buckinghams. One of his compositions for the group, "Kind of a Drag," reached #1 and sold over one million copies. James subsequently formed his own band, the MOB, which were among the first of the rock bands to use horns. 

David Reyes/Composer & Lyricist/Music Director:  He developed an interest in modern classical music in the early 1970’s, and his fascination with the genre led him to study it seriously in college. Because of his dedication to the pursuit of modern classical music, Reyes was awarded a scholarship to study in Europe, where he had the privilege of studying and training with modern masters who changed the course of classical music: Iannis Xenakis and Gyorgy Ligeti at Centre Acante, the Darius Milhaud Conservatory in Aix en Provence, France. . In Los Angeles, he has worked with other influential composers: the late Dorrance Stalvey, musical Director of LACMA, and Aurelio De La Vega, faculty member emeritus at California State University, Northridge

Rudy Salas/Composer and Lyricist: Rudy Salas has been a mainstay in the East LA rock and roll scene since the 1960s. His career began in middle school, when he formed the Salas Brothers with his younger sibling, Steve. In 1971, Rudy and Steve launched Tierra, which soon after released the musically adventurous and politically-charged album of the same name. In 1980, Tierra's brilliant cover of the Intruders' song "Together" became a huge hit across the nation. As a result of that song's success, the band played a sold-out performance at Carnegie Hall. Through the decades, Rudy has written many of Tierra's singles and album tracks. Today, the group continues to perform numerous gigs throughout Southern California and beyond. 

Maria Elena/Resource Development Director:  An educator, writer, and community activist for the past thirty years, Maria Elena Yepes has dedicated her professional career to providing higher educational opportunities for the most underserved populations in Los Angeles. As a professor at East Los Angeles College, she has created several special academic programs and as a development professional has raised millions of dollars for the college's Learning Assistance Center which now serves 20,000 student per year.  She is a well respected community leader with strong ties to community organizations, foundations, government entities and local business. Maria Elena now wants to show the world the achievements of Latinos on Los Angeles' Eastside.

story:
We Need You! 

The Elevation Of Love is a ministry dedicated to illustrating the Love of God through dance. Typically you attend concerts that feature various recording artists, rappers, and musicians of the like, but rarely an evening showcasing the numerous amount of talent among dancers.

On April 30th, Director of EOL, Nikita Dore & Assistant Director, Sasha Blessed, will be featuring dancers from many ministries across the GTA, for a night of LIVE Dance, with a LIVE Audience, in our LIVE Recording; as we lift up the True Love of our life, "Jesus, the Christ." 

"For God so greatly loved and dearly prized the world that He [even] gave up His only begotten (unique) Son, so that whoever believes in (trusts in, clings to, relies on) Him shall not perish (come to destruction, be lost) but have eternal (everlasting) life." -John 3:16 (AMP)


What We Need & What You Get

$700 to help us:

  • Provide opportunities for emerging artists, entrepreneurs and ministries
  • Help us cover the cost of venue, DVD/live interview editing; 2-3 video cameras/operators;  a small honorarium for the professional volunteers
  • Elevation of love t-shirts for the volunteers as our "thank you"
  • Provide FREE ongoing advertising for participating vendors, with the potential of long term sponsorship for upcoming events

Please forward any questions, requests, and future volunteer opportunities to theelevationoflove@gmail.com

The Impact

Here's the difference your contribution will make:

  • Young people coming together from various walks of life for a night of fun, audience interaction, and food for the body & soul.
  • Successfully planned 2 (two) "Poetea" events, sponsored by the Gospel Cafe and other business ministries operated by young adults in the body of Christ
  • A refreshing way of building trust, and a sense of community among young adults 

Other Ways You Can Help

FACEBOOK, TWITTER, INSTAGRAM, YOU NAME IT! 

  • Spread the word about "THE ELEVATION OF LOVE" a dance exposition, here as well https://www.facebook.com/events/1073409189347359/
  • Purchase your advance tickets at  https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/the-love-encounter-tickets-21426520299

Thank you for your support in advance!
story_txt:
We Need You! The Elevation Of Love is a ministry dedicated to illustrating the Love of God through dance. Typically you attend concerts that feature various recording artists, rappers, and musicians of the like, but rarely an evening showcasing the numerous amount of talent among dancers.
On April 30th, Director of EOL, Nikita Dore & Assistant Director, Sasha Blessed, will be featuring dancers from many ministries across the GTA, for a night of LIVE Dance, with a LIVE Audience, in our LIVE Recording; as we lift up the True Love of our life, "Jesus, the Christ." 
"For God so greatly loved and dearly prized the world that He [even] gave up His only begotten (unique) Son, so that whoever believes in (trusts in, clings to, relies on) Him shall not perish (come to destruction, be lost) but have eternal (everlasting) life." -John 3:16 (AMP)


What We Need & What You Get
$700 to help us:


Provide opportunities for emerging artists, entrepreneurs and ministries

Help us cover the cost of venue, DVD/live interview editing; 2-3 video cameras/operators;  a small honorarium for the professional volunteers

Elevation of love t-shirts for the volunteers as our "thank you"
Provide FREE ongoing advertising for participating vendors, with the potential of long term sponsorship for upcoming events

Please forward any questions, requests, and future volunteer opportunities to theelevationoflove@gmail.com

    The Impact Here's the difference your contribution will make:  Young people coming together from various walks of life for a night of fun, audience interaction, and food for the body & soul. Successfully planned 2 (two) "Poetea" events, sponsored by the Gospel Cafe and other business ministries operated by young adults in the body of Christ
A refreshing way of building trust, and a sense of community among young adults 


    Other Ways You Can Help FACEBOOK, TWITTER, INSTAGRAM, YOU NAME IT!   Spread the word about "THE ELEVATION OF LOVE" a dance exposition, here as well https://www.facebook.com/events/1073409189347359/
 Purchase your advance tickets at  https://www.eventbrite.ca/e/the-love-encounter-tickets-21426520299
   Thank you for your support in advance!

story:
What's going on?

I'm Mike Iveson. You might know me from my play SORRY ROBOT at PS122's COIL Festival last year, or maybe you know me from my work with Elevator Repair Service, or maybe you know me and you don't even remember how or why and sometimes you wish that part of your mind would go quiet a while but here we are. 

I'm trying to raise $10,000 to pay for my show, a show with words and songs, called THE TEAR DRINKERS. It’s coming to The Kitchen in May of this year and it tells the extraordinary tale of four humans, kidnapped by the United States government and brought to an underground holding tank in New Mexico to determine which of them is actually an alien from another planet masquerading as an earthling. Compelling, timely stuff; I’m sure you’ll agree.

Through the generous support of The Kitchen and the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, THE TEAR DRINKERS has grown from a tiny brain seed into an oversize eggplant of a production, and that eggplant is now careening (ferociously, excitedly) toward a run of six shows in May this year.

photo by Talya Chalef from SORRY ROBOT, COIL Festival 2015

But what's really going on?

I need your help. And I need it for all the classic reasons: I have hired a number of excellent artists who really should be paid. The Kitchen has been extremely generous with me in giving me the space and time to workshop this piece for more than three years on and off, but as yet I don't have the funds in place to pay the performers in particular what they deserve. Which is where you come in. It's where you swoop in, like a flying squirrel riding a paper airplane that when it unfolds is a giant sign made out of a single Post-It note the size of a movie screen which says  TRYING T0 BE SUPPORTIVE OVER HERE...

I may have mentioned up above that I mounted the very first production of one of my plays last year. I mentioned that right? Uh huh well, it was called SORRY ROBOT and some beautiful people helped out. And other people noticed, and let their feelings be known: 

There was this guy, maybe you've heard of his little rag, who called the show “a gleeful, ramshackle tale”; this dude,  who hailed it as a "standout show”; and called out "performer Mike Iveson's auspicious playwriting debut", as well as this lady, who called the songwriting "singularly weirdo and so very wonderful" and this fellow as well, who set a bar to surpass with TEAR DRINKERS, saying SORRY ROBOT was "Iveson’s first attempt at playwriting—which is like talking about Lizzie Borden’s first attempt at wielding an axe, effective but a little messy.” 

That show was a success beyond my wildest dreams. (Sold out, and seats added to accommodate the clamoring masses.) It was about robots.

This one is about aliens.

You can see where this is going right.

If you didn't make it to SORRY ROBOT, no weird feelings. I want you to hear a live version of the song "Tears on the Treadmill" from that show here, and a live version of the song "Saturday Nights" also from that show here. They will give you a taste of what I am trying to do in my shows, including the new one—as will the video above, which is an excerpt of one of the new songs in THE TEAR DRINKERS.

Who we are

THE TEAR DRINKERS is written and composed by me, Mike Iveson, produced by Ariana Smart Truman, with scenic and costume design by Parker Lutz, video design by Charlie Atlas, and production stage management by Maurina Lioce. The cast includes April Armstrong, Anthony R. Brown, Don Castro, Sarah Ellen Stephens, Courtney Williams, and myself with piano by Gavin Price.

Any money you contribute will go toward paying these phenomenal people, some of whom have been with this project from the beginning. People who have stepped up, who are bringing their incredible minds and voices and bodies and who are working hard to make THE TEAR DRINKERS come to life.

THE TEAR DRINKERS work in progress showing at The Kitchen, July 2015

Wait but there's more

It’s an interesting conundrum I find myself in—The Kitchen, very awesomely, believes in what I'm doing and hence commissioned this work, and provides a few absolutely critical ingredients to mounting a production: rehearsal space, a bit of cash, marketing, advice, some personnel, and most of all a venue in which to perform. However, I am not set up as a producing entity all by my lonesome—I’m just a lone freak who wrote a freaky play and some songs, and is lucky enough to have an amazing circle of acquaintances who have agreed to come on this journey with me. But I have no established financial structure with which to put on plays—no grants, no history of having received grants, no funding streams. I don’t even have a trust fund. There was no way in Hades I was going to say no to the amazing opportunity The Kitchen gave me, but the reality is I need some more cash to make it all come together.

I was gobsmacked by the amazing support I received from people like you (maybe even actually you) when I was putting together SORRY ROBOT (which, to be honest, had even more institutional support than this project does). Donations of $25, of $50, of $100, of $500 came pouring in, and that enabled me to pay everyone, buy materials for a set, costumes, and even spring for beer and pizza on opening night.

The video up top, as I mentioned above, is an excerpt from one of the songs you can hear in THE TEAR DRINKERS. So do me a flavor and take a look at the perks, and then look deep into your heart, or whatever you have in place of a heart (no judgment), and make a decision.

***********                  

The Tear Drinkers is made possible with support from Jerome Foundation, Howard Gilman Foundation, The Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation, and in part by public funds from New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and New York State Council on the Arts with the support of Governor Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature. The Tear Drinkers was developed at residencies at The Kitchen and via Lower Manhattan Cultural Council's Process Space program. Many individuals contributed to make this project possible.

***********

TICKETS ARE NOW AVAILABLE HERE

About me

Mike Iveson is a performer, composer and 2013 Ethyl Eichelberger Award winner. He wrote the music for the plays: DOT, by Kate E. Ryan (Clubbed Thumb/Ohio Theatre), Potatoes of August, by Sibyl Kempson (Dixon Place, Red Eye Theater/MN), and You For Me For You, by Mia Chung (Woolly Mammoth), as well as Kempson’s Fondly, Collette Richland (New York Theater Workshop/Elevator Repair Service). He has also composed music for many of choreographer Sarah Michelson’s dances, including commissions for France’s Lyon Opera Ballet's Love Is Everything and for Mikhail Baryshnikov & the White Oak Dance Project's The Experts, as well as for many Michelson shows including Group Experience (PS122), for which he won a Bessie Award for music composition; Shadowmann (The Kitchen and PS122); Daylight (PS122); and Dogs (BAM). As a performer he has appeared in Elevator Repair Service’s Fondly, Collette Richland; Arguendo; The Select; The Sound and the Fury; and Gatz, in a number of Sarah Michelson’s dances, as well as shows by Richard Maxwell/NYC Players, New Georges, Dancenoise, Nature Theater of Oklahoma, Kate Benson, Tom Murrin/Jack Bump, Kristin Marting/HERE, Erin Courtney, Yvonne Meier,  Aaron Landsman, Mike Taylor, and many others.

About Charles Atlas

Charles Atlas is an artist and filmmaker who has been producing works since the mid-1970s, including media/dance works, multi-channel video installations, feature-length documentaries, video art works for television, and live electronic performances. Throughout his career, Atlas has collaborated with international performers and choreographers including Merce Cunningham, Douglas Dunn, Michael Clark, Leigh Bowery, Marina Abramovic, DANCENOISE, Yvonne Rainer, and Anohni.

About The Kitchen

The Kitchen is one of New York City’s oldest nonprofit spaces, showing innovative work by emerging and established artists across disciplines. Our programs range from dance, music, performance, and theater, to video, film, and art, in addition to literary events, artists’ talks, and lecture series. Since its inception, The Kitchen has been a powerful force in shaping the cultural landscape of this country, and has helped launch the careers of many artists who have gone on to worldwide prominence.

story:
Innovation Dance

Innovation Dance Studios was founded five years ago by Emma Hardy and Zoe Newell, and it now provides classes to children and adults from studios in Ealing, Finchley and Colindale, plus over fifty weekly outreach classes based in schools and community centres.
The Ealing studio in Pitshanger Lane is currently full to capacity, with classes being provided in hired halls in addition to the main studio, and some children still on waiting lists. Due to space availability, the hired venues are in different parts of Ealing, and not always convenient for parents and children.
We have the opportunity to have a second full-time studio on the same road as our existing one, but this would need building from scratch. 
Help us to create a brand new, purpose built studio for the local community of Pitshanger in Ealing. This will allow hundreds more children to be able to come to class, and to learn in a safe, local environment.
 
What We Need
 

The cost of leasing the building and building the studio from scratch is £150,000. We can provide the majority of the funding but are looking for the final £15,000 for the finishing touches to make the dancers have the right sound equipment, A/C, flooring and and teaching tools.

Its sounds like a huge amount, but building a creative space is pretty expensive. Some of the costs are:

Dance Flooring, Mirrors, Barres, Sound System, Air Conditioning, Sound Proofing, Signage, Build Fees, Phone and Internet Installation, Changing Room Benches, Furniture, Marketing and Office Equipment

    The Impact

    The new studio will allow hundreds more children to attend class in a professional environment. It would mean we can take classes out of church halls, which don't have specialist flooring, air conditioning and mirrors, and into a proper studio environment. 
    It would also allow us to open a new range of classes, including break dance, contemporary and GCSE Dance, which we currently can't fit into our existing studio space, giving a much broader range of opportunities for the local children. 
    We will also be able to provide more adult classes, covering different dance styles which are currently frequently requested, such as ballroom, salsa and jazz.
    Our current Ealing studio is a great community space for adults and children to come together and learn - children have the opportunity to perform in annual theatre productions and at local community events, and to enter examinations to gain valuable qualifications. The studio has a lovely family environment, and we would like to re-create the same fun, friendly feel just down the road!
    More space would also allow us to provide affordable studio space to hire for dance companies and artists, which can be difficult to find in London at the right price.

     

    Thank You!

    We want to say a big thank you to everyone who is able to contribute to in any way they can with a range of perks - from merchandise to free classes to one-on-one private lessons. This would not be possible without you, and we want to make sure everyone knows how much we appreciate their help.

     

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Please help us spread the word about our new studio!! We really appreciate every share, post and phone call made on our behalf! 

      http://www.innovationdancestudios.co.uk

story:
Hysterika Jazz Dance

Barbara Angeline is the Founder and Artistic Director of Hysterika Jazz Dance.  HJD is a jazz dance company dedicated to sharing the legacy of jazz dance as an American art form with a rich and compelling history. The company draws historical inspiration  from iconic jazz contributors in order to craft a unique impact on jazz dance in the present day.

Hysterika Jazz Dance was founded to support feminist jazz dance explorations. In addition, dancers from the company are drawn from recent dance major alumni. Barbara Angeline is committed to empowering her dancers as women and helping them make the transition from the relatively structured, safe environment of the dance department to the expressive risk-taking and ownership of professional concert dance.

OUR NEXT PROJECT...

eat Crow explores the relative idea of "freedom" in the 1920s, through the eyes and inspiration of Josephine Baker. This historical collaboration with the iconic Baker and 1920s jazz dance illuminates the kinesthetic and social experiences of black and white performers of that era. In Harlem dance clubs, all-black revues and all-black Broadway shows--such as the ground-breaking "Shuffle Along"--black dancers had loose, wildly sensual, unrestricted "Freedom of Body" but severely limited space to advance in the world. On Broadway stages and off, white dancers had literal and figurative "Freedom of World" but were relatively restrained in body movement, even in the "Roaring 20s". These ideas were used as a structure to frame our exploration of Josephine Baker's wild exhibitionism; her unpredictable mix of sensuality, comedy and loose-limbed dance; her unquenchable quest for love and the "home" that she found in the amusement, adoration and attention of black and white audiences.

To learn more please visit www.barbaraangeline.com

What We Need 

Hysterika Jazz Dance is excited to announce two New York City projects/performances and your help is needed! 

  • On February 20, HJD premiered a solo work for the Artists in Flight Performance Showcase at the TADA! Youth Theater in New York.
  • April 9 and 10 - HJD will perform "eat Crow" as part of the New York Jazz Choreography Project @ Salvatore Capezio Theater. 
Time, space and materials are required to create new works, and Ms. Angeline is committed to paying all artists involved for their dedication to the craft. All money raised will directly fund dancers, studio space, costumes, production fees and other costs associated with future performance opportunities in order to keep the mission of HJD alive. 

The Impact

By supporting Hysterika Jazz Dance, you are supporting the arts community at large, including:

  • An emerging jazz dance company based in New York 
  • A choreographer's voice to be heard
  • Dancers at the start of their professional career
  • The preservation of a historical dance genre

Other Ways You Can Help

Hysterika Jazz Dance understands that it is not possible for everyone to make a monetary contribution, but there are other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word about our campaign! Share the link via Facebook, email, etc.
  • Like our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/hysterikajazzdance to stay updated on future happenings.
  • Come see us perform - bring your friends and family!

story:
Welcome to ACT Aberdeen's crowdfunding page for our amateur production of Cabaret! Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and (hopefully) supporting this wonderful show!

Introduction

Cabaret is set in a glamourous yet seedy nightclub in 1930s Germany as the Nazi party begins its rise to power. Acting as an allegory about the way people become bystanders and ignore the evil going on around them, the show explores how quickly, and with such little resistance, Berlin became unsafe for the Jewish and homosexual communities. This is represented by the struggle of many of the performers and guests at the fictional Kit Kat Klub within the show.

We see this show as a perfect way to mark and reflect on a monumental anniversary and act as a clear call to action in the present; focusing on the contemporary relevance of the Holocaust and subsequent genocides, and considering our individual responsibilities not to be bystanders to hate crime and prejudice.

Our vision for Cabaret is to create an immersive piece of theatre that defies convention and will blur the lines between performance and spectator. We hope to give the audience an experience that feels more like they are entering a real life cabaret in 1930’s Germany, rather than an evening at the theatre. This will be the first time we have attempted a production on this scale in our 50 year history.

What You Get

We have a range of perks on offer for supporters, including exclusive first night tickets, which are not available anywhere else, and invitations to our first night party.

About Us

ACT Aberdeen is a charity which provides facilities, expertise, training and support, enabling the people of Aberdeen to experience and participate in performing arts at

all levels. We believe in the power of the arts to change and enrich lives, and we believe everyone should have the opportunity to access and take part in high quality arts experiences. Our aims are to:

  • To provide a distinctive cultural offer with diversity, engagement and accessibility at our core.
  • To champion, support and celebrate local talent.
  • To increase and develop audiences and users.
  • To provide opportunities for learning at all levels.
  • To create the best possible physical environment for the creation, presentation, participation and enjoyment of the arts, one that is accessible, sustainable and at the heart of the community.

More than 100,000 people pass through ACT Aberdeen's doors each year, with over 40 professional, amateur and youth companies relying on us as the only mid-scale theatre venue in the North East of Scotland.  
About the Production

From the moment audience members pass through the front doors of the building, they will be immediately transported into the world of 1930’s Berlin and the Kit Kat Klub.
To commemorate Holocaust Memorial Day in 2016 ACT Aberdeen are producing a unique event, of which Cabaret, the musical, will be the centrepiece. Based on John Van Druten's play ‘I Am a Camera’, adapted from Christopher Isherwood’s short novel ‘Goodbye to Berlin’, ‘Cabaret’ is set in early 1930s Berlin as the Nazis are rising to power. The seedy Kit Kat Club is at the centre of the action, and features 19-year-old English cabaret performer Sally Bowles and her relationship with young American writer Cliff Bradshaw.

A sub-plot involves a doomed romance between German boarding house owner Fräulein Schneider and a Jewish fruit vendor Herr Schultz. The Master of Ceremonies at the Kit Kat Klub oversees the action, and the club serves as a metaphor for ominous political developments in late Weimar Germany.

The venue will be transformed to look like a nightclub with a 1930s style burlesque and entertainment during the interval, and before and after the performance. To counterpoint the lighter entertainment of the musical and burlesque offerings, our exhibitions spaces will host an experiential journey of life in the concentration camps, giving participants a vivid impression of the suffering of those who perished in the Nazi gas chambers. The exhibition will take people on a journey from the Nazi holocaust through the fifteen confirmed acts of mass genocide since the end of World War Two, drawing attention to the fact that, to this day, acts of mass murder by states are still continuing, despite a United Nations vow, in 1945, that they must never occur again.

ACT Aberdeen is working with the award winning, London based team of David Adkin and Derek Anderson in order to stage this amateur production. David is a theatre producer whose shows have been seen in both London’s West End and Internationally. Derek is a theatre director and designer originally from Aberdeen, who started his theatre career with us at ACT Aberdeen  at the age of 15. Together, they created the sell-out and critically acclaimed production of Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street in London starring David Bedella. The show was the inaugural production at the Twickenham Theatre and was the Winner of the Best Off-West End Production and nominated for Best Musical Revival at the 2015 Whatsonstage Awards.

Risks & Challenges

This is an ambitious amateur production for ACT Aberdeen and demonstrates our desire to create truly different and exciting theatrical productions in Aberdeen. Risks will be mitigated by working with an experienced Director and Producer, as well as a superb cast and our talented in house production team.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help financially at this time, there are other ways you can support ACT Aberdeen:
  • Help us spread the word by telling your friends about us.
  • Like our page on Facebook. 
  • Follow us on Twitter to receive updates and follow all of the exciting events happening in the company.
  • Volunteer! Visit http://www.act-aberdeen.org.uk/volunteering to find out more information.
story_txt:
Welcome to ACT Aberdeen's crowdfunding page for our amateur production of
Cabaret! Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and (hopefully)
supporting this wonderful show!

Introduction
Cabaret is set in a
glamourous yet seedy nightclub in 1930s Germany as the Nazi party begins its
rise to power. Acting as an allegory about the way people become bystanders and
ignore the evil going on around them, the show explores how quickly, and with
such little resistance, Berlin became unsafe for the Jewish and homosexual
communities. This is represented by the struggle of many of the performers and
guests at the fictional Kit Kat Klub within the show.

We see this show
as a perfect way to mark and reflect on a monumental anniversary and act as a
clear call to action in the present; focusing on the contemporary relevance of
the Holocaust and subsequent genocides, and considering our individual
responsibilities not to be bystanders to hate crime and prejudice.

Our vision for Cabaret
is to create an immersive piece of theatre that defies convention and will blur the lines between performance and
spectator. We hope to give the audience an experience that feels more like they
are entering a real life cabaret in 1930’s Germany, rather than an evening at
the theatre. This will be the first time we
have attempted
a production on this scale in our 50 year history.
What You GetWe have a range of perks on offer for supporters,
     including exclusive first night tickets, which are not available anywhere
     else, and invitations to our first night party.

story:
Hi my name is Ana Laidley.  I am a Brazilian Samba Instructor and Founder of the Samba N' Motion and Malandro N' Motion (MNM) groups, based in Los Angeles.  I have been in the USA for 23 years and I have created, participated, and promoted several cultural events.  I have taught samba in several states in the US as well as abroad in places such as in Japan, Australia, Mexico, and Canada. 

On October 2015, MNM assisted one of the founders of Gafieira Brasil, Rodrigo Marques, in coming to USA as a special guest instructor for the National Samba King and Queen Contest in Arizona, when he offered to dance with our group and extended an invitation for the group to participate in the biggest Gafieira (Samba) event in Rio de Janeiro on March 2016.  Gafieira Brasil involves training, Gafieira Contest, and great entertainment with the most qualified group of Brazilian artists.   It an event that received over 3000 people this year and will have live transmission worldwide.  There will have 8 Samba workshops, 1 conference with Carlinhos de Jesus, and a great performance.

It is a honor to be part of this great event and this is an exceptional opportunity for the members of MNM to expand their knowledge, techniques and immerse in to the Brazilian Culture! 

We are very aware that without your contribution, we will not be able to achieve our goals.  We need to have funds to pay for our airlines tickets to go to Brazil.  We will also be studying with the greatest names in Samba in Rio de Janeiro, better saying Brazil.  Our trip will represent a change in the level of SAMBA performances outside of Brazil.  

Additionally, we will have an opportunity to create an alliance with important key people who are directly connected with social, community based youth programs and we will not only learn from them but create a life time connection where we will be able to provide support on a more regular basis. 

I am very excited that my group is having this opportunity to expand and grow and become connected with the roots of Samba in Brazil. But, I am more excited about the opportunity of the exchange and continuous partnership that we are creating with the Family of Gafieira Brasil.   The trip is on March 21-31, 2016...

If you cannot contribute financially, you still can help us by sharing, promoting, and inviting your friends to contribute. 

Samba is about Community and we are trying to make our community stronger and powerful!

story:
I'm Sorry I'll Read That Again... AGAIN!

The seminal BBC Radio classic comedy, spawning The Goodies and Monty Python's Flying Circus and, most importantly, the forerunner to I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue, has been somewhat neglected in the pantheon of '60s and '70s radio comedy goodness. We aim to put this right, with YOUR help!

Starring John Cleese, Graeme Garden, Bill Oddie, Tim Brooke-Taylor, David Hatch and Jo Kendall, this mix of anarchic madness, silly puns, catchphrases galore and gloriously manic characters ran from 1964 to 1973 and had a youth following that made live recordings seem more like a rock concert than a comedy show. It was immediate and fresh and energetic.

By crowdfunding our production, we aim to bring a 'Best Of' package together in one LIVE theatre show in February next year. All we're asking from you is to help raise our production budget, in order to adapt, rehearse and stage this unique show. We'll be donating all the profits to the charities put forward by writers Graeme Garden and Bill Oddie.

We are The OFFSTAGE Theatre Group and have been running from our base in Gloucestershire since 1991. We've won the odd award, toured the 'classics' and premiered a lot of original work, all of which have been highly-acclaimed. We pride ourselves on having a close-knit team of creatives that we call on when we have a special project to do, such as this. Our version of this classic comedy will feature a new team of comic actors who won't be doing slavish impersonations but 'archetypes' of the roles inhabited by the original cast. It's the buzzing of energy and barrage of jokes that we aim to astound the audience with.

We're very humbled to have been granted exclusive rights for this one-off show by ISIRTA's original writers, Graeme Garden and Bill Oddie. We're also very excited to be working alongside the legend that is Dirk Maggs (multi-talented writer/director/producer/musician/bearded wonder), who will be adapting, directing and producing alongside our very own walking chinbeard, Barnaby Eaton-Jones; as well as Andrew Farrington as Musical Director and Band Leader.

The charities that Graeme Garden and Bill Oddie have chosen to benefit from this one-off production are ENRYCH and The League Against Cruel Sports.

Our budget might seem like a lot for a one-off production but here's a little run-down of what this professional production has to pay for...

  • Cost of Venue Hire; Performance (The Bacon Theatre, Cheltenham)
  • Cost of Venue Hire; Technical Rehearsal (The Bacon Theatre, Cheltenham)
  • Cost of Adapting The Script (from 9 series and one 25th anniversary special)
  • Cost of Rehearsal Space (musical and staging separately and then together)
  • Cost of Professional Musicians (a 5-Piece Band)
  • Cost of Professional Actors (5, in total)
  • Cost of Graphic Designer/Artist (posters and artwork)
  • Cost of Set Building (construction and materials)
  • Cost of Copyright Percentage (allowing us to perform this work)
  • Cost of Costumes (actors and musicians)
  • Cost of Live Foley (sound effects props and technician)
  • Cost of extra Sound Equipment for venue (mics, etc)
  • Cost of Public Liability Insurance (one-off, as requested by the venue)
  • Cost of Publicity (posters, flyers, programmes, etc)
  • Cost of Producer/Director fees

By helping us fund this original 'Best Of' stage show, you'll also be ploughing money into two very worthwhile charities. We've tried our best to provide some interesting and fascinating 'perks' that you can buy as a donation. We hope you'll be excited by them. If not, you're always welcome to add a donation just to help see this happen!

This unique production will be performed at
The Bacon Theatre in Cheltenham
on Friday 19th February 2016.

Tickets are on sale NOW via this link...
https://bacontheatre.ticketsolve.com/#/shows/873543607

Please share this page, using the links down the side to your left (Facebook, Twitter, Google+, etc), and see if we can bring this slice of radio magic alive on stage with the sort of madcap style that the original ISIRTA gang were so brilliant at. Thank you.

All images used are (c) BBC and no infringement is intended.
Video created by Nicholas Holland,
with grateful thanks to
Tim Brooke-Taylor, Dirk Maggs, Jem Roberts, Graeme Garden and Bill Oddie.
Artwork by Gary Andrews
Poster Design by Colin Brockhurst

story:
Well Seasoned Productions is a new Canadian entertainment company with a difference!

OUR MANDATE….

We create works that are focused on the joys, challenges and celebration of life over 50 and better.

MISSION STATEMENT….

  • To promote the work of Canadian Theatre Artists who are aged fifty and better.
  • To provide work opportunities so that senior entertainment professionals can enjoy career longevity and sustainability.
  • To inspire, celebrate and promote the vibrant contributions of our senior population.
  • To network with other organizations, creating a strong and united Canadian identity for all artists.

Well Seasoned Productions will enrich our audiences by providing them with a much needed reflection of themselves while shedding light on the issues and emotions pertinent to them. Our performances will empower them to embrace this great stage of their life - to make the most of it, knowing they are not alone and still appreciated as a vibrant and contributing member of our society.

And finally, Well Seasoned Productions will give younger artists a place to grow into. Our senior artists have great stories to tell from their unique perspective; stories that need to be heard. Well Seasoned Productions will fill this current theatrical void and provide opportunities for these great performers to entertain, inspire, and change the perspective of ageing. 

Explore our website: http://www.wellseasonedproductions.ca/ 

Our Plan

We'll begin our new and innovative direction with a series of cabarets called The Act II Revue in 2016, showcasing the WSP team with a bevy of guest performers. 

Our long range goal is to raise “seed money” for our large scale project for 2018 – an original book musical written, designed, and performed by Senior Artists.

We are fundraising to cover the costs of our launch. Your contributions will go toward:

Marketing

Public Relations

Legal costs

Graphic and Web Site Design

Social Media

Production Costs (musical arrangements, rehearsal space, design, etc.)


We cordially invite you to join us for the launch of our new company, Well Seasoned Productions. We'll have some well-seasoned performers to entertain a bit, door prizes, and lots of time to let you know our plans for the company and how you can be a part of it. 

DATE: Monday November 30th, 2015

TIME: 7:30 to 10:30 pm (Doors open at 7:00 pm)

LOCATION: Paint Box Bistro, 555 Dundas Street East, Toronto (at Sackville St.)

TICKETS: $20.00. You can book online by clicking here.

GETTING THERE: There is an underground parking lot or street meter parking. TTC access via the Dundas street car. The Paint Box is a fully accessible space. 

Hosted by Mark Cassius and Scott Walker, the Party will feature some exciting Special Guests plus a bevy of well seasoned performers.

Your ticket includes a complimentary glass of wine or beer.  The Paintbox Bistro bar snack menu will be available plus a cash bar featuring a signature Well Seasoned Cocktail.

We look forward to seeing you there!

Sincerely,

Bob Ashley, Lesley Ballantyne, Mark Cassius, Susan Gattoni, and Anne Wootten

A team of five musical theatre artists who are over 50, with a collective career experience of 200 years in the entertainment industry!  Our Well Seasoned Production team members are Bob Ashley, Lesley Ballantyne, Mark Cassius, Susan Gattoni and Anne Wootten.  We are united in our passion for musical theatre and are committed to showcasing not just our talents, but those of our brilliant colleagues who are still creating in this new and exciting time in their lives. 

Bob Ashley

Bob has over 40 years of experience working with vocalists in many styles from classical, theatre, jazz and pop as a Composer, Musical Director and Vocal Coach. He has been on the faculty at The Randolph Academy, Sheridan College Musical Theatre Programs and The Cardinal Carter Academy For The Arts. Also, he has been Musical Director and Pianist for well over 50 professional musical theatre productions for most of the major theatres and producers in Canada. He is a Dora Mavor Moore Award recipient for his musical direction of “Piaf - Her Work, Her Loves.” As a Composer Bob has 6 professional productions to his credit. IIn addition, he has extensive experience as a Ballet Pianist for The National Ballet of Canada, Dance Teq, Ryerson University, The Banff Centre and is currently a member of the Artistic Staff at Canada's National Ballet School. 

Lesley Ballantyne

Lesley celebrates forty years in the Canadian entertainment business this year. Her talents have allowed her to work as a Director, Choreographer, Performer, Producer, Teacher, and Arts Administrator.  Her peripatetic career has taken her across Canada, parts of the US, and as far south as the Bahamas. She is a proud Dora Mavor Moore Award winner and a Jessie Richardson Award nominee. Lesley is a past Artistic Director of the Muskoka Festival Theatre (theatres in Gravenhurst, Port Carling, and Huntsville ON) where she directed and choreographed many of the Festival’s main-stage and touring productions – many of them original Canadian musicals. She has experienced the joys of both performing and directing & choreographing shows in a range of theatres from small storefront locations to the National Arts Centre in Ottawa.  Recent projects include: Project Manager, The Siminovitch Prize; Co-producer, World AIDS Day Concert; Director, Put Up Your Hand; Director, Brundibar; Co-Producer Confessions of an Operatic Mute. 

herculeaneffort.ca

Mark Cassius 

Mark is a graduate of Sheridan College's Music Theatre Program, he has been featured on Broadway in Jesus Christ Superstar, Ragtime, and Shenandoah. He most recently starred in the Toronto Premiere of the Off-Broadway Musical, The Musical of Musicals. Other credits include: Cats, The Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber in Concert, Joseph and the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat (with Donny Osmond), Miss Saigon, and Showboat. He has performed at both  the Shaw Festival and the Stratford Shakespeare Festival. Mark spent eight years touring with the  world-renowned acappella group, The Nylons. Since leaving the group in 2005 he has been working with many aspiring professionals, instructing them in the disciplines of Music and Theatre. His work as a Music Producer, Director, Writer and Teacher continues to inspire those in pursuit of creative excellence.

markcassius.com

Susan Gattoni

Susan Gattoni has had an esteemed career as one of Canada’s top musical theatre performers. She was in the original Canadian casts of such mega-hits as; CATS (Bombalurina), Crazy for You (Patsy), Sunset Blvd. with Dianne Carroll and the North American tour of Joseph & the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat with Donny Osmond. She was selected to be part of the U.S. Company of Ragtime (Chicago), performed in L.A. & San Francisco in Durante and worked with Tony Award winners Trevor Nunn, Frank Galati, Bob Avian & Susan Stroman. Her starring roles include Cassie (3 productions of A Chorus Line), Anita (West Side Story), Lina Lamont (Singing in the Rain), Kathy (Company) & Audrey (Little Shop of Horrors). Film & T.V. credits: Videodrome, Alfred Hitchcock Presents, The Hearst & Davies Affair, The Last Greatest Vaudeville Show with Donald O’Connor & Debbie Reynolds, CBC’s Side Effects, and numerous variety T.V. shows & specials. Also respected as a choreographer, her work has been seen in many productions, commercials and industrials. 

Anne Wootten

Anne Wootten is a director and choreographer whose career spans theatre, film, television and special events. Her credits include directing everything from one person shows to world premieres of new musicals, from regional theatre to dance sequences in feature films. She spent eight seasons at the Stratford Festival as consulting director/choreographer on productions such as The Mikado, Gypsy, and Carousel.  She was Artistic Director of Reprise Concerts, directing and co-producing its productions of Company, Guys and Dolls and Anything Goes at the St. Lawrence Centre. Anne created the dance scenes for Bette Midler in That Old Feeling, for Brian Dennehy and Chris Farley in Tommy Boy, and for Penelope Ann Miller and Matthew Broderick in The Freshman, which also starred Marlon Brando.

Anne Wootten & Associates is her most recent creation, a company that provides seminars and workshops on how to perfect a professional business image and social awareness for corporate and individual clients. 

www.annewootten.com

“I fully support WELL SEASONED PRODUCTIONS. I have been performing onstage for over 50 years now and I truly believe I am just getting the hang of it! The idea of a platform for all of us to keep doing what we love and entertaining audiences is a stunning idea. I hope I can play a role in this fabulous idea. We may be getting a little older but that just means we are getting better.”
  • Sheila Mccarthy, Performer

“I am pleased to be able to work with five truly well seasoned professional performers. Their dedication, experience and enthusiasm take them far along their new and exciting path. We all look forward to their opening night!”

  • Dr. Joseph Green, Professor Emeritus, York University, and Mentor for Well Seasoned Productions. 

“CSARN commends Well Seasoned Productions for its mandate to create work [and works] for older performers. Canada has a rich legacy of artists who have devoted their lives to enriching our country. But, as they age, there are fewer opportunities to work and display their virtuosity. As an organization whose mission is to help Canada’s senior professional artists, CSARN believes Well Seasoned Productions should be assisted and encouraged in every way possible.”

  •  Scott Walker, Executive Director, Canadian Senior Artists’ Resource Network  
Other Ways You Can Help

Do you have any of the skills we need to help us get Well Seasoned Productions moving along? We are looking for well seasoned expertise in the following areas:

Marketing 

Public Relations 

Legal Council

Graphic and Web Design

Social Media

OUR MANDATE….
We create works that are focused on the joys, challenges and
celebration of life over 50 and better.


MISSION STATEMENT….

To promote the work of
     Canadian Theatre Artists who are aged fifty and better.
To provide work
     opportunities so that senior entertainment professionals can enjoy career longevity
     and sustainability.
To inspire, celebrate and
     promote the vibrant contributions of our senior population.
To network with other
     organizations, creating a strong and united Canadian identity for all
     artists.

Well Seasoned Productions will enrich our audiences by
providing them with a much needed reflection of themselves while shedding light
on the issues and emotions pertinent to them. Our performances will empower
them to embrace this great stage of their life - to make the most of it,
knowing they are not alone and still appreciated as a vibrant and contributing
member of our society.
And finally, Well Seasoned Productions will give younger artists a place to grow
into. Our senior artists have great stories to tell from their unique
perspective; stories that need to be heard. Well Seasoned Productions will fill
this current theatrical void and provide opportunities for these great
performers to entertain, inspire, and change the perspective of ageing. 
Explore our website: http://www.wellseasonedproductions.ca/ 
Our Plan
We'll begin our new and innovative direction with a series of cabarets called The Act II Revue in 2016, showcasing the WSP team with a bevy of guest performers. 
Our long range goal is to raise “seed money” for our large scale project for 2018 – an original book musical written, designed, and performed by Senior Artists.
We are fundraising to cover the costs of our launch. Your contributions will go toward:
Marketing
Public Relations
Legal costs
Graphic and Web Site Design
Social Media
Production Costs (musical arrangements, rehearsal space, design, etc.)


We cordially invite you to join us for the launch of our new company, Well Seasoned Productions. We'll have some well-seasoned performers to entertain a bit, door prizes, and lots of time to let you know our plans for the company and how you can be a part of it. 
DATE: Monday November 30th, 2015
TIME: 7:30 to 10:30 pm (Doors open at 7:00 pm)
LOCATION: Paint Box Bistro, 555 Dundas Street East, Toronto (at Sackville St.)
TICKETS: $20.00. You can book online by clicking here.
GETTING THERE: There is an underground parking lot or street meter parking. TTC access via the Dundas street car. The Paint Box is a fully accessible space. 
Hosted by Mark Cassius and Scott Walker, the Party will feature some exciting Special Guests plus a bevy of well seasoned performers.
Your ticket includes a complimentary glass of wine or beer.  The Paintbox Bistro bar snack menu will be available plus a cash bar featuring a signature Well Seasoned Cocktail.
We look forward to seeing you there!
Sincerely,
Bob Ashley, Lesley Ballantyne, Mark Cassius, Susan Gattoni, and Anne Wootten

A team of five musical theatre artists who are over 50, with a collective career experience of 200 years in the entertainment industry!  Our Well Seasoned Production team members are Bob Ashley, Lesley Ballantyne, Mark Cassius, Susan Gattoni and Anne Wootten.  We are united in our passion for musical theatre and are committed to showcasing not just our talents, but those of our brilliant colleagues who are still creating in this new and exciting time in their lives. 





Bob Ashley


Bob has over 40 years of experience working with vocalists in many
styles from classical, theatre, jazz and pop as a Composer, Musical
Director and Vocal Coach. He has been on the faculty at The Randolph
Academy, Sheridan College Musical Theatre Programs and The Cardinal
Carter Academy For The Arts. Also, he has been Musical Director and
Pianist for well over 50 professional musical theatre productions for
most of the major theatres and producers in Canada. He is a Dora Mavor
Moore Award recipient for his musical direction of “Piaf - Her Work,
Her Loves.” As a Composer Bob has 6 professional productions to his
credit. IIn addition, he has extensive experience as a Ballet Pianist for
The National Ballet of Canada, Dance Teq, Ryerson University, The
Banff Centre and is currently a member of the Artistic Staff at Canada's
National Ballet School. 




Lesley Ballantyne




Lesley celebrates forty years in the Canadian entertainment
business this year. Her talents have allowed her to work as a Director,
Choreographer, Performer, Producer, Teacher, and Arts Administrator.  Her peripatetic career has taken her across
Canada, parts of the US, and as far south as the Bahamas. She is a proud Dora
Mavor Moore Award winner and a Jessie Richardson Award nominee. Lesley is a past Artistic
Director of the Muskoka Festival Theatre (theatres in Gravenhurst, Port Carling,
and Huntsville ON) where she directed and choreographed many of the Festival’s
main-stage and touring productions – many of them original Canadian musicals.
She has experienced the joys of both performing and directing &
choreographing shows in a range of theatres from small storefront locations to
the National Arts Centre in Ottawa.  Recent
projects include: Project Manager, The
Siminovitch Prize; Co-producer, World
AIDS Day Concert; Director, Put Up
Your Hand; Director, Brundibar;
Co-Producer Confessions of an Operatic
Mute. 
herculeaneffort.ca

Mark Cassius 
















Mark is a graduate of Sheridan College's Music Theatre Program, he has been featured on Broadway in Jesus Christ Superstar, Ragtime, and Shenandoah. He most recently starred in the Toronto Premiere of the Off-Broadway Musical, The Musical of Musicals. Other credits include: Cats, The Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber in Concert, Joseph and the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat (with Donny Osmond), Miss Saigon, and Showboat. He has performed at both  the Shaw Festival and the Stratford Shakespeare Festival. Mark spent eight years touring with the  world-renowned acappella group, The Nylons. Since leaving the group in 2005 he has been working with many aspiring professionals, instructing them in the disciplines of Music and Theatre. His work as a Music Producer, Director, Writer and Teacher continues to inspire those in pursuit of creative excellence.
markcassius.com








Susan Gattoni




Susan
Gattoni has had an esteemed career as one of Canada’s top musical theatre
performers. She was in the original Canadian casts of such mega-hits as; CATS (Bombalurina), Crazy for You (Patsy), Sunset
Blvd. with Dianne Carroll and the North American tour of Joseph & the Amazing Technicolour
Dreamcoat with Donny Osmond. She was selected to be part of the U.S. Company
of Ragtime (Chicago), performed in L.A.
& San Francisco in Durante and
worked with Tony Award winners Trevor Nunn, Frank Galati, Bob Avian & Susan
Stroman. Her starring roles include Cassie
(3 productions of A Chorus Line),
Anita (West Side Story), Lina Lamont
(Singing in the Rain), Kathy (Company) & Audrey (Little Shop of Horrors). Film & T.V.
credits: Videodrome, Alfred Hitchcock
Presents, The Hearst & Davies Affair, The Last Greatest Vaudeville Show with
Donald O’Connor & Debbie Reynolds, CBC’s Side Effects, and numerous variety T.V. shows & specials. Also
respected as a choreographer, her work has been seen in many productions,
commercials and industrials. 

Anne Wootten




Anne
Wootten is a director and choreographer whose career spans theatre, film, television
and special events. Her credits include directing everything from one person
shows to world premieres of new musicals, from regional theatre to dance
sequences in feature films. She spent eight seasons at the Stratford Festival
as consulting director/choreographer on productions such as The Mikado, Gypsy, and Carousel.  She was Artistic Director of Reprise Concerts,
directing and co-producing its productions of Company, Guys and Dolls and Anything
Goes at the St. Lawrence Centre. Anne created the dance scenes for Bette
Midler in That Old Feeling, for Brian
Dennehy and Chris Farley in Tommy Boy, and for Penelope Ann Miller and Matthew
Broderick in The Freshman, which
also starred Marlon Brando. 
Anne
Wootten & Associates is her most recent creation, a company that provides
seminars and workshops on how to perfect a professional business image and social
awareness for corporate and individual clients. 
www.annewootten.com

“I fully support WELL
SEASONED PRODUCTIONS. I have been performing onstage for over 50 years now and
I truly believe I am just getting the hang of it! The idea of a platform for
all of us to keep doing what we love and entertaining audiences is a stunning
idea. I hope I can play a role in this fabulous idea. We may be getting a
little older but that just means we are getting better.” 

Sheila Mccarthy, Performer

“I am pleased to be
able to work with five truly well seasoned professional performers. Their
dedication, experience and enthusiasm take them far along their new and
exciting path. We all look forward to their opening night!”

Dr. Joseph Green, Professor Emeritus, York University, and
Mentor for Well Seasoned Productions. 

“CSARN commends Well
Seasoned Productions for its mandate to create work [and works] for older
performers. Canada has a rich legacy of artists who have devoted their lives to
enriching our country. But, as they age, there are fewer opportunities to work
and display their virtuosity. As an organization whose mission is to help
Canada’s senior professional artists, CSARN believes Well Seasoned Productions
should be assisted and encouraged in every way possible.”

 Scott Walker, Executive
Director, Canadian Senior Artists’ Resource Network  




Other Ways You Can Help
 Do you have any of the skills we need to help us get Well Seasoned Productions moving along? We are looking for well seasoned expertise in the following areas:
Marketing Public Relations Legal CouncilGraphic and Web DesignSocial Media

story:
WHO WE ARE

We are graduates from Birmingham School of Acting. Made up of a creative team from Devon to Derby we bring radical new writing to the stage. 

We set up Theatre63 in April 2016 and Cockroached is our debut show. Almost a year on from when the show was conceived we are taking the plunge and going to Edinburgh. 

OUR TEAM

William Proudler - Writer

Ruby Etches- Director

George Alex Pollard- Producer/Actor

Freya Sharp- Actor

Kirsten Banks- Stage Manager

OUR SHOW

Nearly everyone is dead and Taylor is surviving, but alone. Their life was 'fine' until they found the radio, it was 'fine' until they heard that voice. A post apocalyptic black comedy using live radio equipment to explore a connection between two people who shouldn't have listened.

The two characters are gender neutral so the actors will swap roles giving an alternate performance each night.

WHERE WE HAVE BEEN

We have taken the show to venues such as: The Old Joint Stock, The Wardrobe Theatre, The Spread Eagle and the Lion and Unicorn Theatre. We are excited to be working with the Pleasance.

OUR GOAL

In the budget our goal is to reach £4,282 through crowdfunding, this a specific amount as this is the money we need to get to the Fringe.

This campaign is to help develop us as artists and going to the Fringe will be a great opportunity to reach a wider audience and showcase our work. As shown in our budgeting, the main source of finance is through self-funding. This is understandable as unfortunately creating theatre is an expensive endeavour. We still fall short from covering all our expenses, but with your help you can get us to reach our goal. We will survive (like Taylor) on fruit with syrup for our time at the Fringe so any contribution will be greatly appreciated!

DATES AND TIMES

If you are at the Edinburgh Fringe this year, it would be great to see you there! We will be doing the full four week run at the Pleasance That! Pleasance Courtyard, Venue 33 from the 2nd- 28th of August at 2PM.

story:
About the director

I'm Stephanie Unger, a dancer/choreographer, writer, visual artist, and music enthusiast living in Oakland, CA. I'm originally from Florida, but spent several years as a dance artist in Chicago before settling in the Bay Area. For the last six months, I've been in the studio, developing new work. After workshopping ideas over the summer, I realized that many of my new pieces followed similar themes as work that I created 6-7 years ago. I decided to combine them into one seamless hour-long show.

"Being Left, Leaving, and Being" is not only important to me because it is my first evening-length work as an independent artist, but it is also semi-autobiographical. The piece is full of nostalgia, recounting lost love, missed connections, and the struggle to find my place in the world. I know I'm not the only one who experiences the emotions of this work. My hope is that by celebrating the highs and lows, we find peace within ourselves and with each other.

What We Need & What You Get

By contributing to this campaign, you will be a producer of our work! You'll help us create costumes, purchase materials for props (which will be more like installation art pieces), create compelling marketing pieces like posters and post cards. Even more important: you'll help provide stipends for these incredible artists. I am working with six multi-talented dancers (some sing, some write, some create visual art), two composers (with whom I worked to create original music for the show), a musician to play live accompaniment, and a lighting designer.

For your contribution, you will feel amazing about funding original, emotion-driven artwork! If that's not enough, we are including some amazing perks such as:

  • Autographed show post cards
  • Personalized dance phrase video 
  • Opportunities to preview the work and ask questions
  • Tickets to our upcoming sneak-peek party
  • Tickets to the show
  • Canvas prints of our amazing professional photos 

While we would love to reach our goal, anything we receive will go directly to producing the show. If we don't reach our goal, we will have to scale back in some areas. We hope you'll help us realize our full vision!

The Impact

Our work is being created in order to inspire others and connect with one another. This project has brought together a group of dancers of various ages. Each dancer has many strengths and interests and bring a true sense of community to the work. My goal is to encourage and appreciate the "fringe" art scene. 

I've been a part of successfully funded shows when I was working with a dance cooperative in Chicago, and I hope that this campaign will be no different. I am passionate about my work, and I hope that some of that energy will inspire you to be a part of this fundraiser.

Risks & Challenges

Of course, there is a possibility that we won't reach our goal. If we can't raise all the money we intend to, we will:

  • Scale back on costumes and props.
  • Ask for a volunteer technician to run lights, without "designing" them.
  • Not offer various hospitality niceties, like a bar, at the show.
  • Not be able to pay the dancers a rehearsal stipend.

That last one is the hardest to write. These dancers work dozens of hours in the studio and countless hours outside of the studio. They deserve to be paid for their work. However, if we don't raise enough for a rehearsal stipend, they will all receive a performance stipend regardless of our funds.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please help by:

  • Telling a friend.
  • Sharing our campaign on social media.
  • Liking our Facebook and following us on Instagram.
  • Ask Stephanie if you can pass out postcards!

Thank you so much! Love to you all.

story:
"Jordan Monsell has trance channelled the Bard in genuine, scholarly and hilarious fashion to celebrate the Ghostbusters in a  whole new, old way." ~ Dan Aykroyd

 

Whom will thou call?

Ministers of Grace is a  wickedly funny mash-up joy ride of Shakespeare and one of the best loved films of all time! Our production features fast-paced comedy, Shakespearean parody, supernatural shadows and spectral puppetry. The sound track includes original Elizabethan folk music with familiar sounding melodies..

 

Our Story:

Formed in 2015 by James Ducker and Hayley Evenett, REDuck ProDUCKtions are passionate about bringing new scripts to life and showcasing East Anglian talent. A small scale production company nestled in the heart of Norwich, REDuck began as a staged rehearsed reading platform for playwrights to test out their work in progress in front of a live audience.

Just one year into their existence, REDuck ProDUCKtions were nominated for the Norfolk Arts Theatre Award, along with their co-founder Hayley Evenett being nominated for the People's Choice Award.

Last year, we discovered Jordan Monsell's incredible Shakespearean parody of Ghostbusters and before long we found ourselves staging a rehearsed reading on a nominal budget. The reading was a huge success and we know that it's a show worth seeing and with your help, we can get the full production made.

 

The Impact:

Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the best place to get yourself seen by industry professionals and it is our hope, that if we are able to stage this production in Edinburgh,  we may be able to tour it further around the UK (to begin with). We want to give people an opportunity to see this show and your support will make this production a reality.

 

Where the money goes:

We are looking to take a cast of 8 actors and one tech manager up to Edinburgh from Norfolk and while travel is one hurdle, there's also accommodation, venue hire and promotional material. This is our cost breakdown:

Fringe Festival Registration: £250

Theatre hire: £1,500

Accommodation: £2,000

Travel: £500

Promotional material (flyers/posters): £250

Additional set required for full production: £500

£5,000 is a HUGE amount for a small scale production company, but with your help, we can reach this target and reward you for your support. 

Please be as generous as you can and be a part of something hugely exciting!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word - sharing this campaign with your friends, family, other Shakespeare/Ghostbusters fans will help us in so many ways! We are so very grateful for every contribution recieved.

Tell your friends that you were one of the people behind funding the first ever staged production of Ministers of Grace: The Unauthorised Shakespearean Parody of Ghostbusters.

Give us your hands if we be friends and remember ~

Ne'er cross ye streams!
