story:
Hello! Allow us to introduce ourselves, we are Matt Mancuso (conception and book) and Jerome Kurtenbach (music and lyrics), the creators of the new musical Outside the Lines.

Short Summary

Three years ago, the inspiration for Outside the Lines started when a friend expressed a desire dance on a stage again. To most people that is a simple as just finding a stage to get on but this friend is an incomplete quadriplegic. From that one expressed desire the story of learning to live outside the lines that have been drawn for you was born. This campaign is important because it will help us raise the necessary funds to get this story out there. It is story that strives to say that we are all unique and no one way is the right way. It strives to say that we can be more than what we think of ourselves and more than what others might say about you. This musical challenges conventions and aims to create growth. You're generous donation will help us bring this story to its fullest life. We believe that this is a story and musical that has something for everyone and we want to bring together as many people as we can.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need: we are looking to raise $4000 so that we can have a public reading and so that we can record a demo of the music of the show to reach out to possible theatre companies and investors.

Wait! You're generous donation will not go unrewarded. Our perks range from social media shout outs to receiving a PRODUCER CREDIT on the demo. If you ever wanted to feel like you got in on the ground floor of something and helped it grow we are the campaign for you.

The Impact

This musical has been a labor love and devotion to what theatre can do. Matt started writing the project two and half years ago and from the moment he typed the first scene, it felt like something special. Six months later, after meeting in a coffee shop, Jerome came on board and the project began to sore to new heights. Outside the Lines became more than just a love story but a story of overcoming adversity and personal demons. A story of acceptance and imagination. Of hope, enlightenment, perseverance and strength. In our climate, we need stories that challenge the way we see things and show us there are other ways. We need stories of positivity not negativity. When you donate to this campaign you are donating to that, to that story. This musical aims to bring people together not only with its story but combining elements and different styles of music so that everyone can have a great night in the theatre.

Matt has successfully raised money for the premiere of his first play Rum and Cookies and also ran a non-profit theatre company in Los Angeles for two years successfully raising money for its productions.

We know with support from people like you we can achieve the dreams we have for Outside the Lines.  

Risks & Challenges

Raising money for a new project especially a new musical is difficult but we believe in the show itself and all of you who are fans and friends. No matter what, we will be bringing this musical to all of you.  

Jerome and Matt have been working in the industry for many, many years and have seen ideas for projects come and go but Outside the Lines is one to stay. They have done their homework with editors and in-house readings, tirelessly trying out the show so that it is ready to touch the hearts and minds of many. They have contacts and have reached out to many people all over to help bring this story to life and will continue to pursue that dream with their help, support and advice.

Any small amount helps! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate right now, that's ok! How you can help is just by getting the word out. Email anyone, post on your wall or feed, talk to a new person! The world can change in the smallest ways when people come together. Even liking us on facebook can help! Just search "Outside the Lines by Matt Mancuso and Jerome Kurtenbach" and like us! 

Thank you for all of your support in any way that you can!

Outside the Lines became more than just a love story but a story of overcoming adversity and personal demons. A story of acceptance and imagination. Of hope, enlightenment, perseverance and strength. In our climate, we need stories that challenge the way we see things and show us there are other ways. We need stories of positivity not negativity. When you donate to this campaign you are donating to that, to that story. This musical aims to bring people together not only with its story but combining elements and different styles of music so that everyone can have a great night in the theatre.
Matt has successfully raised money for the premiere of his first play Rum and Cookies and also ran a non-profit theatre company in Los Angeles for two years successfully raising money for its productions.
We know with support from people like you we can achieve the dreams we have for Outside the Lines.  

Risks & Challenges
Raising money for a new project especially a new musical is difficult but we believe in the show itself and all of you who are fans and friends. No matter what, we will be bringing this musical to all of you.  
Jerome and Matt have been working in the industry for many, many years and have seen ideas for projects come and go but Outside the Lines is one to stay. They have done their homework with editors and in-house readings, tirelessly trying out the show so that it is ready to touch the hearts and minds of many. They have contacts and have reached out to many people all over to help bring this story to life and will continue to pursue that dream with their help, support and advice.
Any small amount helps! 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate right now, that's ok! How you can help is just by getting the word out. Email anyone, post on your wall or feed, talk to a new person! The world can change in the smallest ways when people come together. Even liking us on facebook can help! Just search "Outside the Lines by Matt Mancuso and Jerome Kurtenbach" and like us! 
Thank you for all of your support in any way that you can!

story:
Who we are:

Thiasus Productions was founded by American actress, Alix Martin, and Austrian actress, Verena Müller. After spending entirely too long bemoaning the lack of stage opportunities for actresses (primarily for themselves, but also the many other talented actresses they know - they aren't selfish), they decided to do something about it!

The plan for Thiasus Productions was born: create a theater company to cast all those talented actresses (and themselves - they are a little selfish). But not exclude men, or anyone else for that matter. But rather to even the odds. And to always pay the casts and directors - it may not be much, but it will always be something. Nobody has to work for "the exposure".

What We Need 

One can't stage shows and run a theater company without funds - who knew?!?! Thus far, we have been entirely self-funded. Which is why we are reaching out to you lovely and generous people! (Did we mention your elevated intelligence, soulful eyes, and snappy fashion sense?) Here's where the money has been spent so far has gone:

  • Performance rights for the two current shows: The Vagina Monologues and The Eight: Reindeer Monologues (no relation)
  • Paying a very generous and talented Graphic Artist for our logo and posters
  • Printing said posters

What we haven't paid yet:

  • Our Actresses and Actors
  • Our Directors
  • The rent on the theater spaces
  • Costumes, sets, props, etc.

What you get

We would never dream of asking for something for nothing (well, not here anyway). As such, we have created some fabulous perks to accompany your generous donation. (Did we mention how you light up a room just by entering it?)

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the shows! 

  • The Vagina Monologues - October 18-20 at the Atelier Theater (https://www.ateliertheater.net/)
  • The Eight: Reindeer Monologues - December 12, 18, and 20 at Spektakel theater (https://spektakel.wien/)

Because, after all, it's all entertainment, folks! And we would love to see you (and your sparkling personality and wit) in our audience!

story:
www.facebook.com/Lightoperaofmontreal/

A New Concept to the Story:    (en francais suivra)

Life in a rural community can be lonely for a teenage girl and her younger sister who creates an imaginary friend as a playmate.  Usually a doll the younger sister carries around, I have brought the doll to life as an on-stage character, responding and guiding with her flute.

Laurie, the teenage girl about to graduate, can sometimes hear those themes of innocence and whimsical fantasy, but the music becomes fainter as she is becoming a woman.  When the strict and fearful mother and grandfather appear, the imaginary friend/flutist disappears.

She reappears in the love duet when drifting migrant worker, Martin (who is now from Mexico), opens his soul to Laurie and is instrumental (literally) in bringing them together in a later duet as the twitter of a bird.  They confirm their love and make plans for their new life on the road.

However, the older drifter travelling with Martin, convinces him that the grandfather would be quick to have them arrested if Laurie comes along.   Martin reluctantly leaves with him.   Laurie discovers they have left without her, but is determined to see the world “beyond that road”.   As the mother tries her best to make her stay, the two finally have it out, expressed so brilliantly in text and music with conflicting rhythms and tempos. 

The sister Beth is shocked as Laurie departs.   The final aria sung by the mother is about how endings are beginnings. She hugs Beth close to her.   No longer needed, the flutist exits down the road echoing the final theme of the opera as Beth waves goodbye.  

Note: Beth is the only role that speaks while the others sing.  To make this production bilingual, Beth will speak in French, as she sets up the opera and often repeats what other characters have just sung.   Quebec is bilingual, so we want everyone to enjoy this opera. 

Bref commentaire sur le nouveau concept de l’histoire: Sur une ferme du monde rural du Mid-West américain, une adolescente, Laurie, et sa jeune cadette, Beth, font face à des réalités de solitude. Laurie sur le point d’être diplômée, rêve d’une vie plus excitante loin de la ferme tandis que la cadette se crée une amie imaginaire, Danielle. Laurie planifie poursuivre son rêve avec son ami Martin, mais ce dernier l’abandonne à la ferme et quitte sans elle. Des déchirements s’en suivent entre la mère et Laurie, cette dernière finira par fuguer aux désarrois de sa mère et de sa soeur cadette.

The Cast:

Danielle/Flute                                 Marie-Noelle Choquette

Beth                                                    Izabella Marengo

Ma Moss                                           Johanne Patry

Mr. Splinters                                    Paul LaFontaine

Laurie                                                 Sandra D’Angelo

Martin                                                 Pedro Diaz

Top                                                      Buck Delaney

Grandpa Moss                                 Lars Lih

Mr. Jenks                                           Rodrigo Monardes

Mrs. Jenks                                         Lisa-Marie Thomas

Chorus of Le Relais                     Johanne Patry, Director

Director                                               Buck Delaney

Executive Musical Director          Graeme Wilkinson, piano

Musical Director/Opera Coach  Giancarlo Scalia, piano

Guitar                                                  Raynald Plante, Pedro Diaz

Set Consultant/Photographer    Marcel Jean

 

WHAT WE NEED:

  • String quartet for the big choral pieces: The Promise of Living and the rousing square-dance piece Stomp Your Foot, a jig that cannot be authentically done without strings.
  • Representational set with a dimensional house, a barn façade and a ramp for the road.
  • Lighting and sound board that can be hooked up to a laptop along with a mini-projector for scrim images. 

Tech equipment will remain in theatre space for use by other non-profit performers!

$6000 should cover it as we pay the flutist and opera coach ourselves.   The cast and crew are all volunteers.  The theatre space is covered.   Costumes are provided and even made by our company members.  We will perform in early May.  The string quartet will rehearse at the start of the new year, if we have the money to pay them.  We’re just asking to cover the bare minimum.

If you are hesitant to pay online, inquire at opera3550montreal@gmail.com on how to contribute the old-fashioned way (remember checks?).  Otherwise, a debit card with a Visa, Mastercard, or American Express logo can be used as well as those credit cards.   We also accept PayPal. 

Soutien à la production: Un soutien de 6 000 $ permettrait l’utilisation d’un quatuor à cordes et un décor décent. Cela aiderait aussi à l’achat du matériel électronique d’éclairage, de son et de projection sur canevas qui demeurerait sur les lieux pour des présentations ultérieures.

story:
Scheherazade

Presented by Generic Ensemble Company in Partnership with The VORTEX

Directed by kt shorb
Featuring: Donnesh Amrollah, Laura Baggs, Carine Choubassi, Lemons Clemons, Olivia Jimenez, Laura J. Khalil, Aisha Melhem, Tonya Pennie, Saray de Jesus Rosales, and Jesus Valles. With additional collaboration with Cyrus Bavarian and Shiva Jabarnia.
Script by the Ensemble, edited by Annie Kim Hedrick and Leena Waarsi
Lighting Design by Rachel Atkinson
Costume Design by E.L. Hohn
Scenic Design by Ann Marie Gordon
Stage Management by Zoë Crabtree
Assistant Stage Management by Jana Zek 
Associate Production by Laura J. Khalil and Lemons Clemons

SCHEHERAZADE (June 2-17, at The VORTEX) center​s collaborators of Middle Eastern descent​,​​ us​ing the​ Arabian Nights​ stories​ as a basis for exploring Islamophobia, terrorism, detention, and the "Muslim Ban​."​​​​​ ​I​n an international airport in ​"​The States,​"​ Scheherazade must tell stories to save her life. Interweaving queer love stories in the context of xenophobia, diaspora and fundamentalism, SCHEHERAZADE asks: what are the stories that take us home? 

Collection

Presented by Generic Ensemble Company as part of a residency at the Dougherty Arts Center

Directed by Laura Khalil and Lemons Clemons
Featuring: Annie Kim Hedrick, Marina Weikel, Eva McQuade, Briana Bower, Emily Rankine, Norman Tran, and Dillon Yruegas. 

Our collections – both tangible and intangible – from past relationships affect the way we love and the way we live. What do we hold on to? How can we let go? What does it mean to love and how to we learn? Partially inspired by bower birds, a species that collects trinkets to court mates, Collection is an intimate view of the things we give and receive during relationships of all kinds. In this time of great change, love feels precious and meaningful now more than ever. Collection runs August 25-September 9 at the Dougherty Arts Center.

 

Physical Actor Training

Lead by kt shorb and special guests. 

May 13, at Doughtery Arts Center, Writing and Viewpoints: Writing and Viewpoints combines embodied performance practice with experience-based writing. Drawing from Anne Bogart's Viewpoints as a main Generic Ensemble Company training, we alternate parsing space and time with writing exercises that mine our personal history and embodied experience. Free.

Date, Place TBA, Austin Stomps: Our ongoing one-day intensive of Viewpoints and Suzuki. Sliding scale; none turned away for lack of funds.

 

Why This Season is Special

Firstly, our work couldn't be more timely. With the awful Trump Administration issuing ridiculous executive orders and aggressively attacking hard-won rights, theatre addressing issues of Islamaphobia, migration, queer love, and home are vital to our collective conversation. Secondly, this is the first time GenEnCo will present two full-productions in one calendar year. It is our biggest season yet and is the next step toward making GenEnCo a sustainable and constant presence in the Austin theatre community. It takes a lot of people-hours to make this kind of work. We hope to take the next two years to increase how much we pay collaborators as well as the frequency with which we present work so that we can offer a more financially, emotionally, and politically stable refuge for artists to create challenging work.

 

How We Will Use These Funds

Donations from this campaign will go directly toward paying creative collaborators, that include at least 20 actors, three directors, two stage managers, seven designers and other personnel and crew. We have already received a grant from the City of Austin, which will cover much of our talent and materials costs. We are grateful to both The VORTEX and the Dougherty Arts Center for underwriting our project through providing performance space and other material goods so we can direct most of our resources toward paying talent. It is our goal to pay each actor and designer at least $500. The $5000 will insure that. It is the goal of the Generic Ensemble Company to make creative labor sustainable for all collaborators. Love makes art good, but you can't eat it. Money helps.

Let's Talk About Accessible Admission

We are so proud to be partnering with The VORTEX on their Radical Rush program that reserves a bloc of free tickets in the spirit of sustainability, accessibility, and participating in the gift economy. Radical Rush tickets are released an hour before the performance starts--first come first serve. For our partnership at the DAC, we will institute a similar program where we will reserve a bank of tickets each night that will be free to walk-ups. Both venues are wheelchair accessible and we provide sign-language interpretation for one show each run and provide admission to deaf and hard of hearing patrons free-of-charge.

As we continue to expand our accessibility, your donation to this campaign allows us to offer our show to more and more patrons, across many social lines. 

Why We Are So Cool

The Generic Ensemble Company (GenEnCo) is one of the few troupes in Austin, and nationally, that centers people of color bodies and experiences in physically engaged, experimental, ensemble-based performance. GenEnCo has some grants and awards under its belt, and director, kt shorb, has presented work nationally. This is the most recent project aimed at asking profound questions toward social change through rigorous, dangerous, and community-conscious theatre. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help out with donating to our cause, we are looking for at least 10 volunteers to participate in our load-in on May 27-28. We really need this, so if you can do it, please contact us at info@genenco.org.

Do you have a blog, radio show, or column? Talk to us and share our project with your audience!

Ticket Info

You can reserve a seat for SCHEHERAZADE by going to The VORTEX ticketing page. Information on Collection tickets will be available in the summer.

story:
LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING:
SEND TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN
TO THE INTERNATIONAL DUBLIN GAY THEATRE FESTIVAL

Provincetown Dramatic Arts (PDA) (www.ptowndramaticarts.org) is going to the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival (www.gaytheatre,ie) with LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN GO TO DUBLIN and we need your help to get there.

In two short plays by Candace Perry and Kathleen Warnock, Provincetown Dramatic Arts collaborates with the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival and Irish actors on sharp, funny and serious takes on lifetimes (and beyond) filled with battles against misogyny, bigotry, racism, homophobia in order to affirm true family values.

MADE IN HEAVEN by Candace Perry

In Perry's MADE IN HEAVEN (European premiere), the afterlife beyond the pearly gates is not what Mrs. Eugene McBride (of the Alabama McBrides) expects at all. Fortunately, Marie Louise Benson, an angel at the gates of heaven, is there to help her connect with her true love. MADE IN HEAVEN is directed by Irish actor and director Maria Blaney.

HOW TO GET MARRIED IN FIVE STEPS AND 17 YEARS by Kathleen Warnock

In Warnock’s HOW TO GET MARRIED IN FIVE STEPS AND 17 YEARS (European premiere), Warnock documents the long journey for her and her wife to the altar. The play is performed by the playwright and directed by Margaret Van Sant.

Both playwrights have deep roots in Provincetown and New York.

MADE IN HEAVEN was presented at the Women's International Theater Festival and And HOW TO GET MARRIED IN FIVE STEPS IN 17 YEARS premiered in New York as part of "Landmarks & TRANSformations," presented by Project Y Theater at the Episcopal Actors Guild, Feb. 2017.

Candace Perry has written over 35 ten-minute plays which have been produced around the United States. She’s also written four full length plays which have had productions and staged readings, as well as several radio plays. Her work deals with issues of social justice and change.  She’s the recipient of the Cape Cod Playwrights’ Award for her full length play “Meridian Summer,” and she received a commission from the Four Squared Theater Collaborative which resulted in her full length play, “Along the River Road.” Both plays deal with racism and the legacy of slavery in the United States. Candace is an activist and feminist who believes that theater can change the world.  She is thrilled to be traveling to Ireland for the first time and honored to be a part of the IDGTF with Provincetown Dramatic Arts.

Kathleen Warnock is a New York City-based playwright who considers Provincetown a theatrical home. Her plays have been seen in New York City, London, Ireland and regionally. Provincetown Dramatic Arts produced her play, "What to Throw Out" in the Fall Playwrights Festival and at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, 2014. In 2015, the TOSOS production of "The Further Adventures of..." was presented at the WITF and also went on to the Dublin Festival. And in 2016, "Julie Andrews is the Devil," was presented at the WITF and went on to the IDGTF. Other plays seen in Provincetown include: "Sharing the Pie," "The Adventures of..." "Seattle," "Not at Home," and a staged reading of "The Audience," which returned in 2015  as "Rock the Line." Kathleen is a member of The Dramatists Guild. Thanks to Margaret Van Sant for her continued friendship & support.

PROVINCETOWN DRAMATIC ARTS COLLABORATES WITH IDGTF

Provincetown Dramatic Arts is honored that this is the fourth time they have been accepted to perform at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival. This is a testament to the quality of work of our Provincetown and New York playwrights who are addressing important cultural issues in their plays. Through our presentations at the IDGTF, we developed a collaborative process and PDA brought and hosted Brian Merriman’s EIREBRUSHED (North American premiere) for a run in Provincetown and New York in 2016. EIREBRUSHED is the inspiring story of the gay and lesbian heroes of the Easter Rebellion of 1916.

LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN GO TO DUBLIN will be our first collaboration using Irish actors and directors, who will be rehearsing in Dublin, and it is our great hope these collaborations will continue and grow and allow us to host more Irish productions in Provincetown and New York.

How You Can Help Us Get To Dublin 

LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN needs your help to get to Ireland. Your contribution (of any amount) will help fund the following:

  • Roundtrip airfare from NYC and Boston to Dublin for the company.
  • The cost of a furnished flat (with kitchen and laundry!) in Dublin for them to stay. And presumably cook and do laundry.
  • Postcards, posters and playbills.
  • A per diem so the company doesn't have to go out busking in the street! (Though they can if they want to).
  • Basic groceries to save money on dinner out.

Other Ways You Can Help

Many of you are artists trying to get your own work up and running... sometimes you're just not able to contribute in cash. But we still need (and love!) you!

Please share, re-post, tweet, busk and otherwise spread the word about our LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN GO TO DUBLIN campaign.

And:

  • Send your friends in Ireland to the International Gay Dublin Theatre Festival!
  • Come and see us in Dublin…we’ll have a drink in the pub after the show.
  • Send us a kind word, and come to our fund raising event in Provincetown in late April (date TBA shortly).

This campaign is raising funds on behalf of Provincetown Community Compact Inc, a verified nonprofit. The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.
story_txt:
LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING:SEND TWO FROM PROVINCETOWNTO THE INTERNATIONAL DUBLIN GAY THEATRE FESTIVALProvincetown Dramatic Arts (PDA) (www.ptowndramaticarts.org) is going to the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival (www.gaytheatre,ie) with LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN GO TO DUBLIN and we need your help to get there.In two short plays by Candace Perry and Kathleen Warnock, Provincetown Dramatic Arts collaborates with the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival and Irish actors on sharp, funny and serious takes on lifetimes (and beyond) filled with battles against misogyny, bigotry, racism, homophobia in order to affirm true family values.MADE IN HEAVEN by Candace PerryIn Perry's MADE IN HEAVEN (European premiere), the afterlife beyond the pearly gates is not what Mrs. Eugene McBride (of the Alabama McBrides) expects at all. Fortunately, Marie Louise Benson, an angel at the gates of heaven, is there to help her connect with her true love. MADE IN HEAVEN is directed by Irish actor and director Maria Blaney.HOW TO GET MARRIED IN FIVE STEPS AND 17 YEARS by Kathleen WarnockIn Warnock’s HOW TO GET MARRIED IN FIVE STEPS AND 17 YEARS (European premiere), Warnock documents the long journey for her and her wife to the altar. The play is performed by the playwright and directed by Margaret Van Sant.Both playwrights have deep roots in Provincetown and New York. MADE IN HEAVEN was presented at the Women's International Theater Festival and And HOW TO GET MARRIED IN FIVE STEPS IN 17 YEARS premiered in New York as part of "Landmarks & TRANSformations," presented by Project Y Theater at the Episcopal Actors Guild, Feb. 2017.Candace Perry has written over 35 ten-minute plays which have been produced around the United States. She’s also written four full length plays which have had productions and staged readings, as well as several radio plays. Her work deals with issues of social justice and change.  She’s the recipient of the Cape Cod Playwrights’ Award for her full length play “Meridian Summer,” and she received a commission from the Four Squared Theater Collaborative which resulted in her full length play, “Along the River Road.” Both plays deal with racism and the legacy of slavery in the United States. Candace is an activist and feminist who believes that theater can change the world.  She is thrilled to be traveling to Ireland for the first time and honored to be a part of the IDGTF with Provincetown Dramatic Arts.Kathleen Warnock is a New York City-based playwright who considers Provincetown a theatrical home. Her plays have been seen in New York City, London, Ireland and regionally. Provincetown Dramatic Arts produced her play, "What to Throw Out" in the Fall Playwrights Festival and at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, 2014. In 2015, the TOSOS production of "The Further Adventures of..." was presented at the WITF and also went on to the Dublin Festival. And in 2016, "Julie Andrews is the Devil," was presented at the WITF and went on to the IDGTF. Other plays seen in Provincetown include: "Sharing the Pie," "The Adventures of..." "Seattle," "Not at Home," and a staged reading of "The Audience," which returned in 2015  as "Rock the Line." Kathleen is a member of The Dramatists Guild. Thanks to Margaret Van Sant for her continued friendship & support.PROVINCETOWN DRAMATIC ARTS COLLABORATES WITH IDGTFProvincetown Dramatic Arts is honored that this is the fourth time they have been accepted to perform at the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival. This is a testament to the quality of work of our Provincetown and New York playwrights who are addressing important cultural issues in their plays. Through our presentations at the IDGTF, we developed a collaborative process and PDA brought and hosted Brian Merriman’s EIREBRUSHED (North American premiere) for a run in Provincetown and New York in 2016. EIREBRUSHED is the inspiring story of the gay and lesbian heroes of the Easter Rebellion of 1916.LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN GO TO DUBLIN will be our first collaboration using Irish actors and directors, who will be rehearsing in Dublin, and it is our great hope these collaborations will continue and grow and allow us to host more Irish productions in Provincetown and New York.How You Can Help Us Get To Dublin LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN needs your help to get to Ireland. Your contribution (of any amount) will help fund the following:
Roundtrip airfare from NYC and Boston to Dublin for the company.
The cost of a furnished flat (with kitchen and laundry!) in Dublin for them to stay. And presumably cook and do laundry.
Postcards, posters and playbills.
A per diem so the company doesn't have to go out busking in the street! (Though they can if they want to).
Basic groceries to save money on dinner out.
Other Ways You Can HelpMany of you are artists trying to get your own work up and running... sometimes you're just not able to contribute in cash. But we still need (and love!) you!Please share, re-post, tweet, busk and otherwise spread the word about our LOVE TRUMPS EVERYTHING: TWO FROM PROVINCETOWN GO TO DUBLIN campaign.And:
Send your friends in Ireland to the International Gay Dublin Theatre Festival!
Come and see us in Dublin…we’ll have a drink in the pub after the show.
Send us a kind word, and come to our fund raising event in Provincetown in late April (date TBA shortly).

The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

story:
We Are Pucqui. 

Pucqui is a curious theatre collaborative rooted in the creation of vibrant, playful, and occasionally sinister performances that reconnect modern audiences with traditional storytelling on an emotional, philosophical, and biological level always through a multicultural, queer, and/or gender-conscious lens. Learn more about us HERE!

We are debuting our second original production, CHANGELINGS, at this year's edinburgh Fringe Festival throughout August. We are deeply committed to the development of new work that empowers the storyteller within each artist in the collaborative, which includes those on and off stage. Changelings is a mash up of Rudyard Kipling's Mowgli and Shakespeare's Puck in a world that lives just behind where your inner child calls home. 

Any contribution you make will go directly toward production costs for our small but mighty ensemble of five- that's right, only 5!- very grateful artists. 

What We Need & What You Get

Let's be honest, theatre is pricey! But we promise it will be worth it. Even if we don't reach the entire goal, we can put every penny (and pence) towards costumes, lodging, paying the directors and staff, marketing, etc. 

We are aiming to raise £8,000 in total, details in all honesty are below. 

PUCQUI

Travel to Edinburgh £190

Venue Cost £2250

Set Cost £250

Costume/Makeup £150

Marketing Materials £500

Website Launch £150

Creative Team Stipends and Travel £3960

Emergency Buffer £300

Film/Sound Rental £250

The PERKS! 

Our aim with the company in general is to create intimate and truthful work, so of course we are keeping all our perks intimate and truthful as well. No matter the donation amount, we want you to feel like you are a part of the magic, so every donation will be met with a personal thank you and flair. There's more about the perks later, but the initial break down is as follows! And YES! We do take USD as well as Pounds. 

£10- Your Name in the Program

£25- Signed Photo of the Ensemble and Social Media Shout Out (and the £10 Perk). 

£50- A signed Changelings Poster (and the £10 and £25 Perks). 

£75- A Changelings T-Shirt (and, you guessed it, the £10, £25, and £50 Perks). 

£100- A Signed and Published copy of the script (w/all above Perks). 

£250- A Video of the Show (above Perks included). 

£350- You can fully sponsor a show of your choice during the Fringe Festival...and of course, get ALL the Perks. 

The Impact

CHANGELINGS will be Pucqui's international debut, both with ensemble and performance space, and we want to step forward into the world with a compassion for the storyteller in us all. This company, and this production, are focused and DEDICATED to the creation of vibrant, playful, and occasionally sinister performances that reconnect modern audiences with traditional storytelling on an emotional, philosophical, and biological level always through a multicultural, queer, and/or gender-conscious lens.

We want to tell YOUR story. The you whose story you are perhaps afraid to tell. We've got you. The Fringe Festival Experience is important to Pucqui's journey because it is a space and an audience that is curious. ​Experiencing Fringe 2017 will contribute to the foundation of Pucqui's principles and mission in a concrete and practical way. 

Can't Spare any $£? No Problem! 

If you can't spare any change, we COMPLETELY understand. Believe it or not, good news does travel fast, so please share us with as many people as you can. Ask us questions, ask us to play, we would love to have you on board in any way. If you are in the UK this summer and want to book tickets, you can do that by simply clicking HERE. 


And finally, above all else, keep believing in magic.

That's really where it all begins.

story:
The New Wolsey Theatre are working to commemorate this anniversary by producing a brand new musical production that will utilise the stories and memories of the people of Ipswich and Suffolk at the time.

The production will open at the theatre exactly 40 years on from the win and will really be a show drawn from the local community, for the local community!

But, this production can only happen with your support. Be a part of the fire that sets to ignite the town in celebration again 40 years on from Ipswich Town's historic FA Cup victory.

We're seeking funding for a musical production, so why aren't we going to an investor? Well, the truth is that we want to make a show for Ipswich that is true to our roots, not the whims of a single investor.

We know that Ipswich Town have passionate, powerful fans. Fans who can make this production happen. We want to cut out investors, and allow you - our backers - to get involved in the whole production process from first rehearsal to opening night.

We have over 60 productions under our belt, so with your support and our skilled team and experience we know Our Blue Heaven will be a truly great production for Ipswich.

Take a look at the rewards to the right and below - each of which has a gift amount attached. The rewards are fantastic, but even better, every penny you spend goes directly towards producing Our Blue Heaven.

For example:

£5 Pays for a copy of the script for one of the cast
£25 Pays for a microphone rental for a week
£100 Buys a sheet of colour filters for the stage lights
£500 Will buy two lead character costumes
£1,000 Pays for instrument rental for a week

 

If you can't support us with a gift, then your support and enthusiasm is just as valuable. Tweet, Facebook, Instagram and Linkedin as much as you can.

Tell your friends and family, your colleagues, your hairdresser, taxi driver and barista. Talk about Our Blue Heaven at work, school, the supermarket and everywhere else you find yourself. Spreading the word is just as important as a cash contribution.

We are eternally grateful for any support you offer during the campaign.

£45,000 may seem like a lot for a single production, but it's actually just a fraction of the cost of producing a musical.

After all, we've got big plans and we want to give the people of Ipswich the best production we know how to make. This isn't a script reading or a try-out. We've got a big cast, a big set, and even bigger ambitions.

This means ticket sales will only go so far towards making this a milestone production for Ipswich.

Investing in a Milestone

Production Budget

Peter Rowe - Writer And Director

Peter is the Artistic Director of the New Wolsey Theatre, where his productions have included Sweeney Todd, Perfect Days, Double Indemnity, A Family Affair, A Mad World My Masters, Leader of the Pack, The Good Companions, Neville’s Island, Stephen Sondheim’s Company, Sugar, The Price, A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, Vincent in Brixton, Blues in the Night, The Glass Menagerie, Laurel and Hardy, Little Shop of Horrors, A Chorus of Disapproval, Chimps, a new musical adaptation of It’s a Wonderful Life, Noises Off, Up on the Roof, Guys and Dolls, 20th Century Boy, Bedroom Farce, Mods And Rox, And Then The Dark, the UK national tour of the Madness musical Our House, Miss Nightingale, a major revival of The Threepenny Opera with co-director Jenny Sealey, a brand new musical Midsummer Songs with Ben Goddard, a co-production with Birmingham Repertory Theatre Feed The Beast, an actor-musician production of Sweet Charity, The Last Five Years, and most recently a tour of Graham Linehan’s The Ladykillers.

After training at the Thorndike Theatre, Peter became the artistic director for the Southampton-based Solent People’s Theatre and then artistic director for the London Bubble Theatre Company, touring London in a big-top tent. He has held two other artistic directorships, at the Gateway Theatre, Chester, and the Liverpool Everyman, while freelance work has included productions for regional theatres and touring companies up and down the country. He has directed Boyband and Return to the Forbidden Planet in the West End and on national tours, together with his own musical, Leader of the Pack.

New Wolsey Theatre - Producer

With a 400 seat main auditorium, and 100 seat studio, the New Wolsey Theatre is nationally renowned for the quality and diversity of its productions. Recent musical revivals have included an actor-musician version of Sweet Charity, Jason Robert Brown’s The Last Five Years, and Made in Dagenham in co-production with Queen’s Theatre Hornchurch. They have joined forces with six other mid-scale theatres and Graeae to create Ramps on the Moon, an Arts Council funded strategic touring project, with the aim of increasing the engagement and participation of D/deaf and disabled actors, artists and audiences. 2017 saw their own production of The Who’s Tommy open in Ipswich before embarking on a national tour.

As a not-for-profit organisation and a registered charity, they are funded by the Arts Council England, Suffolk County Council and Ipswich Borough Council as well as through the invaluable donations, individual giving and corporate support of their many friends, patrons and sponsors.

Q: Can I give my perks as a Christmas gift?

A: Yes! Please let us know by using the Ask A Question button on our profile if this is the case and we will arrange to send a special note to explain the gift which will arrive in May 2018.

Q: When do I get my Perk?

A: Each perk has an estimated delivery month listed in the description. We'll be sending two shipments, one just before the production opens and one just after when we have production photographs and the cast on hand to sign items.

Q: Can I upgrade to another Perk?

A: Yes! Just make a pledge of the difference and use the Ask A Question button on our profile so that we can update your record.

Q: What if I forgot to add shipping for my International order?

A: Just pledge the difference and use the Ask A Question button on our profile so that we can update your record.

Q: I don't see the update on my Indiegogo contribution profile after you confirmed my upgrade?

A: Indiegogo doesn't let us upgrade your pledge, but rest assured we are tracking this separately and you will get the correct perks.

Q: What are you going to use my pledge for?

A: There is a pie chart on the main campaign page that shows how the funding will be divided.

Q: How do I claim the tickets included with my perks?

A: We will be reserving the very best Premium seats and will contact you before the show goes on sale to reserve your tickets. We can either send them to you by email or post, or leave them care of box office.

Q: I live outside the UK, will I still revive my perks?

A: We include the cost of shipping to the UK in the pledge amount. If you live outside the UK, you will have the option of paying a small shipping charge for worldwide delivery.

Q: My perk includes tickets, but I will not be able to attend. Can you help?

A: Yes! We would love to donate your tickets to one of our local charity partners who will distribute them to their service users or residents. Please use the Ask A Question button on our profile if you would like us to make these arrangements for you.

Q: Can my business support Our Blue Heaven?

A: Yes! Please contact Elise Golbourn for more information about business support, including unique recognition and community engagement opportunities. Email egolbourn@wolseytheatre.co.uk or call 01473 295902.

Q: Who can I talk to about making a larger pledge?

A: Joseph Valentine will be happy to discuss bespoke perks with you, including meet and greet opportunities, private events and receptions. Email jvalentine@wolseytheatre.co.uk or call 01473 295902.

story:
Our Project

In the first ever India-Palestine theatre collaboration, The Freedom Theatre from Jenin Refugee Camp will join forces with the legendary street theatre group Jana Natya Manch. Some of the highlights of this historic cultural exchange:
- A three-month residency in India for Palestinian theatre students,
- A ten-city tour of India with over 30 performances and events with local artists,
- A tour in occupied Palestine, showcasing the work produced in India,
- A documentary film and a book about the project.

With every new backer, we are sowing the seeds of a new cultural movement for freedom. Join us!

This south-south solidarity project will focus on the stories that unite us. Through it, we hope to create a community of supporters around the world who share our cause, so that collectively we can spread a cultural movement based on principles of humanity, equality and justice.


What We Need & What You Get

The Freedom Jatha for Palestine is entirely funded by individual contributions. We need to raise $20,000 to cover the costs of travel, simple accommodation, production of a street theatre play and touring it in India and Palestine. Every penny we raise will go directly to these essential costs.

We will make this Freedom Jatha happen. If we don't raise the full amount, we will make do with what we have. If we raise more, we will do more! 

So what's in it for you? Well, in addition to the obvious satisfaction of knowing you have done your bit to support our cause, there are a few unique perks involved:

One of India's foremost visual artists, Orijit Sen , has designed unique art pieces for this Freedom Jatha, and we want to give them to you. Get your own limited edition screen print, signed by the artist, or your own exclusive tote bag, t-shirt or poster with the beautiful artwork. Read more about Orijit's artwork.

As if that was not enough, we're also throwing in some of The Freedom Theatre's most popular products, including the documentary Arna's Children made by one of our founders, the late Juliano Mer Khamis.

The Impact

With your help, eight of The Freedom Theatre's students and artists will go to India for three months of intensive workshops involving some of India’s foremost theatre experts. They will create a unique theatre production together, telling stories of freedom and resistance from both nations, that will tour India and Palestine. 

Imagine that by giving a little of what you have, you can open a door to a whole new world for eight young people from Palestine! 

Not only that, you can help us bring techniques of street theatre from India to Palestine, equipping young emerging artists with tools to create art where art is most needed. Also, you will be part of bringing the stories of Palestine to India. And when you see the fruits of our labour you can say: "I made this project happen!"


"This is truly people-to-people contact, or rather artist-to-artist. They sought us out, and we sought them out because we found inspiration in each other's work. This is third-world talking to third-world, without the first-world telling us who to talk to, or what to talk about.” Sudhanva, Jana Natya Manch


Read more about the project:
For Palestine - Freedom Jatha
Act of activism
Stories of freedom and resistance
Indo-Palestine theatre collaboration to come alive this winter
Finding refuge in an audience
Performing freedom

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, that doesn't mean you can't help. Ask friends, colleagues and family to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools, it's easy!
story_txt:
Our Project 
In the
first ever India-Palestine theatre collaboration, The Freedom Theatre from Jenin Refugee Camp will join
forces with the legendary street theatre group Jana Natya Manch. Some of the highlights of this historic cultural exchange: - A three-month residency in India for Palestinian theatre students, - A ten-city tour of India with over 30 performances
and events with local artists,- A tour in occupied Palestine, showcasing the work produced in India, - A documentary film and a book about the project.
With every new backer, we are sowing the seeds of a new cultural movement for freedom. Join us!

This
south-south solidarity project will focus on the stories that unite us. Through it, we hope to create a community of supporters around the world who share our cause, so that collectively we can spread a cultural movement based on principles of humanity, equality and justice.







  What We Need & What You Get The Freedom Jatha for Palestine is entirely funded by individual contributions. We need to raise $20,000 to cover the costs of travel, simple accommodation, production of a street theatre play and touring it in India and Palestine. Every penny we raise will go directly to these essential costs.
We will make this Freedom Jatha happen. If we don't raise the full amount, we will make do with what we have. If we raise more, we will do more! 
So what's in it for you? Well, in addition to the obvious satisfaction of knowing you have done your bit to support our cause, there are a few unique perks involved:
One of India's foremost visual artists, Orijit Sen , has designed unique art pieces for this Freedom Jatha, and we want to give them to you. Get your own limited edition screen print, signed by the artist, or your own exclusive tote bag, t-shirt or poster with the beautiful artwork. Read more about Orijit's artwork.



As if that was not enough, we're also throwing in some of The Freedom 
Theatre's most popular products, including the documentary Arna's Children made by one of our founders, the late Juliano Mer Khamis.
   The Impact 
With your help, eight of The Freedom Theatre's students and artists will go to India for three months of intensive
workshops involving some of India’s foremost
theatre experts. They will create a unique theatre production together, telling stories of
freedom and resistance from both nations, that will tour India and Palestine.  Imagine that by giving a little of what
you have, you can open a door to a whole new world for eight young people from Palestine! 

Not only that, you can help us bring techniques of street theatre from India to Palestine, equipping young emerging artists with tools to create art where art is most needed. Also, you will be part of bringing the stories of Palestine to India. And when you see the fruits of our labour you can say: "I made
this project happen!"



"This is truly people-to-people contact, or rather artist-to-artist. They sought us out, and we sought them out because we found inspiration in each other's work. story:
Hi!

We are Southern Idaho Youth Theatrics. You may have heard of us under our former name Wilson Junior Musical Theatre! Why the change? To make a long story short, we’re expanding!  By spreading out into the surrounding areas of Southern Idaho, we can expose more young people to the world of live production and theatre.

Who are we?

We are a collection of extremely talented youth from all over Southern Idaho led by a board of passionate directors, each with a different background in the world of music, art, and theatre. We all have the common goal of spreading culture, music, and entertainment to as many people as possible through our acting and singing. So far as the Wilson Junior Musical Theatre, we have had a few years of extremely successful shows like Legally Blonde the Musical Jr. and Fame Jr. Now as Southern Idaho Youth Theatrics, we have a tentative lineup of Elf the Musical Jr. and Peter Pan Jr., both shows we are over the moon about producing!


Why we do what we do.

“Youth Drama offers personal development, self-esteem, self-reliance, self-worth, confidence, responsibility, heightened awareness, deeper consciousness, better and broader social skills, tolerance, understanding, friendship, romance, community development, group dynamic, cross-cultural exchange, collective identity, transformation, transcendentalism… an enhanced vocabulary, with lots of clapping; artistic expression and dishwashing, acting, dancing, singing, and floor-sweeping, set-building and carpet painting, lighting design and ceiling reconstruction, public disorder and general mayhem…”

-Paul Mercier, Playwright

While Paul Mercier definitely sums up the positives of youth in theatre, public disorder and general mayhem might be an exaggeration of backstage shenanigans. There are few things more rewarding to us as directors than seeing a young man or woman take the stage and develop a positive self-esteem and confidence in what he or she can accomplish. Plus, what parent doesn’t want their child to help sweep or do dishes!?

What do we need?

This is where you come in. To make our dream come true of developing this troupe we need $10,000 of seed money. With all the financial hurdles of being an independent company like licensing, venue fees, costumes, and advertising, becoming established enough to put on a quality show is quite an endeavor. We have prepared a series of gifts to thank you for your contribution to our future. It’s our privilege to give something back for your generosity. There is something incredibly special about this company, and we know you, like us, will feel proud to have been a part of its success.

Other Ways To Help

Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

We're on Facebook and Twitter, Just look for Southern Idaho Youth Theatrics

Thank you for all the support!

(SIYT)

story:
So.. You Can Longboard Dance? 

2nd and 3rd of April 2016 Klokgebouw Eindhoven, the Netherlands 

One day we decided to go longboard skate indoor because of the bad weather and invite some other riders. This 'day' grew rapidly into the most well known longboard dance competition in the world with participants from almost all continents. This is OUR event, of every person there and every person involved! 


Why crowdfunding?

We want to keep 'So.. You Can Longboard Dance?' FREE to acces and participate in! But of course an event of this scale needs money to be organised. The funding we got in the past ended and the event grew out of its original one area, one day, setup. 

With your help SYCLD can stay 'for riders' and 'by riders' and grow into a full 2 day, 4 area, free event where everyone contributes to the best of their possibilities. 

No matter if you are a small board builder, a mayor brand, someone who just put their feet on a board recently, a family with kids who get all stoked and want to try for the first time, a sponsored rider, from Eindhoven or from Korea, every effort, every spectator and participant make the event the beautiful way it is! 


We all make SYCLD possible together so please help and support! Every € counts and no worries, will make a 2016 edition happen, no matter what! 

What we need and what for? 

We need this amount of money to make the event happen in the setup we all wish for. Free for spectators and participants, expanding it to 2  full days in the whole venue (4 halls) to have a lot of space for the competitions and for everyone to skate. We need everyone to contribute to the best of their abilities to cover the costs for renting the venue for two days, first aid, sound system, insurance, signs, organising, obstacles etc. With less budget we will try to do most as possible so every euro counts! 

We could choose to ask entrance, ask fees for participating but with your help we would like to avoid this. The funding we got in the past (and for which we are very grateful) is not possible anymore because of the financial risk of a free event like this, the fund stated clearly. Maybe with the amount of support we get from you they will change their mind in the future. 

Other funding parties would want to have more saying in the way the event is organised, set up and promoted. There is a too big chance it would become a political or marketing 'urban hip and happening' playing ball (we know from years of experience) and we have chosen to remain independent and organise it the way it is supposed to be and how we did it in the past editions. This is an event 'by riders', 'for riders' and those who we can inspire. And this has to stay this way. 

The Impact

SYCLD as one of the most awesome gatherings of people with a passion for longboarding there is, made possible by everyones contribution and a blue print to eventually make this happen all over the world. Let's team up and make this a real worldcup on different continents in the future, so more and more people can enjoy! 

Everyone knows the way it feels in Eindhoven and for those who don't, come over and join! 

Risks & challenges

So.. You Can Longboard Dance? has warmed the hearts of many. With a lot of begging and smiles we could do another edition with less money, even when the goal stated here is not met. But after years of so much contribution also by people involved outside of the scene (for example the investments made by the owner of the venue, just because he likes you people so much) it's time to 'hold up our own' and make this happen without others paying for it, right? 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word!! Do you know other people, organisations or who-ever who who would like to contribute, please ask them!

story:
Click Aquí para Espanol!

Short Summary



What is Havana Love Letters?

  • Havana Love Letters is a new ChoreoDrama set to premiere during Havana’s 20th Dias de la Danza Festival in April, 2016. It is the first time a North American team of artists has co-produced a new work with the exceptional dancers, musicians and designers of Cuba’s Juilliard – the famed Instituto Superior del Arte (El ISA). The process will be filmed and photographed in order to share the exciting behind-the-scenes trajectory of inter-cultural art making. Havana Love Letters explores the enduring yet fickle nature of love -- romance, humor, and patience -- so important in this time of change between our two peoples.
  • Havana Love Letters is the creation of choreographer Suki John, composer Joel Diamond, and production designer Brian Clinnan, working closely with production staff sprinkled across the U.S. and performing artists in Havana. The majority of the funds raised will be spent in the United States in preparation for the performance project to take shape in Havana for the Dias de la Danza Festival and El ISA graduation exercises. Once the work has been developed, the composition and choreography created, it will be available for professional companies to present in Cuba and the U.S.

Background on This Project

From the choreographer, Suki John....

"Twenty-two years ago the world famous ballerina Alicia Alonso gave me my big break –a commission from the Cuban National Ballet. A week before departure the composer dropped out, and in my panic a mutual friend - the great music producer Rachel Faro - introduced me to Joel Diamond. Joel wrote a spectacular score in one week; in fact it was so good my own father wondered if I could equal it with my choreography! By all accounts we were a great fit and our work, After Pandora, premiered at the Grand Teatro de la Habana during the International Ballet Festival.

Two years later Joel and I created BarrigaBestia for the Compañia Narciso Medina and the first Havana festival of modern dance: Dias de la Danza. And we started imagining another ballet - Havana Love Letters. In 2016 Dias de la Danza celebrates 20 years as a month-long festival of contemporary dance. Joel and I are still collaborating, this time on the first co-production between El ISA, Cuba’s Juilliard, and a team of North American artists. This unprecedented collaboration is great for building bridges and inter-cultural exchange.

But for me and Joel, it’s a chance to bring Havana Love Letters to life, to tell a story of love in its many twisted and redemptive forms, and to work with the spectacular Cuban artists who inspire us to keep making dances that spark ideas and optimism in audiences – no matter what their language or location." 

Magnitude of This Collaboration 

Dance goes far beyond the spoken word, communicating across language and distance. Havana Love Letters - or Cartas de Amor as it is titled in Cuba - creates a bridge across time and cultures. At the same time, a project of this size and scope builds channels of practical cooperation between our two peoples, who have been kept apart for far too long.

An Unprecedented Cultural Exchange

This production is an historic cultural exchange between two countries and two accomplished groups of artists.  The production process will be filmed and photographed, so this historic collaboration can be shared on the screen as well as the stage. Cuban partners are shouldering the largest costs usually associated with producing dance: providing the performers, costume and set construction, rehearsal space and performance venue. Several dance companies in the U.S. have already expressed interest in performing the work Stateside, including companies boasting Cuban dancers and directors. 

Our Funding Goals

In order to provide El ISA with the necessary components for this production, our goal is to raise $100,000 through several different revenue streams. With this campaign, we hope to reach 15% of that goal as a way provide the composer, choreographer and program assistants with support for operational expenses.

Our goal is to raise $15,000 with this platform, which will be the first of a two part series. The funds raised here will pay for transportation, housing for our team, costumes and set elements. It also guarantees that Cuban drivers, translators and filmmakers who are not paid by El ISA will be compensated fairly for their work on the project.

The Inspirations

Havana Love Letters is inspired by Havana itself, by Cuban dancers and musicians, poet Nicolas Guillen and painter Wilfredo Lam, and by Gabriel Garcia Marquez’s beloved novel, Love in the Time of Cholera. With a passion for Cuban dance, choreographer Suki John combines contemporary moves with the story-telling magic of classical ballet. Suki joins with New York-based composer, Joel Diamond, whose enchanting composition weaves Latin American rhythms and poetry into a lush new score. Suki and Joel have set six works on major Cuban companies, including the Cuban National Ballet. They helped inaugurate the first Cuban festival of modern dance, Dias de la Danza. In April 2016, Havana Love Letters will help kick off the 20th anniversary of this month-long, international dance festival, Dias de la Danza.

The creative team is joined by designer Brian Clinnan, whose magic touch fills the stage with colorful life. ChoreoDrama is a form that includes elements of theater, scenic design, and contemporary ballet; it is perfect for the talented artists of Cuba’s Instituto Superior del Arte, and for telling this sweeping story of compelling characters forced to navigate the currents of passion and history. 

Risks & Challenges

As diplomacy and international developments ebb and flow between the United States and Cuba, this project offers an exciting opportunity to establish cultural exchange through one of Cuba's favorite art forms: dance. 

Joel and Suki have collaborated successfully on six previous ballets in the United States and Cuba - all before the re-establishment of diplomatic ties between the U.S. and Cuba. 

Suki's work with Ballet Nacional de Cuba, Danza Contemporánea de Cuba, and other major dance companies lays the foundation for this large scale event. As diplomatic ties continue to evolve, working with Cuba remains challenging on many levels.

An example of the many potential obstacles is the difficulty of carrying  costumes and set elements from the U.S. to Cuba through customs. The experienced staff,  Suki and Joel's long standing artistic contacts, and the support of El ISA will help ease the inevitable difficulties.

Ways You Can Help

No gift is too small. By supporting this cause, you are actively helping develop cultural relations between United States and Cuba; essentially, extending an olive branch through dance, one of the most basic forms of human communication.

If you are unable to contribute, we encourage you to make some noise on social media about this campaign and use the IndieGoGo share tools to help us spread the word!


Breve resumen

Espanol

¿Qué es La Habana Cartas de Amor?

La Habana Cartas de Amor es una nuevo choreodrama, o ballet narrativo, que se estrenará durante el festival Días de la Danza de La Habana, Cuba en abril 2016.  

En una colaboración sin precedentes, un grupo de artistas de EEUU se une a los bailarines, músicos y diseñadores excepcionales del Instituto Superior del Arte (El ISA, algo asi como el Julliard de Cuba).  La Habana Love Letters explora la naturaleza voluble y perdurable del amor - que ofrece el romance, la esperanza y la paciencia - ideales importantes en estos tiempos de cambio entre nuestros dos pueblos.

La Habana Love Letters, Inc. es una organización de voluntarios sin fines de lucro formada y administrada en Fort Worth, Texas, con una red de voluntarios operando de costa a costa.  Los fondos recaudados se destinarán a la preparación preliminar del proyecto de actuación, que luego tomará forma definitiva en La Habana y se presentará durante el festival Días de la Danza.

Antecedentes sobre este proyecto

Hace veintidós años la famosa bailarina Alicia Alonso encargó a la coreógrafa Suki John un ballet para el Ballet Nacional de Cuba.  Con tal fin, Suki encargó la música  al compositor Joel Diamond, quien escribió una esplendida partitura en tan solo una semana.  Como resultado de esta colaboración, se estrenó Después de Pandora, en el Gran Teatro de La Habana en 1993.

Dos años más tarde Suki y Joel volvieron a colaborar en la creación del ballet BarrigaBestia para la Compañía de Danza de Narciso Medina, presentada durante el primer Festival de La Habana de la danza moderna: Dias de la Danza. Y empezaron a imaginar otro ballet - La Habana Love Letters.

En 2016, Dias de la Danza celebra 20 años como festival de un mes de la danza contemporánea.  La Habana Love Letters será la primera coproducción entre El ISA, Juilliard de Cuba, y un equipo de artistas norteamericanos. Esta colaboración sin precedentes es ideal para la construcción de puentes y el intercambio intercultural entre EEUU y Cuba.

Ninguna contribución es pequeña. Al apoyar este proyecto, usted está ayudando activamente a promover las relaciones culturales entre Estados Unidos y Cuba. Si no puede contribuir, por favor ayúdenos promoviendo y compartiendo esta campaña en las redes sociales. Gracias!

By supporting this cause, you are actively helping develop cultural relations between United States and Cuba; essentially, extending an olive branch through dance, one of the most basic forms of human communication.
If you are unable to contribute, we encourage you to make some noise on social media about this campaign and use the IndieGoGo share tools to help us spread the word!



Breve
resumen
Espanol
¿Qué es La Habana Cartas de Amor?
La Habana Cartas de Amor es una nuevo
choreodrama, o ballet narrativo, que se estrenará durante el festival Días de la Danza de La Habana, Cuba en
abril 2016.  
En una colaboración sin precedentes, un grupo
de artistas de EEUU se une a los bailarines, músicos y diseñadores excepcionales
del Instituto Superior del Arte (El ISA, algo asi como el Julliard de Cuba).  La Habana
Love Letters explora la naturaleza voluble y perdurable del amor - que ofrece
el romance, la esperanza y la paciencia - ideales importantes en estos tiempos
de cambio entre nuestros dos pueblos.
La Habana Love Letters, Inc. es una
organización de voluntarios sin fines de lucro formada y administrada en Fort
Worth, Texas, con una red de voluntarios operando de costa a costa.  Los fondos recaudados se destinarán a la
preparación preliminar del proyecto de actuación, que luego tomará forma definitiva
en La Habana y se presentará durante el festival Días de la Danza.
Antecedentes sobre este proyecto
Hace veintidós años la famosa bailarina Alicia
Alonso encargó a la coreógrafa Suki John un ballet para el Ballet Nacional de
Cuba.  Con tal fin, Suki encargó la música
 al compositor Joel Diamond, quien escribió
una esplendida partitura en tan solo una semana.  Como resultado de esta colaboración, se
estrenó Después de Pandora, en el
Gran Teatro de La Habana en 1993.
Dos años más tarde Suki y Joel volvieron
a colaborar en la creación del ballet BarrigaBestia
para la Compañía de Danza de Narciso Medina, presentada durante el primer Festival
de La Habana de la danza moderna: Dias de
la Danza. Y empezaron a imaginar otro ballet - La Habana Love Letters. 
En 2016, Dias de la Danza celebra 20 años
como festival de un mes de la danza contemporánea.  La Habana Love Letters será la primera
coproducción entre El ISA, Juilliard de Cuba, y un equipo de artistas
norteamericanos. Esta colaboración sin precedentes es ideal para la
construcción de puentes y el intercambio intercultural entre EEUU y Cuba.




Ninguna contribución es pequeña.  Al apoyar este proyecto, usted está ayudando activamente a promover las relaciones culturales entre Estados Unidos y Cuba. Si no puede contribuir, por favor ayúdenos promoviendo y compartiendo esta campaña en las redes sociales.  Gracias!

story:
The best new Australian writing is arriving in NYC.

Emilie Collyer is a playwright whose work you need to know.  So we're bringing her award-winning sci-fi play The Good Girl to off-Broadway in February 2016 and we need your help!

This is an incredible opportunity for Emilie, for us and especially for NYC audiences to experience new, provocative writing that explores issues of gender, power and exploitation.  

Here's what critics said in Melbourne:

     "Collyer’s witty two-hander merges black comedy with the absurd and the political, using sharp, well observed and funny dialogue"  - Herald Sun

     "Smart, slick and funny...hilarious one-liners are peppered liberally throughout this clear, complex, crystallised story: big ideas, with an even bigger heart." - Heckler.com.au 

     "Like a post cyber punk Gertrude Stein" - Theatre Alive

We already have an amazing venue...

Our company, Joyseekers Theatre, have been chosen to present this play as part of 59E59 Theaters' Winter Season.  

Yes, a drama-desk award winning off-Broadway theatre is throwing their full support behind this production!  They're providing us with press, marketing, box office and staffing support at their sleek multi-venue facility in NYC's East Midtown.

We're excited!

...and with your support we can make this happen.

Most importantly, your contribution will go towards stipends for everyone involved in the project.

Then we'll need money for other things too - sets, props, costumes, rehearsal space, vehicle rental, laundry, printing scripts, caffeinating our team on long tech days, insurance, production photographs, etc.

If you can contribute just $20, that's one hour of rehearsal space, or a pair of pants for an actor, some recycled wood we can use to build our set, or gas for the van we'll need to load in and out of the theatre.

If you can't donate...please share!

Helping us get the word out makes a huge difference.

Thank you for choosing our project and for supporting new, international work.  We can't wait to share it with you!

With bucket loads of theatrical passion,

Leah, Evan and Carlos - Producers, Joyseekers Theatre

story:
We're in our final week of fundraising!

Thanks to the support of over 200 generous donors, we've managed to raise over $20,000 towards finishing Planet Ant Hall! That's amazing. We're already getting started using that money, making plans for the construction of the walls that will separate the theatre with the rest of the building, but there is still much to do and more money to raise. 

That's where you come in! 

We're adding some new perks in this final stretch, including a purple version of our new throwback t-shirt and a complete 2016-17 season pass for our original Planet Ant black space.

Consider make a contribution today, and please spread the word!

Here's where we're at...

Planet Ant Theatre is a small, non-profit black box venue that has been a fixture in Hamtramck, Michigan, for 20 years. 

For 20 years, we have focused on Detroit talent, giving Detroit artists a place where they can hone their skills and express themselves.

And for 20 years, we have looked longingly across the street at the old banquet hall, daydreaming about how many more opportunities we could offer to more Detroit artists if we could one day buy that place and fill it with art.  

Finally, this last February, we bought it. 

We immediately began work cleaning it and transforming it into a space fit for theatre.  

We’ve gotten from here…

To here…

But as it turns out, building a new performance space to showcase Detroit area talent is a lot more expensive than you’d think.

So we humbly ask for your help. It’s taken us 20 years to get this far. Without you, it could still be years more before we can give the residents of Hamtramck a cultural gem they can really be proud of, offer audiences the best all-around experience, and provide the Detroit theater community the kind of performance space it deserves.

Help us IndieGoGo. You’re our only hope.

(Psst… hey… there could also be a Tee shirt in it for ya.)


Yeah, but what is Planet Ant Theatre anyway?

Since its opening, Planet Ant has evolved into a cultural hub for southeastern Michigan.

Originally opening in 1993 as a coffeehouse, Planet Ant quickly became known for its art openings, poetry readings and open mic nights.

In 1996, it transitioned into a small black box storefront theatre. Keegan-Michael Key, MadTV alum and co-creator of Comedy Central’s Key and Peele, was one of the original founders of the theater, and the theater has since been an early stepping stone for many other artists who have moved on to prosperous show business careers.

Monday nights at Planet Ant feature the longest running improv show in Michigan, and the Home Team regularly performs for oversold houses.

And for those who wish to accept “Yes And” as their savior, we have provided training to 100’s of aspiring improvisers in our training center.

We have always striven to give artists creative freedom in our space, and thus, we’ve explored various genres and media. We plan to continue that philosophy in our new space, and this new, bigger space will allow us to offer more opportunities to more Detroit artists. This growth in our stable of artists will allow us to expand our audiences. It will also allow for an expansion of our web presence via more short films and music videos and live streaming of performances, even further expanding our audience. Ultimately, this will allow for more Detroit art to be seen around the world… and for more Detroit voices to be heard.  

Cool? Then help out the cause… and seriously… there could be a Tee shirt in it for ya.


How will the Ant Hall impact the community?

The banquet hall we purchased had previously been kind of a menace to the neighborhood, frequently hosting loud parties that Hamtramck police would inevitably have to disperse. Since we’ve acquired it, several neighbors have stopped by to thank us for trying to turn the former nuisance on the block into a home for theatre and music.

Hamtramck, completely surrounded by the city of Detroit, has long had a reputation for being an arts community because of its vibrant music scene. The low cost of living has drawn numerous artists to the neighborhood. Detroit’s continued resurgence has further encouraged people to rediscover the area’s artsy offerings. Planet Ant’s expansion will be another crown jewel in the city’s culture scene, cementing its reputation as a place for art.


How will you spend our donations?

Building a new theatre that will have such an impact on our community isn't cheap. Take a look at all these expensive things that we still need to deal with:

Lighting and Sound Equipment – $25,000

Complete Construction – $20,000

  • Soundproof walls to separate the performance area from the other public areas of the building

  • Finish build-out of dressing room areas

Tables and Chairs – $10,000

And if there’s extra money because you all rally to surpass our goal, there are these things too:

Doors (yikes, they’re expensive) – $7,500

Outside Lighting and Signage – $5,000

Exterior Painting – $7,500

  • Including a cool new mural on the side of the building. (another opportunity for another Detroit artist) 


Your donation is tax deductible. (What?)
(I know, right?)

Planet Ant Theatre is a 501(c)3 non-profit entity, which means the government will allow you to deduct a portion (possibly up to the full amount) of your donation to this campaign on your 2016 taxes.

You may be wondering what we mean by “possibly up to the full amount,” to which we say, “Good catch.” When the campaign ends, we'll contact you to confirm that you want to receive the tangible perks associated with your donation (like that tee shirt). If you do want your perks, the cost of those perks has to be deducted from the amount of your contribution. Sorry, but that’s the law. We'll even e-mail you a tax receipt for your records if you'd like one. 


Here's the Perks

You can find the full list of perks below, but take a look at these photos to get an idea of what you're getting for your money. You know, besides the warm feeling in your heart you'll get from helping us fulfill our dreams.
The Sticker:

Ohh, look at those pretty posters!

We promised you a Tee Shirt. This one is inspired by the original Planet Ant Coffee Shop logo. History on your back.


If that's not cool enough, donate an additional $10 for the purple version of our new shirt.



I mean, come on, who wouldn't want to earn some tickets to a future, kickass show in our new space!


$5 – Ant Call. We’ll put your name on our website, so that everyone knows how grateful we are for your support. And in case anyone misses it on the website, we’ll include your name on our newsletter so that everyone on our mailing list will know of your philanthropic tendencies.

$10 – Ant Pride. You’ll get a Planet Ant Sticker suitable for sticking on your bumper or your back window or your trapper keeper. Plus, we’ll put your name on our website and in our newsletter.

$20 – Reminisce Ant. Receive a Promotional Poster from your favorite show from the last five years, suitable for framing. Plus, a sticker and the shout outs.

$50 – Ant Chic. Impress your friends, family and passers-by with your fancy new Planet Ant T-Shirt. All the other shirts in your closet will be jealous. Plus, the sticker and the shout outs.  

$100 – Hamtown Aces. A pair of tickets for you and a date to see a show at Ant Hall once programming begins this fall. Plus, a pair of t-shirts.

$200 – Ants de Extravagance. You will get admission for two for an opening weekend VIP party and two tickets for an opening weekend performance at Ant Hall. Plus a t-shirt… OK, 2 t-shirts… but no sticker or poster.

$250 – Impart Ant. Your improv team will receive two coaching sessions (of two hours each) from a Home team member (based on availability). Your team will also be one of the first Monday Night guest teams when Improv Monday moves over to Ant Hall.

$500 – Ant Stamp. At this donation level, your name will be stamped into Ant history. In the lobby of Ant Hall, we will permanently display a list of our angels, and your name will be on it. Plus: enjoy 2 tickets to the opening weekend VIP party and 2 tickets to an opening weekend performance at Ant Hall. Plus: 2 T-Shirts.

$1000 – ANThem. The new Planet Ant House Band will write you a personalized thank you song, record it and send you the MP3. Your name will also be stamped into Ant history. Plus, you'll get 2 tickets to the opening weekend VIP party (at which your song will be performed by the House Band), 2 tickets to an opening weekend performance at Ant Hall and 2 t-shirts.


Risks and Challenges

To us, a “sold out” show has always meant 50 people. While we have had success filling our current space, we are now adding three times more seating with the new space. To fill so many seats week after week will be a challenge. Because we’ve built a large, loyal audience in our 20-year history and because we’ve earned a solid reputation for offering audiences a great night out, we are confident that people will most definitely come.

Also, Hamtramck is a very ethnically diverse city. We must challenge ourselves to be all inclusive in our programming, or we will risk just becoming another example of urban gentrification.
