story:
THE GOAL:

Help us produce the world premiere of the new musical BUMPERSTICKER  - by the creators of the award-winning hit musical Bukowsical - at this year’s Hollywood Fringe Festival in Los Angeles, California!   We must raise $17,500 to pay for our cast and crew, equipment, venue rental, and marketing. In return for your generous contribution, we offer an exciting array of perks (see right) ranging from digital copies of the show music, limited edition bumperstickers, tickets to one of the Hollywood Fringe Festival performances, signed show posters, all the way to producing credits!

THE SHOW:  BUMPERSTICKER  is the brainchild of Gary Stockdale and Spencer Green, who created Bukowsical, the acclaimed musical about besotten literary hero Charles Bukowski which won Outstanding Musical at the New York International Fringe Festival.   BUMPERSTICKER is set during a massive urban traffic jam, with each song inspired by one of those blunt, punchy slogans you’ve seen on the backs of cars throughout your life--and, yes, may even have put on the back of your own car. As the frustrations of morning gridlock mount, we get to know the people and stories behind these stickers: you may enthusiastically agree or violently disagree with them but, in the end, everybody has a point of view they think is completely rational...and always correct.

Throughout the show, there will be projected images of freeways, cars and traffic, along with the actual bumperstickers that are the basis for each of the songs. There will also be an Announcer/radio D.J. who serves as our guide and as a link to the different songs, and who takes on a number of different personalities: commercial pitchman, conservative blowhard, shrill left-wing pundit, a trucker, and more. Through this structure, we hope to present a kaleidoscopic view of our culture today, in all of its divisive, varied, and uniquely American attitudes.

THE TEAM:

Gary Stockdale (Music, Book & Lyrics):

Gary is a 2-time EMMY-nominated TV & film composer (Sabrina, the Teenage Witch; Penn & Teller: Bullshit!, The Aristocrats), a veteran studio singer (Jurassic World, Tomorrowland, Skyfall  w/Adele on 2013 Oscars), and a touring songwriter. He was also an original member of The Brian Setzer Orchestra, and sang a featured solo in the cult-classic musical TV series, Cop/Rock.   With Spencer Green, Gary co-wrote the irreverent adult musical Bukowsical, which won Outstanding Musical at the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival. Gary also composed the score for the original Off-Broadway production of Playdead, which recently played at South Coast Rep. Bukowsical, the CD, as well as his pop/comedy album Sure Of Mice Elf are on Amazon and all music sites.

Spencer Green (Book & Lyrics):

Spencer Green reminds you that the use of flash photography or any sound recording devices is strictly prohibited during this biography. Mr. Green has written for In Living Color, AAAHH!!! Real Monsters, Duckman, Mad TV, The Fairly Oddparents, Denis Leary’s Merry F#%$in’ Christmas, Americana for BBC Radio, and the radio play podcast Labora-Story for St. Louis’ Theatre Lab. He was a contributing editor for more than two decades to Leonard Maltin’s annual Movie Guide, as well as co-editor of Maltin’s Movie Encyclopedia and managing editor of Maltin’s Classic Movie Guide, and edited We'll Never Be Young Again: Remembering the Last Days of John F. Kennedy. Mr. Green performs at the Los Angeles comedic writers’ salon Sit ‘n Spin and is co-author/co-lyricist of Bukowsical, which won Outstanding Musical at the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival and was later produced by St. Louis’ New Line Theatre and North Carolina’s C’est La Guerre. He also writes regularly for The Huffington Post and created the parody Web site The Parallel Universe Film Guide; his plays have been produced by St. Louis’ Theatre Lab, Chicago’s Hobo Junction, and Los Angeles’ Sci-Fest LA. We hope you have enjoyed this bio. Now, please exit on the right-hand side.

Michele Spears (Director):

Michele Spears is a theatre director, choreographer, actress and arts educator. Her work has been recognized with New York Nightlife, LA Weekly, StagesceneLA, UNIMA, Saturn, Dramalogue, and Santa Barbara Independent awards, as well as an American Choreographers Award nomination. Recent projects include Object Of Her Affection (Redcat), Sondheim UnScripted (Oregon Shakespeare Festival & Falcon Theatre), and the operas Curlew River and Miss Donnithorne’s Maggot  for Jacaranda. She has also staged works for the Ojai Playwrights Festival, Cornerstone Theatre, The Migrant Youth Theatre Project, Musical Theatre Guild at The Pasadena Playhouse, The Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and  Mercury Musicals in London, among others. She has been an associate artist with the Academy of New Musical Theatre/New Musicals Inc. and the L.A. Gay Men’s Chorus, and was a guest artist at the O’Neill Theatre Center’s National Puppetry Conference. Michele is a founding member of Impro Theatre, a Los Angeles based company specializing in narrative improvisational works, and a member of the performing arts faculty at Harvard Westlake School.

Michael Blaha (Producer):

Mike is very proud to have been a producer of Bukowsical both here in Los Angeles and at the New York International Fringe Festival, where it won Outstanding Musical.  Among Mike’s numerous other Los Angeles stage producing credits are Job: The Hip-Hopera (Stella Adler Theater; Los Angeles Drama Critics and LA Weekly Best Musical nominations), Hoboken to Hollywood (Edgemar Theater, LA Weekly Best Musical of the Year) and several productions at the Hollywood Fringe Festival, including Richard Parker (Best International Production), Nigerian Spam Scam Scam (Encore Award) and Pick of the Fringe (Best Cabaret and Variety Nominee). Mike has also produced over 35 shows at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe , including runt (Fringe First; Sony Radio Academy Award winner for Best Drama for BBC World Service production), Night in November (Best Actor Award), Sabotage: In Fine Form (Perrier Best Newcomer Nominee), and A Night at the Sans Hotel (Stage Award Nominee). Mike is also one of the founding co-producers of Sci-Fest LA, the Festival of One Act Science Fiction Plays, now in its third year, and President of New Musicals, Inc. His film producing credits include Chi Girl (Slamdance Grand Jury Prize Winner), The Dogwalker (Cinefest Best New Director),  runt (Pan African Festival Best New Director Nominee), Tropicalia (Telluride Film Festival selection) and the acclaimed short film Legend of Beaver Dam (multiple international Best Short Awards and Honorable Mention, Sundance Film Festival).

THE HISTORY:

Back in 2001, Spencer Green was a member of a “tightcircle” called The Stump, an internet chat room/forum populated by hundreds of entertainment industry writers, actors, directors, and producers, most of whom were vastly more well-known, rich, and powerful than him. At one of the various Stump get-togethers, Green met fellow Stumper Gary Stockdale, and they talked of pigs and wings and their love for Broadway musicals. The next day, for Gary’s amusement, Green hastily posted on The Stump a list of fictional Broadway shows that were playing, with titles like “Bergen Belsen Bingo,” “Aack! A Cathy Musical!” and “Bukowsical.” Stockdale was intrigued by the last idea and suggested that he and Green actually write some tunes based upon the conceit of the famously profane writer Charles Bukowski being an unlikely subject for a musical. This eventually led to the first productions of Bukowsical at Los Angeles’ respected Sacred Fools Theatre in 2006. The show took the form of a backer’s audition being held by a fictional theatre troupe called The Sacred Angel Fist Circle of Note Gang (SAFCNG), in which they beg the audience for money to mount their latest (highly questionable) project, Bukowsical. They believe in the power of theatre to change the world and keep on plugging away, knowing that some day the world will eventually catch on. Bukowsical received critical acclaim from the “L.A. Weekly” (“riotously funny”), “The Los Angeles Times” (“an uproarious romp”), and “Backstage West,” which said: “It’s terrific fun, and so wrong in all the right ways.” In February of 2007, Bukowsical was invited to appear at New Mexico’s prestigious Revolutions Festival, and then played at 2007’s New York Fringe Festival, where it played to sold-out crowds (Variety described the demand for tickets thusly: “It’s been a frenzy”) and won the award for Outstanding Musical. A CD of the score was released by Kritzerland Records in 2010 and productions of the show were staged by St. Louis’ New Line Theatre and Wilmington’s C’est La Guerre. After Bukowsical, Stockdale and Green wanted to try a different approach for a musical, something that would encompass many different song styles and that did not rely too heavily on a story-driven narrative. And thus, BUMPERSTICKER was born.
story_txt:
THE GOAL: 
 Help us produce the world premiere of the new musical BUMPERSTICKER  - by the creators of the award-winning hit musical Bukowsical - at this year’s Hollywood Fringe Festival in Los Angeles, California!   We must raise $17,500 to pay for our cast and crew, equipment, venue rental, and marketing. In return for your generous contribution, we offer an exciting array of perks (see right) ranging from digital copies of the show music, limited edition bumperstickers, tickets to one of the Hollywood Fringe Festival performances, signed show posters, all the way to producing credits!
THE SHOW:  BUMPERSTICKER  is the brainchild of Gary Stockdale and Spencer Green, who created Bukowsical, the acclaimed musical about besotten literary hero Charles Bukowski which won Outstanding Musical at the New York International Fringe Festival.   BUMPERSTICKER is set during a massive urban traffic jam, with each song inspired by one of those blunt, punchy slogans you’ve seen on the backs of cars throughout your life--and, yes, may even have put on the back of your own car. As the frustrations of morning gridlock mount, we get to know the people and stories behind these stickers: you may enthusiastically agree or violently disagree with them but, in the end, everybody has a point of view they think is completely rational...and always correct.
Throughout the show, there will be projected images of freeways, cars and traffic, along with the actual bumperstickers that are the basis for each of the songs. There will also be an Announcer/radio D.J. who serves as our guide and as a link to the different songs, and who takes on a number of different personalities: commercial pitchman, conservative blowhard, shrill left-wing pundit, a trucker, and more. Through this structure, we hope to present a kaleidoscopic view of our culture today, in all of its divisive, varied, and uniquely American attitudes.

THE TEAM:
 
Gary Stockdale (Music, Book & Lyrics):
Gary is a 2-time EMMY-nominated TV
& film composer (Sabrina, the Teenage
Witch; Penn & Teller: Bullshit!, The Aristocrats), a veteran studio singer (Jurassic World, Tomorrowland, Skyfall  w/Adele on 2013 Oscars), and a touring songwriter. He was also an original
member of The Brian Setzer Orchestra, and sang a featured solo in the
cult-classic musical TV series, Cop/Rock.   With
Spencer Green, Gary co-wrote the irreverent adult musical Bukowsical, which won Outstanding Musical at the 2007 New York International
Fringe Festival. Gary also composed the score for the original Off-Broadway
production of Playdead, which
recently played at South Coast Rep. Bukowsical,
the CD, as well as his pop/comedy album Sure Of Mice Elf are on
Amazon and all music sites.Spencer Green (Book & Lyrics):
Spencer Green reminds you that the use of flash photography or any sound recording devices is strictly prohibited during this biography. Mr. Green has written for In Living Color, AAAHH!!! Real Monsters, Duckman, Mad TV, The Fairly Oddparents, Denis Leary’s Merry F#%$in’ Christmas, Americana for BBC Radio, and the radio play podcast Labora-Story for St. Louis’ Theatre Lab. He was a contributing editor for more than two decades to Leonard Maltin’s annual Movie Guide, as well as co-editor of Maltin’s Movie Encyclopedia and managing editor of Maltin’s Classic Movie Guide, and edited We'll Never Be Young Again: Remembering the Last Days of John F. Kennedy. Mr. Green performs at the Los Angeles comedic writers’ salon Sit ‘n Spin and is co-author/co-lyricist of Bukowsical, which won Outstanding Musical at the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival and was later produced by St. Louis’ New Line Theatre and North Carolina’s C’est La Guerre. He also writes regularly for The Huffington Post and created the parody Web site The Parallel Universe Film Guide; his plays have been produced by St. Louis’ Theatre Lab, Chicago’s Hobo Junction, and Los Angeles’ Sci-Fest LA. We hope you have enjoyed this bio. Now, please exit on the right-hand side.Michele Spears (Director):Michele Spears is a theatre director, choreographer,
actress and arts educator. Her work has been recognized with New York
Nightlife, LA Weekly, StagesceneLA, UNIMA, Saturn, Dramalogue, and Santa
Barbara Independent awards, as well as an American Choreographers Award
nomination. Recent projects include Object Of Her Affection (Redcat), Sondheim
UnScripted (Oregon Shakespeare Festival & Falcon Theatre), and the
operas Curlew River and Miss Donnithorne’s Maggot  for
Jacaranda. She has also staged works for the Ojai Playwrights Festival,
Cornerstone Theatre, The Migrant Youth Theatre Project, Musical Theatre Guild
at The Pasadena Playhouse, The Edinburgh Fringe Festival, and  Mercury
Musicals in London, among others. She has been an associate artist with the Academy
of New Musical Theatre/New Musicals Inc. and the L.A. Gay Men’s Chorus, and was
a guest artist at the O’Neill Theatre Center’s National Puppetry Conference.
Michele is a founding member of Impro Theatre, a Los Angeles based company
specializing in narrative improvisational works, and a member of the performing
arts faculty at Harvard Westlake School.Michael Blaha (Producer):Mike is very proud to have been a producer of Bukowsical both here in Los Angeles and at the New York International Fringe Festival, where it won Outstanding Musical.  Among Mike’s numerous other Los Angeles stage producing credits are Job: The Hip-Hopera (Stella Adler Theater; Los Angeles Drama Critics and LA Weekly Best Musical nominations), Hoboken to Hollywood (Edgemar Theater, LA Weekly Best Musical of the Year) and several productions at the Hollywood Fringe Festival, including Richard Parker (Best International Production), Nigerian Spam Scam Scam (Encore Award) and Pick of the Fringe (Best Cabaret and Variety Nominee).   Mike has also produced over 35 shows at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe , including runt (Fringe First; Sony Radio Academy Award winner for Best Drama for BBC World Service production), Night in November (Best Actor Award), Sabotage: In Fine Form (Perrier Best Newcomer Nominee), and A Night at the Sans Hotel (Stage Award Nominee).   Mike is also one of the founding co-producers of Sci-Fest LA, the Festival of One Act Science Fiction Plays, now in its third year, and President of New Musicals, Inc.    His film producing credits include Chi Girl (Slamdance Grand Jury Prize Winner), The Dogwalker (Cinefest Best New Director),  runt (Pan African Festival Best New Director Nominee), Tropicalia (Telluride Film Festival selection) and the acclaimed short film Legend of Beaver Dam (multiple international Best Short Awards and Honorable Mention, Sundance Film Festival).

A Cathy Musical!” and “Bukowsical.”

This eventually led to the first productions of Bukowsical at Los Angeles’ respected Sacred Fools Theatre in 2006. The show took the form of a backer’s audition being held by a fictional theatre troupe called The Sacred Angel Fist Circle of Note Gang (SAFCNG), in which they beg the audience for money to mount their latest (highly questionable) project, Bukowsical. They believe in the power of theatre to change the world and keep on plugging away, knowing that some day the world will eventually catch on. Bukowsical received critical acclaim from the “L.A. Weekly” (“riotously funny”), “The Los Angeles Times” (“an uproarious romp”), and “Backstage West,” which said: “It’s terrific fun, and so wrong in all the right ways.” In February of 2007, Bukowsical was invited to appear at New Mexico’s prestigious Revolutions Festival, and then played at 2007’s New York Fringe Festival, where it played to sold-out crowds (Variety described the demand for tickets thusly: “It’s been a frenzy”) and won the award for Outstanding Musical. After Bukowsical, Stockdale and Green wanted to try a different approach for a musical, something that would encompass many different song styles and that did not rely too heavily on a story-driven narrative. And thus, BUMPERSTICKER was born.

story:
BRIAH Danse

Artistic Director : Jayne Persch*

Upcoming Performances : Tomorrow's Never Promised                                              April 22nd and 24th at the Dairy Center for Arts Boulder, CO

BRIAH means  'Life Breath'!

BRIAH is a contemporary ballet company, blending the traditions of movement from the past with the stories of today.
The dancers are amazing, the repertory is edgy and the direction is smart.

Tomorrow’s Never Promised is challenging, visually abstract
and musically versatile.

Dance and the expression of the human spirit through the arts are fundamental to our purpose and is the sole reason why this company exists. 

Contribute to BRIAH to ensure it's future and root this new company in Colorado. Your donations support dancers, create more venues, buy pointe shoes for dancers, sponsor new works and encourage more collaborations with visual, musical and performing artists and groups.

Support our company by coming to our performances beginning in April at the Dairy Center for the Arts in Boulder, the Colorado Black Box Theater at the Armstrong Center in Denver and more venues, workshops and performances.


* Jayne Persch has trained and danced with American Ballet Theatre and the Royal Ballet in London. She teaches and sets choreography nationally and internationally including the Royal Danish Ballet , Dansens Hus, Copenhagen Dance Arts in Denmark, Accademia Nazionale di Danza - Roma. She directed Hypaxis Center for the Arts and served as Artistic Director, Resident Choroeographer and Associate Artistic Director for several companies including the Springfield Ballet, New Hampshire Contemporary Ballet, BRIAH Contemporary Dance & Jayne Persch & Co. Ms. Persch has a Master of Arts in Dance & Psychology. She is fully certified in ABT National Training Curriculum, Feldenkrais Self-Corrective Mechanisms and creator of 'Embodied Awareness for Dance & Movement - a blend of knowledge from 'Anatomy Trains', Tai Chi, Yoga and Craniosacral Therapy. Ms. Persch is a member of CID-UNESCO.

story:
The Reason

Hi, there. My name is Greg Adkins, writer of "Executive Decision." I've been pretty passionate about exploring characters and bringing them to life ever since third grade when I won a creative writing contest for a short story about monkeys run amok in our classroom. Since then, I like to believe the stories and the writing have grown marginally more sophisticated ... Jury's still out.

Upon moving to New York City in 1996, I fell hard for live theater. When I first saw "Bring in da' Noise, Bring in da' Funk," I was both fascinated and inspired, and I knew I wanted to be involved in theater in some way. That's one reason this crowd-funding campaign is so important to me; It's an opportunity to fulfill that dream and to bring this work to a larger audience with an amazing director, an incredibly accomplished team of actors, and with a play I'm proud to showcase for three performances at the 2016 New York Theater Thespis Festival at the Hudson Guild Theater at Elliot Center (Oct. 3, 6:15 pm | Oct. 6, 9:00 pm | Oct. 9, 3:30 pm)

The Play

"Executive Decision" explores Presidential politics, the backroom bargaining that is all too often a hallmark of Washington D.C., and the struggle between citizens' right-to-privacy and the U.S. intelligence apparatus. 

In "Executive Decision," we meet Madam President, a Senator who wins the Presidency in unexpected fashion.  Her opposition to the National Security Agency's domestic surveillance program, however, puts her at odds with that organization's top brass. Will she sign an executive order ending the program once and for all, or will a shadowy agent prevent her from acting on principle? 

Recent exposure of the U.S. government's domestic surveillance and monitoring in the wake of revelations by former NSA contractor Edward Snowden have raised serious questions about how far a government should be able to go in securing its citizens. Should we as a people be more concerned with safeguarding the right to privacy, or does the protection of lives surpass even The Constitution? 

The Perks

If you're generous enough to contribute, we have a list of perks we'd love to share, including: 

  • a "Thank You" in the playbill
  • a playbill autographed by the cast, director and playwright
  • a poster autographed by the cast, director and playwright
  • a script autographed by the cast, director and playwright
  • an invite to the dress rehearsal before the play's premiere
  • two tickets to a performance of your choosing.

The Expenses

Just a few of the costs associated with staging a play include renting rehearsal space, purchasing costumes and props, paying the cast, the director and a sound and lighting operator. All of which comes at a price, of course, but we wanted to give the play the best team available to offer audiences the most positive experience we could.

The Team

Lisa Stevens (Director) Credits include: Film: State Like Sleep; Diary of A Wimpy Kid. Theatre: World premiere of The Little Prince; Sister Act, Spamalot, The Little Mermaid, Anne of Green Gables. Randolph Academy: Director of Footloose; U.S. Premiere of Witches of Eastwick; Mary Poppins U.S.; Mary Poppins (Citadel/Theater Calgary -over 17 Theater Critic Nominations); Dolly Parton’s 9 to 5 U.S. Tour/ U.K. Tour; Vancouver Playhouse - In The Heights, Spamalot, Xanadu; World Premiere of Disney’s High School Musical ; Disney’s HSM 1 & 2 U.K., West End, Japan, Spain, and Australia; Cutman (Goodspeed Opera House); First Wives Club (The Old Globe, San Diego). Off-Broadway - Bingo! The Musical, NYMF "Common Grounds" (Excellence in Direction and Choreography Award). On faculty at AMDA in NY, and recently inducted into UNESCO’S CID, the International Dance Counsel in Paris,which recognizes excellence in companies and individuals in Dance. Other: 2010 Olympic Victory Ceremonies, Top of the Pops UK, Smash Hit Awards UK, Royal Variety Performance for Her Majesty the Queen.

Barbara Bayes (actor, Madam President) Theatre: Always A Bridesmaid (Libby Ruth), The Heidi Chronicles (Fran/April), The Vagina Monologues (guess which ones!), Into The Woods (Witch), Nunsense (Robert Anne), Last of the Red Hot Lovers (Elaine) and more. Television: Investigation Discovery: A Crime To Remember (Clara Ward) and Six Degrees of Murder (Suzanne Vincent), HBO: Show Me A Hero (Angry community protestor), QVC (guest host), numerous commercials. Independent Film Credits: Your Own Canoe (Aunt Connie), The Bench (Sylvia). Next up: National Tour – How the Grinch Stole Christmas – the Musical (Grandma Who). 


Richard Clodfelter (actor, Agent Gordon) Theatre: A Little Princess and The Alchemist. His leading roles include Lear (King Lear), Claudius (Hamlet), Oberon (A Midsummer Night's Dream), Banquo (Macbeth), Henry Higgins (Pygmalion), and Willy Loman (Death of a Salesman). He spent nearly three decades acting and directing throughout Europe, Asia and Central America with Munich-based ADG-Europe and TNT Music Theatre Britain in over 90 international tours. Earlier this year, he played Vice President Humphrey in All The Way in Washington, D.C. For 25 years, he has directed the longest-running production of A Christmas Carol in continental Europe and recently directed a Spanish language production of The Fantasticks in Costa Rica.

Josh Evans (actor, Agent #1) Theatre: Remission (Columbia University); Post Concussive Syndrome (The Abingdon Theatre); Rubber Ducks and Sunsets (Ground Up Productions); Outpost (Gallery Players); Domestic (Midtown International Theatre Festival); The Importance of Being Earnest (Ground UP Productions); The Dumb Waiter (Under St. Marks). Film: Killing the Dog (Six Part Productions); Annabelle (Hideout Hill, Cannes Film Festival). Television: “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt” (Netflix), “Blacklist” (NBC), “Show Me a Hero” (HBO, David Simon and Paul Haggis). Graduate - UNC Chapel Hill and Michael Howard Studios. Company Member - Ground UP Productions. Founding Member - Six Part Productions.

Marianne Mason (actor, Doris) Theatre: Other People’s Money (Kate Sullivan, Esq.), Still Life (Nadine), Night of the Iguana (Ms. Judith Fellowes), The Odd Couple (Cecily Pigeon), Nadezhda (Nadezhda, wife of Josef Stalin), Sheila and Angelo (Nurse Debbie), See Through My Lens (Joy Rider) and more. Film and Television: Grand Isle (Mme. Julia Highcamp), False Witness (Dr. Martha Leeds), Lion of the West (Mary Walter), Storyville (Reporter). 

The Challenges

Putting on a play ain't easy. There are logistical headaches and creative differences that can threaten to derail even the most well-crafted play. This team, however, is filled with amazing individuals, seasoned professionals who understand the risks ahead and have faced them down with confidence and poise in the past. 

The Alternative

Even if you can't kick in financially, not to worry. We get it. It would be much appreciated, though, if you could spread the word, tap into your social media outlets, use Indiegogo's sharing options or just come check out the show!

If you're going to be in the New York City area on Oct. 3rd (6:15pm), Oct. 6th (9:00pm) or Oct. 9th (3:30pm), please visit us at the Hudson Guild Theater, Elliott Center, at 441 W. 26th St. To order tickets online, visit:

http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2571114

Thanks a lot, everyone!

story:
The Martial Law era from 1972-1986 were dark days for the Philippines. The massive theft and corruption by the despot Ferdinand E. Marcos were overshadowed only by the atrocities that happened during that regime– tortures, deaths, disappearances, a throttled press and the curtailment of personal freedoms– the effects of which the country is still enduring now.  

In February of 1986, the country finally succeeded in overthrowing the dictatorship. 



Yet in  the evening of May 9, 2016, people watched in shock as Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr. was almost elected as Vice President on May 9, 2016–  only losing by a narrow margin. 14 million people voted for him, nearly putting him in a position that was a heartbeat away from the Presidency. 

The Problem

It was clear that for many Filipinos, Martial Law has become an abstract idea several decades old. And even worse, it has become an appealing idea to the youth, longing for days of discipline, adherence to the law, and a false peace under a police state. The atrocities of that era have become largely invisible, buried by both time and secrecy much like many of the victims of these state-sanctioned crimes.

Worse,  we are now seeing a growing sentiment that devalues human rights, the rule of law, and democracy in the public today as a result.



The lessons of the Martial Law era have not been learned. We have a lot of catching up to do. 

The Project: Never Again, Voices of Martial Law


 

Through  MarkaBayan: Mga Kuwentong Hindi Mabubura  campaign, Ladies Who Launch intends to do its part by staging and touring Never Again: Voices of Martial Law (NAVoML).

NAVoML consists of nine (9) Martial Law-themed one-act plays grouped into sets of three (3). These plays are designed to create awareness on the martyrs of the Martial Law era, the people around them, their work and its impact on the Philippines today. 

Notable names in theatre such as Audie Gemora, Rody Vera, Pinky Amador, Lou Veloso, Kanakan Balintagos, and Chris Martinez are involved in the production. This initiative also has the support of the Coalition Against the Burial of Marcos at LNMB, a broad coalition composed of Martial Law victims, claimants, NGOs, and various civil society groups. 

What We Need

We would like to invite you to partner with us in mounting and touring this theatrical education campaign. The play's preview will be on September 21, the anniversary of the proclamation of Martial Law. Weekend performances will run from September 23 until to October 16 at the Bantayog ng mga Bayani Auditorium.

The money raised in this campaign will go towards 1) funding our first season at Bantayog ng mga Bayani, including costumes, sets, and lighting design, as well as salaries and stipends for actors, playwrights, choreographers, designers, educators, stage managers, and crew, and 2) touring the production around different schools, cities, and provinces. We will put your money directly into the production. 

What You Get

For as little as 500 pesos (12 USD),  you get a ticket to one show of your choice, consisting of a set of 3 plays along with our everlasting gratitude. (descriptions and schedules below.) If you are not able to enjoy the show, let us know, and it will go towards sponsoring a student who needs to learn about the Martial Law era badly. 

You can also choose to sponsor a whole show, as well as other perk packages in this campaign  

The Impact

What we'd like to do is unearth the stories of Martial Law and the Marcos era and make them visible, visceral, and palpable. We want those alive today to remember the victims as people, not just as statistics or bios on a website. Above all, we want to ensure that the evils of Martial Law are never forgotten, never repeated. 

With your help, we hope to win the fight against the blatant revision of history being perpetuated by the Marcoses. In so doing, we can honor those who fought against the injustices of Martial Law, and we can make sure that the horrors of those dark days will never happen again.
 

The Plays 

SET A 
September 23 8PM, October 1 8PM, 9 4PM, 15 8PM

Loyalist Redux, written and directed by Kanakan Balintagos

Imelda returns to the Philippines. A Loyalist mother is ecstatic about this headline and wakes up her activist-artist son to his nightmarish reality. A bag of worms from the past is opened up like Pandora's Box. Will mother and son finally be able to settle their irreconcilable political differences? In the end, are we loyal to those we love? (First staged at the Virgin Lab Fest XII)

Duyan ka ng Magiting, written and directed by Erica Estacio

This tragic one-act play tells the story of how activists and by Erika Estacio patriots Lorena Barros, Macli-ing Dulag, Edjop and Evelio Javier endured and perished in the hands of their torturers and murderers.  (First staged for the People Power Experiential Museum)

Thingy Or Ang Pak na Pak Ganern na Ganern sa Pakikipagsapalaran ni Milenyo,
D’ Great Pokemon Hunter), written by Chris Martinez and directed by Dennis Marasigan ​

One actor portrays a clueless millennial.  Another actor portrays all the other characters who will react to her tweet about the ‘Martial Law thingy.’  (A Never Again: Voices of Martial Law original) 

SET B - September 24 8PM, 30 8PM, October 8 8Pm, 16 4PM 

Disco 1081  written by George De Jesus III, directed by Melvin Lee 

Student activists meet at a disco to celebrate their friend's 18th birthday. As they reach a turning point, are they there to bring her back into the fold? Or are they there to say goodbye?

(A Never Again: Voices of Martial Law original)

Princess Lilli  written by Layeta Bucoy directed by Tuxqs Rutaquio 

“Do not live in the past, act according to the present, so they say, but can you really separate the past from the present, the present from the future?” –Lilliosa Hilao

There are several versions of the truth: some versions are less painful than other. But are those really what we need?

Ten-year old Sarah has a vivid imagination. With her home life, she needs it. She draws fairy tales with happily-ever-afters, but she writes about is the truth. She talks to Princess Lilli and her prince, and we find out that the Martial Law era was never a fairy tale.

(A Never Again: Voices of Martial Law original)

Bulong-Bulungan sa Sangandaan written by Ramon Jocson and directed by Audie Gemora 

Workers billeted at a construction site discuss their daily struggles as below-minimum wage earners from the Martial Law era to the present. Security guards occasionally interrupt their discourse. Is there a better life outside? Should they stay or should they go?

(Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, Second Prize, 1989.) 

SET C

September 25 4PM, October 2 4PM, 7 8PM, 14 8PM 

Shhhh written by Allan Lopez, directed by Jenny Jamora  

On a rainy day in 1977, Kim and Mark discuss a missing friend: what he’s like, his outspokenness, where he could be, and if they should help in the search. They also talk about Imee Marcos. Mark finds her hot, Kim says she is kind.

Two friends join them, saying their friend has been found. He is dead. He is Archie Trajano, 21.

(A Never Again: Voices of Martial Law original)

Indigo Child written by Rody Vera and directed by Jose Estrella 

Felisa, a rebel caught, tortured and raped, is committed to a halfway house as the new millennium breaks. Her son, Jerome, now 20, has been taking care of her since his teens, after she is diagnosed as bipolar due to multiple traumas.

In one confrontation, Felisa reveals many secrets that Jerome finds hard to believe—about Jerome’s father, what happened before his birth, and her belief that he is an indigo child, sent to save the world. Jerome wants to know the truth. But where does he start? And if he does find it, will he be able to handle the truth?

(A Never Again: Voices of Martial Law original) 
 

Ang Lihim na Kasaysayan ng Huling Habilin ni Ferdinand Edralin Marcos (Spiritual King Solomon of Israel) Hinggil sa Pamanang Kayamanan ni King Bernardo Carpio at Jose Protacio Rizal Para sa Pagpapaunlad ng Bansang Pilipinas na Siyang Nalalaman ni Mang Ambo, Taxi Driver  written by Guelan Varela and directed by Roobak Valle 

The gospel according to Mang Ambo, taxi driver and evangelist of the cult of Ferdinand Edralin Marcos, the spiritual once and future King Solomon of the Philippines (the new Israel) about the last will and testament of past kings Bernardo Carpio and Jose Protacio Rizal. As revealed to G, a journalist taking his cab. Prepare to repent, and be enlightened. 

(A Never Again: Voices of Martial Law  Original)
story_txt:
The Martial Law era from 1972-1986 were dark days for the Philippines. The massive theft and corruption by the despot Ferdinand E. Marcos were overshadowed only by the atrocities that happened during that regime– tortures, deaths, disappearances, a throttled press and the curtailment of personal freedoms– the effects of which the country is still enduring now.  In February of 1986, the country finally succeeded in overthrowing the dictatorship. 
Yet in  the evening of May 9, 2016, people watched in shock as Ferdinand R. Marcos, Jr. was almost elected as Vice President on May 9, 2016–  only losing by a narrow margin. 14 million people voted for him, nearly putting him in a position that was a heartbeat away from the Presidency. 
The Problem
It was clear that for many Filipinos, Martial Law has become an abstract idea several decades old. And even worse, it has become an appealing idea to the youth, longing for days of discipline, adherence to the law, and a false peace under a police state. The atrocities of that era have become largely invisible, buried by both time and secrecy much like many of the victims of these state-sanctioned crimes.Worse,  we are now seeing a growing sentiment that devalues human rights, the rule of law, and democracy in the public today as a result.
The lessons of the Martial Law era have not been learned. We have a lot of catching up to do. 
The Project: Never Again, Voices of Martial Law

 
Through  MarkaBayan: Mga Kuwentong Hindi Mabubura  campaign, Ladies Who Launch intends to do its part by staging and touring Never Again: Voices of Martial Law (NAVoML).

Above all, we want to ensure that the evils of Martial Law are never forgotten, never repeated. 
With your help, we hope to win the fight against the blatant revision of history being perpetuated by the Marcoses. In so doing, we can honor those who fought against the injustices of Martial Law, and we can make sure that the horrors of those dark days will never happen again.

story:
Project Summary

Project: Motion collaborates with Carla McDonald and Courtney Oliver of FindMemphis (findmemphis.com), diving into the process and product of Carla’s photographs to show how the city informs us as artists of Memphis, how we thrive in reflecting each other, and how we inspire and in turn are inspired.  

Carla McDonald (formerly of The Bouffants) and Courtney Oliver are Resident Company Members with Playhouse on the Square who create and curate FindMemphis together with England-native Rory Dale. McDonald’s photographs “celebrate the unapologetic soul of a river city.” FindMemphis celebrates and promotes the goings-on of Memphis and expresses McDonald and Oliver’s shared thrill for rediscovering our hometown.

Our choreographers for Tiny Dances/Hidden Spaces include Ballet Memphis alum Travis Bradley; local artist and writer Sheri Bancroft; NYU Tisch alum and Memphis native Jonathan Matthews; Highlands, NC dance teacher and performer with JOYEMOVEMENT Amelia Renee Byrd; St. Mary’s and Roudnev Youth ballet instructor Erin Walter; Hutchison ballet and movement instructor Louisa Koeppel; and more.

Tiny Dances/Hidden Spaces will take place at the Jay Etkin Gallery in Cooper Young, October 22 at 7 pm and October 23 at 6 pm. Come learn why Dr. Elena Stoeva calls Memphis’ longest-running modern dance company’s productions “so complete, and true to the values of dance.”

As Memphis musician Drew Holcomb states, “Memphis doesn’t hide its scars – but instead wears them proudly as it gathers around you to tell its story.” Our artists show these stories through movement – beauty, scars and all.

What We Need & What You Get

Funding a show like this one is a challenge. Pre-production overhead presents a neverending series of surprises, and while we are beyond thrilled to be staging the show in the intimate setting of an art gallery, the smaller venue also limits the number of tickets and, in turn, our revenue. We are seeking donations to help us meet the expenses of staging the show, and we could use any help you can give!

  • We hope to raise $2,000, which will let us breathe a little more easily while we prepare this marvelous dance presentation.
  • As perks, we are offering advance-sale tickets, Project: Motion t-shirts, a sneak peek at pre-show rehearsals, and signed prints of Carla McDonald's photos!
  • Whether or not we reach (or exceed!) our goal, anything raised will go directly into the production!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, there are certainly other ways you can help:

First of all, you can help get the word out! Make some noise about this amazing troupe of artists, creating and presenting original works of dance in Memphis for 30 years! There are sharing buttons right on this page, so you can post links to Facebook or Twitter, copy a link for an email, or grab an HTML embed code for a blog or other web page.

And of course, we hope everyone who reads this, whether you decide to make a donation or not, will come see our show, and help support original dance in Memphis!

story:
WHO ARE WE?

SVDS was established in 2015 by respected Sydney dancer and choreographer Sheena Miss Demeanour.  

We are not asking for donations, rather we are offering a range of discounts and rewards for people to invest in and we would be open to cross promotion for businesses that would like to partner with us.  Donations would be gratefully received should you be that way inclined, however we hope that we can offer something to you for your investment.

SVDS mission is to share the love of vernacular and social dance  trends of the last century by offering courses and workshops in a variety of historical dance styles. Sheena has been teaching dance classes in the inner west and central Sydney for the last 12 years offering tuition through a number of reputable Sydney dance schools.  Prior to this she taught dancing across the northern beaches and eastern suburbs for 10 years, until she found her favourite area of Sydney to settle, the Inner West.

Offering tuition in burlesque, feather fan dance, chair and 60s go-go, strong community interest grew in these dance styles and she then decided to dedicate a school to the vintage dance arts.   Sheena has a passion for sharing her love of dance with the world and this is just the beginning. 

Since 2015 more styles of dance have been added to the timetable such as 30s solo blues, 40s jive, 70s soul train, adult ballet, tap and tribal bellydance.  (PLEASE SEE A COMPREHENSIVE LIST OF CLASSES ON OFFER AND OTHER CLASSES WE HOPE TO OFFER SHOULD WE GET THE FUNDS FOR THE RENOVATION AND BOND COSTS)

In addition to providing dance experiences for the absolute beginner through to intermediate levels, the school also offers advanced tuition for dancers to take things to the next level by way of stage performance or competition. 

The school has taken on 2 additonal instructors (in addition to Sheena) in 2018 and the school is growing in numbers and the demand for more variety in classes is also growing.  Currently we don't have a dedicated space to offer classes from and as such a variety of venues are currently being hired in the surburbs of Newtown, Marrickville and Surry Hills to ensure classes can take place, however this restricts the class numbers and dance styles we can offer.  We have now found a space in a fabulous location with the perfect size room for SVDS’s growing timetable and class numbers. 

This new space would enable us to provide more opportunities for the growing number of students and we will be able to offer many styles of dance not currently available in the inner west, such as feather fan dance, 60s go-go,  70s  soul train, burlesque, 20s charleston, 40s Jive, adult ballet, tribal belly dance and more.

 There is also a growing need for affordable and available rehearsal space for artists in the inner west. This space also presents the opportunity for multi-purpose use by other artists including dancers, yoga/pilates instructors, visual artists, musicians, actors and digital media.
 

WHAT WE WANT TO DO!

We have found a fabulous location and the perfect size space for the classes currently offered by SVDS. The space is in an awesome warehouse in the thriving but still old school hub of Marrickville which will allow for more classes and more students in the class to allow for the growing numbers of students. We have been renting multiple studios across the inner west for the last 2 years, however this has restricted class numbers and dance styles we can offer and the uncertainty around the availability of spaces from month to month becomes very taxing and some times results in courses being postponed or cancelled due to not finding room availability.

Providing a dedicated space will provide location security and more class opportunities for the growing number of students and the offering of many styles of dance not currently offered by any other dance school in the inner west.

SVDS is also expanding and wants to offer children's classes in fairy fan dance, tap dance, baby ballet and drama.  This is an exciting phase in the development of the school and in fact teaching children was Sheena's first teaching role at age 17 and she is excited to revisit this side of her teaching career. 

OTHER BENEFITS OF HAVING A DEDICATED SPACE

- Being able to offer a costume wardrobe for fantasy dress ups and performance courses

- Being able to bespoke hens parties and special life event parties via any of the dance styles we offer

- Storing feather fans and chairs so that Sheena doesn't have to have them hanging out the back of her car!  LOL

- A purpose built office to enable efficient administration of the business

- Making it a warm, friendly and vintage furntiture and artefact space to further reflect the name of the school 

- Expanding the school to include childrens tuition

WEEKLY CLASSES THAT SVDS WILL OFFER ONCE IF WE GET THE FUNDS FOR THE NEW SPACE

Burlesque

Feather Fan Dance

80s Dance

70s Soul Train

60s Go-Go

40s Jive

30s Solo Blues

20s Charleston

Chair Dance

Bump n Grind

Tribal Belly Dance

Floor work & Flow

Contemporary

Ballet

Tap

Yoga

Barre

Pilates

Themed Performance Courses (opportunities to perform at different events around Sydney)

Please see some of our classes and performance courses below in action to get an idea of what we do!  :-)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oG9jpaliPPI

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oTILeQsQoLI&amp...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qnCvhfHUtjs

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nz-hUJomB4c

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-JeScAGCEhw&amp...

Also please check out our Facebook page at:

www.facebook.com/sydneyvintagedancestudio

or follow us on Instagram at 

www.instagram.com/sydneyvintagedance

 

 

WHAT IF I DON'T GET THE FUNDS I HAVE ASKED FOR?

Whilst  we hope we can reach our dream target, the project will still go ahead, however it will take much longer to get off the ground as a fully functioning dance studio.  

If by chance the project falls completely flat on it's head - all supporters that pledge the $500 and $1000 will be returned to the supporters.   All other perks will be available through the school under the current existing structure and are to be used within the timeframes specified on the perks page.

or follow us on Instagram at

WHAT IF I DON'T GET THE FUNDS I HAVE ASKED FOR?
Whilst  we hope we can reach our dream target, the project will still go ahead, however it will take much longer to get off the ground as a fully functioning dance studio.  If by chance the project falls completely flat on it's head - all supporters that pledge the $500 and $1000 will be returned to the supporters.   All other perks will be available through the school under the current existing structure and are to be used within the timeframes specified on the perks page.

story:
Get to Know Us

McCormick/Durham is a unique relationship between Director, Rondrell McCormick and Playwright, Vincent Terrell Durham born over years of friendship, five acclaimed seasons with PlayGround-LA, a monumental YouTube collaboration with Black Women Talking and the upcoming short film The Old Saturday.

Individually They Are:

Rondrell McCormick (Actor/Director/Singer/Writer/Music Producer).
Creator of hit web series, The Wesley's, and long form P.S.A., Black Women Talking. Joseph McNeil in February One (PBS). D-Mac in Channel 00 (Spike). Dijon in Leftovers reading/Oregon Shakespeare Festival). Adrian in Smokey Joe's Cafe (Center REP/nominated for best ensemble). Cassio/understudy in Othello. Duke of Florence in All's Well That Ends Well (Shakespeare and Company). Julius in Still Standing (Vitality Productions). Businessman/Gang in A Christmas Carol (American Conservatory Theater). Young Number 2 in The Road Weeps, The Well Runs Dry (reading/LATC). Alton in The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window (workshop ft. Michael Stuhlbarg/A.C.T.). Richard II, Philistines (ft. Jack Willis), Good Breeding, Little Shop of Horrors, Great Catherine, Ubu Roi, La Ronde, Our Lady Of 121st Street, Seven Guitars among a host of others. Born and raised in the seams of North Carolina, he holds a B.F.A from North Carolina Agricultural And Technical State University and an M.F.A. from the prestigious, Tony Award winning, American Conservatory Theater. Presently, he makes his artistic home at Playground LA as a resident director.

Vincent Terrell Durham (Playwright/Author/Poet) first honed his storytelling skills as a stand-up comic. He strives to create thought-provoking and character driven narratives. But true to his comedy roots, his stories are delivered with unexpected humor for the situations his characters are living through. Vincent’s short and full length plays have received over 40 productions and have entertained audiences from Los Angeles to the Catskills. He is a member of the Dramatist Guild of America and The Alliance of Los Angeles Playwrights. He writes to pay honor to the Johnson family, the best storytellers a little Black boy could ever have.

The Campaign

Our campaign is to supplement an invitation to present two nights of Vol. 1  A Post Racial America at Highways Performance Space. An invite graciously extended to McCormick/Durham by artistic directors Leo Garcia & Patrick Kennelly. 

The Story of Vol. 1 A Post Racial America

With Vol 1. A Post Racial America the team of McCormick/Durham are pouring themselves into presenting an anthology of theatrical shorts examining the notion of a Post Racial America. The pieces range from questioning the "ism" chosen by Martin Luther King Jr. and our Civil Rights leaders, playgrounds no longer being safe places for Black children to play, the impact of the Black Church on a same gender loving couple, a family's reconnection to love across racial lines, along with several other shorts. An ensemble of LA's top actors are excited to bring this new work to Highways Performance Space. *A special thanks to C. Jerome Woods and the Black LGBT Project for the introduction to Highways Performance Space.

How Your Gift Supports the Production

Highways has generously invited us into their performance space without charge, which is a big break when producing theatre in Los Angles. But the production still has plenty of funding needs. Our fund raising goal of $5,000.00 will be allocated among these line items.

  1. Actor Pay - An ensemble of 8 talented actors. Approx. $2,000.00
  2. Rehearsal Space - 2 weeks of rehearsal space rental is needed prior to entering Highways for the final 3rd week of rehearsal. Approx. $1,500.00 
  3. Stage Manager
  4. Assistant Stage Manager
  5. Light and Sound Designer
  6. Costume Designer
  7. Set Designer
  8. Props
  9. Advertising
  10. Craft Services

Perks

Our perks always begin with acknowledgement of your love, support, belief and generosity. The perks continue with memorabilia commemorating the World Premier of Vol 1. A Post Racial America. Items you can store away for the next generation to drag out of the attic and present on and episode of Antique Roadshow in the year 2150. Our belief and hope that Vol. 1 A Post Racial America will move beyond Los Angeles and into theatres across the country. We want everyone to know you were onboard with us from the start. 

The Impact of your Gift

Your contribution will free us to create. INDIEGOGO CROWDFUNDING is the perfect opportunity for the production to state our needs in one central location and reach out to those who are able to support McCormick/Durham and our desire to use theatre as a catalyst for discussion and change. Each INDIEGOGO contribution is a fund raising meeting our production doesn't have to set up or attend. The time we would have dedicated to raising funds individually can be turned towards creating the best two nights of theatre Highways Performance Space has ever witnessed. The impact of your gift is to bless us with the opportunity to be artist creating art.

Other Ways You Can Help

$10, $25 or no dollars. You just taking time to visit our campaign page has already put out good energy towards our success. If you are unable to contribute with a monetary figure, please consider sharing our campaign via the INDIEGOGO share tools near the upper right of our page. And just make a lot of noise about what McCormick/Durham will be up to July 27th and July 28th.

Thank You!

Vincent & Rondrell

story:
The Epic Story of Nana Banana
In her 78 years, my Nana has touched the lives of everyone around her. A lot of my childhood was spent at Nan's house, and I grew up with this vivacious woman as my biggest role model. Her thirst for knowledge, zest for life, and myriad of eccentricities were, like the wardrobes of handmade sweaters and scarfs, tenderly knitted and stitched by Nan into my genetics. She exposed me to the great artists, to black and white films, to Cheez Whiz and The Simpsons, to feminism and the great perils of shaving one's legs. 

I saw and admired the strength in my Nana, but I never knew where the source of the strength originated. Thus, this project was born. I am discovering a 40 year-old story that has been right in front of me my whole life, waiting to be told. A story not only belonging to my Nana, but to her parents, children, and grandchildren. 

It's been a remarkable process, personally, and for the entire family. Truths have been revealed, repressed feelings released, carpet-munching stories regaled, and I respect my grandmother more than ever. Nana and I are both extremely excited (and nervous) to share her story with you this summer.

What We Need & What You Get
Unfortunately, the cost of creating art isn't cheap. It would be a dream if the profits from ticket sales were enough to cover the expenditures attached to producing a show, but alas, it seldom is. Because the show is being mounted out of town, the travel expenses of a three-week stay add up. I have also made the spontaneous/irrational decision to quit my job in order to work on this show with all the time and energy I have to offer, so unlike my previous theatre endeavours, I won't be able to pay out of pocket to produce this story. 

Here is where your generous donations will go:

  • Getting my poor butt on a plane and out to Winnipeg and saving my Mum the stress of having me hitchhike. 
  • Set materials, costumes, and props. 
  • Promotional materials- posters, handbills, buttons, and social media exposure. 
  • BONUS: The ideal outcome of this fundraising process would be to raise enough money to fly my Nana, the fabulous protagonist of the show, to Winnipeg to get to see her story debut on stage.

If you donate, not only will you be elevated to the highest moral standing and guaranteed entry into the holy Thespian Afterlife (lots of wine, Maenads, and good ol' debaucherous times), but you will score some sweet, more tangible perks as well!

  • Delicious baked goods from original Nana recipes- lemon bars, peanut butter cookies, blueberry pies, and more!
  • Super swaggy buttons!
  • Thank-you cards featuring prints of Nana's paintings!
  • Mini-Recipe books of original Nana recipes! 
  • Hand-Knitted Nana creations! 
  • Shout Outs/Ad Space in the show program!  

The Impact
It wasn't until about two weeks ago, that Nana realized I was performing her life story on stage, in front of an audience. I swear I had mentioned it to her at the beginning of the process, but we've decided to agree to disagree. This made Nan a little nervous, but together we made a list of why it's important that her story be told to others, and this turned the nerves into excitement. 

  • To give a voice to the elderly queer community. We are lucky to be seeing LGBTQ2+ stories emerging more and more frequently on stage, but unfortunately the stories of seniors are not as common. 
  • To inspire those exploring their sexual identities while living under oppressive societal circumstances: religion and the church, homophobic-centric neighborhoods, professions in which being queer can cost you your job, etc. 
  • To bring together a family whose shared experience caused an unspoken divide. To liberate the thoughts, opinions, and secrets kept to oneself for forty years. To normalize a family's story with less-than-normal aspects. 

Other Ways You Can Help
No money, no problem! Support us in other ways too!

  • Share this campaign on social media! Share anything I post in the future about this project!
  • Holler at your Winnipeg pals (everyone's got at least one!) and send them my way July 18-29! 
  • Send your warm fuzzies and well wishes... emotional support is just as valuable!

story:
About the Play

Anwu is turning 60. Against her wishes her daughters, Nike and Tolu are preparing a party. Their older brother, Chi, is nowhere to be seen and Dad is in Nigeria building the family home that never seems to finish. In the midst of the chaos Anwu struggles to hold her family together, and hold onto herself in the process.

 King's Head Theatre, 10-14th July. Click here to buy tickets

 

Help us tell the story of 'UMUADA'

We're excited to perform a newly extended version of UMUADA at one of London's most prestigious fringe venues, the King's Head Theatre. 

An exploration of black-motherhood and mental health within the urban-African diaspora, UMUADA premiered in 2017 at the Bunker Theatre as part of Damsel Productions Women-Director’s festival. Meaning ‘first-born daughters’ in Igbo, UMUADA explores the innate and often unacknowledged process of un-becoming that first generation migrant women are forced to experience and - moreover survive - if their husbands, children and communities are to thrive.

We are now staging a lengthened and adapted version to bring the story and its subject to a wider London audience. With a platform like the King's Head Theatre, we hope that we can share this play with a new audience, and we plan to run post-show Q+As where we carry on the conversation on mental health and migration within the wider Black British community. 

A cultural and artistic production that is led and populated by women of African heritage, UMUADA gives space to issues around gender, race and mental health that are too often shrouded in silence. 

About the Writer

Justina Kehinde is an award winning poet, jazz singer, actress and director. She directed and co-produced the first-all black all-female production on a Cambridge stage, Ntozake Shange’s ‘For Colored Girls…’, before successfully taking the production to London for a sell out performance [2012/13]. In 2014 she directed and co-produced the South African political-musical Sophiatown (ADC Theatre) and in 2017 was the assistant director and poet for FRONTLINE, a dance- theatre piece on Human Trafficking (The Place, London). In 2017 she was awarded a Damsel Productions directorial development scheme through which she developed and co-wrote the first draft of UMUADA. Passionate about centring, exploring and making visible the black experience through art, Justina Kehinde is dedicated to producing work that better narrates the nuance and  complexity of diasporic identity. 

Watch our writer's TEDx talk

 

Why we need your help

UMUADA is an independently funded production, made up of an incredible team of talented professionals to ensure the highest quality  of work and the best use of our budget. However this is also a unique play that is as much theatre as it is community dialogue. We want to make this play as accessible and as inclusive as possible for the communities UMUADA speaks to and about, communities that are often marginalised and underrepresented in the theatrical arts and in theatre audiences. By donating to this campaign, you will help us cover our production costs and provide free and discounted tickets to new and diverse audience members. 

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Please buy a ticket

2. Even if you can’t contribute financially, sharing this campaign on Facebook or Twitter (@Umuadaprod) dramatically increases the visibility of our project and our likelihood of reaching our goal.

story:
THE STORY

My name is Paula Josa-Jones.  I am a choreographer, performer, author, activist, and the artistic director of Paula Josa-Jones/Performance Works.  For the past thirty-five years,I have been creating dance theater with my collaborators, including dancers, horses, actors, composers, musicians, set, lighting, costume and projection designers.

RIVER/BODY is an expression of what matters most to me at this time. This dance is about the intense and immediate way that our bodies and the body of the earth are inseparably intertwined. We are water bodies living on a water planet. RIVER/BODY is about awakening the compassionate heart of that relationship.

We live on a water planet: 70% of the earth’s surface is covered with water. We are water beings:  60–70% of the human body is water. Our once casual relationship to water and often unconscious relationship to our own bodies are co-mingled in the growing social and ecological crises. RIVER/BODY is our response to the global “rising tide” of water-related concerns and connects with all of the “water-is-life” efforts around the globe. We want to make dance - the precious vulnerability of the moving body -  an essential part of that conversation.

RIVER/BODY asks how our bodies and that of the river are connected. How does the continuous coming and going of the river waters parallel our own short lives? What are our own wild currents? What is the heart of the river, the mind of the river and how are we a part of each other?

I grew up in Minnesota on the Mississippi River. As a child, that river felt huge – remote and unknowable. Now I live on the Housatonic River in Kent, Connecticut. I walk along this river, drive next to it during my commutes; listen to the trains traveling the river corridor at night. This river feels intimate, sensual. The Housatonic and its relationship to the rivers of my childhood – the water that I am and the water that surrounds me - inspire me powerfully at this time.

The Housatonic - named “usi-a-di-en-uk” meaning “beyond the mountains” - is wild and turbulent in some places, bucolic in others, running from Pittsfield, Massachusetts to the Long Island Sound. Besides its extraordinary beauty, the river has a troubled history, involving the unregulated dumping of toxic chemicals by General Electric upriver, which continues to affect the entire river habitat, including fish, frogs, turtles, and waterfowl. The river waters upstream are still contaminated. Further downstream, the PCB’s are held in the silt of the river bottom and the banks.

When I first entered the river last summer with dancers Amy Wynn, Sandrine Harris and Aislinn MacMaster, I had no idea how powerful and emotional that experience would be.  Almost immediately, we felt ourselves in an intimate, even tender relationship with the “beingness” of the river.  Then a friend sent me this beautiful water story by Lakota artist and activist Pat McCabe, and I understood that as we moved with the waters, we were feeling the very consciousness of the water.  For more about that, watch this video by Bernd Muller.

The worlds that will merge in the course of this project include artists, natural resource conservation people, outdoor recreation enthusiasts, students, lovers of art and dance - anyone who appreciates or interacts with the river. Our idea is to create shared audiences through the intersection of diverse interests at various sites.

RIVER/BODY is a performance project in the tradition of National Park "artists on the trail." We see ourselves as artists-in-residence on a water trail, participants in the river and its contingent communities and ecosystems. Each time we enter the water we are dancing between two states, solid and fluid, present and transient – allowing ourselves to be transformed as we invite the audience to experience the river as an "open-ended being with [its] own inherent spontaneity and active agency." (David Abram)

ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE

DANCE: Dancing in the river is very different from dancing on a stage, or even a grassy lawn.  There are the slippery rocks, the fallen logs, the continuous, persuasive current.  Entering the water, we are blending our bodies with the body of the river - allowing ourselves to be danced by the waters. Every performance is unique and shaped by the river on that day.

SOUND/MUSIC: We have invited musician/percussionist John Marshall and actor/vocalist Evangeline Johns to join the performance.  Student performers with improvised vessels for carrying and pouring water will be an accompanying “Water Orchestra.”

VISUAL DESIGN: Costumes will wrap and extend the bodies of the performers, integrating layers of dyed and painted fabric with natural materials such as leaves, branches, bark, and mud.

AUDIENCE: For some performances, we may invite the audience to join us in moments of sounding and moving - to deepen our shared fluidity and relationship to the river.

TIMELINE

We will premiere RIVER/BODY in August 2018, taking place in Northwest Connecticut,  Massachusetts, and New York.  Sites include the Housatonic River and several tributary rivers, including the Shepaug and Ten Mile Rivers.

WHAT WE NEED

We must raise $9500 to get this project afloat.  Our total budget is $30,000. In addition to approaching foundations, we are reaching out to you, in large part because of the ongoing uncertainty of funding for state and local arts organizations. We have received a small grant from the Berkshire Taconic Foundation but must match that several times over. Here are some of the production costs that your donation will support

  • paying dancers, musicians, performers for rehearsals and performance
  • paying our costume designer for design and construction
  • developing and printing educational/engagement materials for our work with schools
  • graphic designer for publicity materials and web design
  • printing of posters and publicity materials
  • travel costs for participating artists
  • permits and fees for rehearsals and performances at various sites
  • transportation for underserved communities including youth and elders

THE PERKS: Here’s are some of what you could get:

  • A big thank you and your name in social media news about the project
  • An invitation to attend a rehearsal
  • Tickets to the premiere 
  • Tickets for the Premiere  and After Party
  • An elegant t-shirt with the RIVER/BODY design
  • A downloadable link to the RIVER/BODY video.
  • A signed photograph by Pam White

THE IMPACT: you make a difference!

We want this project to be inclusive!!! We all have to become a single ecosystem – organized like a body, moving like a river with a common purpose to make a difference as residents of the shared earth. Your donation in support of RIVER/BODY is a way to join that purposeful effort.

RISKS, CHALLENGES & SUPPORT

This is an ambitious project,  one that demands coordination with many partners and communities.  The river can be unpredictable, and its conditions will determine what we can and can't do.  Cleaning the sites, creating opportunities for underserved populations to participate and attend performances, working within the limits of school budgets and curricula are all part of the challenges we face.

Oh the other hand, we have enthusiastic regional partners with deep knowledge of the river and the surrounding communities. They include:

  • Housatonic Valley Association

  • The Wassaic Project

  • Housatonic Heritage

  • Housatonic Valley Regional High School

  • Northwest Connecticut Arts Council

  • Steep Rock Association

If you can't make a cash donation, you can still help. 

  • Get the word out to your social media worlds. 
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools, and let us know what else you need to spread the word effectively.
  • Offer to help us! Tell us what your skills are.
  • Reach out to your friends with cash.
story_txt:
THE STORY
My name is Paula Josa-Jones.  I am a choreographer, performer, author, activist, and the artistic director of Paula Josa-Jones/Performance Works.  For the past thirty-five years,I have been creating dance theater with my collaborators, including dancers, horses, actors, composers, musicians, set, lighting, costume and projection designers.
RIVER/BODY is an expression of what matters most to me at this time. This dance is about the intense and immediate way that our bodies and the body of the earth are inseparably intertwined. We are water bodies living on a water planet. RIVER/BODY is about awakening the compassionate heart of that relationship.
We live on a water planet: 70% of the earth’s surface is covered with water. We are water beings:  60–70% of the human body is water. Our once casual relationship to water and often unconscious relationship to our own bodies are co-mingled in the growing social and ecological crises. RIVER/BODY is our response to the global “rising tide” of water-related concerns and connects with all of the “water-is-life” efforts around the globe. We want to make dance - the precious vulnerability of the moving body -  an essential part of that conversation.
RIVER/BODY asks how our bodies and that of the river are connected. How does the continuous coming and going of the river waters parallel our own short lives? What are our own wild currents? What is the heart of the river, the mind of the river and how are we a part of each other?

I grew up in Minnesota on the Mississippi River. As a child, that river felt huge – remote and unknowable. Now I live on the Housatonic River in Kent, Connecticut. I walk along this river, drive next to it during my commutes; listen to the trains traveling the river corridor at night. This river feels intimate, sensual. The Housatonic and its relationship to the rivers of my childhood – the water that I am and the water that surrounds me - inspire me powerfully at this time.
The Housatonic - named “usi-a-di-en-uk” meaning “beyond the mountains” - is wild and turbulent in some places, bucolic in others, running from Pittsfield, Massachusetts to the Long Island Sound. Besides its extraordinary beauty, the river has a troubled history, involving the unregulated dumping of toxic chemicals by General Electric upriver, which continues to affect the entire river habitat, including fish, frogs, turtles, and waterfowl. The river waters upstream are still contaminated. Further downstream, the PCB’s are held in the silt of the river bottom and the banks.

When I first entered the river last summer with dancers Amy Wynn, Sandrine Harris and Aislinn MacMaster, I had no idea how powerful and emotional that experience would be.  Almost immediately, we felt ourselves in an intimate, even tender relationship with the “beingness” of the river.  Then a friend sent me this beautiful water story by Lakota artist and activist Pat McCabe, and I understood that as we moved with the waters, we were feeling the very consciousness of the water.  For more about that, watch this video by Bernd Muller.
The worlds that will merge in the course of this project include artists, natural resource conservation people, outdoor recreation enthusiasts, students, lovers of art and dance - anyone who appreciates or interacts with the river. Our idea is to create shared audiences through the intersection of diverse interests at various sites.
RIVER/BODY is a performance project in the tradition of National Park "artists on the trail." We see ourselves as artists-in-residence on a water trail, participants in the river and its contingent communities and ecosystems. Each time we enter the water we are dancing between two states, solid and fluid, present and transient – allowing ourselves to be transformed as we invite the audience to experience the river as an "open-ended being with [its] own inherent spontaneity and active agency." (David Abram)

ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE
DANCE: Dancing in the river is very different from dancing on a stage, or even a grassy lawn.  There are the slippery rocks, the fallen logs, the continuous, persuasive current.  Entering the water, we are blending our bodies with the body of the river - allowing ourselves to be danced by the waters. Every performance is unique and shaped by the river on that day.
SOUND/MUSIC: We have invited musician/percussionist John Marshall and actor/vocalist Evangeline Johns to join the performance.  Student performers with improvised vessels for carrying and pouring water will be an accompanying “Water Orchestra.”
VISUAL DESIGN: Costumes will wrap and extend the bodies of the performers, integrating layers of dyed and painted fabric with natural materials such as leaves, branches, bark, and mud.
AUDIENCE: For some performances, we may invite the audience to join us in moments of sounding and moving - to deepen our shared fluidity and relationship to the river.
TIMELINE
We will premiere RIVER/BODY in August 2018, taking place in Northwest Connecticut,  Massachusetts, and New York.  Sites include the Housatonic River and several tributary rivers, including the Shepaug and Ten Mile Rivers.
WHAT WE NEED 
We must raise $9500 to get this project afloat.  Our total budget is $30,000. In addition to approaching foundations, we are reaching out to you, in large part because of the ongoing uncertainty of funding for state and local arts organizations. We have received a small grant from the Berkshire Taconic Foundation but must match that several times over. Here are some of the production costs that your donation will support

paying dancers, musicians, performers for rehearsals and performance
paying our costume designer for design and construction
developing and printing educational/engagement materials for our work with schools
graphic designer for publicity materials and web design
printing of posters and publicity materials
travel costs for participating artists
permits and fees for rehearsals and performances at various sites
transportation for underserved communities including youth and elders

THE PERKS: Here’s are some of what you could get:

A big thank you and your name in social media news about the project
An invitation to attend a rehearsal
Tickets to the premiere 
Tickets for the Premiere  and After Party
An elegant t-shirt with the RIVER/BODY design
A downloadable link to the RIVER/BODY video.
A signed photograph by Pam White


THE IMPACT: you make a difference!
We want this project to be inclusive!!! We all have to become a single ecosystem – organized like a body, moving like a river with a common purpose to make a difference as residents of the shared earth. Your donation in support of RIVER/BODY is a way to join that purposeful effort.
RISKS, CHALLENGES & SUPPORT
This is an ambitious project,  one that demands coordination with many partners and communities.  The river can be unpredictable, and its conditions will determine what we can and can't do.  Cleaning the sites, creating opportunities for underserved populations to participate and attend performances, working within the limits of school budgets and curricula are all part of the challenges we face.
Oh the other hand, we have enthusiastic regional partners with deep knowledge of the river and the surrounding communities. They include:

Housatonic Valley Association
The Wassaic Project
Housatonic Heritage
Housatonic Valley Regional High School
Northwest Connecticut Arts Council
Steep Rock Association

If you can't make a cash donation, you can still help. 

Get the word out to your social media worlds. 
Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools, and let us know what else you need to spread the word effectively.

story:
Our Story

I'm Melanie Wilderman, an Oklahoma writer and journalism professor, who has been penning poems and fan fiction since I learned my ABCs. My most recent writing passions include magazine features and short film scripts, and, as you may have guessed from this campaign, stage plays. My husband, Ted Satterfield, and I co-wrote the play Alcoholidays, a Christmas comedy that ran in 2013, 2015, and 2017 on Oklahoma stages.

I have now completed my first solo stage play, Faithiest, and with your help, I'm hoping to reward the actors and others who make this show possible with a more appropriate amount of pay than many usually receive. For this new show, I have teamed up with director Rodney Brazil and the theatre troupe Next Stage, who were involved in two of the three Alcoholidays runs and have produced numerous original shows since 2012, including All My Ex Boyfriends are Gay, Worthy Causes, and Birth. 

In my experiences with producing Alcoholidays as an independent writer and artist, two of the major financial obstacles in Oklahoma theatre are 1) affording a quality venue and 2) paying actors, directors, stage managers, etc. what they deserve. Many of these creative individuals work for free or just a few dollars per performance. While they do this because they have a passion and dedication for performance, I believe they deserve more. 

We Need Your Support

We need your help to raise $2,000 to assist in paying our actors closer to what they deserve, and helping to pay for the venue. If additional funds are secured, they may be spent on costuming, props, or promotional materials, but our first and most important financial concern, is appropriate pay for the actors, director, stage assistants, and any others involved making Faithiest the play happen. 

Why Contribute?

Your contribution will support the Oklahoma arts and the talented and hard-working individuals who bring you unique, fresh entertainment. 

Our previous stage play, Alcoholidays, sold out nearly all performance dates in 2013, and then every performance in 2015. You will be contributing to a group with a proven track record of successful performances, and all contributors will be listed on the playbill to showcase the amazing support we receive from people like you! Also, make sure to check out the additional perks based on your level of contribution, including free tickets and reserved preferred seating. 

The Show Must Go On!

Regardless of the outcome of this campaign, the show will go on starting July 20, and will run through July 29. Our hope with this campaign is that the show will go on with the talent being well compensated for all their hard work!  

If you can't help financially at this time, but you still support the arts and this campaign, please share our Indiegogo link via social media and email and help us spread the word! Thank you for your support of Oklahoma theatre and the arts in general. Hope to see you at Faithiest! Get your tickets here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/faithiest-the-play...

What's the show about? Faithiest blurb:

This original, new play from Melanie Wilderman explores best friends, beliefs, and a little bit of booze. A dramatic comedy, Faithiest tells the story of small-town Oklahoma school teacher, Abagail Asher, a well-liked young woman respected as a dedicated educator, church volunteer, and all-around good person. But her standing in the community crumbles as quickly as the locals can yell, “It’s a twister!”

Following a destructive tornado, during which Abagail rescues a group of children, she is thrust into the national spotlight after an accidental, personal revelation during a live cable news interview. Now, everyone she's known her whole life, including her best friend of 20 years, sees her in a new light--and that light is not so heavenly. How can Abagail return to normal when her private beliefs are trending on Twitter and the people she loves most aren't sure who she is anymore? 

From one-half of the writing duo who penned Alcoholidays, this new work brings a similar sharp wit, occasional course humor, and moments of brute poignancy to a topic best left unspoken at the dinner table: religion.
